description: Description: A Middle to Late Bronze Age copper-alloy gold plated penannular ring. It is circular in cross-section and 5.11mm thick with a small gap to one side. There are a few small cracks on each surface revealing the copper-alloy core within and in places patches of copper-alloy corrosion have accumulated.Date: c.1300-c.800 BC.Dimensions: Diameter: 15.97mm, thickness: 5.11mm, weight: 9.21gDiscussion: Gold and gold-on-base-metal rings of this type, including penannular forms, are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c.1300–c.800 BC).  Although variously termed ‘hair-rings’ or ‘ring-money’ in the literature (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al. 2008; O’Connor et al. 2008) their function remains unresolved (see Armbruster 2021, 191–196). Current consensus increasingly favours interpretation as items of personal adornment, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than as hair ornaments or units of exchange.Interpretation is, however, hampered by the fact that relatively few examples derive from secure archaeological contexts. Burial assemblages from Belgium, north-east France and the Netherlands, alongside Scottish and Irish hoard associations, suggest a floruit during the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (c.1000–c.800 BC) (Eogan 1997). However, growing evidence indicates an earlier origin and a longer period of manufacture and circulation than previously assumed (Raftery 2004, 87–88). Two examples from Scotland were recovered from a hoard and a cave site respectively, both associated with Late Bronze Age sequences dating to c.1150–c.800 BC. Although, given the predominantly southern English distribution of such rings, it is possible that their introduction occurred slightly earlier (Eogan 1997). On comparative stylistic grounds, the present example is therefore best dated to the Middle or Late Bronze Age (c.1300–c.800 BC).The object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Bibliography Armbruster, B. R. 2021. Gold in the Bronze Age of Europe. Leiden: Sidestone Press.Eogan, G. 1994. The Accomplished Art: Gold and Gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300–650 BC). Oxford: Oxbow Books.Eogan, G. 1997. The Later Bronze Age Gold Hoards of the British Isles. Dublin: Irish Academy Press.Green, H. S. 1988. ‘The hoards of the Irish Later Bronze Age’. Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society 54, 241–256.Hobbs, R. 2003. British Iron Age Gold in the British Museum. London: British Museum Press.Meeks, N., Craddock, P., Cowell, M. & Taylor, J. J. 2008. ‘Analysis of Bronze Age goldwork from the British Isles’. In M. J. Allen, J. Gardiner & J. Sheridan (eds), Is there a British Chalcolithic? People, Place and Polity in the Late 3rd Millennium, 45–56. Oxford: Oxbow Books.O’Connor, B., Cowell, M. & Hook, D. 2008. ‘Bronze Age gold in Britain: alloying, circulation and use’. Antiquaries Journal 88, 1–28.Raftery, B. 2004. Pagan Celtic Ireland: The Enigma of the Irish Iron Age. London: Thames & Hudson.Taylor, J. J. 1980. Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Varndell, G. 2001. ‘Ring-money reconsidered’. Antiquaries Journal 81, 1–16.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Ring 1, A complete quadripartite penannular ring that is C-shaped in plan comprised of four penannular rings that are D-shaped in sectioned, having a flat inside edge and arched outer, all have been soldered one on top of the other. Each end terminates in a straight and even break that has rounded edges.Diameter 13mm, height 6mm, thickness 1mm, weight 2.65gRing 2A complete tripartite penannular ring that is C-shaped in plan comprised of three penannular rings that are D-shaped in sectioned, having a flat inside edge and arched outer, all have been soldered one on top of the other. Each end terminates bevelled edge.Diameter 12mm, height 6mm, thickness 1mm, weight 1.81gRing 3A complete gold bipartite penannular ring that is C-shaped in plan comprised of two penannular rings that have a sub-D-shaped cross-section, having a slight concave inside edge and arched outer, all have been soldered one on top of the other. Each end terminates flat edge, one side displaying a slight bevel.Diameter 14mm, height 7mm, thickness 2mm, weight 5.69gRing 4 A complete bipartite penannular ring that is C-shaped in plan comprised of two circular cross-sectioned penannular rings soldered together. Each terminates in a straight and even break.Diameter 15mm, height 7.5mm, thickness 3mm, weight 10.75gRing 5&6Two complete gold tripartite penannular rings both of which are that are C-shaped. However, one is made from circular cross-section rings, while the other is made from thinner D-shaped cross-section rings. Each terminates in a slight bevelled and rounded break.The rings have been linked so that one passes through the centre of the other.Ring 5 (circular rings) Diameter 13mm, height 9mm, thickness 1.5mmRing 6 (D-section rings) Diameter 14mm, height 6mm, thickness 1mmOverall weight 9.19gRing 7A complete tripartite penannular ring that is sub-oval in plan comprised of three penannular rings that are sub-D-shaped in cross-section, having a concave inside edge and arched outer, all have been soldered one on top of the other. Each end terminates in an inverted bevelled edge length 17mm, width 13mm, height 9mm, thickness 1.4mm, weight 5.07gDiscussion:There are a number of various styles of penannular rings that are recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database that have been declared as Treasure. These cases include a gold bipartite penannular ring HAMP-CAC0B5 (2022 T509), a gold tripartite penannular GLO-E2B412 (2023 T962), a gold quadripartite penannular LVPL-E57A04 (2024 T384) and two interlocking tripartite rings recorded at ESS-F1E21D (2023 T194) This class of object is largely dated to the Middle c.1300-1150 BC.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete cast copper alloy core of a penannular ring, probably dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c. 1300-800 cal BC). The ring is made of a bar that has a sub-triangular cross-section, with a flattened inner face and two flattened outer faces converging to a central ridge. This bar has been bent into an approximately circular loop with a small gap (2-3mm) between the two terminals.The ring is mostly covered in a pale matte green-grey corrosion layer, which has fine pitting throughout, and is more brown in colour on the interior face of the ring. There are no traces of gold remaining on the surface, suggesting that perhaps this is an unfinished object that was never gold-plated.The ring has a maximum outer diameter of 20.93mm, maximum inner diameter of 11.01mm, and a thickness of 5.61mm. It weighs 4.24 grams.A close parallel is recorded on the PAS database under NMS-97017C. Bronze penannular ring cores of slightly different shapes are recorded under PUBLIC-6A6D9E, LVPL-8FFAFD, LANCUM-165058 and YORYM-9D0DD3, among others. There are some broken or damaged gold-plated examples that evidence a copper alloy core, under SF-3247BC, DUR-2FFBF0 and BM-377122, for example. HAMP-259538 is an example of a complete hollow gold penannular ring featuring a similar shape with a triangular cross-section.Penannular rings have been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). They may well have a longer chronology within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC); This is now further supported by examples found with burials from Changis-sur-Marne, France, being radiocarbon dated to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1460-1290 cal BC) (Lafage et al. 2024, 339). As such a Middle Bronze Age to Late Bronze Age date is appropriate c.1300-800 cal BC.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Treasure Case 2025 T1225An incomplete late Bronze Age gold plated penannular striped ring with silvery gold alloy wire circumferentially inlaid dating circa 1300-800 BC. Meeks et al. 2008 type 3d ‘gold foil plated copper alloy ring, with silvery gold wire inlay’. The body is circular in cross-section and decorated with broad, spiralling stripes that wind in a clockwise direction. This pattern appears to be created by inlaying a continuous strip of silvery gold around the core, giving the impression of alternating bands of gold and silver. The entire copper alloy core is gold-plated, though there is some damage at the terminals that reveals the underlying copper core. The tapering of the stripes towards the centre suggests that the ring was bent into shape after the silver wire was inlaid. MeasurementsDiameter: 17.80 mm; Thickness: 5.81 mm; Width: 5.67 mm; Weight: 10.83gDiscussionSimilar examples on the database include PAS-011055 (2016T920), SUR-F8960C (2025 T519), CORN-4C0618 (2024T214) and ESS-5DF4B7 (2023T513). These belong to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980, Eogan 1994, 1997, Meeks et al 2008 and O'Connor et al 2008).Their function remains uncertain. It is perhaps most likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange (see discussion in Armbruster 2021: 191-196). The uncertainties around their use are complicated by the fact that very few are recorded from secure archaeological contexts.Scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). This fits their type 3d: ‘gold foil plated copper alloy ring, with silvery gold wire inlay’. Analysis of a similar example in the British Museum collections suggests that the technical skill involved in creating the fine silver-rich gold striped effect on the surface was highly complex.They have previously been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). They may well have a longer chronology within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC); This is now further supported by examples found with burials from Changis-sur-Marne, France, being radiocarbon dated to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1460-1290 cal BC) (Lafage et al. 2024, 339). As such a Middle Bronze Age to Late Bronze Age date is appropriate c.1300-800 cal BC.ReferencesArmbruster, B.R. 2021. Les ors de l’Europe atlantique à l’âge du bronze: technologie et ateliers. Mémoire LIV. Chauvigny, Association des publications chauvinoises.Eogan, G. 1994, The Accomplished Art: Gold and Gold-Working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age, Oxford: Oxbow BooksLafage, F., Brun, P., Armbruster, B., Bauvais, S., et al. (2024) Occupations protohistoriques à Changis-sur-Marne « Les Pétreaux ». Première modélisation de finages (Bronze ancien-Hallstatt D). CNRS Éditions.Meeks, N.D., Craddock, P. & Needham, S.P. (2008) Bronze Age Penannular Gold Rings from the British Isles: Technology and Composition, Jewellery Studies 11, 13-30.O'Connor, B., Cowie, T. & Worrell, S. (2008) Ring money: dernières nouvelles d,outré- manche, Bulletin de l'Association pour la Promotion des Reserches sur l'Age du Bronze 5, 12-13.Taylor, JJ. (1980) Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Varndell, G. (2001) Ringing the changes: when terminology matters, Antiquity 75, 515-6
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete, copper alloy, possible Bronze Age penannular ring, possibly dating to c.1300 - 800 BC.The object is crescent shaped in plan and D-shaped in cross section. The outer edges are convex and plain, the inner edges are flat. The terminals are rounded and end 2.9mm apart. The copper alloy has an even, well developed, dark green patina.The object is 20.8mm long, 18.1mm wide and 8.5m thick. It weighs 10.35g.The form of the piece is very similar to Bronze Age penannular rings whose precise function is unknown. They are often assumed to have been items of exchange and are frequently described as 'ring money' because of this, though there is no proof this was the case. They may instead have been items of personal adornment or hair ornaments. Though few examples have been excavated from secure archaeological contexts, they are generally deemed to date from the middle - late Bronze Age (c. 1300-800 BC). They are usually composed of gold, or a bronze core plated with gold, but copper alloy examples have been recorded on the database, such as YORYM-9D0DD3, BH-70330D, BERK-30B91C and BH-8B4BED. All of these records recommend a bronze age date, but note they cannot be dated with certainty.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold ingot or billet fragment of probable middle to late Bronze Age date, about 1600 - 800 BC. The object is a short length of flat bar, of sub-rectangular cross-section with straight sides and flat faces. One end tapers to a flat point, the other end has an irregular break.Length: 10.79 mmWidth: 5.76 mmThickness: 1.65 mmWeight: 0.89 gSingle gold ingots/billets can be difficult to date out of context, with dated examples known from the Bronze Age to the Early Medieval period. The form of this billet is best paralleled in later Bronze Age hoards, in particular, the find from Donhead St Mary, Wiltshire (WILT-7EDEA6) 1,200-800 BC, Fittleworth, West Sussex (British Museum 1996,0902.1-10) 1,400-1,100 BC and Cirencester Hoard, Gloucestershire (BM-28B710).As such the Bronze Age parallels are stronger than the evidence for the ingot being Early Medieval, although an Early Medieval date remains possible.In conclusion, the Bronze Age parallels are much stronger than the evidence for the ingot being Early Medieval, although an Early Medieval date remains possible.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A Late Bronze Age, gold, D-sectioned, penannular bar-bracelet, dating to c.1300-750 BC.It consists of a rectangular gold bar which is D-shaped in cross section. It has flared flat oval terminals, which would have been bent into a circular form to wrap around a wrist but is now distorted into a slight spiral shape. The surfaces are scratched and abraded, but otherwise undecorated and smoothly finished.It measures: Length 61.3mm, Width 57.5mm, width of bar 5mm, thickness of bar 2.1mm and weight 19.8 grams. Discussion: The bracelet has several parallels on the database. There are a number of examples consisting of a solid strip of gold with flared oval/circular terminals, such as: WILT-830027 (2023T286), GLO-4998DD (2024T1300), WILT-81DC63 (2020T602) and CAM-21F97B (2017T867). Other similar examples are illustrated in Eogan (1994, p.176), from Ormingdale, Arran (no.1-4). These examples are all dated to between 1300 BC - 750 BC. Three other Bronze Age objects were found at the same rally, albeit different fields. The objects are a gold lock ring, spearhead and dagger. They are currently with the finders until a handover date can be arranged. Depending on their locations, this could be a potential hoard. HESH-2A1A85, recorded in 2006 was found 0.3km from the bracelet.Conclusion: Consequently, in terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996References:Eogan, G. (1994) The accomplished art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC). Oxford, Oxbow.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A gold fragment of broadly trapezoidal shape which has breaks and fracturing around three edges. The fourth edge is straight and shows signs of working and there are clear hammered facets on the two broad faces. The cross section of the fragment is triangular, tapering in two directions.
notes: Possibly part of an ingot. The form is similar to fragments seen in the assemblage from Fitzleroi Farm, Fittleworth (British museum Accession No. 1996,0902.20) and the hoard from Cirencester, Gloucestershire (2004 T416) illustrated in the Treasure Annual Report 2004 on pages 232-3, Fig.17.3 & 17.5 and dated on page 26 to c.1300-1100 BC. On this basis a Bronze Age date can be proposed.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A group of two gold objects, found in direct association (bead within ribbon), a ribbon ornament and bead of Bronze Age date (1300-1100 BC).Description: A gold band or Ribbon probably from a Penannular ring of Middle to Late Bronze age date (1300-800 BC). The object is composed of a rectangular strip of gold, which is curved backward in an irregular fashion.  The short edges of the object are slightly bevelled and unabraded. The upper surface is decorated with three embossed, repousse linear ribs, forming 2 grooves between, running along the long edges of the object. The strip is thin and the negative impressions of the ribs are visible on the reverse of the strip. Discussion:  Whilst the appearance of ribs may be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date including examples from The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Case 1980; Palmer 1980). The curve to these ribs is most similar to a number of penannular rings such as from the Granta Fen Hoard (British Museum Accession number: 1884,0520.3) and the Burton Hoard (PAS-5B1745; Gwilt et al. in Barton 2011) both of which are associated with Middle Bronze Age material. For similar tripartite rings on the PAS database see NMS-3A21E4 (2025 T187), HAMP-CAC0B5 (2022T509) WILT-788C7B (2019T253) and BERK-35E144 (2022T70).Description: A gold, sheet, hollow annular bead of Middle Bronze Age date (1400-1100 BC). The object is circular in plan and biconical in profile. The object has a pronounced circumferential rib with minor post-depositional distortion to one portion of object. the centre of the object has a circular aperture measuring 4.88mm in diameter.  Discussion: The bead is of similar form to several of sheet gold reported through the Treasure Act, namely HAMP-72E451 (2011 T526),GLO-46CA05 (2014 T358) and NMS-AEC678 (2013 T20) and notably the three biconical gold beads from the Burton, Wrexham hoard which are similar in form, size and weight (PAS-5B1745; Gwilt et al. in Barton 2011). The Burton hoard comprised of several typo-chronologically distinctive artefacts, including bronze palstaves, that allow it to be dated from c.1300-1150 BC (Ibid).The bead is also similar to those from Bourton-on-the-Water, Gloucestershire and Harlow, Essex, the former from a stratified Middle Bronze Age context (Varndell 2000, 12, no.1; 2005/6, 17, 270, no.6), and Buriton, Hampshire (HAMP-72E451).Middle Bronze Age gold beads are a relatively rare find (Murgia et al. 2014) and can be contextualised with reference to the so-called 'ornament horizon(s)', which see a proliferation of bronze and gold ornaments in Southern England and Britain (respectively) during the period c.1400-1100 BC (Smith 1959, pp.151-155; Roberts 2007, pp.14-16).Dimensions:  1 Length: 16.13mm, Width: 9.35mm, Thickness (folded): 10.91mm, Thickness (strip): 0.96mm, Weight: 3.2g2 Diameter: 9.62mm, Diameter (aperture): 4.88mm, Height: 4.59mm, Thickness: 0.30mm, Weight: 0.2gConclusion: Both objects have parallels in known hoards and object associations (discussed above) and both may be dated at least in part to the Middle Bronze Age. As such the objects can be considered contemporary and being found in direct association are likely to represent a hoard of gold objects dating to the Middle Bronze Age. Each item individually appears to consist of over 10% precious metal and to be over 300 years old at the time of finding and as such qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.References:Gwilt, A (2004). Late Bronze Age Societies (1150-600BC); Tools and Weapons. Cardiff University of Wales Press.Murgia, A. Melkonian, M. & Roberts, B.W. (2014), European Bronze Age Gold in the British Museum, British Museum Press.Palmer, N. (1980). A Beaker burial and Medieval Tenements in the Hamel. Oxoniensia.Smith, M.A. (1959). Middle Bronze Hoards from Southern England. Garraway.
notes: As the objects contain a minimum of 10% precious metal and were over 300 years old at the time of finding and were found in association, they therefore qualify as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Circumstances of discovery: Recovered from an environmental soil sample taken from an un-urned cremation whilst part of an organised archaeological excavation.Description: A complete small penannular ring of gold foil overlaying a copper alloy core (RF<1>), and a second, partial, small penannular ring (RF<2>) consisting of the gold foil ?terminal of the ring, without the copper alloy core. Small penannular ring RF<1>:  A small penannular ring of gold foil over a copper alloy core, decorated with six rows of punched dots, conforming to type 3.7.8: gold plated metal core with punched decoration (Murgia et al 2014; Meeks et al 2008). The ring is of a similar diameter around the circumference, tapering to a rounded point at both terminals, where the gold foil can be seen to be folded and smoothed over the ends (Fig.1 and 2). The cross- section of the ring appears heptagonal rather than circular, and the inner facet is not punched with dots. One terminal exhibits a slight thickening of the diameter before tapering again, giving the impression of an animal-like head at that end of the ring. It is not clear whether this is intentional; the dot pattern is distorted by the thickened area but does not deviate from its intended path. A slight split in the gold foil casing can be observed where the core thickens, and although this does not appear to be as a result of corrosion within the core, the x-radiograph (Fig.3) does show losses to the core at this terminal in particular. The gold foil appears to have been applied to the core before bending; visual inspection under a hand lens of x40 magnification rendered the seam visible as a very faint line along the interior surface, broken by two areas of vertical folding which have been annealed or burnished flat. It is uncertain at which stage in the process the punched decoration was applied, either before or after the application of the gold to the core or before or after the ring was bent into shape; any distortion in the form of the dots which might be expected from them being applied before the ring was bent seems to be absent, other than over the thickened area at the terminal where the dots are noticeably shallower than those to either side.Small penannular ring RF<2>: A small section of gold foil from the exterior of a penannular ring (Fig.4 and 5). The surface of the metal is dull and pitted. This is perhaps due to the composition of the gold alloy used in manufacturing this object, which differs from that of the gold utilised in the complete ring (see discussion below). The foil appears to have been wrapped around a base metal core which has corroded away, now forming a hollow, curving, tube which tapers slightly towards the terminal. Both ends are open. It is not clear whether the fragment was originally decorated.Dimensions: Penannular ring RF<1> has an external diameter of 10.1mm and is 2.1mm in diameter at the midpoint of the hoop body. The ring is of a similar diameter around the circumference, tapering to a rounded point at both terminals, however, one terminal exhibits a slight thickening of the diameter, to c.2.2mm, before tapering again, giving the impression of an animal-like head at that end of the ring. The gap between the terminals is c.0.5mm. Weight 0.66gPenannular ring RF<2> measures c.6mm in length and 2mm in diameter. Weight <0.1gDating: The cremation from which the penannular rings were excavated was one of a group of five unurned cremations which formed a discrete collection of features unrelated to the later Saxon and medieval features encountered across the wider excavation. Due to bone fragment size, it is thought to have contained the remains of a juvenile or adult individual, however no sexually diagnostic material was present.  Radiocarbon determinations on cremated human bone (Beta-751303) and Corylus avellana charcoal (Beta-751304) from the cremation, are statistically inconsistent at the 5% significance level (T=9.4; v=1; T’(5%)= 3.8; Ward and Wilson 1978); and at the 1% significance level T=9.4; v=1; T’(1%)= 6.6; ibid.). It is therefore likely that the cremated bone and charcoal are of different ages. The later/younger measurement of 2850±30 BP (Beta-751303); 1120-920 cal BC (95% probability), on the cremated bone probably provides the best estimate for the context. It is possible that the older date of 2990±30 BP (Beta-751304); 1380-1120 cal BC (95% probability) on the hazel (Corylus avellana) charcoal is due to the wood having a built-in age-at-death which produces an age-offset referred to as the ‘old wood effect’. Unfortunately, the original size and maturity of the hazel charcoal could not be determined and although hazel is generally considered a small, ‘short’-lived tree, living for around 80 years, it can reach greater maturity especially when managed (Allott 2025). This date range is consistent with the broad dating of penannular rings which are characteristic of the Middle to Late Bronze Age, and is noteworthy due to the comparative lack of stratified, well dated examples (Meeks et al 2008, 13). In recent years, the dating of these smaller rings has been subject to revision and the C14 dating in this case is consistent with both British, Irish and continental examples (Becker et al 2020, 120-2; Warmenbol 2021).Analytical results: Portable XRF analysis of the rings’ surface was carried out by Victoria Lucas at the Institute of Archaeology, UCL (Table 1). Both rings are made from gold, alloyed with silver and copper, with a lower gold content than some previously studied examples (e.g.Meeks et al 2008, 15). The results for Ring RF <1> are superficially consistent in gold content with a group of small rings from Sculptors cave (Becker et al 2020, 122 Table 5.13).  There is a consistency in the amount of silver within the alloys of both rings, however the percentage of copper present in Ring RF<2> exceeds that of comparable examples, recording a much lower percentage of gold, with a much correspondingly higher percentage of copper.  This may be a true reflection of the composition of the gold alloy used to produce the foil, or the result of the pXRF picking up the remnants of a copper or copper alloy core (c.f. Warner 2014); if the former, the higher copper percentage may account for the comparatively poorer preservation of Ring RF<2> (V. Lucas pers comm). Further quantitative analysis from subsurface samples would be required to ascertain the true metal composition. 												Element/wt%										 						Fe									Cu									Zn									Ag									Sn									Sb									Au									Pb													Ring RF <1>									0.3									8.63									<LOD									9.95									1.25									0.88									78.7									<LOD													Ring RF<2>									0.98									47.28									0.69									8.87									0.41									0.19									41.27									0.04						Table 1: pXRF results on the two objectsDiscussion: The function of penannular rings is not known (Eogan 1997; Meeks et al 2008; Murgia et al 2014); they are presently understood to be objects of personal adornment which could have been used as hair, nose or ear rings (Murgia et al 2014), and use as ‘ring money’ has also been suggested (Eogan 1997; Northover 2000). There is considerable variation in size, decoration and composition across the known examples of penannular rings, which perhaps argues for variation in their use (Becker et al 2020, 122).   Decoration in the form of punched dots and/ or incised lines are less frequently encountered than undecorated rings or, in the larger penannulars, those with striped decoration.  A small number of rings in the British Museum collections share characteristics of the current example: a plated ring with punched and incised decoration and copper alloy core from Ireland is perhaps of similar construction (BM 1869,0923.1), as is an example with a white metal core (Meeks et al 2008 fig.1 xvii; BM 1965,0606.1), both of which are much larger than the current examples. Another Irish ring, of solid gold with punched dot decoration (BM 1862,0617.2) is a close parallel in terms of size and decoration.  More recently, a small solid gold penannular ring from Kent with punched dot and incised line decoration was recorded via the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS-5607C5; 2005 T282) and a similarly sized ring with incised chevron decoration was recovered from an un-urned Middle Bronze Age cremation in Wales (Gilbert et al 2024; PAS ID NMGW-615AC8), which also contained a burnt wooden comb. Closer geographically to the current site, cremation (344), one of the small number of  Deverel -Rimbury cremations at North Ring, Mucking (Bond 1988, 14 and Fig.13) produced two gold foil over tin core rings of similar morphology; Northover (2000, 302) dates this method of construction to the Penard Phase, i.e. 13-12th centuries BC, pre-dating the various other forms of penannular ring which are associated with the Ewart Park phase (ibid.).  Of the European examples cited by Eogan (1997, figure 2), the majority were found in cremation burials, including two from the same burial at Villneuve-saint-Germain, France which appear to be of similar size and morphology to ring <2> (ibid.). In France, burials are fairly poorly furnished, containing one or two rings, in contrast with the Low Countries, where burials are more richly furnished with other artefacts alongside penannular rings; an association with cremated human remains prevails, as well as some recovered, as at Sculpter’s Cove, with inhumations, and also within caves (Warmenbol 2021).These objects contain a minimum of 10% precious metal and are over 300 years old. Consequently, they qualify as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content, and as part of the same find.References Allott, L in prep Radiocarbon dating in Dyson, A et al Archaeological Mitigation, Land off Ellen Aldous Avenue (Phase 2b) ASE report no.2025149Armit, I and Büster, L 2020 Darkness Visible: The Sculptor’s Cave, Covesea, from the Bronze Age to the Picts. Edinburgh: Society of Antiquaries of Scotland. https://doi.org/10.9750/9781908332233Becker, K, Cowie, T, Troalen, L and Tate, J 2020 ‘Late Bronze Age Objects’ in Armit, I and Büster, L 2020 Darkness Visible: The Sculptor’s Cave, Covesea, from the Bronze Age to the Picts. Morteani (eds), Beiträge aus der Mineralogie, Geochemie, Lagerstättenforschung, Archäometrie, Archäologie und Denkmalpflege 8, 299–304. subsequentActionTerm: Donated to a museum after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A damaged and incomplete gold plated penannular ring of late Bronze Age date. The plating has been lost from one side revealing a copper alloy core. The surface is heavily worn and decorated with faint banding of an inlaid silver alloy. The terminals are flat and 4mm in diameter.
notes: A recent scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). This fits their type 3d: ‘gold foil plated copper alloy ring, with silvery gold wire inlay’. Analysis of a similar example in the British Museum collections suggests that the technical skill involved in creating the fine silver-rich gold striped effect on the surface was highly complex.These penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC). They have variously been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Eogan 1994; 1997), but their function remains uncertain. It is perhaps most likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange (see discussion in Armbruster 2021: 191-196).  The uncertainties around their use are complicated by the fact that very few are recorded from secure archaeological contexts.They have previously been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). They may well have a longer chronology within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC); This is now further supported by examples found with burials from Changis-sur-Marne, France, being radiocarbon dated to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1460-1290 cal BC) (Lafage et al. 2024, 339). As such a Middle Bronze Age to Late Bronze Age date is appropriate c.1300-800 cal BC.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: An incomplete copper or copper alloy miniature flat axehead dating to the Early Bronze Age. This example fits best into the earliest known copper axe and early bronze axes discovered in Britain. These are dated to the Early Bronze Age of metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC.The object is broadly sub-triangular in plan with a broad, rounded crescent shaped blade. The cutting edge has a width of 56.1mm and a thickness of 5.5mm. It is asymmetrical. From the cutting edge the body of the axe gradually narrows in shape and curves inwards. The axehead gradually gets thicker in the centre and before it tapers off towards the now missing butt, to create a broadly lentoid profile with slight tapering edges.All edges of the axehead are worn and smoothed. The overall surface has a rough dark green patina with patches of dark brown / red.Dimensions: Overall length 67.5mm; width (widest point) 56.1mm; thickest point 10.5mm; weight 152.72gThis axehead is best described as coming from the later phases of the Migdale tradition (specifically the undecorated variant) dated: 2250-1900 CAL. BC / end of EBA II - III. It is very similar to Needham's flat axe class 3 having a medium sized butt, lenticular profile, no stop and no side flanges (i.e. flat). They are dated to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A complete copper-alloy short-flanged axehead, dating to the Middle Bronze Age (c. 1500-1250 BC).The object has a rectangular body which flares outwards from approximately halfway along its length. There is a slightly raised transverse ridge where the flanges terminate. The sides of the blade are waisted and it flares outwards into a crescent-shaped cutting-edge. The flanges are lozenge-shaped and extend from the straight linear butt to a slightly raised ridge. The flanges curve gently towards the body, with chamfered outer edges. All surfaces of the object have a consistent metallic yellow-grey patina with patches of red-brown. Where the surface of the metal has been scratched a metallic gold colour is visible.157.5 mm long and mass of 423.09 g. Blade 58.65 mm tall, 14.69 mm thick at widest point. Flanges 29.71 mm wide at widest point. Butt 20.88 mm tall and 2.17 mm thick.
notes: Several late Early to Middle Bronze Age objects have been recovered from a c. 500 m area north of Haydon Bridge, between the Stangate and Housestead fort. Due to the condition of the objects and their spatial distribution they are not being considered as a single hoard, and therefore do not meet the criteria of the Treasure Act 1996. It is probable that they represent a series of structured deposits within a ritualised landscape context. See DUR-6BAA41, DUR-6B962E, NCL-6B6F35, NCL-6B5F49, and NCL-6B4608.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: An incomplete gold plated penannular ring of late Bronze Age date, originally around 20mm in overall diameter. The ring has a cross section of 7.2mm diameter and has broken in half revealing its construction with a copper alloy core and gold plated exterior. There is heavily worn banded decoration, originally with a silver alloy inlay although this has largely corroded away. The banding is largely preserved on the interior surface and tooling marks are evident along these lines demonstrating how they were made by a punch or similar tool after the plating had been applied to the copper alloy core.
notes: These gold penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC). They have variously been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Eogan 1994; 1997; Green 1988), but their function remains uncertain. It is perhaps most likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.  The uncertainties around their use are complicated by the fact that very few are recorded from secure archaeological contexts.They have previously been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). They may well have a longer chronology within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC); however thus far this has been difficult to confirm as few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological context or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A complete solid copper alloy bead dating to the middle Bronze Age (c.1300-1150 BC).The bead is circular with a bi-conical profile with a central perforation measuring 5.1mm in diameter. The surface is smooth and undecorated with a mid green patina.Dimensions: External diameter: 10.30mm; internal diameter: 5.5 mm; thickness: 4.9mm and weight: 1.81g.Similar examples of copper alloy beads recorded on the PAS database include  CAM-DD9C51 and LEIC-3641F5. A gold example from Gloucestershire, GLO-46CA05 (2014T358) has also been reported and the record by Kurt Adams comments: "The gold bead is likely to date to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1500-1100 BC) based on several close comparanda. The three biconical gold beads from the Burton, Wrexham, hoard are similar in form, size and weight to the Salthouse bead (PAS-5B1745; Gwilt et al. in Barton 2011). The Burton hoard comprised of several typo-chronologically distinctive artefacts (including bronze palstaves) that allow it to be dated to c.1300-1150 BC (Ibid.). The bead is also similar to those from Bourton-on-the-Water, Gloucestershire and Harlow, Essex, the former from a stratified Middle Bronze Age context (Varndell 2000, 12, no.1; 2005/6, 17, 270, no.6), and Buriton, Hampshire (HAMP-72E451).Middle Bronze Age gold beads are a relatively rare find (Murgia et al. forthcoming) and can be contextualised with reference to the so-called 'ornament horizon(s)', which see a proliferation of bronze and gold ornaments in Southern England and Britain (respectively) during the period c.1400-1100 BC (Smith 1959; Roberts 2007)."
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A complete silver and gold penannular ring of Late Bronze Age date (1150-750 BC). The object is oval in plan and sub-circular in cross-section with a rounded external edge and a flat internal edge. The external edges of the terminals are flattened where the ring has been struck. The ring has been formed by inlaying silver strips around a gold core which has then been cut to the required length. Both terminals are gold and show no sign of a core although both terminals may have been worked over after the length was cut. There is some damage to the silver portion of the ring with some surface loss but no sign of a core. On balance, it is likely that this example is made purely of gold and silver similar to NMGW-04216C.This penannular ring is very similar to BERK-053BB0. The report on NMGW-04216C states that 'The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980, Egan 1994, 1997, Hobbs 2003, Meeks et al 2008 and O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange'. A number of such rings have been reported to the PAS and declared treasure in recent years.Measurements: Diameter 14.52mm, Internal diameter 7.34mm, Thickness 3.85mm, Weight 4.84g.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Circumstances of discovery: Metal-detecting on cultivated land.Description: A thin strip of Bronze Age gold dating to c 2200 BC - c 800 BC. The strip is roughly rectangular but tapers along the long sides from the centre towards each terminal. The ends of the terminals have a slightly curved profile. One end of the ribbon is folded over and then folded back on itself. The ribbon is undecorated but is slightly twisted and is damaged by a small hole in the centre.Dimensions: Length 43.4mm; Width 6.8mm (at centre tapering to 4.4mm); Thickness 0.5mm; Weight 2.75g.Discussion: The object has few diagnostic features being made of a thin strip of gold. Gold bands are relatively undiagnostic component of (perhaps especially Middle and Later) Bronze Age goldwork in Southern England (c.1500-800 BC) (see Murgia et al. 2014a; Murgia et al. 2014b). There are similar examples previously recorded on the database that have been declared treasure from Dorset (2014T256), Wiltshire (2020T803), Warwickshire (2018T288), Surrey (2017T922) and Lancashire (2023 T750) which are suggested to be fragments from Bronze Age bracelets (e.g. 2009T435 and 2014T39). A further Bronze Age examples includes a gold securing strip, with perforated folded terminals, from a gold armlet or cuff found in the hoard from Capel Isaf, Manordeilo, Carmarthenshire, and illustrated in Savory (1980: 195, fig.47, no.1), which is now dated from the Middle Bronze Age c.1600-1400 BC. A Bronze Age date is supported by those gold ribbons with more diagnostic features such as lateral ribs (see OXON-E7AB6A) due to an in-context example found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980) in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd -early 2nd millennium BC. However, there are also examples which are suggested to come from the Roman to Early Medieval period (NLM-E8C60D, SWYOR-089827 and IOW-36803C).As a result on the balance of probabilities this band can also be assigned to the Bronze Age, although a more precise date within the period is difficult to ascertain.Conclusion: The object appears to have a composition of more than 10% precious metal and is probably at least 300 years old; it therefore meets the criteria for consideration as Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.Alyson Tanner, Finds Liaison Assistant for Wiltshire, Portable Antiquities SchemeWith contributions from Dr Edward Caswell, Finds Liaison Officer, OxfordshireReferences:Savory, H.N. (1980) Guide Catalogue of the Bronze Age Collections. National Museum of Wales.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A fragment of a cast copper-alloy probably dagger of probable Late Bronze Age date (c.1300-1150 BC).Description: The object remains as a fragment of the hilt with transverse breaks at either end. The fragment increases in width from one end to the other, curving outward slightly at the location of two rivet holes. There are a further rivet holes at the wider end, half missing along with the break. The the object has areas of an origanal silvery and gold patina with vertical striations dark brown and medium green patching.Measurements: length: 35mm; width: 21.8mm; thickness: 3.9mm; weight: 7.36gDiscussion: Compare with LANCUM-EDDE97.Bronze Age metal work does not usually display such colouring and it is therefore possible that the object could be of a later date. Other possibilities include a medieval to post-medieval vessel.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold ingot or billet fragment of probable middle to late Bronze Age date, about 1600 - 800 BC. The object is a short length of flat bar, of sub-rectangular cross-section with straight sides and flat faces. Both ends are cut. The object is not decorated.Length: 11.8 mmWidth: 9 mmWeight: 1.4 gSingle gold ingots/billets can be difficult to date out of context, with dated examples known from the Bronze Age to the Early Medieval period. The form of this billet is best paralleled in later Bronze Age hoards, in particular, the find from Donhead St Mary, Wiltshire (WILT-7EDEA6) 1,200-800 BC, Fittleworth, West Sussex (British Museum 1996,0902.1-10) 1,400-1,100 BC and Cirencester Hoard, Gloucestershire (BM-28B710).As such the Bronze Age parallels are stronger than the evidence for the ingot being Early Medieval, although an Early Medieval date remains possible.In conclusion, the Bronze Age parallels are much stronger than the evidence for the ingot being Early Medieval, although an Early Medieval date remains possible.References:Bruce-Mitford, R., 1975. The Sutton Hoo Ship-burial, Volume 1, Excavation background, the ship, dating and inventory. London: British Museum.
notes: Since discovery, the find is missing.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: TREASURE CASE : 2025 T60.Description: A fragment of a decorated sheet or ribbon of gold of probable Bronze Age date, c.2400 - 800 BC.The object is formed of a thin sub-rectangular sheet of gold, folded over at the centre. The outer surface of the sheet is decorated by a series parallel ridge and grooves running along its length. The interior surface appears flat. It is not possible to determine if the object is complete or cut down though the latter is likely. Dimensions:Length: 14mm; Width: 8.5mm; Thickness: 0.2mm; Weight: 0.6g.Discussion: Similar objects have been recorded as 2019 T316 (LEIC-47D0C2), 2018 T650 (HAMP-F792A5), 2010 T664 (LVPL-83FE92) and 2013 T471 (WMID-3CBCF0). Similar multi-grooved strips of Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as recent finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48). An in-context example has been found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980) in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd -early 2nd millennium BC.Similar narrow embossed strips are also illustrated by Taylor (1980, fig 28a-f) which are suggested to date to the Early Bronze Age. 2017 T882 (SOM-62CE08) states that several similar pieces have also been found bent into cylindrical beads (citing Eluère 1982, 30, fig 25, no. 3) and it is unclear if this was their original purpose or if this was a common reuse for parts of larger ribbon ornaments. That this would not have been a regular cylinder might suggest this example was not used as a bead.Conclusion: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.References:Eluère, C. (1982) Les Ors préhistoriques en France. [Online]. Picard. Available at: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/2708400851/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1. Palmer, N. (1980) A beaker burial and medieval tenements in the Hamel, Oxford. Oxoniensia Oxford. 45, 124–225.Taylor, J.J. (1980) Bronze age goldwork of the British Isles. Gulbenkian archaeological series. Cambridge, Cambridge University Press.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description: Bronze Age gold penannular ring with striped surface, almost circular in shape. It is sub-rectangular or sub-oval in cross-section, with wider, flattish inner and outer faces, and narrower, more curved faces on the front and back. It flares very slightly from the terminals to the centre. The surface is a polished gold, with ten widely and irregularly set oblique lines of a different material on each face, formed from an inlaid continuous spiral. The centre of these lines is golden brown, pitted and corroded in many places, and of inconsistent width, sometimes spreadlng out and then narrowing again. They are flanked by narrow silvery lines which fade into the gold background, but which can be seen to also curve out and in again around the spread-out edges, as if a sandwich of lines had been inlaid by being hammered into place; alternatively, the centre of the bands has corroded differently to the edges.The terminals are almost parallel and facing each other. They are separated by a gap of c. 2.0-2.5mm, narrowest on the inside of the ring and slightly wider on the outside. They are broadly flat, but in the centre of each one is a short slot-like indentation parallel to the long axis of the cross-section, so running from front to back of the ring. This is again not gold, and appears to be where the inlaid spiral starts and finishes; on one terminal it can be seen apparently running through a groove in the gold.Dimensions: When held with terminals uppermost, width 16.5mm, length perpendicular to this 15.3mm, thickness 5.2mm. The cross-section of the ring varies from 4.2 x 5.2mm at the terminals to 5.0 x 5.2mm at the centre. It weighs 10.50g.Discussion: Penannular rings are fairly common finds; around 150 have been recorded on the PAS database, with at least as many having been discovered before the advent of the Scheme (Meeks et al. 2008, 13). Despite this, their function remains mysterious.Many of the PAS-recorded examples are from central southern England, but fifteen, including this example, come from Norfolk, with eleven having a banded or striped surface. One, from Hockwold-cum-Wilton (BM-377122, 2003T6) has a similar appearance to this one, with the centre of the inlaid stripes appearing dark and corroded, but the edges staying silvery.It is hard to tell the material of the inlay from visual inspection alone, although where they have been analysed the inlays are of electrum (a naturally occurring silvery gold). The variable colour and differential corrosion is not easy to explain.They have until recently been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC, based firstly on burials in Belgium, north-east France and the Netherlands, and secondly on Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13).Gwilt suggests, in discussion of an example recorded at NMGW-04216C (citing Raftery in Roche et al 2004, 87-8) that in recent years the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing, to the extent that these items may now be placed within a wider date-range encompassing the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC).Date: Middle to Late Bronze Age, 1300-800 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: An incomplete gold middle to late Bronze Age penannular ring (c. 1300 – 800 BC). The object consists of the flattened gold sheet which would have been wrapped around a copper alloy core to form the complete penannular ring shape. The sheet is sub-rectangular in shape, with most of the edges curled round to the reverse where they may have covered the core. The obverse of the sheet is decorated with a series of alternating parallel bands of two different alloys of gold or silver, radiating from where the centre of the ring would be.Length 16.61 mm, width 8.06 mm, thickness 0.89 mm and weight 0.91 g.Similar objects have been recorded on the PAS database, dating to the Late Bronze Age, and classed as Treasure, such as DUR-1B2FA1 (2019 T1012), SF-45670E (2019 T110) and WILT-63B6DE (2020 T255). DENO-EB8F48 (2021 T465) notes that these types of gold or gold-on-base-metal rings and penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300 - 800 BC). Relatively few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation, or radiocarbon dating, though burials in Belgium, north-east France, and The Netherlands, in addition to Scottish and Irish hoard associations, have suggested a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 BC (Eogan 1997). In recent years however, evidence for earlier development and a longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing (Raftery 2004, 87-8; Needham 2007, 26-33, Figs 17.3-4). Therefore, on comparative stylistic grounds, this penannular ring may be dated to the Middle or Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC).This object contains precious metal and is over 300 years old, therefore it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.References:Eogan, G. 1997. ‘Hair-rings’ and European Late Bronze Age society. Antiquity, 71(272), 308-320.Needham, S.P. 2007. Cirencester area, Gloucestershire: Bronze Age gold and base-metal scatter (2004 T416). Treasure Annual Report 2004, 26-33, figs. 17.1-6.Raftery, B. 2004. Pit 119: Rathgall, Co. Wicklow. In: Roche, H., Bradley, J., Coles, J., Raftery, B. (eds) 2004. From Megaliths to Metal. Essays in Honour of George Eogan. Oxford: Oxbow Books, 83-91
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A Late Bronze Age, gold, oval-sectioned, penannular bar-bracelet, dating to c.1300-800 cal BC. The body of the bracelet is solid, with curving sides that crate a squished penannular loop. The base and sides of the loop have an even thickness of 5mm high and 3mm wide. However, both ends are expanded to form trumpet terminals that are 6.5mm high and 6mm wide. Smith (2023) records that gold penannular bracelet is characteristic of British Bronze Age ornamentation. Typically, gold bars were a feature in their manufacture, such that the majority, like this example, have solid bodies and termini, and decoration was not common in Britain (Eogan, 1994, p84-5).Particularly similar examples with square cross sections and slightly expanded terminals include examples from the from Sporle with Palgrave hoard (Taylor 1988: EA86), Morvah Hoard (Pearce 1983: case 108) and an example from the British Museum Collections from Towednack, Cornwall (Accession number 1932,0511.7 f). This is described as a gold bar which may have been an unfinished bracelet, dating to c. 1400-1100 BC.Other similar, complete bracelets have been found as part of hoards at Beachy Head, Sussex (Eogan, 1994, Plate 10, p170) and at Stonehill, Lanark (Eogan, 1994, Plate 15, p175). Further examples on the PAS include 2022T980 (SUR-3DE17A), from Guildford, Surrey and 2004T490 (BM-25EFE8), from Roxby cum Risby, North Lincolnshire, although these are incomplete.The above examples predominantly suggest a Middle to Late Bronze Age date. Within a radius of 1km of this findspot, no other finds at all are listed on the PAS database, however, there are several bowl barrows dating from the Late Neolithic to the Late Bronze Age (c.2400-1000 BC), in the vicinity, as well as a Middle Bronze Age field system. A Middle to Late Bronze Age date can also be supported by the find’s context.Eogan, G. (1994), The Accomplished Art: Gold and Gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c.2300-650BC). Oxbow Books: Oxford.Pearce, S.M. (1983) The Bronze Age metalwork of South Western Britain. BAR British series 120. BAR Publishing.Smith, A. (2023) BRACELET, (online) Portable Antiquities Scheme Database at: https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/1103538 Taylor, R.J. (1988) Hoards?: The interpretation and analysis of hoards of the Bronze Age in Southern Britain. Ph.D. [Online]. University of Reading. Available at: https://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?did=1&uin=uk.bl.ethos.380811Conclusion: The find contains a minimum of 10% gold and is over 300 years old in date. It therefore qualifies as Treasure under the provisions of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of Early Bronze Age dating (c. 2350 BC to c. 2050 BC).The flat axe is broadly sub rectangular in shape with a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with slight tapering edges. The butt is relatively thin, having a flat, broken terminal. The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the butt to the blade; in shape they are relatively curved. The axe is thickest at the butt, tapering to the blade. The sides of the blade expand to produce a crescentic blade edge. The axe is a mid to dark green colour, with an uneven surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the plough soil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface detail.It measures 76.14mm in length, maximum width at the blade is 38.09mm, width at the butt is 20.71mm and it has a maximum thickness of 9.49mm. It weighs 102.69 grams.The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to (although not containing all the attributes of Migdale axes (many of these tend to have narrower butts which flare at the cutting edge).These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Reference:Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp 121-140Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.46-47.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A complete solid copper alloy bead dating to the middle Bronze Age (1300-1150).The bead is circular with a bi-conical profile with a central perforation measuring 5.1mm in diameter. The surface is smooth and undecorated with a mid green patina.Dimensions: Diameter 11.3mm; thickness 4.5mm; weight 1.85gSimilar examples of copper alloy beads recorded on the PAS database include  CAM-DD9C51 and LEIC-3641F5. A gold example from Gloucestershire, GLO-46CA05 (2014T358) has also been reported and the record by Kurt Adams comments: "The gold bead is likely to date to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1500-1100 BC) based on several close comparanda. The three biconical gold beads from the Burton, Wrexham, hoard are similar in form, size and weight to the Salthouse bead (PAS-5B1745; Gwilt et al. in Barton 2011). The Burton hoard comprised of several typo-chronologically distinctive artefacts (including bronze palstaves) that allow it to be dated to c.1300-1150 BC (Ibid.). The bead is also similar to those from Bourton-on-the-Water, Gloucestershire and Harlow, Essex, the former from a stratified Middle Bronze Age context (Varndell 2000, 12, no.1; 2005/6, 17, 270, no.6), and Buriton, Hampshire (HAMP-72E451).Middle Bronze Age gold beads are a relatively rare find (Murgia et al. forthcoming) and can be contextualised with reference to the so-called 'ornament horizon(s)', which see a proliferation of bronze and gold ornaments in Southern England and Britain (respectively) during the period c.1400-1100 BC (Smith 1959; Roberts 2007)."
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: An incomplete gold unidentified object, possibly a ribbon or bracelet, of probable Bronze Age date (c.2350-800BC).Description: The object sub-rectangular in plan, although now bent out of shape, and tapers at each end to a curved terminal. Both sides are undecorated and with similar surfaces. Measurements: length: 44.9mm; width: 5.6mm; thickness: 0.6mm; weight: 4.84g.Discussion: Similar strips of gold with tapering, rounded terminals dated to the Bronze Age are recorded on the database including ESS-54776E (2023T985); BUC-095886 (2021T497); KENT-21C63F (2021T630), both described as possible ribbons or bracelets, and LANCUM-9E38B6 (2023T750), a ribbon.A further Bronze Age examples includes a gold securing strip, with perforated folded terminals, from a gold armlet or cuff found in the hoard from Capel Isaf, Manordeilo, Carmarthenshire, and illustrated in Savory (1980: 195, fig.47, no.1), which is now dated from the Middle Bronze Age c.1600-1400 BC. A Bronze Age date is supported by those gold ribbons with more diagnostic features such as lateral ribs (see OXON-E7AB6A) due to an in-context example found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980) in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd -early 2nd millennium BC. However, there are also examples which are suggested to come from the Roman to Early Medieval period (NLM-E8C60D, SWYOR-089827 and IOW-36803C).Two similarly shaped strips twisted together and recorded as metal working debris has also been given a possible Bronze Age date based on the comparisons with a gold 'ring' from Ammerbuch-Reusten, Southwestern Germany, the metal for which was sourced in Cornwall, with the record also including a discussion on the possibility of it having an early medieval date (WILT-1D8478 (2022T286).Conclusion: It is therefore likely that this object was at least 300 years old at the time of discovery. As the object is also made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: 2024 T1130Middle Bronze Age Gold Coiled Ring PAS Database number: DUR-639197Date: c. 1300-1100 BC.Description: A complete solid gold Bronze Age coiled ring dating to the Middle Bronze Age, c. 1300-1100 BC.The artefact comprises a single gold strand with a sub-rectangular cross-section coiled into a stack reaching a maximum height of three strands. Both terminals are tapered suggesting they have been cut. Overall, the artefact has a sub-oval plan. The surface is smooth and gold with some small nicks and dents. Dimensions: Height: 4.6 mm; Thickness: 1.58 mm; Weight: 1.05 g; Diameter: 6.73 mm.Discussion: Single finds of gold coiled rings are usually assigned Middle Bronze Age dates based on comparable examples found in hoards with other dateable artefacts. The Fittleworth Hoard (BM 1996, 0902.18) from West Sussex contains two, admittedly slightly larger, coiled rings together with a range of other Middle Bronze Age gold artefacts. Similarly, 2023-T1094 (LANCUM-D7E08D) comprises a gold bracelet or armlet with five closed penannular rings of a similar size and form and has been assigned a Middle Bronze Age date based on the size form of the twisted wire bracelet. Similar gold coiled rings have met the criteria for Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996 including: 2023-T205 (KENT-0BF691), 2021-T716 (SF-6FD899).Conclusion: The age and precious metal content of this object meets the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996. Author: Caroline Smith, Finds Liaison Assistant for Northeast England; Benjamin Westwood, Finds Liaison Officer for Durham, Darlington & Teesside.Date: 19/06/2025References:        Eoghan, G. (1994).   The Accomplished Art: Gold and Gold-Working in Britain and Ireland During the Bronze Age. Oxford: Oxbow Books.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A Bronze Age gold ribbon, dating to c. 2200 - 800 BC. It comprises a folded/rolled rectangular strip of sheet or ribbon gold, the object is now sub-cylindrical. Both sides are undecorated, at each end is a small circular perforation. Width: 7.4 mmHeight: 10.3 mmWeight: 2.64 g
notes: The object is consistent with a number of examples which have been determined to be Treasure on the PAS database including 2024T589 (LON-F193B6), 2022T983 (OXON-40190C) and 2017T922 (SUR-4956AF) These are plain strips, some exhibit one or two perforations. A broad Bronze Age date is offered here of between circa 2300-800 BC. In all of these examples, it is not clear what their function was.The object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Complete copper alloy flat axe, dating to the early Bronze Age (c.2350-2050 BC).The object flares from a rounded butt (22.91 mm wide) into a gradually widened crescent shaped blade (51.34 mm wide). It has a lenticular cross section and slightly rounded sides, with a thickness of 8.49 mm at the centre, 4.88 mm at the butt, and 4.98 mm at the blade. There is no evidence for decoration on any of the surfaces of the object, and it exhibits a consistent red-brown to light green patina. The object has been heavily abraded and has active copper corrosion along the edge of the blade.The form of this object suggests it fits within Schmidt and Burgess' (1981, 35) Migdale Type, dating to the first half of the early Bronze Age. These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 c. 2350- 2050 BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Length: 103.35 mmWidth: 51.34 mmThickness: 8.49 mmWeight: 143.63 g
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Gold ingot fragment of Bronze Age date, c.1600-800BC.The ingot is roughly cylindrical in shape with a slight taper from 4.5mm at one end to 3.7mm at the other.  The wider terminal is set at a slight angle where it has been cut, displaying a straight edge until the final fifth which is burred and uneven. The opposite terminal is straight and does not appear to have been cut/hacked, but there is a small circular dent towards one edge.  The sides of the ingot have an even curve, but the top and top and bottom edges are flat with a rough surface. Several similar fragments of goldwork have been recovered from hoards containing diagnostically Bronze Age objects such as the Poulton, Gloucestershire: Treasure case 2004 T17 which is held in the Corinium Museum https://coriniummuseum.org/2016/08/early-gold/Plus, several items from the hoard found at the Fitzleroi Farm in West Sussex, that are now held in the British Museum collection such as the bars 1996,0902.1-42 and 1996,0902.32See also IOW-50D55F (2018 T5), KENT-731554 (2024 T217) for similar parallels that have been recorded as treasure.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold penannular ring of Middle Bronze Age date (c.1300-1100 cal BC).Description: The ring is circular in plan, and constructed from two lengths of wire, of D-shaped cross section, fused together. The ends of the ring are straight and end overlaps the other slightly. The grove between the two strands has been worked with a tool. Where the two stands meet on the inside surface, there is a raised seam. One of the strands also has a seam running down the centre of its length and the other, a slightly visible seam. Measurements: diameter: 13mm; width: 5.2mm; thickness: 1mm; weight: 1.85gDiscussion: Bronze Age gold penannular rings constructed from separate wires are usually constructed from circular rods, maintaining a circular cross-section, or C-shaped rods. Those which are D-shaped and flat on the inside, like the example recorded here, are less common, but examples which have also been submitted for the consideration as Treasure include OXON-B69005 (2022T1110); ESS-9DB6CE (2020T1020), both fragments. Complete examples of this form, all constructed with three strands (tripartite) include HAMP-38D723 (2020T623); SF-6CDBFB (2017T200) and NMS-ACBFA4 (2014T3). These have been dated to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1300-1100 cal BC) based on parallels found in Middle Bronze Age contexts. The most closely comparable to the example recorded here is that which was found within in a hoard of objects CORN-705C14 (2020T222) which span the Penard (c.1275-1150 BC) phase of the late Middle Bronze Age to the Ewart Park / Carp's Tongue phase of the Late Bronze Age (c.1000-800 BC). Other examples of multi-strand penannular rings, including those of circular and C-shaped section have been found as part of hoards dated to the Middle Bronze Age. The Burton Hoard (PAS-5B1745 – Welsh Treasure case 04:02) includes a composite gold penannular ring formed from three round-sectioned wires which have been fused together, with simple clipped or cut terminals. The Cirencester Hoard (BM-28B710 – 2004 T416) includes two double penannular rings and a fragment of a third. Finally, the Granta Fen hoard (British Museum Accession No. 1884,0520) includes several multistranded penannular rings looped around a gold bracelet which was found with an incomplete rapier. It is therefore likely that the penannular ring recorded here dates to the same period. Conclusion: It is therefore likely that the find was at least 300 years old at the time of discovery. As the object also contains at least 10% precious metal, it constitutes Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act (1996).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A Fragment of a hacked gold double penannular ring dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c. 1300 – 800 cal BC).This ring has a circular cross-section and a flat terminal, the other end is missing because the item has been cut is half at the apex of the arch by a bladed item. This has created a straight side edge for the first 3/4, the final 1/4 has a slight lip suggesting that the initial cut was not deep enough to sever it completely, making it necessary to finish the process by bending and snapping the object in two. There is a thick scar that runs along the top edge of the penannular showing that a second ring would have been attached above. See LIN-B62849 (2024 T476) for a complete example. Many penannular rings of his type are composite with copper alloy cores (See Green 1988 or Ashby 2007 for examples) but this not the case with this example as the cut has clearly exposing the core of the artefact. Discussion:  Dr Edward Caswell discusses a similar ring record at GLO-A9AD4A (2018T98) where he writes. Penannular rings belong to a class of artefact which have in the past been given various terms such as 'hair-rings' (Eogan 1997) and other monikers such as ‘Ring Money’ (Geen 1988) which are now no longer supported (Taylor 1980, 65 Varndell 2001). Their function remains uncertain (Varndell 2001, 516), although it is likely that they were personal adornments (Hobbs 2003, 102-107), possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.They are given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and The Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008,  13). Gwilt (2015) suggests (citing Raftery 2004, 87-8) that, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing such that these items may be placed within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC).Many penannular rings of his type are composite with copper alloy cores (See Green 1988 or Ashby 2007 for examples) but this not the case with this example as the cut has clearly exposing  the core of the artefact. Conclusion: The penannular rings appear to be over 10% precious metal and more than 300 years old and as such qualify as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Bibliography:Ashby, S. 2007. NARC-773944: A BRONZE AGE PENANNULAR RING Web page available at: https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/189173 [Accessed: 13 Mar 2019 10:07:03]Atherton, R. 2010. Essays in Honour of George Eogan. Oxford:Oxbow Books, 83–91Taylor, J.J. 1980. Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles. Cambridge: Cambridge University PressVarndell, G. 2001.
