description: Probable Middle Bronze Age hoard (5/6 artefacts) Penard metalworking phase (1300-1150 BC)1. Transitional palstave Length 167.0mm, blade width 40.2mm, surviving butt width 21.4mm, body width below loop 26.0mm, length of butt (to stop) approx. 67.0mm, maximum thickness at stop 28.8mm, stop heights 8.0 & 9.5mm; Weight: 411.6g (prior to cleaning)This is a complete bronze looped palstave with a narrow blade, whose sides are straight and divergent to an unexpanded edge. There is slight waisting below the stop, with slight widening convexity of butt sides above the stop. A single medial ridge, wider below the stop and then tapering down the blade, extends half-way down one blade face, being less distinct on the reverse face. The hafting slot is sub-rectangular, while the septum floor is slightly concave in cross-section. The stop is slightly protuberant in side-section, while the flanges are relatively straight. In side view, the stop levels are misaligned, while the casting-seam is off-centre, indicating a mismatching of mould parts in the casting of the palstave. The butt is square ended and the loop is complete and narrow in side-section. There is dried soil adhering to many surfaces, with powdery light green surfaces evident along stop, flange tops and blade edge. There are powdery ‘warts’ on one face and along the non-loop side. 2. Transitional palstave Length 166.0mm, blade width 39.9mm, butt width 22.2mm, body width below loop 27.1mm, length of butt (to stop) approx. 65.6mm, maximum thickness at stop 28.7mm, stop heights 7.5 & 10.0mm; Weight: 409.7g (prior to cleaning)This is a complete bronze looped palstave with a narrow blade, whose sides are straight and divergent to an unexpanded edge. There is slight waisting below the stop, with slight widening convexity of butt sides above the stop. A single medial ridge appears to be wider below the stop, becoming indistinct around one third of the way down each blade surface. The hafting slot is sub-rectangular, while the septum floor is slightly concave in cross-section. The stop is slightly protuberant in side-section, while the flanges are relatively straight. In side view the stop levels are misaligned, while the casting seam is off-centre, indicating a mismatching of mould parts in the casting of the palstave. The butt is square ended and the loop is complete and narrow in side-section. The excess bronze on the side interior of the loop remains untrimmed. There is dried soil adhering to many surfaces, with powdery green surfaces on upper flange, butt and stop, also extending in patches down the blade surfaces and sides. There are traces of blackening on one upper septum surface near the butt-end. 3. Transitional palstave Surviving length 170.0mm, blade width 39.6mm, butt width 22.2mm, body width below loop 25.9mm, length of butt (to stop) approx. 68.8mm, maximum thickness at stop 29.1mm, stop heights 8.5 & 9.5mm; Weight: 422.2g (after cleaning, prior to conservation)This is a virtually complete bronze looped palstave with a narrow blade. The upper sides have a very slight concavity, then becoming straight along mid and lower sections and divergent to an unexpanded edge. There is slight waisting below the stop, with a slight widening convexity of butt sides above the stop. A single medial ridge extends about one half of the way down each blade surface. The hafting slot is sub-rectangular, while the septum floor is slightly concave in cross-section. The stop is slightly protuberant in side-section, while the flanges are relatively straight. In side view the stop levels are misaligned, while the casting seam is off-centre, indicating a mismatching of mould parts in the casting of the palstave. The butt is sub-rounded, though slightly asymmetric in plan view and the loop is complete and narrow in side-section. The palstave has been cleaned, probably in water, since discovery by the temporary holder and before the palstave was recalled to the National Museum as possible treasure. This has resulted in differential surface decay of this palstave, with large areas of light powdery corrosion with pits and warts. In addition the blade end is very unstable, with blade edge fragments having broken off, since initial PAS recording and photography, but before the axe entered the National Museum. 4. Transitional palstave Surviving length 163.0mm, blade width 41.4mm, butt width 22.9mm, body width below loop 26.6mm, length of butt (to stop) approx. 65.9mm, maximum thickness at stop 28.5mm, stop heights 8.5 & 8.5mm; Weight: 410.4g (prior to cleaning)This is a complete bronze looped palstave with a narrow blade, whose sides are very slightly concave and divergent to an unexpanded edge. There is slight waisting below the stop, with a slight widening convexity of butt sides above the stop. A single medial ridge extends about one third of the way down each blade surface. The hafting slot is sub-angular, while the septum floor is slightly concave in cross-section. The flanges are relatively straight. In side view the stop levels are misaligned, while the casting seam is off-centre, indicating a mismatching of mould parts in the casting of the palstave. The butt is square ended and the loop is complete and relatively narrow in side-section. There is dried mud adhering to many surfaces, though with surviving original surfaces with grey-green patination also showing through. The flange tops and loop side have light green powdery and unstable surfaces. The blade edge is also very unstable with small fragments having detached since discovery and with light green powdery surfaces. On one mid blade face, there are modern gouged nicks and similarly on the opposite upper blade face, there are recent surface scars. Each has small patches of light green powdery surface around them. 5. Transitional palstave Surviving length 165.0mm, blade width 39.2mm, butt width 21.9mm, body width below loop 26.0mm, length of butt (to stop) approx. 64.5mm, maximum thickness at stop 29.8mm, stop heights 9.0 & 9.5mm; Weight: 424.6g (prior to cleaning)This is a virtually complete bronze looped palstave with a narrow blade. The upper sides have a very slight concavity, then becoming straight along mid and lower sections and divergent to an unexpanded edge. There is slight waisting below the stop, with a slight widening convexity of butt sides above the stop. A single medial ridge extends around half way down each blade surface. The hafting slot is sub-rectangular, while the septum floor is slightly concave in cross-section. The stop is slightly protuberant in side section, while the flanges are relatively straight. In side view the stop levels are misaligned, while the casting seam is off-centre, indicating a mismatching of mould parts in the casting of the palstave. The butt is heavily worn, but sub-rounded in plan view and the loop is complete and narrow in side-section. There is dried mud adhering to some surfaces, however a reasonable proportion of original srfaces survive with a grey-green coloured patination. On the sides, flange tops, butt end and blade end, there are light green areas of unstable powdery surface, with some pitting and ‘warts’. 6. Possible casting jet (PAS ref. CPAT-53DDB6)Length 27.6mm, diameter of top surface 24.6mm, length near base 13.4mm, width near base 8.2mm; Weight 35.9g. This deliberately shaped copper alloy fragment has a near circular top-surface, which is convex in profile. The sides are concave, tapering to a narrower base, which is rounded, though oval in plan view. There is no evidence remaining of one or two runner-stubs, the base surface being worn. Though deliberately shaped, the surfaces of this fragment have irregularities, small projections and depressions, consistent with being a bi-product rather than an artefact. The fragment has a grey green patination. The five palstaves show a remarkable degree of similarity with each other, which manifests itself in their stylistic and chronological similarity, weight and dimensional similarities and specific visual similarities in their shape as cast in the mould. These observations are pertinent in assessing the likelihood of their being found at five different single find locations, as reported by the finder, or alternatively as a hoard of five artefacts buried together in one place, as argued by the lead author (AG). All five palstaves may be identified as Transitional palstaves of Type Shelf and Midribbed Variant (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 146-8 & Cats. 846-874). In other words they all have narrow unexpanded blades, similar proportions and a medial ridge extending from the stop down each upper blade face. They may all be similarly dated to between 1350-1050BC during the Middle Bronze Age and early part of the Late Bronze Age. The degree of similarity is heightened further by virtue of a comparison of weights and dimensions, as tabulated and grouped below. Two close sub-groups may be identified. Palstaves 1, 2 & 4 are remarkably similar and Palstaves 3 & 5 form a second apparent sub-grouping. Here it is worth qualifying that Palstave 1 has an eroded butt end, therefore was originally a little wider when cast. In addition, Palstave 5 has a particularly worn butt end, which has resulted in a loss in overall length and a reduction in its butt length relative to Palstave 3, however all other measurements are closely similar. These observations may be further heightened by shape characteristics, which suggest that these palstaves may be mould linked: in other words that certain palstaves were cast in the same mould:-Palstaves 1 & 2 (and possibly 4)Palstaves 1 & 2 both have a squared butt end and a very similar form with straight slightly divergent sides and no expansion of the blade. The blade ends are flat. The mid-ridges on the upper faces are exactly alike and extend down the upper third of the blade faces. In side view, both axes share exactly the same shape of casting seams and flange profiles. Both have the same and asymmetric mismatching of mould halves, to the extent that one mould side was deeper than the other. Moreover on the loop side, the stop levels are similarly mismatching, the left side having a lower and less pronounced stop. Though very similar in dimensions to Palstaves 1 & 2, Palstave 4 is slightly shorter in length. Unlike Palstaves 1 & 2, it has a very slightly expanded blade edge and the edge is markedly more rounded and crescent shaped than the other two. The different preparation of the blade and the more recent erosion and chipping along the blade edge may account for the noticeably shorter length of this artefact (amounting to 3-4mm). Palstave 4 shares a squared butt end and almost identical mid ridge definition as Palstaves 1 & 2. In addition, a very similar shaped casting seam and asymmetry of mould pairing is seen, exactly the same as with Palstaves 1 & 2. Therefore, while the degree of similarity is less – perhaps accounted for due to a difference in palstave blade preparation after casting – Palstave 4 could be suggested as possibly mould linked with Palstaves 1 & 2. Palstaves 3 & 5These palstaves share a sub-rounded butt end and a very similar form, with slight concavity on upper blades, with slight lower blade side convexity, coming to an unexpanded blade, giving a similar slightly bulbous or sinuous blade outline. The blade ends are both similarly rounded. On one face, the stops share exactly the same blemish, showing as a central depression in the stop and diminishing of the stop-height. The mid-ridge below each stop has a slight uneven bulbous and sinuous imperfection – very precisely matching imperfections strongly suggesting they were cast in the same mould. On the non-loop side, the casting seams have exactly the same asymmetry – left side shallower than right – with a projecting sinuosity immediately above the level of the stop in both instances. When the palstaves are placed with their loops to the right, then the upper non-loop face edges have the same waisting and definition, almost identical similarities further strongly suggesting they were cast in the same mould. Palstave 3 has experienced differentially higher erosion of its butt end since burial in the ground, accounting for noticeable differences in palstave length and butt length. Palstave 5 has been washed, possibly accounting for its lower weight, due to the removal of soil and also to consequential differential corrosion of the original surfaces. Transitional palstaves flourished during the Penard metalworking tradition of the Middle Bronze Age (1300-1150BC) and continued into the Wilburton tradition of the Late Bronze Age (1150-1000BC) (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 152-7; Northover unpublished 193-4 & 212). The earliest examples were made towards the end of the Taunton / Cemmaes metalworking phase (1350-1275BC), being found in hoard associations with Group III low-flanged palstaves (e.g. Hawkes 1955; Burgess 1970; Rowlands 1976; Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 152-3; Gwilt et al unpublished). An overview of the occurrence of Transitional palstaves known in Wales indicates they are relatively uncommon in relation to the incidence of other more common palstave forms. There are only 39 examples known prior to the Nantmel five, bringing the total now known from Wales to 44. Of these, 31 are single finds, while a further 8 examples have been found in 6 different hoards (Northover unpublished; with recently reported PAS finds). These include hoards from Burton (Wrexham), Llantwit Major (Vale of Glamorgan), ‘central Wales’, Porthamel (Anglesey) and Monkton (Pembrokeshire) (Williams 1867, 283 & Pl.; Laws 1908; Grimes 1933, 90-1 & Fig. 2; Savory 1980,  117 & 126, Cats. 265 & 300, Figs. 23 & 31,  Pl. VIIa; Lynch 1991, 232 & Fig. 63.10-11; Gwilt et al 2007; unpublished; Northover unpublished, Hoards 16, 144 & 167). In neighbouring Shropshire and Cheshire, the Bryn Siop, Meol Brace and Wilmslow hoards also contain Transitional palstaves (Chitty, 1925; Davey & Forster 1975, Cats 54-55 & Figs.; Savory 1980, 106, Cat. 168 & Fig. 22; Longley 1987, 103 & Fig. 18.3; Northover unpublished Hoards 44,149 & 160). However, the only known hoard containing Transitional palstaves from Powys (two examples of the different Type Roundhay, Midribbed Variant form) is the Ffynhonnau hoard (Banks 1884; Savory 1955, 102 & Pl. VI; 1958, 27-8 & Fig. 3; Northover unpublished, Hoard 19). To the knowledge of the author, no single finds of Transitional palstaves have previously been reported from Powys, prior to these five discoveries from Nantmel. Seen in this context, the discovery of five reportedly single finds of the same form of Type Shelf, Midribbed Variant, Transitional palstaves, specifically from the Nantmel locality, discovered at around the same time and by the same finder would be a truly remarkable and unparalleled coincidence. In the opinion of the author (AG), a much more likely probability is that the five closely similar palstaves were in fact buried and found as an associated hoard group in one location, contrary to the reported account of the discovery given by the finder. The issue of whether or not the possible casting jet was buried with the five palstaves is more difficult to ascertain from the available evidence. In form, casting jets are not always chronologically diagnostic, therefore there may be little to differentiate a jet of Middle Bronze Age date from one of Late Bronze Age date. In general, casting jets are most commonly found within Late Bronze Age hoards spanning the period 1150-800BC and slightly later than these palstaves. Casting jets are rare in Middle Bronze Age hoards, however not unknown. A Middle Bronze Age palstave with a casting jet was recently discovered and reported as treasure from Ottery St. Mary, Devon (Worrell 2008), while probable eroded jets were associated with the maritime metalwork assemblage from Langdon Bay, off the coast of Kent (Muckelroy 1981; Stuart Needham pers. comm.). This latter assemblage probably relates to a shipwreck site, but dates to the same Penard metalworking tradition of the Middle Bronze Age as the five Nantmel palstaves (1300-1150BC). Surface metallurgical analysis of the possible jet has confirmed it is made of a leaded tin bronze. If viewed on its own and compared with other analysed artefacts, this would tend to be viewed as most consistent with a Late Bronze Age metal signature, though the possibility of another date of manufacture could not be discounted. However, similar and comparable analysis of the five Middle Bronze Age palstaves has indicated that all were also made of a leaded tin bronze. In particular, palstave 4 has a higher lead content, with a similar signature to the possible casting jet. Consequently, the possible jet, on the current evidence presented, could have been associated with the palstaves as part of the same hoard, however there is insufficient stylistic and compelling dating evidence to advise a balance of probability that it was. Therefore, one is forced to return to the coincidences relating to its discovery: the possible jet was found by the same finder as the palstaves, in the same reported vicinity and just a short time after the palstaves. The very similar metal compositions of palstaves 1, 2, 3 & 5 are consistent with the assertion, on strong morphological grounds, that palstaves 1 & 2 and palstaves 3 & 5 were mould linked. This metallurgical evidence, based on surface and preliminary scan evidence, should however only be regarded as minor supporting evidence, rather than strong conclusive evidence in its own right. The higher level of lead in palstave 4 does not appreciably contrast in signature with the others and remains within the realm of possible variation seen within a contemporary, single hoard and mould linked group. Opinion & recommendationIt is the primary author’s opinion (AG), that the five palstaves here identified may be considered as treasure within the recently reviewed definition of treasure (Treasure Act 1996 and the Treasure (Designation) Order 2002). Contrary to the finder’s account of discovery of the palstaves in five different localities, the close stylistic, morphological and casting characteristics exhibited by the palstaves provide strong grounds for suggesting the palstaves were found together as a hoard. Moreover, when seen within the broader context of discovery and reporting of Transitional palstaves in Powys and Wales to date, the discovery of five new examples in five different locations in the same vicinity, by the same finder and within a short space of time, can be regarded as unlikely and completely unparalleled. On a balance of probability, it is argued that the five palstaves were actually found directly associated together in the ground and that as contemporary prehistoric base-metal artefacts, buried together as a closed group they qualify under the current definition of treasure. Please refer to Section C, Paragraphs 6, 11 & 14 of the Treasure Act 1996 Code of Practice (Revised) (DCMS 2002).

description: An unlooped copper alloy palstave axehead dating to the Bronze Age period, c. 1600-1200 BC.The palstave is nearly complete, with only a minor break at the butt causing a sloping edge at the terminal. The blade flares from the stop ridge progressively, forming a crescent-shaped convex cutting edge. The blade tapers from the stop ridge to the blade edge, creating a wedge-shaped, triangular profile. On one face of the palstave, there is a depression in the shape of a shield; on the other face this is not apparent. The stop ridge is well developed on the side which bears the shield, with a rounded depression at the head of the septum. On the other face of the palstave, the septum is shallower and sub-rectangular in plan. The flanges are straight in plan and leaf-shaped in profile. The butt ascends from the stop ridge to the butt terminal. There is a casting ridge on both sides of the palstave. The palstave has a light-green patina and an uneven surface.Dimensions: The palstave measures 168 mm in length. The width at the blade edge is 67.28 mm, the thickness at the blade edge is 2.10 mm, the width at the stop is 25.97 mm, the thickness at the stop is 34.44 mm, the length of the socket is 67.81 mm. It weighs 522 g.Discussion: This form of palstave belongs to Rowlands (1976) Group 1 (or Schmidt and Burgess 1981, Class 1) primary shield type. It is comparable to Rowlands (1976) no. 699 (vol ii, plate 7), and Hoard 66, No. 1-6 (vol ii, plate 6).  It dates to the Middle Bronze Age, between the Acton Park and Taunton phase, c. 1600-1200 cal. BC. (Ed Caswell, pers. comm.). Similar palstaves are recorded on the PAS database, such as WREX-9DC990, SUR-73F678, DENO-F6A145, and DOR-6ADAF9. *The palstave was originally submitted as part of a potential hoard along with a fragment of gold ribbon (DEV-BD02FA/2022T421). However, gold ribbons of this from are notable for having few in context discoveries and so few direct associations with contemporary items. The gold ribbon has been described by the finder having been “found one foot away but a little deeper”. A test pit has also been reported by the finder as having been dug in the area by archaeologists. The results of this excavation suggests that both were “found in hill wash and were out of context, most probably through ploughing”. Therefore, while the ribbon and the palstave were found suitably close to suggest they may have come from a single deposit their location in a disturbed hill wash context requires there to be good evidence why this might be the case rather than the items being buried over two separate events in the same region. While ribbons have been given broad dates, their only firm association has been with objects dating to the Early phase of the Bronze Age. The axehead meanwhile is of a type suggested most frequently to be found in isolation (Schmidt and Burgess 1981) or alternatively with material dating to the Middle Bronze Age. As these are not contemporary periods the ribbon, being an object of more than 10% precious metal over 300 years old qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 while the palstave does not on the balance of probability meet this threshold.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Treasure Case 2024 T992A gold sheet ribbon, probably dating from the Bronze Age dating (c. 2150 BC to c. 1150 BC). The strip is sub-rectangular with irregular sides and is folded over both at the short edge and long edge. Both sides carry a corrugated design of at least five grooves and six ridges, one side is not as prominent as the other. The ridges and grooves are tightly spaced at one end and flare gently outward towards the opposite end.MeasurementsLength: 17.1 mm; Width: 13.1 mm; Thickness: 1.6 mm; Weight: 0.75gDiscussionDue to its incompleteness it is difficult to identify this gold strip to a particular object type with any high degree of certainty. Based on its surviving form and dimensions, it is probable that it once belonged to a broad range of strip or ribbon ornaments of Bronze Age date. Similar strips have been found throughout Britain, including several recent finds from England that have been reported as treasure including: WAW-052196 (2010T604), SWYOR-DBF058 (2020T516) and WMID-FE3C28 (2016T1039). In general, these have been loosely dated to the Early or Middle Bronze Ages (ca. 2150-1150 BC) on stylistic and technical grounds. Some of these strips are flat, with parallel linear grooved decoration incised from the front and not showing on the rear surface (e.g. PAS-067AC5, 2013T154). One such example, approximately 8.7cm long and 0.8cm wide, was found from The Hamel, Oxford, associated in a soil context with flint artefacts located near to a Beaker burial containing late Beaker pottery dating to the second half of the Early Bronze Age (ca. 1900-1700 BC) (Palmer 1980, 128-132, Fig. 3.11).ReferencesPalmer, N. 1980. A Beaker Burial and Medieval Tenements in The Hamel, Oxford, Oxoniensia 45, 124-225.ConclusionAs this fragment is older than 300 years in age, with a precious metal content of greater than 10%, it should be considered as potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
notes: Measurements and pictures kindly provided by Manx Museum
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A strip of ribbon gold, dating to the Bronze Age c. 2200 - 800 BC. The strip is 40mm in length, 7.6mm wide and made from 10 pieces of gold wire which have been soldered together to produce a reeded effect; these are coming apart in places. Both ends are squared and have been cut. The ribbon is opened out to its full length and it is unclear whether it was ever intended to be used curled up into a ring or some other closed shape.
notes: The style of this object with its parallel linear ridges made from soldered wire is typical of gold items of known and probable Bronze Age date, variously identified as penannular rings (WREX-584607 (2022T36)), bracelets (NARC-4CA897) and more generically as gold ornaments (SUR-1B64F5 (2012T659)). This multiple-stranded form has parallels with gold items from the Burton Hoard (PAS-5B1745, Welsh Treasure case 04:02), The Cirencester Hoard (BM-28B710, 2004 T416) and the Granta Fen hoard (British Museum Accession No. 1884,0520) which have been dated to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1300-1150 BC) based on association with diagnostic artefacts; however a wider date range for items of ribbon gold made in this fashion during the Bronze Age is also likely.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Probable Middle Bronze Age composite annular gold band (1500-1150 BC)1.  Composite annular gold band – completeDimensions: maximum surviving external diameter 26.7mm; minimum surviving external diameter 15.8mm; width band 4.5-4.6mm; width of individual wires making up whole band 0.8-1.0mm; thickness 1.1-1.3mm; weight 2.89g. This is a complete annular gold band with parallel straight sides, now bent out of original shape with a current maximum external diameter of 26.7mm. If originally circular in shape, the band would have had a diameter of approximately 24 mm. The band has been constructed from five wires which have been fused and/or soldered together. The central wire and the pair of outer wires are of twisted S-spun form, later pressed flat when fused and possibly soldered together. The pair of wires located between the central and outer pair are plain and flat, possibly originally of round-section and pressed flat when fused together. The joins between each wire, now showing as three grooves on both upper and interior surfaces, were expertly made, with no gaps or tears evident around the circumference. The contours of the grooves and linear surface striations along them suggest that the joins were made and defined using a fine-pointed tool. A straight and fused transverse join is visible on one interior surface, showing as a linear groove, indicating the band was formed from an elongate strip, approximately 75mm long. In places, the joins between the twisted wires have failed, possibly as the band was bent out of its original shape, creating localized areas of detachment. Parallel striations are visible under the microscope along the band edges, suggesting tooling marks created by a file during the making process. The outer surface is more worn than the interior surface, where the wire twists are better defined. There are occasional scratches on the outer surface, probably created after the burial of the band or during its discovery and retrieval. The surfaces have a silvery- or white-gold patina, rather than an orange-gold patina more typical of gold containing a high copper content. The composite annular gold band finds technological and stylistic parallels with the twisted goldworking tradition spanning Atlantic Europe during the Penard metalworking tradition of the Middle Bronze Age (Bronze Final I in France) and dating from 1300-1150 BC (e.g. Taylor 1980, 60-4; Eogan 1994, 42-79; Roberts 2007). This period saw the widespread creation and use of twisted gold torcs and bracelets, often carefully deposited in hoards or as single objects. The twisted gold wire working technique, as illustrated through this composite band, finds close parallel with composite twisted gold wire bracelets, as known from the Burton hoard, Wrexham (Gwilt et al 2005; 2007) and the Salcombe Wreck, Devon (Needham et al 2013; Murgia et al 2014; British Museum Acc. Nos. 2010,8032.4 & 2010,8032.7). The individual wire strands in these bracelets have been fused to each other at intervals, using early soldering technique. However, the weld and joins are discontinuous, in contrast to this annular band, where the weld is continuous. Further parallels in technique are found with composite gold penannular rings, comprising multiple plain wire strands fused together, another known artefact class linked with gold hoards of the Penard phase of the British Middle Bronze Age equating with Bronze Final I in France (e.g. Eogan 1967, 149-51; 1983, No. 28, Fig. 15E; Eluère 1982, 26-7 & 187; Gwilt et al 2004; Varndell 2007, 22-3 & 229, Fig 6). However, the interleaving of plain with twisted wires, as apparent on this artefact and their fusing together into a composite ring, is an unusual variation which proves difficult to parallel. The apparent flattening of the external surfaces of the twisted wires on this ring, possibly created when the multiple wire strands were being fused together along their lengths, also hints at pressing or compression, possibly concurrently with the heating of the gold, perhaps to create the continuous weld. This is a novel aspect of this composite band, difficult to parallel elsewhere based on preliminary comparison. Most known composite rings are penannular in form with simple and flat-ended terminals. The continuous annular form of this composite band could suggest a different function. The current misshapen form of the ring makes it difficult to ascertain for certain whether it was originally circular or elongated and sub-rectangular with rounded corners. An original diameter of approximately 24 mm is large for it to have functioned as a finger ring, with more recent external finger ring diameters tending to be in the 16-22mm range. At 24mm diameter, if used as a ring, it is more likely to be in the thumb- or toe-ring range, or possibly worn over a glove. Were the band to demonstrate bending consistent with shaping around a narrow object, then it may have functioned as a decorative band around the hilt of a bronze dagger. Corrugated gold hilt bands are a feature of a small number of Early Bronze Age dagger burials, where they serve as pommel mounts (Henshall 1968, 173-195; Needham 2000, 52-54; Becker 2008, 75; Needham & Sheridan 2014, 905 & 914, Fig. 2; Noble & Brophy 2011, 796-799, Fig. 8a). The lack of any tightly angled crease marks on this particular composite gold band tends to argue in favour of it probably once having been circular in shape and more likely to have functioned as a decorative ring.Similar annular gold rings have recently been reported from Ropley, Hampshire (Hinds 2015) and Takely, Essex (McLean 2007), however these were made of single coiled wires in spiral fashion, with weld joins between the twists. To these may be added examples of misshapen composite gold strips with wires welded or part welded to each other, where it is difficult to know whether the strips were originally annular or penannular in shape, with examples recently reported from Hepple, Northumberland (Collins 2009) and Prees, Shropshire (White 2022). In Wales, an example has recently been reported from St Ishmael Community, Carmarthenshire (Treasure Case 23.56), the subject of another ongoing treasure case not yet reported upon. Semi-quantitative surface XRF analysis of this composite annular band has indicated a mean gold content of 84.124%, silver content of 15.420% and copper content of 0.455%. This very low copper content is best paralleled with items of Early Bronze Age date in Wales, where a range of 0.3-1% copper is typical (Gwilt et al 2005, 36 & Fig. 4). This initially appears at odds with the stylistic and technical parallels, which best fit with a Middle Bronze Age date. However, it is possible that there has been a surface depletion of copper on the gold band and only further drill sampling would establish whether the interior of the gold had a higher copper content than present on the surface. Also of interest is that recent metallurgical analysis of the gold twisted wire bracelet in the Burton, Wrexham hoard has produced a similar low copper composition of 0.91-1.01% sitting at the top end of the Early Bronze Age range (Davis 2018). Also, of probable Penard date, this hints that occasional gold artefacts were made using ‘archaic’ low copper gold compositions during the Middle Bronze Age, possibly using gold deriving from different source locations. This is a matter for further future research and consideration. On balance, and on the basis of the evidence currently available, a probable Middle Bronze Age date for the composite gold ring is favoured.

description: Middle to Late Bronze Age gold penannular ring (1300-800 BC)Gold penannular ring Dimensions: external diameter 17.7mm (side to side) by 17.3mm (front to back); internal diameter 6.4mm (side to side) by 6.2mm (front to back); thickness of body 5.9-6.0mm (top to bottom) by 5.5-6.0mm (internal to external); weight 17.82g. This is a complete and small penannular ring of solid gold. The significant weight of the ring and the absence of any evidence for the detachment of foil indicates that the ring is of solid gold. Examination of the visible flat terminal surfaces under the microscope also confirm its solid gold composition, with no evidence of any folded over gold foil apparent. The even thickness of the ring, absence of internal compression ridges and its precisely circular shape are notable features. The upper and lower surfaces of the ring are slightly flattened, while the external diameter surface is generally rounded in profile. When viewed under the microscope numerous diagonal striations are visible across the outer surface, likely created when the ring was burnished in antiquity. On the external surface at the back of the ring is a small area of irregular pitting in the surface, probably an area of the original artefact form which escaped polishing and finishing before use. The internal ring surface appears relatively flat with rounded edge sections, giving the impression of a slightly D-shaped cross-section to the ring. Large areas of the internal surface, appear to have been smoothed, shiny and with parallel fine striations created either by polishing or during use. There is a slight and meandering faceting around the internal circumference, whose surface appears not to have been polished and is dull. The flat terminal ends are almost touching, separated by a narrow gap of between 0.2-0.5mm. Microscope examination of the terminal surfaces indicates the presence of parallel striations, consistent with fine file marks. There is some evidence that the ring has been gripped, possibly during its period of use or as working preparation prior to its burial. Two slightly flattened facets are visible on the external surface, one either side of the ring. The facet surfaces have damage striations on them. Another flattened facet is located across the external surfaces of the terminals. This shows more as a surface flattening and deformation of the outer terminal edges, so that they almost touch at their external margins. This penannular ring belongs to a group of artefacts which are commonly referred to as ‘hair-rings’ or ‘ring-money’, dating to the Middle and Late Bronze Ages (1300-800 BC). This is the tenth known example of a hair-ring to be discovered from Wales and may be identified as of Type 1a – a plain, solid gold ring (Meeks et al 2008, 16-7, Fig. 1 i-iv). Only one other example of a hair-ring has previously been recorded from ‘Carmarthenshire’, a ring with a copper or copper alloy core with a plain gold foil surface, said to have been a metal-detector find before 1990 and offered for sale on the ebay website in August 2006. The only other hair-ring with a gold core from Wales is from Cwm Cadnant Community, Anglesey, which had a striped surface decoration, created by an inlayed spiral strip of silver-coloured electrum (Gwilt et al 2014). Hair-rings are far more common across other parts of Britain and Ireland, with 234 examples known from Ireland, 172 from England and 25 from Scotland (e.g. Becker et al 2020, 119-30 & Table 5.12; Casaly 2021, 194).The sets of semi-quantitative analysis readings of the ring confirm that it is largely composed of gold, with some silver content and the deliberate addition of copper as a minor component. The surface copper composition at 3.2% is consistent with existing compositions derived from Middle Bronze Age gold artefacts from Wales, which are generally in the 2-6% ranges (Gwilt et al 2005, 34-6, Fig. 4; Gwilt & Davis 2020, 357, Fig X.3). However, it is likely that the surface copper levels within this penannular ring have become differentially depleted through time, meaning that a possible Late Bronze Age date cannot be dismissed. Similar Late Bronze Age gold artefacts in Wales have been found to contain a range of 4-10% copper composition (Gwilt et al 2005, 34-6, Fig. 4; Gwilt & Davis 2020, 357, Fig X.3). Further drill sampling and quantitative analysis of the internal composition of the gold would be required to determine an accurate copper content and in turn help date this penannular ring more accurately.
notes: PLEASE NOTE: This gold penannular ring is the subject of an ongoing piece of active research towards a wider publication. description: Middle to Late Bronze Age semi-worked gold fragment (1500-800 BC)1.  Semi-worked gold fragmentDimensions: surviving length 10.3mm; width at break 5.2mm; mid-section width 4.9mm; maximum thickness 2.2mm; surviving weight 1.25g. A small semi-worked gold fragment of sub-rectangular shape, with one sub-rounded and hammered terminal and a snapped break with a fresh edge-surface at the opposite end. The fragment has near straight and flat sides with angular edges to the upper and lower surfaces and looks to have been hammered into its current shape. On the terminal end, a number of small, angular hammer facets are evident. On the upper and lower surfaces, approximately 2-3mm from the break, there is a slight raised ridging across the surfaces and near parallel with the break axis. This also corresponds with a kink or change of angle to both sides of the fragment and in the same parallel alignment, giving it a slightly bent profile in plan view. The fragment has a dull gold patina on hammered surfaces, the break edge also dull gold colour with a granular appearance across the crisp break. This gold fragment retains evidence for hammer flattening and shaping, indicating clearly that this is not a naturally occurring gold nugget and was partially worked and shaped by a gold-worker and subsequently probably deliberately bent and snapped. However, it is not possible to identify this with certainty to a class of finished gold artefact type of known period or date. The hammering and working technique observed on this fragment is consistent with observed Bronze Age working technology, however is not, in itself, diagnostic to a particular date. Semi-quantitative surface XRF analysis of the fragment has indicated an approximate composition of 78-9% gold, 15-16% silver and 5.3% copper. Copper was deliberately added to gold alloys in the Bronze Age, with the general trend for increasing proportions of copper with time, Late Bronze Age artefacts generally containing 4-10% copper and Early Bronze Age gold generally with less than 1% copper content (e.g. Hartmann 1980; Northover 1993, 517, Fig. 2). This copper component of approximately 5.3% is consistent with a Middle or Late Bronze Age signature, when compared with analyses of other Bronze Age gold artefacts from Wales (Gwilt et al 2005, 36 & Fig. 4). Both Middle and Late Bronze Age artefacts have been identified as having copper compositions in an overlapping 4-6% zone. Part-worked or re-worked fragments of Bronze Age gold are sometimes discovered, as single finds or as elements within hoards (e.g. Green 1983; Green & Northover 1996; Gwilt et al 2005; DCMS 2004, 19, Cat. & Fig. 11; DCMS 2007, 22-3, 26, & 39, Cats. & Figs. 5, 7, 17 & 25; British Museum 2008, 22 & 24, 273-5, Cats. & Figs. 27, 33 & 34). Their occurrence as single finds has been increasing in recent years, as better levels of reporting treasure finds have been achieved through the Portable Antiquities Scheme in England and Wales. Therefore, the possibility of this part-worked fragment being a single find of Bronze Age date is also consistent with a wider reported pattern.

description: Early Bronze Age gold corrugated strip fragment (2150-1650 BC)Gold corrugated sheet strip fragmentDimensions: surviving length (as folded) 19.6mm; estimated surviving length (unfolded) approx. 37.0mm; width of strip 13.7-16.4mm; thickness of sheet 0.2mm; weight (prior to conservation) 2.48g.This is a fragment of a straight-sided and slightly tapering sheet strip of gold which has eight, impressed and scribed longitudinal lines, created from the reverse surface, producing a corrugated effect of ridges and troughs on both sides of the strip. The distance between the inscribed troughs varies slightly, though in the 1.5-3mm range. One end of the strip is slightly wider (c. 16.4mm), with the sides converging slightly towards the opposing end (c. 13.7mm). The strip is folded over along both long side-edges, producing slightly thicker edges (approx. 0.5mm thickness), the folded over widths varying along their respective lengths (c. 0.7-2.8mm and c. 0.7-4.8mm). The narrower end of the strip has a straight and uniform edge, suggesting that the strip was cut with a sharp and straight-edged tool. This may have been a deliberate and simple terminal, or a careful cutting of the strip prior to its burial. The break-edge along the widest end appears is irregular with jagged edges, indicating that it has been broken and that part of the original object is now missing. The fragment has been folded into thirds, probably during or since burial in the ground, the strip now having a roughly Z-shaped profile in side-view. There are frequent small tears where the strip has been partially folded, with one larger tear visible across one face and extending across approximately one-third of the strip’s width.Both faces have a yellow-gold patina, but the reverse face, where the folded long edges are visible, appears slightly paler and dulled in appearance. Small quantities of soil are still visible within some of the recesses/creases.Owing to its incompleteness, it is difficult to identify this gold strip to a particular object type with any high degree of certainty. Based on its surviving form and dimensions, it is probable that it once belonged to a broad range of strip or ribbon ornaments of Bronze Age date. Similar strips have been found throughout Britain, including several recent finds from England that have been reported as treasure, with linked Portable Antiquities Scheme records generated (e.g. Bolton 2010; Byard 2018; Downes 2020; Flynn 2020; Gilmore 2016; Needham 2008; Wilkin 2013). In general, these have been loosely dated to the Early or Middle Bronze Ages (ca. 2150-1150 BC) on stylistic and technical grounds. Some of these strips are flat, with parallel linear grooved decoration incised from the front and not showing on the rear surface (e.g. Wilkin 2013). One such example, approximately 8.7cm long and 0.8cm wide, was found from The Hamel, Oxford, associated in a soil context with flint artefacts located near to a Beaker burial containing late Beaker pottery dating to the second half of the Early Bronze Age (ca. 1900-1700 BC) (Palmer 1981, 128-132, Fig. 3.11). The Grosmont sheet strip is both incised and embossed, working from the lower surface to create a true corrugated profile, the rear grooves creating the upper surface ridges. Technologically and stylistically, this may be significant, allying this corrugated strip with either a class of corrugated dagger hilt-bands of Scotland and Ireland or the Embossed gold-working tradition of southern Britain and Ireland. From Scotland and Ireland, corrugated gold hilt bands are a feature of a small number of Early Bronze Age dagger burials, where they serve as pommel mounts (Henshall 1968, 173-195; Needham 2000, 52-54; Becker 2008, 75; Needham & Sheridan 2014, 905 & 914, Fig. 2; Noble & Brophy 2011, 796-799, Fig. 8a). These may be dated to Period 2 of the Early Bronze Age (ca. 2150-1950 BC) (Needham & Sheridan 2014, 905 & 914, Fig. 2). Recently, a possible dagger hilt-band has also been recorded as a treasure case (Treasure 2010 T604) from Shrawley, Worcestershire (Bolton 2010; Needham & Sheridan 2014, 927). This has four embossed ribs, with a surviving length of 2.8cm and a width of 0.95cm. In southern Britain an Embossed gold-working tradition involving the making of armlets, cups and capes was current during later Period 2 and Period 3 of the Early Bronze Age spanning from around 2050-1650 BC (Needham 2000; Needham et al 2006; Needham & Sheridan 2014, 905 & 914-5, Fig. 2). The corrugated handles of corrugated gold cups (dating from ca. 1850-1650 BC), such as the examples from Ringlemere, Kent, Rillaton, Cornwall and Fritzdorf, Nordrhein-Westfalen (Needham et al 2006) have some similar technical and stylistic features as those witnessed on the Grosmont strip (e.g. corrugated and bordered strips). However, these also differ, by virtue of being made of wider sheet strips, having concave shaped sides rather than straight and slightly tapering sides and showing superior working technique and execution. Nevertheless, their presence and dating provide a plausible wider gold-working context and technological tradition within which this corrugated strip could be located. In combination therefore, both the corrugated hilt bands and the Embossed gold-working tradition provide the most plausible, overlapping cultural, technical and stylistic contexts, spanning between 2150-1650 BC, within which this corrugated gold strip probably sits.  Although it is not possible to be certain about the function of this corrugated gold strip from Grosmont community, it closely shares stylistic and technical features with corrugated sheet strips from Askern, Doncaster (Downes, 2020), Chapel and Hill Chorlton, Staffordshire (Gilmore 2016), and Shrawley, Worcestershire (Bolton 2010). These include embossed ridges and grooves, a corrugated profile, folded over margins and similar size ranges. It is possible that they may, in future, be shown to have adorned the hilts or pommels of bronze daggers, as in Scotland and Ireland. However, alternative possible decorative functions may also be revealed in future, when further examples are discovered with more secure contexts and associations.

Copper alloy sheet fragment (associated with socketed axe 7)Dimensions: surviving length (visible from X-ray) approx. 47.7mm; surviving width approx. 9.7mm; surviving thickness 1.6 mm; combined surviving weight (with axe No. 7 and fragments 18 and 19) (before conservation) 240.3g18. Copper alloy sheet fragment – (associated with socketed axe 7)Dimensions: surviving length (visible from X-ray) approx. 31.9mm; surviving width approx. 12.1mm; surviving thickness 0.5mm; combined surviving weight (with axe No. 7 and fragments 17 and 19) (before conservation) 240.3g19. Copper alloy bracelet terminal fragment (associated with socketed axe 7)Dimensions: surviving length (visible from X-ray) – at least 18.8mm; maximum width approx. 9.9mm; surviving thickness 2.8mm; combined surviving weight (with axe No. 7 and fragments 17 and 18) (before conservation) 240.3g20. Casting jet – single runner form – incompleteDimensions: surviving top surface length 33.3mm; max. top surface width 20.3mm; max height 15.3mm; surviving runner dimensions 13.1 by 3.4mm; height 3.0mm; surviving weight (before conservation) 27.1gThe complete spearhead (No. 1 above) may be identified as a Plain Pegged socketed spearhead with a Flame-shaped blade of Group 11, Type 11A (Davis 2015, 44-94). They span the end of the Middle Bronze Age to the Earliest Iron Age (1300-600 BC), but are most common in hoards belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, spanning the tenth and ninth centuries BC (Davis 2015, 94). In Wales, early examples of similar Plain Pegged socketed spearheads are found in the Penard, Guilsfield and Princetown hoards, the first dating to 1300-1150BC and the second and third dating to 1020-920BC (Barnwell 1864; Savory 1965; 1972; 1980, 117-19, Cats. 266, 268 & 272; Figs. 32-8 & 40). There are eighteen other known hoards of Ewart Park date (1000-800 BC) from Wales which include Plain Pegged spearhead associations: the T? Mawr (Anglesey), Llandderfel (Gwynedd), Llantysilio (Denbighshire), Llanharan (Rhondda Cynon Taf), Pant-y-Maen, Manorbier (both Pembrokeshire), Llantwit Major, Cowbridge, Penllyn, (all Vale of Glamorgan), St Ishmael (Carmarthenshire), St Fagans (Cardiff), Llantarnam, Trevethin, (both Torfaen), Llangwm, Glascoed, Llantilio Crossenny, Llanvihangel Gobion, and Grosmont (all Monmouthshire) hoards (Barnwell 1864; Williams 1877; Davies 1929, 368; Griffiths 1957; Burgess et al 1972, 240; Savory 1980, 120-1, Cats. 273 & 281; Gwilt 2004, 132-4, Appendix 1, Nos. 1, 3 & 9; Lynch 1991, 246-9 & Fig. 69; Gwilt & Lodwick 2002; 2012; 2016; Gwilt et al 2011; 2012; 2015a; 2015b; 2016a; 2016b; 2018; Northover unpublished, H4, 53, 74, 85, 108, 121, 141). The wooden hafts of a number of Plain Pegged spearheads in England have also been radiocarbon dated to the Ewart Park period of the Late Bronze Age dating to between 1000 BC and 800 BC (Needham 1996, 136-7 & Fig. 3; Needham et al 1997, 93-8).The lower blade fragment of a spearhead (No. 2 above) is difficult to identify owing to its fragmentary and deformed nature. Although it has been distorted through repeated hammering, the lack of a midrib precludes many recognised types. The observation that this fragment has a bevelled edge also discounts the possibility that this fragment belongs to a spearhead with a Barbed Blade of Group 15 (Davis 2015, 181). It is more likely that this fragment belongs to a spearhead with a Hollow Blade of Davis’ Group 12 (Davis 2015, 152-162, Nos. 1077-1148, Pls. 98-104) the wide internal hollow aperture providing good evidence to support this assertion. Group 12 spearheads have been found in several hoards spanning the Late Bronze Age, but they largely correlate with the Wilburton and Blackmoor phases of the Late Bronze Age, spanning the late twelfth to late tenth centuries BC (Davis 2015, 162). In Wales, the Guilsfield, Powys, hoard is the only example where Group 12 spearheads are found associated with other artefacts, and this dates to the Blackmoor phase (1020-920 BC) (Savory 1965; 1972; 1980, 117-19, Cats. 266, 268 & 272; Figs. 32-8 & 40). Outside of Wales, Group 12 spearheads are also primarily found in Wilburton and Blackmoor phase hoards from Wilburton, Isleham and Bradley Fen (all Cambridgeshire). Radiocarbon dating has been carried out on two spearheads from the Wilburton and Bradley Fen hoards, providing a date of 1260-940 BC and 1190-930 BC, respectively (Davis 2015, 162). A fragment of a Group 12 spearhead was also found in the Gorleston-on-Sea, Norfolk, hoard which dates to the Ewart Park phase (920-800 BC), and so it is possible that usage of these spearheads might have continued at a low level throughout the latter stages of the Late Bronze Age (Davis 2015, 162). It is also possible that this spearhead fragment represents an old object that continued to circulate as an object, or perhaps as a piece of scrap metal, until the Ewart Park phase. Two of the artefact fragments (Nos. 3 & 4) from within this reported hoard can be identified as tubular spear-ferrules. Based on their different patinated surfaces and the lack of a join between them, the two fragments appear to belong to two separate artefacts, as opposed to deriving from the same object. Ferrules of a long and tubular form have been described as dating to the Wilburton and Blackmoor phase of the Late Bronze Age (1150-920), whereas those of a shorter form are more characteristic of the Ewart Park phase (1000-800 BC) (Burgess et al 1972, 216; Needham 1990, 58). The highly fragmented and distorted nature of the two artefacts means that they lack any further diagnostic features which might allow further identification (Burgess et al 1972, 216), although the evidence for two opposing rivet holes on one (No. 4, above) is a typical feature of ferrules. Spear-ferrules are relatively rare finds from Wales, but they have been found associated within weapon dominated hoards belonging to the Broadward metalworking tradition spanning the Late Bronze Age. As well as the slightly earlier Guilsfield, Powys, which dates to the Blackmoor phase (1020-920 BC), spear ferrules also appear in the Pant-y-Maen, Pembrokeshire weapon hoard, which is dated to the Ewart Park phase (1000-800 BC) and contemporary with the Llanddeusant hoard (Griffiths 1957; Savory 1965; 1972; 1980, 117-19, Cats. 266, 268 & 272; Figs. 32-8 & 40; Burgess et al1972, 240).Six of the socketed axes in this reported group (Nos. 5 -10, above) may be identified as South Wales Type socketed axes or Variant forms. The combination of narrow and out-splayed mouths, high placed and ephemeral loops, blocky rectangular or hexagonal form, three ribs descending from the underside of the collars, and evidence for being cast with four-runner technology are all diagnostic elements which, in combination, help to identify this type (e.g. Needham 1981, 31; Northover unpublished, 259-60; Burgess 2012, 239 & Fig. 1). South Wales Type socketed axes and their Variant forms are a frequent and dominating element within Ewart Park hoards of Late Bronze Age date across south-east Wales (e.g., McNeil 1973, Fig. 9; Moore 1978; Savory 1980, 49, 120-2; Needham 1981; Gwilt 2004). Here, around fifty hoards now contain approaching 250 examples, making it the core area within Britain for their burial within hoards. Over fifty single finds of South Wales Type socketed axes have also been discovered in south-east Wales. They are also frequent smaller presences in contemporary hoards across mid and north-east Wales, south-western England, southern England, and northern France, with occasional outliers in northern Britain and Ireland (McNeil 1973, 61-4; Moore 1978; Needham 1981, 55-66; Burgess 2012, 241-4 & Fig. 2).The Breiddin Type socketed axe (No. 11, above), with its swollen mouth and ribs descending from a lower horizontal moulding, broadly equates with Southern English Ribbed axes and Type Welby axes in northern Britain (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 221-3; Needham 1990, 32-9). They are uncommon elements of hoards in south-east Wales, although single examples have been found in recently discovered hoards from Cowbridge, Colwinston and Llancarfan (all Vale of Glamorgan) (Gwilt & Lodwick 2002; 2014; Gwilt et al. 2013). They take their name from an example discovered during excavations at The Breiddin hillfort in Powys (Coombs 1990, 133 & 6, Fig. 56). Wood surviving in the socket of this axe was radiocarbon dated, providing a date of 2704+-50bp, calibrating to 908-814 BC at 1 sigma (Musson 1990, 176 & 195, Table 6). Breiddin Type axes are most common in north and east Wales and The Marches (Coombs 1990, 133; Northover unpublished, 253) with examples found within hoards from Plas yn Cefn and Ruabon, Denbighshire, Cherrytree Bank, Powys and Congleton, Cheshire (Davies 1929, 68 & 397; Burgess et al 1972, 236 & 267, Fig. 26; Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust 1977; Savory 1980, 123, Cat. 286 & Fig. 44; Northover unpublished, hoards 41, 48, 55 & 139).One complete socketed axe (No. 12, above) may be identified as of Croxton Type, also known as a particular form of Class B - Southern English ribbed axes (Northover unpublished, 267; Needham 1990, 32-8). The Croxton type, with its diagnostic flaring trumpet mouth, deep collar band and ribs is so named after a defining example found in Cheshire, within a wider frequency observed along the Welsh Marches (Northover unpublished, 267). It is one form within a wider variety of Class B ribbed axes, found in hoards and as single finds across southern Britain. They are almost always found within hoards dating to the Ewart Park phase (1000-800 BC) of the Late Bronze Age (Needham 1996; Needham et al 1997). Croxton Type socketed axes have been found in increasing numbers of hoards across south-east Wales in recent years, with examples in the Pendoylan, Llantwit Major, Wick Community, Tal-y-garn 1, Colwinston Community, and Llancarfan Community (all Vale of Glamorgan) hoards, as well as an additional example from the St Arvans (Monmouthshire) hoard (Storrie 1887; Fox 1926; GGAT 1977-8; Metcalf & Lambert 1979; Savory 1980, Cats. 280 & 281; 1984, 441b; Northover unpublished, H79 & H124; Gwilt 2004, Appendix 1, Cat. 10; Gwilt & Lodwick 2003; 2005; 2014; Lodwick & Gwilt 2007; Gwilt et al 2013).The slender and faceted bronze socketed axe (No. 13, above) may be identified as of Type Meldreth or Class D faceted axe, which have a variety of sub-types, dependent upon the shape and depth of their collar and mouth shape (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 204-11; Needham 1990, 41-3). The axe from this reported group may be identified as a Variant Aylsham based on the presence of a horizontal moulding at the base of a trumpet-shaped mouth, in place of the collar step of the Type Meldreth itself (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 206-7). Nearly all of the known hoard associations containing Type Meldreth or Class D axes are securely Late Bronze Age in date (1150-800 BC). A few examples have been found in earlier hoards belonging to the Wilburton phase of the Late Bronze Age dating to 1150-1000 BC, however most hoard associations may be dated to the succeeding Ewart Park phase dating to 1000-800 BC (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 210-1; Needham 1990, 43; Eogan 2000, 61). This type is generally regarded as a British type, but they do occur in Ireland and France. In Wales, near 40 examples of slender faceted axes of Meldreth or Class D type are now known, mostly from south-east Wales. Examples of these axes have been found in recently reported hoards from Llanfrynach Community (Powys), Grosmont Community (Monmouthshire), Llanharan Community (Rhondda Cynon Taf), and Llanfihangel Cwmdu with Bwlch & Cathedine Community (Powys), all belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (Gwilt et al 2016c; 2018a; 2018b; Knight et al 2018).The complete, small, plain, and waisted socketed axe (No. 14, above) is difficult to identify to a widespread type. The combination of a plain decoration, a simple and flared mouth with a bevelled rim, concave sides, and the positioning of the loop below the rim, are all features consistent with Class 11A axes/Type Portree, Variant Alford axes (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 188-9, Cats. 1075-93; Eogan 2000, 86-122, Cats. 640-1113C). Whilst the Llanddeusant example does share many of the Class 11A characteristics, it lacks the typical wide and baggy form of these axes. There are however some examples of more slender and waisted Irish axes of this type, and the length and blade width of this example are consistent with the range of dimensions of other Class 11A (Eogan 2000, 87-122, c.f., Nos. 712, 713). All axes of Class 11/Type Portree, Variant Alford can be assigned to the Ewart Park (Dowris) phase of the Late Bronze Age (1000-800 BC). Close parallels for this axe are difficult to find from Wales, but a plain socketed axe of similar form was found within a hoard from Llantwit Major, Vale of Glamorgan, which is dated to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (Savory 1980, 121, No. 281, Fig. 42). The small, plain, and slender socketed axe with a flared and onset collar (No. 15 above) is also difficult to identify to a widespread type, where the absence of a lower mouth moulding indicates that it is not of Class A – South-eastern type (e.g., Needham 1990, 28-31). Although it shares some similarities with Class 2A and Type Wallington socketed axes, it lacks the straight collar form of these axes. Close parallels for this axe are difficult to find from Wales, but a plain socketed axe of similar form was found in a hoard from Pendoylan (Vale of Glamorgan) along with one other plain socketed axe and four ribbed socketed axes of South Wales Type (GGAT 1977-8, 31-2; Green 1985, 276-80 Fig. 5 & Pl. 5; Northover unpublished, 209-210, Hoard Cat. H79 & 641). This hoard is dated to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (1000-800 BC). Plain slender socketed axes of slightly different forms are now known from numerous Late Bronze Age hoards in Wales, including the Freshwater West (Pembrokeshire), Margam (Neath Port Talbot) and Myddfai (Carmarthenshire) hoards (Briggs & Williams 1995, 46 & Fig 4.1; Northover unpublished H. 38, 76, & 140; Wear unpublished). The socketed axe blade fragment (No. 16, above) belonged to a ribbed socketed axe, however this blade end fragment is not diagnostic to precise type. Various forms of ribbed axes are common components of hoards from south-east Wales and belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (1000-800 BC). As discussed above, ribbed axes of South Wales Type and their Variant forms are a frequent and dominating element within Ewart Park hoards of Late Bronze Age date across south-east Wales (e.g., McNeil 1973, Fig. 9; Moore 1978; Savory 1980, 49, 120-2; Needham 1981; Gwilt 2004). In addition, ribbed socketed axes, variously known as Southern English/Welby Type ribbed axes, Yorkshire Type axes, Croxton Type axes, Breiddin Type axes and Llanarth Type axes have been found beside South Wales type axes in several hoards of Ewart Park date from south-east Wales (e.g., Storrie 1887; Metcalf & Lambert 1979; Savory 1980, 120-1, Cats. 273, 280, 281; Gwilt 2004, 132-4, Appendix 1.1, 1.3, 1.10; Gwilt & Lodwick 2002; 2004; 2006; Gwilt et al. 2013; Lodwick & Gwilt 2007; Northover unpublished, Hoards 74, 79, 85, 124). Therefore, the presence of this blade-end fragment is entirely consistent with a Late Bronze Age hoard association from this region.Two of the fragments (Nos. 17 & 18 above) which are enclosed within the socket of a South Wales Type axe are problematic to identify to a known class of finished artefact of Bronze Age date. One of the fragments (No. 17) has a more curvilinear form and a ‘c’-shaped section, and so it could possibly have once formed part of the rim of a vessel or perhaps a hollow sectioned bracelet. The second fragment (No. 18) is flatter and has a less pronounced convex exterior, but it could have once belonged to a bronze vessel or belonged to a larger artefact of sheet bronze construction. Ingot, plate and sheet scrap fragments become recognised raw material components of hoards during the Late Bronze Age, particularly in hoards of the Carp’s Tongue tradition which often contain an eclectic admixture of decorative pieces, ornamentation, and various pieces of sheet metalworking, and occasionally bronze vessel fragments; this often-fragmented admixture of material is sometimes referred to as bric-a-brac (Burgess 1968, 39). In Britain, the Carp’s Tongue complex appears to be an intrusive or specialised metalworking industry which had its centre in northern and western France, appearing alongside the indigenous Ewart Park metalworking tradition (Burgess 1968, 38-9). Although it is impossible to assign the bronze sheet fragments to any known finished object with any degree of certainty, their presence within this hoard is entirely consistent with an Ewart Park date (1000-800 BC).One fragment (No. 19 above) is different from the other enclosed artefacts (Nos. 17 & 18) as it is noticeably thicker, has a c-shaped section, and possesses an everted terminal. It is likely that this fragment was once part of a ‘C’ sectioned bracelet, and within Davies’ (2012) reassessment of Late Bronze Age ornaments it can be considered a Type 4E (Outwardly Expanded Solid Terminal with ‘C’ shaped section). Only a few examples of this type of bracelet exist from Britain, with bronze examples found in Carp’s Tongue hoards from Petters Sports Field, Surrey (Needham 1990, 62), Leigh II, Kent (Turner 1998, vol II, 137, fig. 55), Minnis Bay, Kent (Turner 1998, vol III, 105, fig. 49, no. 19/52), and a gold example from Bexley, Kent (Hook & Needham 1989, 16, No. 5). Although they possess similar morphological traits, the four bronze bracelets are quite varied in terms of the presence of decoration, type of decoration, the thickness of the bar, and the degree to which the edges enclose the internal gap. The bracelet fragment from the Leigh II (Kent) hoard is the closest in form to the example from this reported group, but it is decorated with lateral ribs around the surviving terminal (Turner 1998, vol II, 137, fig. 56). Although the Llanddeusant fragment is plain, the majority of it is hidden within the socket of the axe and so there is the possibility that decorative elements might be found on those sections of the object which are obscured within the socket of the axe. In terms of overall style, the undecorated Llanddeusant bracelet is closer paralleled with the C-sectioned bracelets found in Carp’s Tongue hoards from western France (Coffyn, Gomez and Mohen 1981, 134-9, Pl. 30-32), suggesting that the object was made in France and evidence for inter-regional exchange between west Wales and western France. C-sectioned bronze bracelets are not considered a diagnostic element of the Carp’s Tongue complex (Burgess 1968, 38-9; Matthews 2013, 57-9; Brandherm & Moskal-del-Hoyo 2014, footnote 60), but their presence and association as components within these hoards suggests a date within the ninth century BC and contemporary with the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (1000-800 BC).The jet of one-runner form (No. 20, above) is the excess reservoir of metal at the top of a mould and a bi-product of the casting process. Jets are commonly incorporated into hoards during the Late Bronze Age yet are rarely present within hoards of Early and Middle Bronze Age date. There are numerous Ewart Park hoards from south and west Wales which have jets as components within them, where examples with between one and four runners are known (e.g., Storrie 1887; Savory 1980, 120-2, Cats. 274, 281 & 284, Figs. 31, 42 & 43; Gwilt 2004, 132-4, Appendix 1, Nos. 3 & 4; Gwilt & Lodwick 2018; Northover unpublished, H 23, 74, 78, 125).In combination, all of the artefacts included in this hoard can be confidently dated to the Late Bronze Age (1150-800 BC) (Needham 1996, Needham et al 1997). The majority of the artefacts retain chronologically diagnostic features, and the overall composition and character of the hoard indicates that it was deposited during the Ewart Park phase (1000-800 BC). The Group 12 spearhead is slightly earlier in manufacture and largely belongs to the Wilburton and Blackmoor phases of the Late Bronze Age (1150-920 BC), but later examples have been found in hoards of Ewart Park date and so its presence does not present a dating problem.
