description: TREASURE CASE : 2000 – BM Ref: PRB 67DescriptionA thick penannular ring of circular section, lightly tapered towards the terminals. The surface shows banding in alternate stripes of darker and lighter golden colours.Maximum diameter 18mm; weight 14.99.CompositionMeasurement of specific gravity indicates that the object is gold throughout. X-ray fluorescence analysis of the differently-coloured stripes gave a result of approximately 78% gold content for the yellower stripes and 47% for the whiter stripes.IdentificationThe object is a well-known Late Bronze Age type, dating to circa 1150-750 BC.Author: G. L. VarndellDate: 5.10.00
notes: Note 2024-07-31This object was found not to be treasure at inquest because it was interpreted as a coin. Single, stray finds of coins are not counted as treasure, whereas any ornament of precious metal at least 300 years old is eligible under the Treasure Act 1996.As explained in Gillian Varndell’s paper ‘Ringing the changes: when terminology matters’ in Antiquity 75 (2001: 515-16) the term ‘ring-money’ or ‘tress-ring’ has often been applied to these objects by archaeologists. Others have used the terms literally, believing these objects to be either an early form of currency or hair ornaments, though there is evidence for neither. The Code of Practice of the 1996 Treasure Act is quite clear on the definition of 'coin'. This includes 'any metal token that was, or can reasonably be assumed to have been, used or intended for use as or instead of money'. However, this only includes coins and tokens 'made after the introduction of the first coinage into this country during the lron Age period and excludes objects made earlier such as iron currency bars' (Section 3 [2] of the Act and p.4 of the Code of Practice). Bronze Age gold penannular rings should therefore be regarded as an ornament and several subsequent examples have been treated as such see: 2023 T312 (YORYM-2A8B0B), 2023 T1080 (WMID-A28DF7), 2023 T783 (SUR-8A035F), 2023 T177 (CAM-23BCAB), 2011 T499 (LANCUM-80A136), and 2005 T201 (IOW-240A63).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being declared not Treasure

description: A complete Early Bronze Age copper alloy flanged axehead, probably dating to  c. 2200 - 1800  BC. It is relatively narrow, including at the blade, complete except for some surface deterioration and a very small chip off the butt end. There are longitudinal flanges possibly raised by hammering rather than moulded.The flanged length, creating a curved profile, takes up most of the length of the axehead, leading to a straight butt end. There is no transverse stop ridge. There is no indication of particular sharpening of the cutting edge but the axehead is quite pitted.Dimensions: 106.9mm overall length;  39.2mm in width (blade); 18.8mm thick; weight: 205.00g.See NARC-EB50E6 the record for which states,: "(It) dates to the Early Bronze Age and fits within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae (Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp121-140)"
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A complete gold-plated penannular ring dating to the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c. 1300-800 BC). The ring is circular in both plan and cross-section, with flat, slightly slanted terminals. The gold plating is flaking at the terminals. There is also a small flake of gold plating missing from the external surface of the ring, exposing a green copper-alloy core. There is a small circumferential crack on one side of the ring and a transverse crack on the outer surface, located opposite the gap between the terminals. The gap is approximately 1.95 mm. There is no sign of banding in differential shades of gold, this being a common form of decoration on similar rings.Dimensions: diameter 16.37 mm, width 4.81 mm, thickness 4.31 mm. Weight: 4.41 g.Discussion: These types of gold or gold-on-base-metal rings and penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC). They have been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008), but their function remains uncertain. It is perhaps most likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.Relatively few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation, or radiocarbon dating. However, burials in Belgium, north-east France, and The Netherlands, in addition to Scottish and Irish hoard associations, have suggested a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 BC (Eogan 1997). However, in recent years, evidence for earlier development and a longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing (Raftery 2004, 87-8; Needham 2007, 26-33, Figs 17.3-4). Therefore, on comparative stylistic grounds, this penannular ring may be dated to the Middle or Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC). Similar undecorated penannular rings on the PAS database include SUR-C145ED, BM-275770, HAMP-2419C2 and LANCUM-C2543F.Scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). This particular example comes under their ‘Type 2a Gold Plated on copper alloy core’.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: The Leicestershire torc is a four-flange twisted bar torc dating to the Middle Bronze Age, associated with the Penard phase dating to c. 1300-1100 BC (Taylor 1980, 62; Needham 2001; Roberts 2007). It consists of five distinct components: two decorated terminals affixed at either end of three spiral-twisted bars (47cm in length, excluding the terminals) with a regular cruciform (i.e. ‘+’ shaped) cross section. The torc from Leicestershire has such deep flanges that they are almost cut away from the central cruciform. Taylor (1980, 61-2) discusses the advantages of casting an elaborate torc in multiple pieces. The terminals are unique in appearance, with few comparable examples. While such torcs typically feature ‘trumpet’-shaped terminals, this example instead has sheet gold ferrules adorned with three decorative bands. These bands, incised with lines to give the impression of twisting, are evenly spaced and soldered onto the torc afterward. Additionally, strand 1 is broken, with the damaged ends appearing crushed.The construction of this torc is unusual in comparison with other contemporary examples, with the closest parallel being the Moulsford torc from Berkshire (Hawkes, 1961). Typically, torcs from this period feature a single flange-twisted bar with ‘trumpet’-shaped terminals and range in length from 40cm to 126cm. Examples of multi-stranded flange-twisted torcs are rare and include the torc from the Towednack Hoard, Cornwall (Eogan, 1967), the Monkton Deverill torc, Wiltshire (unpublished, Salisbury Museum collection), and the Moulsford torc (Hawkes, 1961). However, of these, the Moulsford torc is the only example that incorporates multiple strands set into sheet gold ferrules, making it similar to the torc under discussion.One of the strands is broken, and its ends appear to have been deliberately hammered to compress the flanges. This is reminiscent of the torc fragments discovered at Woodham Walter, Essex (Meeks and Varndell, 1994). However, while the Woodham Walter fragments were significantly flattened, the example under discussion seems to have been crushed specifically to remove the flange twisting.The torc measures approximately 47cm in length and weights 243g, making it relatively light compared to other examples, such as the Ely torc, which weights 732g. There is an approximate gap of c. 4 mm between the flanges and the flanges themselves have a length of c. 3mm. The spiral of the bar has been created by twisting it in both clockwise and anti-clockwise directions: two strands are twisted clockwise, while one is twisted anti-clockwise. However, it is possible that the torc was originally made by twisting a single long bar in a clockwise direction (approximately 141cm in length), which was later cut into three segments. One segment may have then been reorientated to create the appearance of anti-clockwise twisting. The segments were then capped at the ends, forming a smaller torc. The edges of the flanges are blunt, with no lipping or burring present.  Further research is needed to fully understand the precise construction details of this torc and to gain broader insights into flange-twisted gold torcs in general. The terminals of the torc are gold sheet ferrules, stylistically similar to those of the Moulsford torc but assembled in a different manner. This example features three gold wire ornaments encircling each ferrule at evenly spaced intervals. The gold wire is incised to mimic twisted appearance, while the end of the ferrule bears a rough incised cross which has been ‘filled in’. The decoration on the terminals shows greater similarity to torc examples found in France and one example in Ireland than those found in England. For instance, the incised terminals resemble the Torque de Saint-Jean-Trolimon, a torc fragment found in the Seine and also a torc from Co.Mayo (Armbruster, 2021; 153). However, while the end of the ferrule is stylistically similar to that of the Moulsford torc, the Moulsford example is executed with greater finesse and assembled in a different way. The ferrule is constructed in multiple stages, incorporating the cuff, cap, and three pieces of wire, all soldered together. This torc has been coiled around once to form a compact bundle. The method of coiling is consistent with examples such as the torcs from Grunty Fen, Cambridgeshire; the Ropley torc in Hampshire; and the Yeovil torc (Taylor, 1980).Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis was undertaken on the torc by the Science department of the British Museum. It indicated a surface composition of approximately 85-87% gold and 10-12% silver, the rest being copper. This composition is consistent along the length of the bar but varies slightly at the terminals with a surface composition of 83-85% gold and 12-14% silver. Unassociated findsIn addition to the torc, two pieces of undiagnostic copper alloy were discovered. The pieces are complete and intact suggesting that they represent casting waste. While it is possible that they are Bronze Age, they were not found at the same location as the torc, they were recovered from within the same field, based on the coordinates provided by the finder. They therefore do not form part of this Treasure case but have been included in this report for the sake of completeness. Dimensions:Torc body:Circumference: 47cms (excluding the terminals)Diameter of coiled torc: c. 90-91mm Width of ‘arms’ of cruciform cross-section: c.6mmSpacing between flanges: c. 4mmApproximate length of flanges from centre of torc: c.3mmTerminals:Diameter of Terminal A: c. 6mmDiameter of Terminal B: c.6-6.5mmLength of Terminal A: c. 17mmLength of Terminal B: c.17mmTotal weight: 243gDimensions of the unassociated copper alloy waste:Piece one: 55mmx 55mmx 33mmPiece two: 35mmx 10mmx 8mmTotal weight of both pieces: 108g
notes: DiscussionThe Leicestershire torc has several close comparanda among the four-flange twisted type variety found in Britain and Ireland. However, no Middle Bronze Age torcs are known from Leicestershire itself. The closest example of a multi-stranded torc is the Moulsford torc from Berkshire, however Moulsford was bar-twisted rather than flange-twisted and includes four rather than three strands. Other multi-strand torcs, such as the Towednack torc and the Monkton Deverill torc, terminate in trumpet-shaped terminals rather than the ferrule-like terminals seen on this example. This raises questions about the construction of this torc and similar examples. Why does this example shows three strands (and similarly the Moulsford torc with four)? Were the strands fashioned from a single long flanged bar that was cut into segments, or were they made separated and then combined? These considerations open further avenues for discussion and research into the manufacturing techniques of multi-strand torcs. Taylor discusses the advantages of torcs with separately formed terminals, although this was with a focus on trumpet-shaped terminals. While ferrule terminals, like those present on this torc, are less common, they provide similar benefits. Specifically, they contribute to the overall neat appearance through having uniform twists that extend the whole length of the torc before being capped. An interesting aspect of the Leicestershire torc is the break in one of the strands. If the torc had been broken and discarded, it would typically be assumed that the break would have been left as is. However, the broken ends were re-worked to flatten the flanges, suggesting an attempt to repair the break- or at least to prepare for repair without completing it. This is reminiscent of a spiral-twisted torc found in the Wylie hoard in Wiltshire (Treasure case 2012 T786), which features a section that is globular in form, untwisted, and undecorated, possibly indicating a repair.The functionality of coiled torcs has been debated, with suggestions that they were too narrow to be worn on the arm or leg. It has been proposed that the coiling instead served as a means of decommissioning the torcs prior to deposition (Ramsey 2012). However, the coiling effect of the multi-stranded torc enhances the impression that it may have been reworked from an earlier object. ConclusionThe torc is made of more than 10% precious metal (in this case gold) and therefore qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act (1996). The two pieces of copper alloy (possibly casting waste) are not diagnostic and therefore do not qualify as Treasure under the Act (1996) or Designation Order (2002). Author:Petra Jones, Project Curator, The British Museum BibliographyArmbruster, B. 2021. Les Ors De L’Europe Atlantique À L’Âge Du Bronze. Technologie et ateliers. subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: Gold ribbon torcThe object is formed of rectangular section gold wire which has been twisted along its length at approximately 15-18mm intervals. The ends of the strip are narrowed and have a hexagonal section, before broadening slightly to forming two interlocking hooks. The oval terminals have a cuboid pattern with faces having been cut into the ends, or perhaps a this is a relic of the hexagonal wire section. There is a collar formed under the terminals and a line cut into them giving the appearance of a mouth, although this is probably coincidental. The wire is 4.5-5mm in length and 0.5-0.75mm in thickness. It is approximately 360mm long and would therefore fit around a small neck, or a wider upper arm.Dimensions: In its folded state it is 109mm wide and 83mm long, and approximately 45mm deep. It weighs 15.5g Discussion:  Similar ribbon torcs are pictured by Taylor (1980: fig 42, 44), Eogan (1994: fig 23B, 25). Similar examples were also found in the Priddy hoard (2005T523, SOM-1C2C53). The British Museum also holds several similar examples (Accession numbers 1873,0602.1, 1838,0718.1 and 1857,0729.1).  Taylor (1980, Plate 42, 64) notes that these torcs are of 'Welsh type', although related to one found in Swineford, Co. Mayo, and seem to originate as a local development in the mid Bronze Age, remaining in vogue until the late part of the period. The British Museum entry for 1873,0601.1 states 'There is a considerable debate regarding the dating of Ribbon Torcs either to the Middle Bronze Age or Iron Age on the basis of compositional analyses, terminal forms and limited contextual evidence as from Somerset, Co. Galway and Dooyork, Co Mayo, Ireland and the Blair Drummond hoard, Stirling, Scotland. The emerging typological consensus places loosely coiled torcs with simple hook terminals from Ireland in the Middle Bronze Age whilst tightly coiled torcs with knobbed terminals in Britain and Ireland are placed in the Iron Age (Fraser Hunter, Mary Cahill, Jody Joy and Trevor Cowie pers. comm. 9/12/11)'. This example fits best the loosely coiled class and could therefore be dated to the Middle Bronze Age.Conclusion: The age and precious metal content of this object meets the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Two solid gold pennannular neck-rings.Both neck-rings consist of a thick penannular hoop with the larger having a crescentic section and the smaller a slightly concave ‘D’ section. The hoops terminate in a gentle trumpet shape with a circular flat end. Both lack decoration. The larger neck-ring shows signs of hammer markings on the inside, and flaws on the outside may indicate post-casting work to cover up casting defects. The smaller is slightly distorted, and shows some very minor signs of presumed plough damage. The two ornaments fit into a Late Bronze Age tradition of solid bar neck-rings, 1150–800 BC. It is possible that they are in an unfinished state.Date: Late Bronze Age - 1150–800 BCDimensions: Large neck-ring: maximum diameter: 192 mm; maximum width: 26 mm; weight 716.34g. Smaller neck-ring: maximum diameter: 172 mm; maximum width: 14 mm; weight: 399.91g.Note: Large neck-ring: 86 per cent for gold; smaller neck-ring: 80 per cent for gold.Disposition: Dorset County MuseumReport by A West and S P Needham, 1999
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of Early Bronze Age dating (c. 2350 BC to c. 2050 BC).The flat axe is broadly sub rectangular in shape with a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with slight tapering edges. The butt is relatively thin having a narrow rounded profile; the width at the butt is 29.9 mm (thickness: 3.3 mm). The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the butt to the blade; in shape they are relatively curved. The axe is thickest at the mid point (12.3 mm). The sides of the blade expand to produce a crescentic blade edge with a width of 61.4 mm. The axe is a mid to dark green colour, with an uneven surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the plough soil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface detail.It measures 113.5 mm in length, maximum width at the blade is 61.4 mm, width at the butt is 29.9mm and it has a maximum thickness of 12.3 mm. It weighs 304 grams.The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to (although not containing all the attributes of Migdale axes (many of these tend to have narrower butts which flare at the cutting edge).These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Reference:Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp121-140Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.46-47.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Found on the 15th of March 2020 while metal detecting during a rally on an arable field at a depth of c. 1-2 inches.A complete but bent Late Bronze Age gold bracelet dating to c. 950-750 BC. It consists of a rectangular gold plate with expanded terminals, which would have been bent into a circular form to wrap around a wrist but is now distorted into an irregular wavy form.The plate is widest at its midpoint where it is c.10.5mm wide and 1.1mm thick. It is mostly straight-sided for its middle third but narrows along its remaining length, becoming as narrow as 4.2mm just before its terminals. Here it begins to expand in width and thickness, becoming oval in cross-section, to form two flared flat-ended terminals. One is 9.5mm long and 8.5mm wide; the other is more circular, being 9.0mm long and 8.7mm wide. The bracelet's long edges are slightly expanded, giving each the feel of a subtle lip or flange running along their length. It is otherwise undecorated.The bracelet retains its gold lustre, but has several scratches across its surfaces and occasional soil concreted to its surface.Dimensions: Using a string, it is possible to estimate the unbent length of the bracelet as c. 155mm. In its current state however it is 78.5mm long, and weighs 25.37g.Discussion: The bracelet has several parallels on the database. For example there are a number of fragments which contain a rectangular body which narrows and then expands to a flared terminal such as NMGW-E48854, DOR-86B8B9 (2020T480) and CORN-705C14 (2020T222) the latter being found in a hoard of goldwork.Further similar examples are also illustrated by Eogan (1994) from Caister on Sea Norfolk (Eogan 1994: pl 13, no. 1) and Berwickshire (Eogan 1994: pl 15, no. 6) while another is held by the British Museum (Accession number: WG.7 ) all of which are also suggested to date to the Late Bronze Age. This is supported by a bracelet with an expanded terminal being found with a Late Bronze Age socketed axehead at Llanarmon-yn-Iâl in Denbighshire (Green 1983). These are sometimes termed Potterne type bracelets following the publication of a similar bracelet from this site (Taylor 1984).The form also corresponds to Hook and Needham's (1989) Class B1 bracelet (which may or may not have the flanges). Hook and Needham list 21 examples of Class B1 and related bracelets from Britain and Europe, with a clear concentration of the type in southern England and with a band stretching across north Wales and Cheshire.Conclusion: The bracelet appears to consist of more than 10% precious metal and at the time of finding was more than 300 years old, it thus qualifies as Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.Authors: Dr Edward Caswell, Finds Liaison Officer, OxfordshireReferencesEogan, G. (1994) The accomplished art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC). Oxford, Oxbow.Green, H. S. (1983).'A late Bronze Age hoard from Llanarmon-yn-Ial, Clwyd', Antiquaries Journal, 63, 384-7.Hook, D.R. and Needham, S.P. (1989) A comparison of recent analyses of British Late Bronze Age goldwork with Irish parallels. Jewellery studies. 315–24.Taylor, J. (1984) The Potterne gold bracelet and its affinities. Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Magazine, 78, 35–40. Available from https://archive.org/details/wiltshirearchaeo7819wilt/page/40/mode/2up?view=theater last accessed 13th February 2023
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to landowner after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of Early Bronze Age dating (c. 2350 BC to c. 2050 BC).The flat axe is broadly sub rectangular in shape with a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with slight tapering edges. The butt is relatively thin having a narrow rounded profile; the width at the butt is 15.9 mm (thickness: 1.6 mm). The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the butt to the blade; in shape they are relatively curved. The axe is thickest at the mid point (7.8 mm), with traces of a proto stop ridge present. The sides of the blade expand to produce a crescentic blade edge with an abraded width of 38.4 mm. The tips of the crescent shaped blade have been damaged through either abrasion or wear, as has the blade edge itself.The axe is a mid to dark green colour, with an uneven surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the ploughsoil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface detail.It measures 77.9 mm in length, maximum width at the blade is 38.4 mm, width at the butt is 15.9 mm and it has a maximum thickness of 7.8 mm. It weighs 79.8 grams.The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to (although not containing all the attributes of Migdale axes (many of these tend to have narrower butts which flare at the cutting edge).These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Reference:Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp121-140Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.46-47.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Gold ingot fragment of Bronze Age date, c.1600-800BC.The ingot is roughly cylindrical in shaped fragment, both ends are set at a slight angle where there have been cut and display straight edges until the final fifth with is rough and uneven. The surface of the cylinder is faceted with multiple ridges that run lengthways around the circumference of the piece suggesting that the cylindrical shape was formed by hammering rather than being drawn.Several similar fragments of goldwork have been recovered from hoards containing diagnostically Bronze Age objects such as the Poulton, Gloucestershire: Treasure case 2004 T17 which is held in the Corinium Museum https://coriniummuseum.org/2016/08/early-gold/Plus, the Fitzleroi Farm, West Sussex, hoard: BM accession nos. 1996, 0902.1-42See also IOW-50D55F (2018 T5), KENT-731554 (2024 T217) for similar parallels that have been recorded as treasure.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: A fragment of gold strip with a flared terminal probably from a Late Bronze Age bracelet c.950-800 cal BC. The strip is rectangular in cross section. At one end is a flared, flat-ended, terminal with a sub-circular cross-section. The strip is flattened from the terminal and expands in width to a cut end.Dimensions: The strip is  16.34 mm long, x 9.33 mm wide, x 2.98 mm thick and weighs 2.7 grams. The terminal is x 5.76 mm long and 4.53 mm wide.Discussion: On the PAS database the fragment is very similar to SWYOR-DDC942 (2023 T790) which is dated to the Middle Bronze age to the Late Bronze Age, c.1150 -750 BC. There are other parallels including DOR-86B8B9 (2020T480) and LEIC-1F1276 (2014 T303) both dated to the late Bronze Age c. 950 – 750 BC.Further similar examples are also illustrated by Eogan (1994) from Caister on Sea Norfolk (Eogan 1994: pl 13, no. 1) and Berwickshire (Eogan 1994: pl 15, no. 6) all of which are also suggested to date to the Late Bronze Age. This is supported by a bracelet with an expanded terminal being found with a Late Bronze Age socketed axehead at Llanarmon-yn-Iâl in Denbighshire (Green 1983). These are sometimes termed Potterne type bracelets following the publication of a similar bracelet from this site (Taylor 1984)ReferencesEogan, G. (1994) The accomplished art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC). Oxford, Oxbow.Green, H. S. (1983).'A late Bronze Age hoard from Llanarmon-yn-Ial, Clwyd', Antiquaries Journal, 63, 384-7.Taylor, J. (1984) The Potterne gold bracelet and its affinities. Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Magazine, 78, 35–40. Available from https://archive.org/details/wiltshirearchaeo7819wilt/page/40/mode/2up?view=theater last accessed 13th February 2023Tyacke, A. (1993). Recent archaeological acquisitions at the Royal Cornwall Museum. Cornish Archaeology, 32, 142-145.
notes: From the same area as 2020 T554
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A gold penannular ring of Bronze Age date. The ring forms a circular penannular loop with a small gap between two flat terminals. It has a circular cross section. The object is plain and covered with slight pitting, dents and scratches on all surfaces. No decoration is present.
subsequentActionTerm: Treasure item found pre 1997, so undergoing Treasure Trove

description: A cast copper-alloy penannular ring of uncertain date, probably of the Bronze Age (c. 1300-800 BC). The hoop is circular in cross-section. The two terminals are parallel to each other and have relatively flat and worn faces that are rounded by wear. There is no trace of the gold coating that is usually found on Middle to Late Bronze Age penannular rings that are similar in style.Similar copper-alloy penannular rings recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database include BUC-251D11, NMS-97017C and SF-2A1951. All are of unknown date but could be of the Bronze Age. This example comes from the opposite end of the same field as other penannular rings of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c.1150-750 BC) (see BH-9326BA).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A fragment of a gold bracelet of Middle Bronze Age date (c.1300-1150BC).Description: The bracelet is composed of four twisted wires, closley soldered together and to plain circular-sectioned wires at either side. All of the wires wires flatten towards the terminal, becoming rectnagular in cross-section where they meet the plain transverse, flattened, end wire. The opposite ends ends in a breakMeasurements: Length: 21.8mm, Width: 5.8 mm, Thickness: 1.2mm, Weight: 1.21g.Discussion: This fragment can be compared with similar objects constructed from lengths of soldered twisted wire between plain wires including BH-EFD841 (2012T9) recorded on the database and submitted for the consideration as Treasure. This example draws parallels with similarly constucted objects identified as bracelets, one from the Middle Bronze Age Burton hoard found near Wrexham (PAS-5B1745) and the others from the Middle Bronze Age Salcombe shipwreck found off Devon, now in the British Museum collections (2010,8032.4). These are all dated to c.1300-1150BC and so a similar date is suggested for the example recorded here.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: A fragment from a gold bracelet dating to the Bronze Age c.2400-800 cal BC. The fragment was originally bent into a rough L-shape but was then flattened by the finder. The surface of one corner was then subjected to an acid test by a jeweller before being brought to the Finds Liaison Officer for recording.The ribbbon is made from a single flat rectangular shaped gold sheet. One terminal has a slightly rounded end while the other has a slightly diagonal not quite ragged break.The outer surface of the sheet has incised decoration consisting of 13 parallel lines that run the length of the object taking up its entire width. This creates a ridged design. The reverse is plain although traces of the upper design’s creation are faintly visible.The object is a bright gold colour.Dimensions: The ribbon is 104.2mm long, 10.9mm wide, 0.8mm thick and weighs 6.30 grams.Discussion:  Similar gold strips with incised decoration have been found as isolated objects in Hampshire (2019 T866 Hinds 2019, 2019T 513 Adams 2019), Shropshire (2017 T42 Oakden 2017), Yorkshire (2019 T274 Griffiths 2019), Sussex (2018T513 Richardson 2018) Staffordshire (2016 T1039 Gilmore 2016), and Warwickshire (2007 T672 Bolton 2007).One has also been found in a hoard on the database from Cornwall (2020 T222 Tyacke 2020) which has been dated to the Penard phase (c.1275-1150 cal BC following Roberts et al. 2013)Similar narrow embossed strips are also illustrated by Taylor (1980, fig 28a-f) which are suggested to date to the Early Bronze Age. Further multi-grooved strips of Bronze Age date are in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) while an in-context example has been found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980) in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd -early 2nd millennium BC.As such there are a number of parallels spread from across the country that would support this is Bronze age in date, these tend to be suggested to be Early Bronze Age but the Penard dated hoard cited above suggests they may also date later into the Bronze Age.Conclusion:  The object is a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: 2024 T347Bronze Age Copper Alloy and Gold Penannular RingPAS Database number: DUR-2FFBF0Date: Late Bronze Age - c. 1000-800 BC.Description: An incomplete copper alloy and gold penannular ring dating to the Late Bronze Age (c.1000-800 BC).The penannular ring is comprised of a copper alloy core with circular cross-section with a beaten gold exterior plating created with coiled silver thread resulting in a stripy appearance. In one obvious place the gold has come away, possibly due to copper alloy corrosion from the core beneath. One terminal has retained its gold plating, while the other has lost it leaving a jagged terminal. Dimensions: Thickness: 5.4 mm; Weight: 2.15 g; Diameter: 13.2 mm.Discussion: Penannular rings are well-attested Bronze Age finds with many comparable examples recorded through the Portable Antiquities Scheme database. See for example, 2023 T312 (YORYM-2A8B0B), 2019 T1247 (DUR-B76D9B) and 2019 T1012 (DUR-1B2FA1). The record for the latter two examples notes that There is no clear consensus in terms of how these penannular rings may have been used in the past. Although latterly often described as ‘hair-rings’ (implying they were decorative elements worn in the hair) and as ‘ring-money’ to be used as a proto-monetary exchange object and used in trade, there is no evidence for either of these uses. Although it is unlikely they were worn in the hair, the possibility remains that they were worn on the body and used as personal adornment (e.g. as earrings or nose-rings).Eogan’s (2004) distribution shows that Bronze Age penannular rings are found in both Britain and Ireland and a small number have been found in northwest continental Europe. Finds recorded on the PAS database for England and Wales reflect a general bias towards southern Britain, with very few recorded in Wales and northern England. This particular penannular ring (2024 T347 / DUR-2FFBF0) fits generally with this distribution pattern.A recent scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). As such 2019-T1012 (DUR-1B2FA1) as Type 3d: ‘gold foil plated copper alloy ring, with silvery gold wire inlay’. Analysis of a similar example in the British Museum collections suggests that the technical skill involved in creating the fine silver-rich gold striped effect on the surface was highly complex. Penannular rings of this form, particularly gold sheet examples with stripes, are generally considered to date to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (c.1000–800BC; Needham 2007, 33).Conclusion: The age and precious metal content of this object meets the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996. Author: Caroline Smith, Finds Liaison Officer for Assistant for Co. Durham, Newcastle, and Northumberland; Benjamin Westwood, Finds Liaison Officer for Durham, Darlington & Teesside.Date: 28/09/2024References:       Eogan, G. (1994) The Accomplished Art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c.2300–650BC). Oxford: Oxbow.Meeks, N.D., Craddock, P.T., and S.P. Needham (2008) ‘Bronze Age penannular gold rings from the British Isles: technology and composition’, Jewellery Studies 11, 13–30.Needham, S.P. (2007) ‘17. Cirencester area, Gloucestershire: Bronze Age gold and base-metal scatter (2004 T416)’ in DCMS (2007) Treasure Annual Report 2004, London: Department for Culture Media and Sport.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A copper alloy penannular ring or ring core of probable Bronze Age date (c. 1300-800BC). The ring is made from a circular sectioned loop with a moulded in feature around the outside circumferemce. It is wider in the middle than at the terminals. The material is quite degraded and only half of the ring survives, still, it is apparant that the terminal (the smaller diameter end) was flat. The wider end is more damaged and has been crudely broken. It may be a core onto which gold or silver would have been fixed and the finder comments that traces of gold may be present. Objects such as this are often termed “ring money” or “hair rings” but are most likely a different form of personal adornment, perhaps worn on the nose or ears.  Typically dated to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, it is suggested in NMGW-04216C that they in fact originate in the Middle bronze age and continue in use until the end of the Bronze Age. This means a wider date range of c.1300-800BC must be given for this object. Thanks to the finder for the photographs and identificationAlthough the object is over 300 years old, the lack of surving gold or silver plating would mean that the precious metal content of the object would be under 10%, and it would therefore not be considered as TreasureDimensions: It is 25mm ouside diameter and 10mm inside diameter. The ends are 6mm and 8mm in diameter and it weighs 6.57g
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Description: Small gold penannular ring. It is not quite circular, being slightly longer in width (when held with terminals upwards or downwards) and slightly shorter in length (from terminals to the opposite side of the ring, which might be thought of as the centre of the object). The circular cross-section flares very slightly from a minimum of 3.5mm diameter at the centre to 3.8mm at the terminals; the terminals are flat-ended, at a slight angle to each other and c. 2mm apart. From the tiny cracks and seams in the gold at the terminals, it appears that a piece of sheet gold projected from the outside of either end and was then bent in to cover the flat end of the terminal, suggesting that the ring may have been made from a core wrapped in sheet gold. The ring is in good condition, however, and there is no other visible evidence that it is not solid gold. The surface has lots of tiny pits and scratches, but there is no hint of decoration.Dimensions: Length from gap in ring to centre of object, 12.8mm. Width 14.1mm, maximum thickness 3.8mm, internal width 7.2mm. Weight 2.46g.Discussion: There are over a hundred of these rings recorded on the PAS database, with a distribution focused on central southern England, but this is a relatively small and slim example of the type; only a few weigh less than 3g. Good parallels include WILT-299199, ESS-046731 and SUR-491236.Although they have in the past been called 'hair-rings' or 'ring-money', their function remains uncertain (see for example discussion in Armbruster 2021: 191-196). They have until recently been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC, based firstly on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly on Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13).Gwilt suggests, in discussion of an example recorded at NMGW-04216C (citing Raftery in Roche et al 2004, 87-8) that, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing, to the extent that these items may now be placed within a wider date-range encompassing the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC).Date: Middle to Late Bronze Age, 1300-800 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Circumstances of discovery: Metal detecting on cultivated land during a commercial rally Description: A gold ribbon or band, dating to c.1500 BC- AD 800. It comprises a folded/rolled rectangular strip of ribbon gold, the object is now sub-cylindrical. Both sides are undecorated.Dimensions: Diameter 20.1mm; width 6.4mm; thickness 1.3mm; approximate straight length 95mm; weight 10.51g.Discussion: The object has few diagnostic features being made of a thin strip of gold. Gold bands are relatively undiagnostic component of (perhaps especially Middle and Later) Bronze Age goldwork in Southern England (c.1500-800 BC) (see Murgia et al. 2014a; Murgia et al. 2014b). A Bronze Age date is supported by those gold ribbons with more diagnostic features including SOM-A4086 (2018T164) and DOR-86B8B9 (2020T480) identified as bracelets, OXON-A33005 (2022T736) recorded as a ribbon, YORYM-B1A82B (2021T608) recorded as a mount, and BERK-73615E (2020T803), an unidentified object, as well as two objects identified as bracelets which made up part of a hoard from Wiltshire (WILT-DE7029; 2022T800). All have been folded, suggesting that the folding of such objects prior to deposition is a phenomenon mostly occurring in the Bronze Age. SUR-4956AF (2017T922) and HAMP-EA6ECD (2017T1156) are both undecorated examples dated to the Bronze Age, the latter partly due to it being folded.However, there are also examples which are suggested to come from the Roman to Early Medieval period (NLM-E8C60D, SWYOR-089827 and IOW-36803C). In the British Museum's collections, 2010,8032.9 is an undecorated folded gold strip dated 1300BC-750BC, whilst folded gold strips not dating to the Bronze Age include 1996,0701.2 dated 50 BC - AD 50 and 1986,0401.350.d from the Snettisham hoard dated to the Roman period, both in the British Museum's collections.This piece of gold is undecorated, slightly thicker than most recorded examples, and less tightly folded, making it difficult to date with any certainty. Perhaps the closest in thickenss is from the Llanarmon-yn-Iâl Hoard (Green 1983) which would support a Bronze Age date. Similarly, the site is near to the Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age hillfort, Liddington Camp and other Bronze Age activity in the area includes WILT-BD61FB (2022 T471) a Late Bronze Age hoard of three socketed axeheads, SUR-B10DA4 (2024T323) a Bronze Age gold bracelet, and WILT-F6A02E, a Bronze Age scraper. Approximately 10 Roman coins, as well as one or two medieval and post medieval coins, have also been found nearby, but on the balance of probabilities this band can also be assigned to the Bronze Age, although a more precise date within the period is difficult to ascertain.Conclusion: The object is over 300 years old and comprises over 10% precious metal. It is therefore submitted for consideration as treasure under the terms of the 1996 Treasure Act.Alix SmithFinds Liaison Assistant for WiltshirePortable Antiquities SchemeReferences:Green, H. S. (1983). "Note: A Late Bronze Age gold hoard from Llanarmon-yn-Iâl". Antiquaries Journal. 63: 384–387.Murgia, A., Melkonian, M. and Roberts, B.W. (2014) European Bronze Age Gold in the British Museum. London: The Trustees of the British Museum.Murgia, A., Roberts, B.W. and Wiseman, R. (2014) What have metal-detectorists ever done for us? Discovering Bronze Age Gold in England and Wales. Unknown: unknown.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A complete gold Bronze Age basket ornament (generally described as earrings or hair tresses) dated c. 2500-2200 BC. This item has been cut from thin gold sheet and would normally have been wrapped into a cylindrical 'basket' shape. This flattened-out example is comprised of an oval body with a  thin rectangular 'tang' that projects at a right angle from the centre of one of the sides.The tang remains partially folded towards the body of the ornament. The ornament measures 27.63mm long and 15.87mm wide (excluding the tang) and 21.48 mm wide if including the tang. The body of the earring has been decorated across its surface with a series of small, punched dots and fine incised lines which are visible on both sides of the ornament. The decoration appears to have been engraved and punched on one side, with the some of the decorations showing through quite clearly on the opposite side (excluding a fine zig-zag pattern). The decoration is as follows, starting from the edges of the object: a concentric band of punched dots, followed by a band of very light zig-zags that slightly overlap a lower concentric engraved line, followed by a concentric line of punched dots. Within this border of punched dots and lines, towards the centre of the object and on either side of the tang, there are a series of horizontal incised lines aligned at 90-degree angles to the long sides.  These central decorations are made up of one group of three lines and one group of four lines, that would have provided a border to the tang when the ornament was in its original basket-shape.   The tang has fine zig-zag pattern near its tip. The ornament is damaged with extensive creasing and some tearing on the edges and in the centre. This item was discovered in a folded-up condition and subsequently flattened out by the finder.  Found in association with another gold basket ornament, HAMP-43A112, which was about 5-10 metres away.
notes: These gold basket-shaped ornaments belong to the earliest phases of metallurgy in Britain, dating to the early Bronze Age.  They are usually associated with adult male burials dating to the early Beaker period (c. 2400-2200 BC) and are regarded as personal ornaments, possibly worn on hair, ears or items of costume.There are several excavated examples of similar form to 2023 T188, including:   A pair of sheet gold basket earrings or hair ornaments found in 1944 during excavations of Radley Barrow Hills, Oxfordshire and are now held at the Ashmolean Museum:  Asset ID: 10847CMS Object ID: 342488 . The Amesbury Archer, excavated by Wessex Archaeology in 2002, had a large assemblage of grave-goods associated with his burial, including pair of basket earrings (hair tresses). This grave has been securely dated to 2400 BC. A grave in close proximity to the Amesbury archer (likely to be a close relative) also had a pair of basket earrings associated with it.Several examples of basket ornaments have been recorded on the PAS database and declared Treasure, including: HAMP-C5178B , 2012 T774 BERK-0D1A05, BERK-F548E6, SUSS-096CEB, LON-FF7E65 and BH-956274The British Museum also has Basket earrings in its collection, including from the Boltby Scar Hoard excavation in North Yorkshire: 1940,0404.2
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold Bronze Age basket ornament (generally described as earrings or hair tresses) dated c. 2500-2200 BC. This item has been cut from thin gold sheet and would normally have been wrapped into a cylindrical 'basket' shape. This flattened-out example is comprised of an oval body with a thin rectangular 'tang' that projects at a right angle from the centre of one of the sides. The ornament measures 28.52 mm long and 16.09mm wide (excluding the tang) and 25.34 mm wide if including the tang. The body of the earring has been decorated across its surface with a series of small, punched dots and fine incised lines most of which are visible on both sides of the ornament (except the zig-zags and dashes). The decoration is as follows, starting from the edges of the object: a concentric band of punched dots, followed by a band decorated with zig-zags, then a concentric engraved line, followed by a band decorated with fine incised vertical  and oblique dashes, then a concentric line of punched dots. Within this border of punched dots and lines, towards the centre of the object and on either side of the tang, there are a series of   horizontal incised lines aligned at 90-degree angles to the long sides. These central decorations are made up of two groups of three clearly defined  lines  overlaid by three fine additionall lines that would have provided a border to the tang when the ornament was in its original basket-shape. The ornament is damaged with extensive creasing and some tearing on the edges. This item was discovered in a folded-up condition and subsequently flattened out by the finder.  Found in association with another gold basket ornament HAMP-43D3D6, which was about 10-15 metres away, according to the finders.
notes: These gold basket-shaped ornaments belong to the earliest phases of metallurgy in Britain, dating to the early Bronze Age.  They are usually associated with adult male burials dating to the early Beaker period (c. 2400-2200 BC) and are regarded as personal ornaments, possibly worn on hair, ears or items of costume.There are several excavated examples of similar form to 2023 T188, including:   A pair of sheet gold basket earrings or hair ornaments found in 1944 during excavations of Radley Barrow Hills, Oxfordshire and are now held at the Ashmolean Museum:  Asset ID: 10847CMS Object ID: 342488 . The Amesbury Archer, excavated by Wessex Archaeology in 2002, had a large assemblage of grave-goods associated with his burial, including pair of basket earrings (hair tresses). This grave has been securely dated to 2400 BC. A grave in close proximity to the Amesbury archer (likely to be a close relative) also had a pair of basket earrings associated with it.Several examples of basket ornaments have been recorded on the PAS database and declared Treasure, including: HAMP-C5178B , 2012 T774 BERK-0D1A05, BERK-F548E6, SUSS-096CEB, LON-FF7E65 and BH-956274The British Museum also has Basket earrings in its collection, including from the Boltby Scar Hoard excavation in North Yorkshire: 1940,0404.2
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold or gold pennanular ring of Late Bronze Age date (1150-750 BC). The object is oval in plan broadly sub-circular to D-shaped in cross-section with the outside edge being more rounded than the straighter inside edge.The terminals are slightly flared with slight rims and have irregular facets which suggest they have been hammered. The ring is mostly gold in colour, with the exception of several discoloured bands that wrap around half of the cross-section circumference.
notes: From NMGW-04216C 'The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980, Eogan 1994, 1997, Hobbs 2003, Meeks et al 2008 and O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange'. A number of such rings have been reported to the PAS and declared treasure in recent years. E.g banded plated example PAS-011055 (2016T920), plane plated SUSS-1CBAB0 (2017T984) rolled up tube LANCUM-80A136 (2011T499).
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description: A gold tripartite composite penannular ring of Middle Bronze Age date (c.1300-1150 BC), made of three C-section strips apparently soldered together and bent round to form a loop, with a second penannular gold ring, of only one C-section element, linked within.The tripartite ring is bent into a sub-circular loop measuring c. 15mm wide in all directions, but flattened slightly as it approaches the gap between the ends, so that it approaches a sub-triangular shape. The gap between the ends flares from 2.2mm to 3mm wide.Each element of the tripartite ring is convex on the outer but hollow on the inside. The outside is neatly made and well polished, including the bevelled short edges. The inside, however, is not nearly so neat; the surfaces are rough and the edges of each element are crumpled where they have been joined together. The longitudinal seams are slightly overlapping, so that the total width (or depth) of the ring at 8.3mm is less than the sum of the width of each individual element. Traces of surplus gold can be seen in places within the seams on the outside, suggesting that gold solder used to join the three elements. The absence of this on top or bottom edges suggests that the ring has always only consisted of these three elements. The second, single-element ring is of similar proportions to the individual elements of the tripartite ring, being made up of a strip 3.2mm wide with convex polished exterior face and hollow inner. The hollow inside has the same rough appearance as the elements of the tripartite ring, but the long edges are a little different. Both are flatter, and one has a slight longitudinal groove added on the exterior close to the edge. The single ring is now bent so that the loop is smaller and sub-square, and the open ends are now side by side. One end has a clear short groove across close to the end, wider and neater than the longitudinal groove, and both ends have bevelled ends which look as if they have been made using similar grooves.The rings have been cleaned by the finder and can now be separated, but a photograph of it at the time of finding shows them linked together, and so that is likely to be the way in which they were deposited.Dimensions:  Diameter of tripartite ring, c. 15mm; total width (or depth) of all three elements together, 8.3mm; total thickness, c. 2mm; weight 4.30g. Diameter of single ring, c. 11-13mm; width of its single element 3.2mm; thickness 1.2mm; weight 1.42g.The thickness of both rings is hard to measure, but the quoted thickness is in total, across the curve of each element. Total weight of both elements, 5.72g.Discussion: There are several other tripartite penannular gold rings recorded on the PAS database, but they tend to have elements with solid cross-sections. Similar C-shaped cross-sections are found on a few, including IOW-0EAD26, ESS-CB3683 and apparently BUC-9754C7, although the photograph of this last example appears to contradict the description by showing flat inner surfaces. It has been suggested that YORYM-06C5C1, with a very deeply hollowed interior, might have been a sheet cover for a base-metal core, but this is perhaps less likely for 2024T411, as any core would have been clearly visible. The linking of a tripartite ring to another object is also well paralleled. A good parallel on the PAS database is ESS-F1E21D (2023T194, from Beaumont-cum-Moze), where two tripartite rings with solid cross-sections are linked together. These small rings are often found threaded onto larger objects, for example in the Stretham (Cambs) hoard, discovered in 1850 and now in the British Museum (1884,0520.3). Here two three-strand rings are interlinked, and one in turn strung on a larger penannular bracelet (Eogan 1967, 141-143, fig 3.2; Eogan 1994, p. 56, fig. 22.4).Cowie et al (2011, 22) comment that "the presence of diminutive rings threaded on to the hoops of some torcs and bracelets suggests that the smaller rings may have served as dangles on larger ornaments" and further examples can be seen at BM-261FA2 (2004T81, from north-east Norfolk), LANCUM-D7E08D (2023T1094, from near Barnoldswick, Lancashire) and BERK-A5FFE5 (2009T755, from the Windsor area).Date: Middle Bronze Age, c.1300-1150 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A cast copper-alloy penannular ring of uncertain date, probably of the Bronze Age (c. 1300-800 BC). The hoop is sub-pentagonal in cross-section with a flat inner surface and bevelled outer panels that meet at a circumferential ridge on the outer surface. The two terminals meet with little space between them. There is no trace of the gold coating that is usually found on Middle to Late Bronze Age penannular rings that are similar in style. Instead, the metal has a pale green-grey patina and is generally worn.The penannular ring measures 15mm in external width and 4.2mm in thickness. It weighs 4.94 grams.Similar copper-alloy penannular rings recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database include BUC-251D11, NMS-97017C and SF-2A1951. All are of unknown date but could be of the Bronze Age.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A fragment of gold, likely hack gold from a penannular bracelet of Bronze Age date, possibly c.1100-850 BC.Description: The object is broadly 'axe-shaped' with a sub-circular terminal that tapers to a flat rectangular cross section. This was likely achieved by cutting and hammering. The tapered end has been cut, indicated by a bright rugged cut. The terminal also appears to have been cut from a larger object and then hammered smooth. The gold has a rich, bright yellow colour. Measurements: Length: 14.77 mm; Width: 7.03 mm; Thickness: 6.43 - 2.37 mm and Weight: 6.5 g.Discussion: Gold ingots generally fall into three main date ranges: Bronze Age, Early Medieval and Modern. While gold ingots are often dated to the Early Medieval period, in association with the Viking bullion economy, this piece is not diagnostic of the other examples on this database (see BERK-842965, HAMP-3C8EAE and GLO-64767B). This example also weighs 6.5 g which does not conform to the Anglo-Scandinavian örtugar - mark weight system (as outlined in Kruse, 1988 and in Haldeny & Kershaw, 2014). Additionally, the ingot does not appear to be Modern, due to the high purity of the gold content. Thus, it suggests that this could be Bronze Age, as will be discussed below. The surrounding area has mainly produced Post-Medieval finds, with no Bronze Age or Early Medieval activity recorded on the PAS or the Kent Historic Environment Record. However, 3 km from the ingot findspot was KENT-8C3793, a gold torc fragment dating to the Iron Age which may suggest more local prehistoric activity that previously thought.The shape of the ingot is strikingly similar to a number of Bronze Age dated examples. Most notably is the hack gold present in the Middle Bronze Age Fittleworth Hoard, dated from 1400-1100 BC, currently in the collection of the British Museum. The record IOW-9F0C84 (and the addenda IOW-21EDC1) shows Late Bronze Age (c.1150-800 BC) hack gold in association with penannular rings that display the characteristic oblique ‘V’ shape seen on this example. These examples suggest that the hack gold is a fragment of a penannular bracelet; other database examples of a similar form are also identified as bracelet fragments as are the objects alongside the hack gold in the Fittleworth Hoard. IOW-50D55F is a Late Bronze Age penannular bracelet that has been ‘snipped’ and modified to become hack gold. CORN-705C14, SWYOR-DDC942, Green (1983) and Eogan (1994) also discuss bracelet fragments that are reminiscent of hack gold.Other isolated fragments posited as Bronze Age, such as BH-E08E66, SOM-E5EF83 and NMS-E6AF84, have been deemed Not Treasure on the balance of probability due to the lack of diagnostic indicators. However, it is argued above that this object is diagnostic enough to be considered Bronze Age and, as such, Treasure.Treasure Conclusion: It is therefore clear that this object dates to before 1724 and as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold-plated penannular ring dating to the Late Bronze Age, c. 1000-800 BC.  Description:                                  The ring is circular in cross section, with corrosion between the terminals. The corrosion likely indicates that it was made by covering a circular copper-alloy bar with gold sheet and hammering it flat, giving it the appearance of being made from solid gold. The ring was decorated with silver or silver rich gold wire, which covers the ring in a continuous spiral that provides a striped effect. Overall, it is in fairly good condition, but there are a couple of scratches, nicks and dents in the surface, as well as some damage around the terminals. Penannular gold rings are often inlaid with bands of paler gold, also known as electrum (a naturally occurring silvery gold). This creates a striped effect with each gold or electrum stripe being around a millimetre or less in width.Date: c.1600-800 BCDimensions: Outer width, 15.3mm. Length of space between terminals, 4mm (average). Diameter of internal perforation, 6mm. Thickness, 6.7mm (average).Weight: 4.96g.Discussion: A number of penannular rings of similar size and decoration have been recorded as treasure on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database; 2020T565 (BUC-AD669C), 2019T1091 (HAMP-BE4072), 2015T809 (DOR-0A6139) and 2003T290 (SUR-8E1010). Six Bronze Age gold penannular rings were illustrated in the Treasure Annual Report 2003 (p. 196-197). While this is the first gold Bronze Age penannular ring to be recorded for Cornwall, this type of find is not unusual for the South West, with 5 being recorded from Dorset, 4 from Somerset, and 1 from Devon. However, it is noted that this example is very highly decorated, especially when considered in comparative terms to other examples from the South West. However, there are closely comparable objects of this type and age on the database, including three from the above mentioned sub-set, all from Dorset: 2015T809 (DOR-0A6139), 2013T383 (DOR-18E227),  and 2011T229 (DOR-D914C7).It is not clear how these rings were used. In the past they were called ‘hair-rings’ because they were thought to have been worn in the hair and they have been called ‘ring-money’ as they were thought to have been used as a proto-monetary exchange object and used in trade (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although use as hair decoration has been ruled out. However, the possibility remains that they were worn on the body and used as personal adornment (see discussion in Armbruster 2021: 191-196).Eogan’s (2004) distribution shows that Bronze Age penannular rings are found in both Britain and Ireland and a small number have been found in northwest continental Europe. Finds recorded on the PAS database for England and Wales reflect a general bias towards southern Britain, with fewer recorded in Wales and northern England.A recent scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). This particular example comes under their ‘Type 3d gold foil plated copper alloy ring, with silvery gold wire inlay’ and analysis of a similar one in the British Museum collections suggests that the technical skill involved in creating the fine silver-rich gold striped effect on the surface was highly complex.These penannular rings, especially the gold sheet examples with stripes, are generally considered to date to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (c.1000–800BC; Needham 2007, 33).There is a suspected Bronze Age Barrow site nearby, which this find may be associated with: Heritage Gateway - Results.Conclusion:This object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Author: Laura Miucci, Cornwall FLO With contributions by: Rebecca Griffiths, and Adam Rivett
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold bar ingot with chisel end probably dating from the Middle Bronze Age to Roman periods c. 1400 BC - AD 410. The ingot comprises a flat, rectangular bar with a rectangular cross-section that has been hammered along its length on one side and is smoother on the other. One end has been hammered into a chisel form with an oblique angled edge; the opposing end terminates in a worn, irregular break.  There are no signs of any test marks. Length: 31.18mm; width: 8.56 -6.86mm; thickness; 2.68mm and weight: 6.885g. PXrf results provided by finder:  Gold 83.93%; silver 11.46% and copper 2.99% with traces of iron 0.393 %.Discussion: without context gold ingots are hard to date with confidence but similar flat bar forms with chisel ends have been dated to the Bronze Age period. See: CORN-AE219D (2018T556) which has also been XRF analysed by Professor Peter Northover whose comments on the levels of copper present indicate that this example is possibly of Middle Bronze Age date due to the very low copper content. Compare also a very close parallel also dated to the Middle Bronze Age found in the Fittleworth Hoard from West Sussex, (2016T651) now in the British Museum; see: (1996,0902.11). However, notably the weight compares almost exactly to two Roman Drachma (6.82g) and finds from the immediate vicinity are also predominantly Roman with no Bronze Age material so a Roman date is also possible for this object.
notes: The object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old at the time of finding. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description:  A fragment from a gold bar shaped ingot with an oval cross section. It has two slightly ragged transverse breaks both marked by the bar becoming flatter (almost rectangular in cross section) through two D-shaped  facets on opposite sides of the bar. It is notable that these are at a right angle to one another with one edge flaring out more widely than the opposite example.There are several scratches to the surface in addition to pitting and marks from abrasion.Dimensions: The ingot is 33.9 long, 8.5mm wide by 2.1mm at one end and 7.9mm by 1.8mm at the other. It weighs 9.80 gramsDiscussion: A number of fragments of gold rods of similar dimensions have been found in isolation and recorded by the PAS (e.g. KENT-A071A8 (2017T131), HAMP-8AFE65 (2019T1197), SWYOR-CBC05F (2019T849) etc). Dating these individually can be problematic, due to the smallness of this piece the full form of the ingot is not clear and similar forms were used in different periods. However there are similar examples are included in a number of Bronze Age hoards including the Fittleworth Hoard (British Museum Accession no: 1996,0902 1996,0902), the Rossett Hoard (Davis 2006) a hoard found on the Isle of Wight (IOW-9F0C84 2020T2, 2018T5 IOW-50D55F) and another example from near Cirencester (BM-28B710 2004T416)Conclusion: The object is a minimum of 10% precious metal and is, on the balance of probability, over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Gold ingot fragment from the Bronze Age, c.1600-800 BCDescription:This is a single cylindrical fragment of solid gold, with two parallel flattened faces, which appears to have been snapped at both ends. The surface is slightly scratched with some abrasions and slight indentations, but otherwise smoothly finished. The “damage” may well have been caused by being buried. It is possible that this was a segment of wire used in a larger bracelet.Dimensions: Length: 14 mm; Width: 7 mm; Thickness: 5 mm; Weight: 4.44 g.Discussion:The precise date and function of this object is unclear; however, Further gold rods with cut edges appear to have been found in a number of Bronze Age hoards including the Fittleworth Hoard (British Museum Accession no: 1996,0902 1996,0902), a hoard found on the Isle of Wight (IOW-9F0C84 2020T2, 2018T5 IOW-50D55F) and another example from near Cirencester (BM-28B710 2004T416)
notes: Found as part of the Mottistone project.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Gold ingot fragment from the Bronze Age, c.1600-800 BC.A single cylindrical fragment of solid gold which appears to have been cut at both ends. The surface is slightly scratched with some abrasions and slight indentations, but otherwise smoothly finished. The “damage” may well have been caused by being buried.Discussion:The precise date and function of this object is unclear; however, a hoard of two penannular rings and one hacked gold ingot (IOW-9F0C84 2020T2) was found approximately 100m to the east. The small gap between these two, as well as the similarities between the hacked ingots, strongly suggest this was part of the same hoard.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A small sheet of ribbed gold; that might once have been folded into a cylinder but is now flattened. The object is made of a single rectangular sheet of gold that has been folded in a spiral over 540 degrees and then squashed almost flat.  It is decorated by a series of c.22 nearly parallel incised lines running across its length creating a decorative ridged design. Each line is placed circa 0.5mm apart. As its visible edges appear to be cut, rather than broken, it is likely that this object is complete.Dimensions: Length (remaining), 13mm. Width (average; not diameter as it is now flattened), 7.5mm. Average thickness of the gold sheet, 0.23mm.Weight: 0.68g.Discussion: The linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date, including finds from Wiltshire, Shropshire, Nottinghamshire, Gloucestershire, and Suffolk (LVPL-954858, LVPL-25FCB6, LVPL-34D297, GLO-F8F3B7, and SF-D30D10). Similar narrow embossed strips are also illustrated by Taylor (1980, fig 28a-f) which are suggested to date to the Early Bronze Age. Multi-grooved strips of Bronze Age date are in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) while an in-context example has been found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980), in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd-early 2nd millennium BC.As such there are a number of parallels spread from across the country that would support that this object is Bronze Age in date. Objects of this kind tend to be suggested to be Early Bronze Age, but the Penard dated hoard cited above suggests they may also date later into the Bronze Age.Conclusion: This object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Author: Laura Miucci (Finds Liaison Officer, Cornwall)With contributions by Dr Edward Caswell (Finds Liaison Officer, Oxfordshire)References:Palmer, N., 1980. A beaker burial and medieval tenements in the Hamel, Oxford. Oxoniensia Oxford, 45, pp.124-225.Taylor, J.J. (1980) Bronze age goldwork of the British Isles. Gulbenkian archaeological series. Cambridge, Cambridge University Press.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A fragment of gold ribbon dating to the Bronze Age period, c. 2350-800 BC. The fragment possibly formed part of a bracelet or pendant, or another form of jewellery, such as an ear ornament. The ribbon is made from a buttery-yellow sheet gold. In plan, the remaining fragment is sub-triangular, or tongue-shaped. There is a narrow terminal, with a slightly convex edge. There is a circular perforation near the edge of the terminal. The perforation has been pierced from one side, leaving a slight lip around the hole on the opposing side. From the terminal, the ribbon tapers outward, ending in a worn transverse break. The ribbon is flat and undecorated, but slight undulations are visible, probably from when it was hammered. The longitudinal edges of the ribbon are flat.Dimensions: The extant ribbon is 26.29 mm in length, the strip is 5.58 mm in width at the terminal and 11.95 mm in width at the break, and 0.63 mm thick. It weighs 2.00 g.Discussion: There are several similarly shaped gold ribbon fragments, with perforations at the terminal, dated to the Bronze Age on the PAS database. Examples include BUC-192802, HAMP-B9814B, DOR-173265, SOMDOR-D3E8B7 and BH-1BE953.  These examples are part of a range of gold strip and ribbon ornaments datable to the British Bronze Age. A pair of gold ornaments from Binstead, West Sussex, form another example of comparable ornaments with hook and eye fastenings. This latter example has been dated to the Middle Bronze Age, c. 1500-1300 BC (Treasure Annual Report 1998-1999).
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: A folded fragment of a gold band or ribbon of probable Bronze age date (2100-1150 BC). The object is composed of a rectangular fragment which is curved backward in an irregular fashion.  The open ends of the object are unabraded. The ribbon is decorated with 21 embossed, repousse linear ribs, forming 19 grooves between, running vertically from the long edges of the object. The strip is thin and the negative impressions of the ribs are visible on the reverse of the strip. Measurements:  Length: 16.63mm, Width: 8.59mm, Thickness (including folded portion): 8.99mm, Thickness (strip): 0.26mm, Weight: 0.9gthickness of folded object: 3.72mm; thickness of strip: 0.35mm Discussion:  The linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date including examples from The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Case 1980; Palmer 1980); Corringham, Lincolnshire 2011 T459 (LIN-946F12); Hook, Hampshire 2014 T777 (HAMP-36C41B); Tendring District, Essex 2012 T577 (ESS-C13B97) and a similar folded example from Laneham Nottinghamshire: 2012 T926 (LVPL-34D297). The majority of the above examples are thicker with the ribs visible on one side only. There are similar thinner parallels with ribs visible on the reverse see: 2010 T664 (LVPL-83FE92), 2023 T724 (), 2020 T516 (SWYOR-DBF058) and 2017 T42 (LVPL-25FCB6).
notes: As the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal and was over 300 years old at the time of finding it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Gold penannular ring Dimensions: external diameter (front to back) 10.1mm, external diameter (side to side) 10.7mm, internal diameter (front to back) approx. 6.0mm; internal diameter (side to side) approx. 6.5mm, diameter of body (internal to external) approx. 2.0mm; diameter of body (upper to lower face) 2.5mm, distance between terminals 0.3-0.5mm, weight (before conservation cleaning) 0.27g. This is a complete and very small penannular ring of gold with incised linear decoration around its sides and external diameter surface. Judging from surface dents and a localised small tear near one terminal on the external surface and sides, and the light weight of the ring, a sheet construction with hollow or non-metal core may be suggested. The ring is near circular, though slightly wider from side-to-side than from front-to-back, with near touching terminals. The terminals have slightly convex or domed gold end-faces. The body is oval-sectioned, widest between upper and lower surfaces relative to internal and external surfaces. There are no visible seams running along any of the surfaces of the ring.The decoration comprises three parallel zones made up of repeating short, incised line decoration running completely around the sides and external surfaces of the ring body. Each zone of lines is angled on a diagonal to create a double chevron or herringbone pattern. Seen from one face, the V direction of the chevron goes in one direction, while that on the opposing face goes in the opposite direction. The interior surface of the ring is plain. The slight damage and denting to one terminal end of the ring may have happened in antiquity, since soil survives adhering to the dented surfaces and there is no evidence of newly exposed break edge surfaces. Burnt ‘toothed’ organic artefact Current Dimensions: Large fragment: max. length 42mm, width 23mm, thickness of individual ‘teeth’ approx. 4mm, not weighed, as very fragile. Small fragments (10): all less than 12mm long, thickness of individual ‘teeth’ approx. 4mm, not weighed, as very fragileThis is a fragmentary, burnt wooden artefact, with eight narrow and parallel ‘teeth’ surviving and visible during excavation (photo, above). Each ‘tooth’ strand is approximately 2mm wide and approximately 4mm deep and separated by soil-filled gaps, each 1mm wide. The maximum surviving length of one of the teeth is approximately 38mm long. Any evidence of any possible handle component, into which the teeth may once have combined and belonged, has not survived, leaving just the partial burnt ‘teeth’ component of a possible larger original. The wooden artefact has been completely burnt black and carbonised within a reducing environment, resulting in its long-term preservation in the ground.
notes: 4.0 Recommendation (AG)It is my opinion that the penannular ring is a prehistoric gold artefact whose composition has been tested and found to be well over 10% precious metal, therefore does constitute treasure. The burnt wooden ‘toothed’ artefact fragment was found in direct association with the ring, therefore as an associated artefact, is also recommended as treasure (see Section CI, paragraphs 6 & 8 and Section CII, paragraph 14 of the Treasure Act 1996; Code of Practice (2nd Revision) (DCMS 2008,10-12). The associated human cremation, as a non-artefact deposit, is deemed an unworked natural object and is recommended as not qualifying as treasure (see Section CII, paragraph 13 of the Treasure Act 1996; Code of Practice (2nd Revision) (DCMS 2008, 11).Essential References DCMS, 2008. Gwilt, A. & Davis, M. 2020b. Part X Gold Penannular Ring, In (C.
