subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of Early Bronze Age dating (c. 2350 BC to c. 2050 BC).The flat axe is broadly sub rectangular in shape with a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with slight tapering edges. The butt is relatively thin having a narrow rounded profile; the width at the butt is 16.5 mm (thickness: 4.2 mm). The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the butt to the blade; in shape they are relatively curved. The axe is thickest at the mid point (10.4 mm), with traces of a proto stop ridge present. The sides of the blade expand to produce a crescentic blade edge with an abraded width of 47.0 mm. The tips of the crescent shaped blade have been damaged through either abrasion or wear, as has the blade edge itself. Casting 'flaws' or air bubbles are present over most of the surface of the flat axehead.The axe is a mid to dark green colour, with an uneven surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the ploughsoil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface detail.It measures 92.5 mm in length, maximum width at the blade is 47.0 mm, width at the butt is 16.5 mm and it has a maximum thickness of 10.4 mm. It weighs 113.4 grams.The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to (although not containing all the attributes of Migdale axes (many of these tend to have narrower butts which flare at the cutting edge).These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Reference:Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp121-140Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.46-47.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A near complete gold bead or folded ribbon of Bronze Age date (c.1500BC - 800BC)Description: The object is now rectangular plan, possibly having been squashed. It is constructed from a single strip of gold sheet, bent or folded so that one end overlaps the other. One of the corners here has bent inwards. The two short ends are now slightly irregular. Prior to construction, the sheet had been decorated with all over parallel incised grooves. Measurements: Length: 14mm; width: 6.5mm; thickness: 2.6mm; weight: 0.6gDiscussion: The object can be paralleled with two others recorded as beads on the database and submitted for the consideration as Treasure. These are LVPL-954858 (2020T120) also from Wiltshire, LVPL-34D297 (2012T926) from Nottinghamshire and CORN-C0312E (2024T59) from Cornwall. It can also be paralleled with objects recorded as ribbons including SOM-62CE08 (2017T882) from Somerset, SUSS-2655B2 (2023T724) from Hampshire and LIN-A74505 (2023T1035) from Lincolnshire. Others have been recorded as unidentified objects such as GLO-FE959E (2019T513) and SF-AC2907 (2018T876) which has not been flattened and retains a tubular form. All have been dated to the Early Bronze Age within the range 2200 BC-800 BC.An excavated example of a gold sheet with linear grooves from The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Case 1980; Palmer 1980) was dated to the Early Bronze Age based on its associated with typologically late Beaker pottery.A date of c.2200-800 BC is therefore suggested for the example recorded here.Conclusion: It is therefore likely that this object was at least 300 years old at the time of discovery. As the object is also made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A single hacked gold fragment of a probable Bronze Age gold armlet, c.1600-800 BC. Description:  This assessment is based on a comparative study of other Bronze Age armlets on the PAS database; one of which is noted as part of the 2020 T 222 Treasure hoard of 14 items, that came from the same parish, with a nearby findspot.It is a bracelet fragment, hammered flat, triangular in plan and rectangular in section at the broken end. The broken end is 7.5 mm wide and 1 mm thick, and has been sheared off from the rest of the armlet. The arm tapers to 4 mm in width and then expands into the circular 'buffer' terminal that is 4 mm in diameter, surrounded by a slightly raised edge.Other similar examples can be seen on the database at: CORN-705C14, and HAMP-5E48D1.Date: c.1600-800 BCDimensions: Length 35 mm; (max) width 7.5 mm; thickness 1 mm; terminal diameter 4 mm.Weight: 5.21gConclusion:This object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold plated penannular ring dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1150-800 BC). Description: The ring forms a circular penannular loop with a small gap between two flat terminals measuring 3.1mm. It has a sub-circular cross section measuring 5mm in diameter. The object is plain and covered with slight pitting, dents and scratches on all surfaces. No decoration is present. The ring is most likely gold plated with a clay core; on both terminals cracking is evident, which may derive from post depositional impact damage or expansion of the core.Measurements: 15.2mm length. 14mm width. 5mm diameter thickness. Weight 3.7grams.Discussion: Several penannular rings of similar size have been recorded as treasure on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database, for example: LIN-A0EDEA (2019T1203), SUR-6C5354 (2022T407), SUSS-5B32DE (2018T771), BH-719492 (2018T761) and HAMP-425F0D (2018T89)As stated by WMID-CAF4EB: It is not clear how these rings were used. In the past they were called ‘hair-rings’ because they were thought to have been worn in the hair and they have been called ‘ring-money’ as they were thought to have been used as a proto-monetary exchange object and used in trade. However, there is no evidence for either of these uses. Although use as hair decoration has been ruled out, the possibility remains that they were worn on the body and used as personal adornment (e.g. as earrings or nose-rings). Relatively few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating, however, burials in Belgium, northeast France and The Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations, have suggested a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800BC (e.g. Eogan 1997).For a further in-depth discussion on Bronze Age penannular rings see LANCUM-C2543FConclusion:  The penannular ring is substantially precious in nature and is older than 300 years. It therefore falls within the requirements of the Treasure Act 1996 and should be considered to be Treasure.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold penannular ring dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1150-800 BC). Description: The ring forms a circular penannular loop with a small gap between two flat terminals measuring 3.4mm. It has a sub-circular cross section measuring 4.5mm in diameter. The object is plain and covered with slight pitting, dents and scratches on all surfaces. No decoration is present. Measurements: 14.6mm length. 15.4mm width. 4.5mm diameter thickness. Weight 4.3grams.Discussion: Several penannular rings of similar size have been recorded as treasure on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database, for example: WMID-A28DF7 (2023T1080), LIN-A0EDEA (2019T1203), SUR-6C5354 (2022T407), SUSS-5B32DE (2018T771), BH-719492 (2018T761) and HAMP-425F0D (2018T89).As stated by WMID-CAF4EB: It is not clear how these rings were used. In the past they were called ‘hair-rings’ because they were thought to have been worn in the hair and they have been called ‘ring-money’ as they were thought to have been used as a proto-monetary exchange object and used in trade. However, there is no evidence for either of these uses. Although use as hair decoration has been ruled out, the possibility remains that they were worn on the body and used as personal adornment (e.g. as earrings or nose-rings). Relatively few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating, however, burials in Belgium, northeast France and The Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations, have suggested a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800BC (e.g. Eogan 1997).For a further in-depth discussion on Bronze Age penannular rings see LANCUM-C2543FConclusion:  The penannular ring is substantially precious in nature and is older than 300 years. It therefore falls within the requirements of the Treasure Act 1996 and should be considered to be Treasure.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description:  A single fragment of a probable Bronze Age gold ingot dating to c.1600-800 cal BC. It is a single cuboidal fragment of solid gold which appears to have been truncated vertically at one end and flattened and broken horizontally at the other. The surface is fairly smooth, with only occasional abrasions - this minor "damage" is likely to have been caused by taphonomic processes during deposition.Date: c.1600-800 BCDimensions: It is 12.3mm in length, and at its widest end, it is 4.9mm wide. Its average thickness is 4.15mm.Weight: It weighs 2.2g.Discussion: The object can be suggested to be a gold ingot based on a comparative study of other Bronze Age ingots on the PAS database, several of which are also from Cornwall (an area rich in prehistoric archaeology). For example other similar ingots can be seen on the database at: CORN-50D181, CORN-129596, IOW-3C4021, NMS-9533FB, and SUSS-23E3A5. While simplicity of the form and the lack of archaeological context make firm dating difficult it is notable that similar rectangular sectioned bars with flattened edges are known from two Middle Bronze Age hoards, namely the Fittleworth hoard (British Museum accession number: 1996,0902.7) and Cirencester hoard (BM-28B710, 2004 T416). Both hoards have been suggested to date to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1600-1150 cal BC) such that a date in this period is likely. Conclusion:This object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.NB: This find was recorded in collaboration with Ms Tasha Fullbrook, the former F.L.O for Cornwall.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: Penannular gold ring inlaid with bands of paler gold, also known as electrum (a naturally occurring silvery gold). This creates a striped effect with each gold or electrum stripe being around a millimetre or less in width.The ring is roughly circular in cross-section and the hole in the middle is quite small. The cross-section tapers very slightly towards the terminals, which are flat and set at right angles. The surface is smoothly polished.The narrow gap between the two flat terminals is blocked by corrosion which includes some green copper compounds, suggesting that there is an inner core of copper alloy, although there are no cracks in the gold visible underneath the corrosion.Dimensions: The gap in the ring measures c. 2.5mm wide. When held with the gap in the hoop uppermost, the ring is 18.7mm wide (from side to side) and 12.9mm long (from top to bottom). It is a fairly consistent 7.3mm thick when measured lying flat, tapering very slightly to 7.0mm thick at the ends. Opposite the gap, the hoop is 6.6mm wide, tapering to c. 5.2mm wide at the ends. It weighs 10.71g.Discussion: There are now around 150 of these penannular rings recorded on the PAS database, with a distribution focused on central southern England. Only a dozen or so are recorded from Norfolk, with eight other examples having a banded or striped surface.They have until recently been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC, based firstly on burials in Belgium, north-east France and the Netherlands, and secondly on Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13).Gwilt suggests, in discussion of an example recorded at NMGW-04216C (citing Raftery in Roche et al 2004, 87-8) that, in recent years the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing, to the extent that these items may now be placed within a wider date-range encompassing the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC).Date: Middle to Late Bronze Age, 1300-800 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: TREASURE CASE : 2023 T989Description:A fragment of a decorated sheet or ribbon of gold of probable Bronze Age date, c.2400 - 800 BC.The object is formed of a thin sub-rectangular sheet of gold, folded over at both end. One end in narrowed and double folded. It is not possible to determine if the object is complete or cut down though the latter is likely. Both the interior and exterior surface of the sheet is decorated by a series of sub-parallel indented grooves running along its length.Dimensions:Length: 10.26mm; Width: 6.61mm; Thickness: 1.23mm; Weight: 0.27g.Discussion:Similar objects have been recorded as 2019 T316 (LEIC-47D0C2), 2018 T650 (HAMP-F792A5), 2010 T664 (LVPL-83FE92) and 2013 T471 (WMID-3CBCF0). Similar multi-grooved strips of Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as recent finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48). An in-context example has been found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980) in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd -early 2nd millennium BC.Similar narrow embossed strips are also illustrated by Taylor (1980, fig 28a-f) which are suggested to date to the Early Bronze Age.2017 T882 (SOM-62CE08) states that several similar pieces have also been found bent into cylindrical beads (citing Eluère 1982, 30, fig 25, no. 3) and it is unclear if this was their original purpose or if this was a common reuse for parts of larger ribbon ornaments. That this would not have been a regular cylinder might suggest this example was not used as a bead.Conclusion: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.References:Eluère, C. (1982) Les Ors préhistoriques en France. [Online]. Picard. Available at: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/2708400851/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1.Palmer, N. (1980) A beaker burial and medieval tenements in the Hamel, Oxford. Oxoniensia Oxford. 45, 124–225.Taylor, J.J. (1980) Bronze age goldwork of the British Isles. Gulbenkian archaeological series. Cambridge, Cambridge University Press.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A complete Middle to Late Bronze Age gold penannular ring, dating to c. 1300 BC - 800 BC.Description: The object is a small penannular ring, round in plan and oval sectioned with flat terminals. The terminals are cleanly cut and form a narrow gap measuring 1.8 mm. The ring is a bright gold in colour and is even across the surface and ends. There is no suggestion of differential gold or silver banding, as can be seen on examples such as KENT-D6DB1B.Measurements: Length: 13.14 mm; Internal Width: 7.3 mm; External Width: 14.22 mm; Gap Width: 2.39 mm Thickness: 3.63 mm and Weight: 4.6 g.Discussion: These class of objects are a well-known Bronze Age type with a concentrated distribution in central southern England. Initially, these were dated to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, c. 1000 - 800 cal BC, due to northern European burial and hoarding evidence. However, further excavated examples have pushed for an earlier date, such as an association with twisted torc and bracelet fragments from the Penard phase of the Middle Bronze Age (Needham 2007).Thus, these objects are situated within a wider date range, encompassing the Middle and Late Bronze Age, c. 1300 - 800 BC.The function of penannular rings remains uncertain. Previously, they have been well recorded as 'hair-rings' or 'ring-money' (see Taylor 1981; Eogan 1994; Eogan 1997; Varndell 2001; Meeks et al 2008). However, rather than being hair ornaments or objects of exchange, it is posited that these were personal adornments worn on the ears or nose (Armbruster 2021: 191-196).Some examples are solid gold whilst others are a copper alloy core wrapped in gold sheet. The even gold colouring on this example and the lack of copper alloy corrosion suggests this is comprised of solid gold. However, the ring is noticeably lighter in weight than many solid gold examples on the database. A British Museum study has suggested the rings were created using strips of silvery gold inlaid around a gold core or alternatively a base metal core covered in gold foil. Thus, the object's composition is difficult to determine.Further discussions of these objects can be seen at ESS-EDCA69 and NMS-775561.Treasure Conclusion: It is therefore clear that this object likely dates to before 1723 and as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of the The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Declared Treasure but returned to Finder as Museum unable to acquire

description: An incomplete gold unidentified object, possibly a ribbon or bracelet, of probable Bronze Age date (c.2350-800BC).Description: The object sub-rectangular in plan, tapering at one end to a curved terminal and ending in a jagged transverse break at the other where it is widest. Here, there are linear tool marks or scratches radiating from the break. Both sides are undecorated and with similar surfaces. In profile, the object is slightly misshapen. Measurements: length: 62.3mm; width: 5.5mm; thickness: 0.5mm; weight: 3.10gDiscussion: Similar strips of gold with tapering, rounded terminals dated to the Bronze Age are recorded on the database including BUC-095886 (2021T497); KENT-21C63F (2021T630), both described as possible ribbons or bracelets, and LANCUM-9E38B6 (2023T750), a ribbon.Two similarly shaped strips twisted together and recorded as metal working debris has also been given a possible Bronze Age date based on the comparisons with a gold 'ring' from Ammerbuch-Reusten, Southwestern Germany, the metal for which was sourced in Cornwall, with the record also including a discussion on the possibility of it having an early medieval date (WILT-1D8478 (2022T286)). A second gold strip (ESS-54DA44 (2023T986)) found approximately 250 metres away, and also probably dating to the Bronze Age based on its form, was also submitted for the consideration of Treasure at the same time. Conclusion: It is therefore likely that the find was at least 300 years old at the time of discovery. As the object also contains at least 10% precious metal, it constitutes Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act (1996).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Found during metal-detecting on cultivated land at a depth of 6”.Description: A Late Bronze Age gold and silver penannular ring dating to 1150-800BC. The ring is circular in cross section. It has been made from a solid gold round sectioned, straight bar which has had a silvery strip inlaid in a continuous spiral to provide a striped colour effect. The bar has then been bent round into a penannular shape with flat faced terminals with a narrow space between them. The faces show evidence of the construction technique. The surface is otherwise undecorated. The outer surface of the ring is worn while there is little evidence of wear on the inner surface of the centre of the penannular ring.Dimensions: 17.6mm outer diameter; 5.43mm inner diameter; 6.7mm thickness; 2.76mm space between the two terminals; 16.87g weight.Discussion: A similar example in this British Museum collection is described as a penannular ring (accession number 2004,0601.1 penannular ring | British Museum). There are various such examples on the PAS database include HAMP-BE4072 - 2019T1091; WILT-299199 - 2021T306.These penannular rings belong to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money'. It is not clear how these rings were used. In the past they were called ‘hair-rings’ because they were thought to have been worn in the hair and they have been called ‘ring-money’ as they were thought to have been used as a proto-monetary exchange object and used in trade (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although use as hair decoration has been ruled out. However, the possibility remains that they were worn on the body and used as personal adornment (see discussion in Armbruster 2021: 191-196).Eogan’s (2004) distribution shows that Bronze Age penannular rings are found in both Britain and Ireland and a small number have been found in northwest continental Europe. Finds recorded on the PAS database for England and Wales reflect a general bias towards southern Britain, with fewer recorded in Wales and northern England.Scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). This particular example comes under their ‘Type 3a striped rings with silver gold alloy wire circumferentially inlaid’ and analysis of a similar one in the British Museum collections suggests that the technical skill involved in creating the fine silver-rich gold striped effect on the surface was highly complex. These penannular rings, especially the gold sheet examples with stripes, are generally considered to date to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (c.1000–800BC; Needham 2007, 33).Conclusion: Due to its age and precious metal content this object qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.Alyson TannerFinds Liaison Assistant for WiltshireSophie HawkeFinds Liaison Officer for WiltshirePortable Antiquities SchemeReferences:Armbruster, B.R. 2021. Cirencester area, Gloucestershire: Bronze Age gold and base-metal scatter (2004 T416). Treasure Annual Report 2004, 26-33, figs. 17.1-6.O'Connor, B., Cowie, T. & Worrell, S. 2008. Ring money: dernières nouvelles d’outre- manche. Bulletin de l’Association pour la promotion des recherches sur l’âge du bronze 5, 12-13.Raftery, B. 2004. Pit 119: Rathgall, Co. Wicklow. In: Roche, H., Bradley, J., Coles, J., Raftery, B. (eds) 2004. From Megaliths to Metal. Essays in Honour of George Eogan. Oxford: Oxbow Books, 83-91.Taylor, J.J. 1980. Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Varndell, G. 2001. Ringing the Changes: when terminology matters. Antiquity 75, 515-516.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Treasure Number: 2023T1094Description: A Middle Bronze Age hoard of gold consisting of a bracelet or arm band, and five closed penannular rings.The bracelet is made up of a single strand of gold bar twisted to create projecting flanges. The bars terminals narrow to form conical pointed terminals which have been bent into slight hooks resembling raptor beaks in form. The triple ribbed gold rings are each made of one piece and solid with one exception, R3, which is shaped thick foil. There are now several similar examples of twisted bar torcs with threaded penannular rings including Burton, Powys, Wales (PAS-5B1745 2004, W2) penannular bracelet; Windsor (BERK-A5FFE5, 2009 T755), twisted wire ornament and penannular rings; Granta Fen, Cambs, England (British Museum 1884,0520.3) torc and ring; Isle of Axholme, Lincs, England (British Museum 1880,0820.36),  torc and ring and Skelly Co. Tyrone, Ireland (Eogan 1994 fig24E). All are suggested to date to the Middle Bronze Age. These ornaments are part of a wider pattern seen in at least ten hoards of objects being threaded onto other objects dating to the Taunton and Penard phases of the Bronze Age (Wilkin 2017: 30-31).Dimensions: Bracelet - Wire thickness 2.5mm, 3mm at terminals.R1 - Approximate diameter 14mm, thickness 6mm.R2 - Approximate diameter 14mm, thickness 6mm.Bracelet, R1, R2 - weight 32.67g.R3 - Approximate diameter 11mm, thickness 6mm, weight 1.57g.R4 - Approximate diameter 12mm, thickness 6mm, weight 5.54g.R5 - Approximate diameter 12mm, thickness 6.5mm, weight 5.60g.Total weight 45.38gDiscussion: The objects were all found in close proximity and represent a single deposition, possibly in association with an inhumation, though the topography of the find site as it exists now would argue against that There are no extant features that could relate to the Middle Bronze Age in the immediate vicinity. The proximity of the findspot to heavily disturbed ground could mean the original deposition site was elsewhere. Suggested date of deposition is c.1300 to c1100 cal BC.Conclusion: The objects contain a minimum of 10% precious metal and are over 300 years old and therefore meet the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.References:Eogan, G. (1994) The accomplished art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC). Oxford, Oxbow.Wilkin, N. (2017) Combination, composition and context: Readdressing British Middle Bronze Age ornament hoards (c. 1400–1100 cal. BC). Dress and Society: Contributions from archaeology. 14–47.Author:Alex Whitlock  – Finds Liaison Officer for Lancashire and Cumbria.With contribution from Dr Edward Caswell – Finds Liaison Officer, Oxfordshire
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: Piece of gold rod, probably a small fragment of a flange-twisted or bar-twisted torc with three flanges, now bent into a spiral of two full turns. One end is original, with a rounded tip and neat triangular cross-section. From the rounded tip, the terminal flares slightly for c. 10mm and runs straight, before starting to coil. As it starts to curve, each face becomes concave so that the cross-section is Y-shaped, and the rod is then neatly twisted as well as bent into a coil. After two full turns the rod is apparently cut or broken. It is S-twisted (also called a left-hand twist), and the end of each flange, or arm of the Y, is polished or worn so that it is burred, or smooth and flat. The apparently broken or cut end also has some smoothly bent and worn areas. The fragment has a slightly pale, brownish colour.Dimensions: Overall diameter of coil, c. 11mm. Overall thickness of the coil, 6mm. Maximum diameter of the twisted rod, 2.4mm. Weight, 2.2g.Discussion: Gold torcs with twisted square or (more rarely) triangular cross-sections were popular in the Penard phase of the Middle Bronze Age, c. 1400-1100BC. The simplest form is the bar-twisted torc, where the rod is left with a square or triangular cross-section. When the corners of the square or triangle are extended into flanges, to produce a cross-shaped or Y-shaped cross-section, it is known as a flange-twisted torc; this example is perhaps on the border of both types (Hawkes 1961, fig. 3, nos. 2-4). Fragments of square bar-twisted or four-flanged torcs bent into small loops are recorded on the PAS database at GLO-2AF0AE and SOM-AA390A, and another (probably with four flanges) was found in 1961 in the Sporle hoard (Eogan 1967, 173, pl. 22.3). They vary in their gold content, some being fairly pure and others (e.g. ESS-D1D1E9) being only c. 75% gold.This object has some unusual features. Firstly, triangular bar-twisted torcs or three-flanged torcs are much less common than four-flanged examples, although a comparable three-flanged fragment is recorded at BUC-EF04B8.  Secondly, torcs normally have terminals which flare outwards towards their ends, rather than taper as this one does. The terminal on this example is unusual, but can be compared with the terminals on a small Bronze Age gold twist-effect loop in the British Museum (OA.10875). Thirdly, twisted torcs are, according to Eogan (1967, 131), more often Z-twisted (also called right-hand twist). This example has an S twist, as do the small loops from the Sporle hoard, GLO-2AF0AE, and SOM-AA390A, and the short length of three-flange torc BUC-EF04B8.Date: Middle Bronze Age, 1400-1100 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Treasure Case 2023 T1035A rolled gold sheet of probable Bronze age date (2100-1150 BC). It is rectangular, flat and carries a reeded motif on one side. It is bent out of shape, probably as the result of plough damage. The outside edge that is visible is straight and of a similar patina as the object indicating it was probably cut and rolled in antiquity.MeasurementsLength: 11.83 mm; Width: 6.83 mm; Thickness of sheet: 0.31 mm; Weight: 0.46gDiscussionIt is difficult to identify this as a particular object type, beyond its belonging to a broad range of ribbon, or strip, ornaments of Bronze Age date. A range of ribbon, or strip ornaments in gold are known from the British Bronze Age, including for torcs, bracelets and small fittings (see Stuart Needham's comments in 2006 T250). The linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date including examples from The Hamel, Oxford, Oxfordshire excavated from a layer which yielded Beaker pottery of the Early Bronze Age (Palmer 1980, 124-134); Corringham, Lincolnshire 2011 T459 (LIN-946F12); Hook, Hampshire 2014 T777 (HAMP-36C41B); Tendring District, Essex 2012 T577 (ESS-C13B97) and a similar folded example from Laneham Nottinghamshire: 2012 T926 (LVPL-34D297).ReferencesPalmer, N., 1980. A beaker burial and medieval tenements in the Hamel, Oxford. Oxoniensia Oxford, 45, pp.124-225.ConclusionAs the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal and was over 300 years old at the time of finding it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description: Middle Bronze Age bipartite penannular ring comprising two bands of gold stacked one on top of the other and bent round into a ring; the ring is now slightly drop-shaped or heart-shaped, being wider towards the gap than away from it. The bands are soldered together with a neat longitudinal seam which has a few small holes in it.Each of the C-section (or U-section) bands or strips is hollow on the inside and convex on the outside. The exterior is smoothly polished with the long edges slightly raised in some places; one edge is perhaps a little wider and flatter than the other and has some filemarks surviving.The interior retains longitudinal grooves or furrows within the concave hollows. The ends of the bands have rather variable ridges across the hollows to close or wall them off into a D-section; of the four, one has a full-height wall at the end, another (at the same end) little if any wall, and the other two have slight ridges. The two with slight ridges have their ends in line, but the taller ridge is slightly longer than its pair, which may suggest that the walls at the ends were soldered on and that one is now missing.Dimensions: Length (with gap held at top) 15.6mm. Width (perpendicular to this) 15.3mm. Height 8.3mm. Maximum thickness across the bands, 1.9mm. Gap between the ends, 1.6 and .9mm. Weight 5.23g.Discussion: Although penannular rings are fairly common Bronze Age finds, bipartite composite penannular rings of C-shaped cross-section are not. Most C-section composite rings are tripartite, and most bipartite rings are made from oval-section strips. It is possible that this ring originally had at least one other strip soldered to it, as one of the long edges is slightly more raised, wider and flatter, and has filemarks which could have been intended as keying for solder. Date: Middle Bronze Age, c.1300-1150 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A gold bipartite composite penannular ring of Middle Bronze Age date (c.1300-1150 BC). Description: The object is constructed from two circular-sectioned rods, stacked one on top of the other and curled round to form an open loop. The rods terminate in flat ends. The surface of the gold is rough on the inside of each ring and smooth on the outside.Measurements: diameter: 13.9mm; width: 5.5mm; thickness: 2.6mm; weight: 6.44gDiscussion: Other examples of single bipartite composite rings have been dated to c.1300-1150 BC and reported as Treasure including  BUC-9754C7 (2007T118) and SUSS-63B7A6 (2012T165). They have also been found along side tripartite rings threaded onto longer lengths of gold wire such as BM-261FA2 (2004T81) which includes the following discussion:Composite rings have been found singly and associated with other gold personal ornaments. They may also be found linked together. In Britain they may be dated by association to the Middle Bronze Age, c.1300-1100BC. In common with some other Bronze Age ornament types they are found also in Ireland and France, though they appear to be rarer in Ireland. At Stretham, Cambridgeshire, six composite rings were found threaded onto a penannular bracelet; a twisted neck ornament and a bronze rapier were found in association.A date of 1300-1150 BC is therefore suggested for this object. Conclusion: It is therefore likely that the find was at least 300 years old at the time of discovery. As the object also contains at least 10% precious metal, it constitutes Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act (1996).
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A folded piece of gold sheet, probably dating from the early Bronze Age, 2200 - 1700 BC, but possibly later.The rectangular piece of gold sheet has been folded in half, short end to short end, and the long sides of the resulting rectangle have also become partially bent at the open end; one corner towards one face, and the other corner towards the other face. All the original edges of the sheet appear to be slightly bevelled suggesting the sheet was cut to this shape. It is difficult to establish if the folding is deliberate and pre depositional or later damage in the ploughsoil.Only the outer faces of the folded sheet are visible. They are decorated with six concentric curved lines of small circular punched dots (pointille). These surround a convex circular area, apparently repousse, and inside the circular area are five partially overlapping circular motifs. These are faint stamped line rings, each containing a central recessed dot. To the side of the outer curved lines is part of another convex circular area. All these designs appear to continue off the edge of the sheet, suggesting that a larger decorated object has been cut down. The decoration must have been applied before the sheet was bent. The object as it is now, folded, is 18mm long, 13.9mm wide and 4.6mm thick. The sheet gold is 0.4 - 0.5mm thick. 2.6g. This object has numerous Bronze Age parallels recorded on the database variously known (based on their complete form) as ribbons (2019 T383, 2021 T937), mounts (2021 T608), discs (NMS-1657F1, 2022 T155) and plaques (2020 T332) with one example also possibly coming from a lunula (2017T405). These are all dated to the Bronze Age and often paralleled to objects dating to the Early Bronze Age although similar techniques are also seen on Middle Bronze Age gold bracelets (e.g. 2013 T805). This artefact is most likely to be of Early Bronze Age date, when thin sheet gold artefacts were made rather than moulded objects, but sheet gold artefacts are also known from the late Bronze Age, and from later periods too. Due to the condition and the small size of the fragment the overall design of this piece is unclear, but it is most likely to be prehistoric.
notes: This object is made of gold and is over 300 years old, so it appears to meet the requirements of the 1996 Treasure Act.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A strip of gold ribbon of probable Bronze Age date c. 2350-800 BC.  The strip is rectangular in shape and decorated on one side with 14 grooves that run along the length of the strip.  One terminal is complete and has an even curving edge. The other end of the ribbon has been damaged and is jagged. The edges of the ribbon are damaged by nicks towards the centre, and it is slightly bent in several places. Length: 52.93mm; Width: .81mm; Thickness: 0.3mm; Weight: 2.24 g.
notes: Similar multi-grooved strips of a Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain, though it is not clear how these gold ribbons were used or what period of the Bronze Age they date to. Eogan (1994) has categorised these objects as ‘Tress’-rings, including them in his discussion of gold working in the mid to late Bronze Age. More generally, there are a range of comparable ribbon gold ornaments known from the duration of the Bronze Age, particularly from the 'ornament horizon' of the Taunton phase of the Middle Bronze Age (Roberts 2007).  Similar objects have been noted in earlier Bronze Age sheet gold tradition and an excavated example found in along with a Beaker period flint scraper and pottery (Palmer 1980) suggests that an early Bronze Age date for this type of artefact is possible.  A number of similar objects have been reported as potential Treasure and are recorded on the PAS database, including ESS-71837F (2022T575), HAMP-0FCEE9 (2020 T581), HAMP-B9814B (2018T700), SUR-DE6DF2 (2017T644) and BH-1BE953 (2014T901). Thes British Museum collection include examples from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906, 1224.1-2).Conclusion: The item comprises more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old at the time of finding. As such it qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A cast copper-alloy penannular ring of uncertain date, probably of the Bronze Age (c. 1300-800 BC). The hoop is sub-pentagonal in cross-section with a flat inner surface, flat side panels and bevelled outer panels that meet at a circumferential ridge on the outer surface. The two terminals are parallel to each other and have relatively flat and worn faces that are rounded by wear. There is no trace of the gold coating that is usually found on Middle to Late Bronze Age penannular rings that are similar in style. Instead, the metal has a pale green-grey patina and is generally worn with several areas of pitting and widespread scratching.The penannular ring measures 16mm in external width and 4.7mm in thickness. From base to top of the terminals is 14.9mm. It weighs 3.4 grams.Similar copper-alloy penannular rings recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database include BUC-251D11, NMS-97017C and SF-2A1951. All are of unknown date but could be of the Bronze Age. This example comes from the opposite end of the same field as other penannular rings of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c.1150-750 BC) (see BH-9326BA).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A fragment of a flange- or bar-twisted gold torc, 39.7mm in length, dating to the Middle Bronze Age (probably Penard phase) c. 1300 - 1100 BC. The torc has a x-shaped cross-section with four flanges twisted into a spiral with a circular cross-section of 6.6mm diameter. Both ends of the fragment are abraded and one appears to have been crushed. It is unclear whether the fragment has broken off from or been cut from the original torc.
notes: Gold flange twisted torcs have been dated typologically to both the Taunton (c.1400-1250 BC) and Penard (c. 1300-1150 BC), metalwork phases of the Middle Bronze Age (Roberts 2007), when twisting and flange twisting bars and ribbons of gold were common metalworking techniques in Britain (Taylor 1980). Torcs of this style are most common in southern England and East Anglia, and deliberately cut fragments like this occur both in hoards and as stray finds. For similar items previously reported under the 1996 Treasure Act see SOM-AA390A (2016 T203), HAMP-C8DC02 (2015 T983), HAMP-DBAD3A (2019 T356), GLO-2AF0AE and BERK-CDCA77 etc.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A dispersed Bronze Age hoard dating to circa 1400-1150BC. The hoard consists of three objects. These include two gold penannular rings and a fragment of a gold torc.Gold penannular ring 1.A complete gold bipartite penannular ring of probable Middle to Late Bronze Age date (c. 1300-800 BC). The ring is composed of two bands of gold, stacked on top of one another and apparently soldered together. Each band is U-shaped in cross-section, featuring a convex, rounded exterior and a concave interior surface, with a roughly V-shaped groove. The terminals are flat and do not meet, though the ring is bent in such a manner that one set of terminals is bending downward towards another, so that the centre of the top left-hand terminal is close to meeting the bottom of the top right-hand terminal. This bend results in the top band being more oval in plan whilst the bottom band is more sub-circular. There is no further decoration. Gold penannular ring 2.A complete gold bipartite penannular ring of probable Middle to Late Bronze Age date (c. 1300-800 BC). The ring is composed of two bands of gold, stacked on top of one another and apparently soldered together. Both bands are oval in plan and have oval cross sections. The terminals are flat and do not meet. There is no further decoration.Gold torc fragment.A fragment of a flange-or-bar twisted gold torc of Middle Bronze Age date (probably Penard phase c. 1300-1100 BC). The torc has a X-shaped cross section with four flanges twisted into a spiral with a circular cross section of 7.62mm diameter. The fragment is straight and has been cut at either end.Dimensions:Gold penannular ring 1.Length: 13.74mm. Width: 13.09mm. Height: 8.97mm. Weight: 5.63g.Gold penannular ring 2.Length: 17.23mm. Width: 14.91mm. Height: 8.26mm. Weight: 14.71g.Gold torc fragment.Length: 29.47mm. Diameter: 7.62mm. Weight: 6.00g.
notes: Gold penannular rings.There are a number of penannular rings that are recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database that have been declared as Treasure. These cases include a gold bipartite penannular ring (2018T14) recovered from West Bagborough, Somerset (Burnett, 2018); and a gold penannular ring (2017T810) recovered from Westward, Cumbria (Boughton, 2017). This class of object is largely dated to the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c. 1300-750 BC).Gold torc fragment.There are similar examples to this piece that are illustrated in Eogan (1994: pl.4) and Taylor (1980: pl.41) who term these as Gold “bar” and “flanged twisted” torcs. Whilst these have been dated typologically to the Penard (c. 1300-1150 BC) metalwork phase of the Middle Bronze Age (Eogan 1994: 69, 74, 91; Roberts 2007: 141), it has been suggested that they may overlap into the preceding Taunton phase (c. 1400-1250 BC) when flange twisting and twisting ribbons and bars of gold were common techniques in Britain (Taylor 1980:60). There are several comparable items that have been recorded as Treasure on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database, including a fragment of a Middle Bronze Age gold torc (2023T801) that was recovered from Whitchurch, Hampshire (Maslin, 2023); and a fragment of a Middle Bronze Age gold torc (2019T356) recovered from Swanmore, Hampshire (Hinds, 2019).Conclusion: As the hoard is over 300 years old and predominantly gold, the age and precious metal content of the hoard meets the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.Author: Mr Malcolm Adams, Treasure Finds Liaison Assistant for the West Midlands.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description:A fragment of a solid gold penannular ribbon bracelet dating from the Middle Bronze age to the Late Bronze Age, about BC 1150 - BC 750. The fragment is the buffer terminal of a penannular bracelet, which has a plain and sub-circular cross-section at the terminal, tapering to a flat rectangular cross-section. The object is partially cut and partially broken about 10mm from the end of the terminal.Dimensions:The object is 11.98mm in length, 6.33mm in width, 4.55mm in thickness and it weighs 2.44g. The diameter of the terminal end is 6.17mm. The flat end is 6.5mm wide and 1.3mm thick. Discussion: The gold penannular bracelet is characteristic of the British Bronze Age. Objects like this typically have solid bodies and termini (Eogan, 1994, pp. 84-85). The fragment has its closest parallel to NMGW-E48854 on this database which is dated to the Late Bronze Age. That example has a circular cross section to the flared terminal and is similarly flattened beyond this point. Further parallels include IOW-7477D4, DOR-86B8B9 and Fragment 1 from CORN-705C14, which have been paralleled to an example from St Martin's, Isles of Scilly (Tyacke 1993). Further similar examples are also illustrated by Eogan (1994) from Caister on Sea Norfolk (Eogan 1994: pl 13, no. 1) and Berwickshire (Eogan 1994: pl 15, no. 6) all of which are also suggested to date to the Late Bronze Age. This is supported by a bracelet with an expanded terminal being found with a Late Bronze Age socketed axehead at Llanarmon-yn-Iâl in Denbighshire (Green 1983). These are sometimes termed Potterne type bracelets following the publication of a similar bracelet from this site (Taylor 1984).References:Eogan, G. (1994) The Accomplished Art: Gold and Gold-Working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age. Oxford: Oxbow BooksGreen, H. S. (1983).'A late Bronze Age hoard from Llanarmon-yn-Ial, Clwyd', Antiquaries Journal, 63, 384-7.Taylor, J. (1984) The Potterne gold bracelet and its affinities. Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Magazine, 78, 35–40. Available from https://archive.org/details/wiltshirearchaeo7819wilt/page/40/mode/2up?view=theater last accessed 13th February 2023Tyacke, A. (1993). Recent archaeological acquisitions at the Royal Cornwall Museum. Cornish Archaeology, 32, 142-145.
notes: The find contains a minimum of 10% gold and is over 300 years old in date. It therefore appears to qualify as Treasure under the provisions of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A gold penannular ring of late Bronze Age date. The ring is 17.5mm in diameter and has a circular cross section of 6mm diameter, with a gap of 2mm between the flat ends. The ring appears to be solid gold rather than plated as there are no evident cracks or fracturing in the surface which would be expected from corrosion of a copper alloy core. No decorative banding is evident.
notes: These gold penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC). They have variously been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Eogan 1994; 1997; Green 1988), but their function remains uncertain. It is perhaps most likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.  The uncertainties around their use are complicated by the fact that very few are recorded from secure archaeological contexts.They have previously been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). They may well have a longer chronology within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC); however thus far this has been difficult to confirm as few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological context or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A complete Middle Bronze Age gold tripartite penannular ring dating to circa 1300-1150 BC. It is C-shaped in plan comprised of three circular-sectioned penannular rings soldered together. Each terminates in a straight and even break.Discussion: The form is consistent with other examples processed through the Treasure Act including 2021 T762 (Gard 2021) and 2012 T165 (Smith 2012) each of which is dated to the Middle Bronze Age. In those records, it is noted that gold tripartite penannular rings often lack secure archaeological contexts (Meeks, Craddock and Needham 2008: 13) while the appearance associated with the onset of the Bronze Age ‘ornament horizon’ dating to circa 1400-1100 BC, congruent with the Taunton to Penard metalwork phases of the Bronze Age (Roberts 2007: 7).Conclusion: The object contains a minimum of 10% of precious metal. The object contains a minimum of 10% of precious metal and is over 300 years old. As a result, in terms of both age and precious metal content, it satisfies the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.References:Gard, M. 2021. ‘LEIC-88F086’. Available at https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/1037959.Meeks, Nigel D., Craddock, Paul T., & Needham, Stuart P., 2008. ‘Bronze Age Penannular Gold Rings from the British Isles: Technology and Composition’. Jewellery Studies 11: 13-3.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: An incomplete gold lunula found in 2 pieces, dating from 2400-2000BC. It is probably a provincial type (Taylor 1970). The lunula was found in a stream. It may have been eroded from the bank or carried to the place of discovery by the water.  It was rolled up when it was found and the finder unrolled it to see what it was. During the unrolling, one end became detached leaving the object in two pieces, but the terminal (or horn) of that end was already missing and has not been recovered.Description:The lunula weighs 75.6 grams and the additional fragment weighs 3.7 grams. It is flexible, making it difficult to measure precisely. It is approximately 180mm long, 170mm wide and the maximum width of the band is 65.4mm. The metal is about 0.25mm thick in most places.The complete terminal is on the end of a shaft which is 4.5mm wide and 1.3mm thick at the base of the terminal. The terminal is an oval sheet which is folded at each side of the shaft to form a three dimensional D shaped cap. The external face has incised decoration which is perhaps the best preserved of all the decoration on the lunula. It has a double incised line border, flanked by chevrons on both sides. The pattern is repeated in two straight lines across the terminal, on the same alignment as the shaft. Away from the terminal, the plane of the shaft changes by 90 degrees, and it widens and thins into the main face of the lunula. The angled surface expands to 65.4mm wide at the widest point. At the other end is an uneven break that matches the end of the separate piece. The lunula is 26.7mm wide at the break. The narrow end of the separate piece is also broken, and the other terminal is missing.The main part of the lunula is decorated, but the incised lines are very, very faint and only visible in a few places. There are at least 5 parallel border lines along the lower edge which are about 1.5mm away from each other, and the outermost one is 3.0mm - 3.8mm from the edge of the object. The middle two zones of the four created by these lines are cross hatched with incised evenly spaced transverse lines forming a ladder pattern. Inside the border lines are very faint traces of two incised zigzag lines. The pattern of border lines and ladder pattern appears to be repeated, perhaps without the internal chevrons, along the upper edge of the object, but it is only visible in one area.Near the broken end of the main piece is a band of patterning running across the surface of the lunula (38mm from the longest part of the broken end). This pattern is a double incised line flanked by a double zigzag line. It is only visible near the lower edge of the lunula.The centre of the lunula appears to be undecorated. At the more complete end, there are several areas of decoration. 151mm from the complete end is a straight line across the face of the lunula, with a zigzag line or double line alongside, closer to the terminal end. 138mm from the complete end is a zigzag line and then a curving line across the face. Further towards the terminal from that is an area of cross-hatching, and then a zigzag band which is 113mm from the end. There are further zigzags at 85mm from the end, a ladder pattern at 78mm from the end, and next to that, two straight lines across the face and a zigzag line. No further decoration is visible closer to the terminal. The separate piece is sub-rectangular, but wider at one end. It is 43.5mm long, 25.2mm wide and 0.36mm thick. Incised parallel lines are visible along the outer edge and there are outward pointing chevrons along the inside of the edge lines. There is a band of ladder pattern running across the fragment at the wider end. This lunula is extremely worn, with the decoration being hardly visible. It is unclear whether this is owing to the findspot being in running water, which may have caused wear, or whether the lunula’s decoration had been extensively rubbed (perhaps as an act of erasure prior to decommissioning for functional and/or symbolic reasons) before it was rolled up and deposited. Although the lunula is incomplete it is remarkably lop-sided and asymmetrical when compared to the majority of recorded lunulae, especially Irish examples. The left (broken) terminal is clearly longer than the right and the lunula would have appeared ‘off kilter’ if ever worn. A similar feature is evident in the case of the lunula from Tarrant Valley, Dorset (DOR-2198F8). This unusual aspect is the subject of an ongoing study (Wilkin et al. in prep). Scientific analysis was undertaken on the detached piece by a friend of the finder: The results are:Time: 2.5 sec 						Ag			7.04%			0.57%							Au			91.92%			1.16%							Cu			0.29%			0.14%			Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis of the lunula undertaken at the British Museum indicated a surface composition of approximately 91-93% gold, 6-8% silver, with traces of copper. Discussion:Lunulae are flat gold crescentic ornaments with spatulate terminals. According to Needham (2000) they may largely overlap primary Bell Beaker goldwork, and date from about 2400-2000BC. There are only 4 other lunulae recorded on the PAS database: DUR-44A99A (terminal only), DOR-2198F8, DUR-A24C08 and LANCUM-449151.DUR-A24C08 records that: "Finds of Bronze Age lunulae are very rare from Britain although they are a slightly more common find in Ireland. A lunula was found near Thwing, East Yorkshire in 2012 (British Museum Reg 2015, 8031.1.a-b; Treasure case 2012 T811). Examples from Britain are known from the West of the country, there are three in the National Museum of Scotland (X.FE.1, X.FE.3 and X.FE.4) which are from Western Scotland and one (X.FE.2) which was found in Northern Scotland. There are also several Irish examples in the British Museum such as the Blessington lunula (WG.31) [...]."DUR-44A99A reports that "Lunulae are described as crescent-shaped flat plates with a sub-rectangular expansion at each end constituting the terminals, the latter being usually turned at right angles to the plane of the body and thus enabling the collar to be fastened (Eogan 1994, p30). The excellent condition of many recovered examples indicates they were cherished and cared for objects, possibly worn to symbolise power or rank and perhaps used in religious practices (ibid, 34). It is suggested that since few are found in association with graves lunulae may have been owned collectively by groups or clans rather than being personal property, while the style and form of decoration is indicative of close links to the Beaker period in the later Neolithic and early Bronze Age, c.2400-2000BC (Taylor 1980, p28; Eogan 1994, p33). Wiseman and Roberts, (2014, p359) characterise the period  as the “chalcolithic / early Bronze Age (c. 2500-1500 Bc) phase of gold-working in England and Wales” where sheet metal-working techniques were used to produce a range of objects. Lunulae were themselves manufactured by the beating out of an ingot or rod, demonstrating considerable skill, with the thickness of the resulting sheet, applied decoration, and geographical distribution determining the tripartite classification of the lunula as defined by Taylor (1980, p25; Eogan 1994, p30)."Taylor (1970) has created three classes of lunula and this example is likely to be of the provincial linear type. The provincial type of lunula is made of slightly thicker foil and is narrower than the classical type of which the Blessington lunula (https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/H_WG-31) is an example. Having said that, the thickness of this example is approaching that of some Classical types, and is thinner than some provincial types. However, allowing the for extremely worn state of this example, and the findspot, it is more likely to be a provincial type.DUR-44A99A goes on to say "Classical and Unaccomplished lunulae are the most numerous known, and are finely (often symmetrically) decorated with the sheets of gold beaten out very thinly. The majority have been found in Ireland, with only a handful of Classical examples being recovered in Cornwall; no Unaccomplished lunulae have been found outside of Ireland (Eogan 1994, p30-1). Provincial lunulae, as the name suggests, “form a cohesive group by their geographical isolation from the other two” being found (with isolated exceptions) solely outside of Ireland (Taylor 1980, p33 and 40). More specifically, Provincial forms are also thicker, thus more rigid, and more sparely decorated. Taylor (ibid) classifies two decorative variations: the dot-line, and the linear."
notes: This object is prehistoric and is made of gold, and thus appears to meet the requirements of the 1996 Treasure Act.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description:This is a circular sheet of gold disc decorated with a single dotted line along the edge and three concentric impressed circles within this. In the centre of the item are two circular holes. Discs of this type are sometimes referred to as ‘sun discs’, owing to their apparent symbolic significance in relation to solar imagery (Cahill 2015). Sheridan and Needham (2014, 908) prefer the more neutral term ‘flat disc’ and that is maintained here. Discs of this type belong to the earliest group of gold (or indeed metal) objects found in Britain or Ireland, dating to c.2400 - 2200 BCE and form an important group within the ‘primary Beaker goldwork’ tradition (Ibid, 908).Dimensions:Diameter: 18 mmThickness: <1 mmWeight: 0.39 gDiscussion:Early gold flat discs are rare in Britain. The Arreton disc is the tenth to come to light to date. Their distribution is primarily southerly: five (from three separate findspots) from Wiltshire, one from Kent, (this) one from Isle of Wight, with the outlier being a single find from the Isle of Man. The decoration of the Arreton find is of the ‘concentric and dot’ variety (as defined by Sheridan and Needham 2014, 907, fig. 5a-c). Of the ten known discs, the circle and dot motif found on the Arreton find is the most common (it is found on five others) (Table 1).									Findspot									Decorative type													Banc Tynddol, Cwmystwyth, Ceredigion 									Circle and dot 													Cobham, Kent									Circle and dot 													Longbridge Deverill, Wiltshire									Circle and dot 													Arreton, Isle of Wight [this find] 									Circle and dot 													‘Kirby Cane, Norfolk’									Circle and dot 													Farleigh Wick, Wiltshire (1 of 2)									Cross motif													Farleigh Wick, Wiltshire (2 of 2)									Cross motif													Mere, Wiltshire (1 of 2)									Cross motif													Mere, Wiltshire (2 of 2)									Cross motif													Kirk Andreas, Isle of Man									Concentric dot circles						Table 1: British flat discs by decorative typeConclusion:On balance of probability, the item is more than 300 years old and as it is made of over 10% precious metal, it appears to meet the criteria for 'Treasure' under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.References:Cahill, M. 2015. ‘Here comes the sun… Solar Symbolism in early Bronze Age Ireland’, Archaeology Ireland, 29 (1), pp. 26-33.Needham, S. & Sheridan, A. 2014. ‘Chalcolithic and Early Bronze Age goldwork from Britain: new finds and new perspectives’, in H. Meller, E. Pernicka & R. Risch (eds), Metals of Power: Early Gold and Silver. Proceedings of the 6th Archaeological Congress of Central Germany. Halle: Landesmuseum für Vorgeschichte Halle (Tagungen des Landesmuseums Band 11/2), pp. 903–41.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: Thin gold strip probably dating to the Bronze Age. The strip has parallel sides, narrowing towards the ends, which finish in a curve. It is folded over at one end and then back on itself, which would add another 10mm to the overall length if straightened. The other end is not folded. The finder has already straightened this out somewhat, it originally had more bends in it. It is not broken though and the shape at the ends suggest that it is complete. There is some distortion to the shape but no breaks.Dimensions: Diameter: Length 65mm long and 4.5mm wide, up to 1mm in thickness. It weighs 3.73g   Discussion: Parallels also find in isolated contexts exist on the database, such as BH-DE3D16, DOR-52C762 and CORN-8EC344 which are often dated to the Bronze Age due to parallels which have a pattern of parallel lines on them.However these are paralleled with similar plain gold strips found in association with Bronze Age objects. This includes a gold securing strip, with perforated folded terminals, from a gold armlet or cuff found in the hoard from Capel Isaf, Manordeilo, Carmarthenshire, and illustrated in Savory (1980: 195, fig.47, no.1), which is now dated from the Middle Bronze Age c.1600-1400 BC. The colouring and shape also closely resemble an example excavated near Llanwit Major in 2008 (NMGW-09A1A5), now in the collection of Amgueddfa Cymru, which was found in association with fragments of middle Bronze Age pottery dated to 1500-1150 BC (Middle Bronze Age gold strip - Collections Online | Museum Wales). This example also has rounded and which have been folded but it has holes pierced at these ends, which the example under discussion does not have. Stylistically though both examples are very similar and there is no reason not to conclude that the example here is not of the same period.Conclusion: The object appears to have a composition of more than 10% precious metal and is probably at least 300 years old; it therefore meets the criteria for consideration as Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Complete Bronze Age handmade gold spacer bead, c.2500-1200 BC.A cylindrical gold spacer bead made from a rectangular piece of metal curled into a tube, 17 mm in length, 4-5 mm in diameter and 0.68 g in weight. The two ends of the metal sheet overlap down one side. The outside is decorated with 15 fine incised lines running around the circumference which create a ridged surface. The openings at either end have thickened rims (c.1 mm thick) and the bead has an internal diameter of approximately 5 mm.See HAMP-86FED0 for a similar example.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A folded fragment of a gold band or ribbon with repousse linear ribs of probable Bronze age date c. 2100 BC - 1150 BC.Description: the rectangular fragment has been folded twice into three layers. Unfolded it would have been approximately 20mm x 16mm. The visible long broken edge is split in three places, the edges folded inward with fresh breaks. The short side edges appear less ragged and possibly represent the original width of the ribbon. The ribbon is decorated with 19 or 20 repousse plain linear ribs, running vertically from the long edges of the folded fragment. Broadly halfway down each rib on both sides of the fragment is an interruption in the moulding, creating a horizontal impression; possibly where the strip has been previously folded and straightened. The strip is very thin and the impressions of the ribs are visible on the reverse of the strip. The finder has undertaken portable XRF analysis which indicated it was 16.5ct. This would be 66% gold with the rest being silver and other traces elements. Measurements: length: 16.65mm; width: 9.01mm; thickness of folded object: 3.72mm; thickness of strip: 0.35mm and weight: 0.72g.Discussion: The linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date including examples from The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Palmer 1980). The find from The Hamel, Oxfordshire, came from the same layer as typologically late Beaker pottery dating to the Early Bronze Age. Other similar examples have also been reported through the Treasure process see: 2011 T459 (LIN-946F12); 2014 T777(HAMP-36C41B) and a similar folded example: 2012T926 (LVPL-34D297). However, many of these examples are much thicker with the ribs present on one side. For thinner parallels see 2010 T664 (LVPL-83FE92) which is of a similar thickness with ribs visible on the reverse.  Also compare : 2020T516 (SWYOR-DBF058) and  2017T42 (LVPL-25FCB6). The former notes that embossed (repousee), rather than incised decoration makes an early Bronze Age date seem more likely, but a date in the middle to late Bronze Age cannot be entirely discounted.
notes: As the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal and was over 300 years old at the time of finding it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: TREASURE CASE : 2023 T707.Description: An incomplete gold object, probably a basket ornament generally described as earrings or hair tresses, of early Bronze Age date, c.2500-2200 BC.The object comprises a thin sub-circular sheet of gold with projecting triangular loop to one edge. The sheet has been folded four times in a concertina style and the loop is folded over on to the sheet. The object appears undecorated. A cross shaped indentation is present where the loop meets the body of the object though this appears to be the result of damage rather than a deliberate addition to the object. Dimensions:Length: 10.6mm; Width: 21.8mm; Thickness: 4.3mm; Weight: 2.1g.Discussion: Similar objects have been recorded as GLO-92912E (2019 T537), LON-FF7E65 (2018 T386) and BERK-F548E6 (2015 T72). This class of object belongs to the earliest phases of metallurgy in Britain (Taylor 1980: 22; Needham and Sheridan 2014: 907). They are usually associated with burials and are very rare, dating to the earliest phase of the Bronze Age, c. 2500-2200 BC. Such objects are referred to as 'basket ornaments’ with the initial suggestion that they formed earrings (Butler 1963: 188; Eogan 1994: 15) but have also been suggested as hair ornaments (Sherratt 1986) to be slid on to plaits. They are in any case personal ornaments and have been found in pairs in graves dating to the early Beaker period. Needham’s reappraisal of the forms of these items has placed this shape to Group A (Needham 2011: 383, fig 44) and list six known examples and one further possible example (ibid: Table 22).Conclusion: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold-plated copper-alloy or iron penannular ring of Late Bronze Age date (c.1150-800 BC).Description: The object is broadly circular in plan and broadly oval in cross-section, wider at the midpoint and narrowing towards the transverse terminals. The object is plated in pale gold with yellow gold stripes creating a repeating pattern of alternating rings which encircle it. A circular-sectioned iron rod links the terminals.Measurements: diameter: 19.6mm; width: 7.7mm; thickness: 6.6mm; weight: 12.84gDiscussion: The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980, Eogan 1994, 1997, Hobbs 2003, Meeks et al 2008 and O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.A recent scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). This particular example comes under their ‘Type 3d gold foil plated copper alloy ring, with silvery gold wire inlay’ and analysis of a similar one in the British Museum collections suggests that the technical skill involved in creating the fine silver-rich gold striped effect on the surface was highly complex.A number of this type of penannular ring have been reported to the PAS and declared treasure in recent years, including PAS-011055 and BM-BEFAF7.CAM-5B1D08 also has an iron core and is therefore given a later date range of c.1150-800 BC. Conclusion: It is therefore likely that this object was at least 300 years old at the time of discovery and, as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, therefore constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: An incomplete sub-rectangular pierced strip of flat sheet Bronze Age gold (c. 2200 – 800 BC). The strip is crumpled, folded, and broken into three pieces. One end appears complete yet crumpled and appears to have one deliberately pierced hole near the centre, the other end has been cut or broken off with one deliberately pierced hole through the top corner. All other holes through the ribbon appear to the result of damage rather than deliberate. The ribbon is decorated with at least ten horizontal ridges. The lines are all parallel to each other, possibly made with a comb or similar tool. There may be more decoration, but it is not visible due to the amount of damage the ribbon has sustained. Length 55.86 mm, width 13.08 mm, thickness 2.57 mm and weight 1.99 g.Similar multi-grooved strips of a Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire, and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48). There is also a similar grooved strip from The Hamel, Oxford, Oxfordshire excavated from a layer which yielded Beaker pottery of the Early Bronze Age (Palmer 1980, 124-134). Similar objects have also been recorded on the PAS database and reported as Treasure; LVPL-BBA759 (2022 T1057) WMID-804501 (2021 T768) and LIN-946F12 (2011 T459). Therefore, this item is more than 300 years old and composed of more than 10% precious metal, and therefore should be considered Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of Early Bronze Age dating (c. 2350 BC to c. 2050 BC).Less than 25% of the flat axehead is present, consisting of the butt of the axe head. The flat axe fragment is broadly sub rectangular in shape with a rounded butt. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with slight tapering edges. The butt is relatively thin having a narrow rounded profile; the width at the butt is 26.8 mm (thickness: 2.7 mm). The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the butt to the midpoint; in shape they are relatively straight. The axe is thickest at the mid point (9.0 mm), with no traces of a proto stop ridge present. It measures 56.1 mm in length, width at the butt is 26.8 mm and it has a maximum thickness of 9.0 mm. It weighs 60.3 grams.The axe is a mid to dark green colour, with an uneven surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the ploughsoil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface detail.The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to (although not containing all the attributes of Migdale axes (many of these tend to have narrower butts which flare at the cutting edge). These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Reference:Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp121-140Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.46-47.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold penannular ring of late Bronze Age date. The ring is 21mm in diameter and has a circular cross section of 6.7mm diameter, with a gap of 2.4mm between the flat ends. The surface is banded yellow gold and silver or white gold. The ring is gold plated with a copper alloy core; the plating is complete but has patches of copper alloy corrosion and cracking from expansion of the core as it corrodes.
notes: These types of gold penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC). They have variously been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Eogan 1994; 1997; Green 1988), but their function remains uncertain. It is perhaps most likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange (see debate in Armbruster 2021: 191-196). The uncertainties around their use are complicated by the fact that very few are recorded from secure archaeological contexts.They are given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13). Gwilt (2015) suggests (citing Raftery 2004, 87-8) that, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing such that these items may be placed within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC).A recent scientific analysis of penannular rings categorised the rings into four broad types based on their components and decoration (Meeks et al. 2008). This particular example comes under their ‘Type 3d gold foil plated copper alloy ring, with silvery gold wire inlay’ and analysis of a similar one in the British Museum collections suggests that the technical skill involved in creating the fine silver-rich gold striped effect on the surface was highly complex.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A short length of a Bronze Age gold twisted torc or bracelet with four flanges arranged as a cruciform or X shape in cross-section. It dates from about 1400 - 1150 BC. Both ends have been cut on an oblique angle, probably using a single blade (rather than opposed blades) and the flanges are therefore distorted an flattened at either end. The fragment is 18.1mm long, 6.7mm diameter and 2.6g.A close parallel is BH-149F18 (2014T25), the record for which suggests that the fragment can be dated typologically to the Taunton metalwork phase (c.1400-1250 BC), or more probably the Penard metalwork phase (c.1300-1150 BC), of the British Middle Bronze Age.BH-149F18 goes on to note that: "Gold working in Britain at this time is dominated by the casting of bars and ribbons and techniques as twisting and flange twisting comparable to this find (see Murgia et al. 2014). Similar torc fragments have been recorded as Treasure on the Isle of Wight (2011 T501) and at Langtham, Essex (2014 T698), while two complete flange-twisted torc were found as part of the Crow Down hoard (2004 T348; see Varndell et al. 2007) and one was part of the Wrexham hoard (2004 W2). Other similar (complete) torcs are known from Hampshire: from Christchurch, Blackwater (Taylor 1980, Ha 2; Eogan 1967 n. 41) and from Ropley (Taylor 1980, Ha 6; Eogan 1967 n.43)."
notes: The object is comprised of precious metal and is of prehistoric date; however it was found prior to the commencement of the 1996 Treasure Act. As such, its legal status is subject to the common law of Treasure Trove in place at the time. In order to be Treasure Trove, evidence has to suggest that a find was buried with the deliberate intention of future recovery. As a single find it is not possible to be certain on the balance of probability that the item was buried with the intention of retrieval rather than a casual loss. As such it fails to meet the criteria and therefore appears to be Not Treasure Trove.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being declared not Treasure

description: An incomplete copper alloy flat axehead, probably dating from the Early Bronze Age period (c. BC 2350 - c. BC 2050). The axe is broadly rectangular in plan with a slightly splayed crescentric blade. In profile and in section the object is broadly lentoid.The sides of the axe gently taper outwards with a shallow curve, from the rounded butt to the blade. The curve is less shallow towards the blade.
