description: Description: Penannular circular ring of late Bronze Age date, apparently made of gold throughout. The ring is almost circular in cross-section, with a flat facet around the interior. The ends are cleanly made across the thickness, forming a straight narrow gap 1.8mm wide at most. The ends are neat and flat, but cracked slightly implying that the gold may be a thick plating over a core of different material. The ring flares slightly in thickness, from 4.2mm wide and 4.8mm thick at the ends to 4.6mm wide and 5.1mm thick in the centre. The gold is an even colour all over the surface including the ends. Dimensions: With the gap in the ring held uppermost, the length from the gap in the ring to the other side is 14.5mm. Perpendicular to this, the width is 15.4mm. The maximum thickness is 5.1mm; the central hole is 6.2mm in diameter. It weighs 5.39g.Discussion and Date: Similarly proportioned, evenly coloured penannular rings are also recorded at BH-B85122 (2021T906), SUSS-42C974 (2021T174), two from IOW-9F0C84 (2020T2) etc. Although they have in the past been called 'hair-rings' or 'ring-money', their function remains uncertain (see for example discussion in Armbruster 2021: 191-196).There are now around 150 recorded on the PAS database, with a distribution focused on central southern England. They have until recently been given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC, based firstly on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly on Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13).Gwilt suggests, in discussion of an example recorded at NMGW-04216C (citing Raftery in Roche et al 2004, 87-8) that, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing, to the extent that these items may now be placed within a wider date-range encompassing the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC).
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.ENF152742
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Treasure Case 2022 T1119Gold foil sheet, probably Early Bronze Age in date c. 2400-2200 BC.The gold sheet is flat and drop shaped with a triangular projection or tang at the apex that terminates with an old break. One face carries two longitudinal rows of circular punchmarks decorated along one length of the sheet. The punchmarks appear on the reverse as small circular bosses. The object is battered and incomplete with cracks and a torn area.MeasurementsTotal length: 31.91 mm; Width: 16.49 mm; Thickness: 0.51 mm; Weight: 1.15g; Length of tang: 7.30mm.DiscussionSimilar gold sheets, albeit ones which have a tab projecting from their wider surfaces are recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme including GLO-92912E (2019 T537) and BERK-0D1A05 (2012 T774). Two closer examples with a tab extending from its narrow edge is also recorded LEIC-448088 (2006T154) Each of these objects are referred to as 'basket ornaments’ with the initial suggestion that they formed earrings (Butler 1963: 188; Eogan 1994: 15; Russel et al. 1990: 166) but have also been suggested as hair ornaments (Sherratt 1986; 1987) to be slid on to plaits. They are in any case personal ornaments and have been found in pairs in graves dating to the early Beaker period.The majority of these have tangs extending from their longest side. This is then notable for having a tang extending from its narrowest edge. This is identical to objects illustrated by Taylor (1980: pl.3h-j) and Armbruster (2021: fig. 107) which both group these with similar basket shaped objects. Needham’s reappraisal of the forms of these items has placed this shape to Group A (Needham 2011: 383, fig 44) and list six known examples and one further possible example (ibid: Table 22).  At the time of Taylor’s summary only one example of this form was known from the British Isles at Dacomet (Taylor 1980: 22) – now known as Benraw (O’Connor 2004: 2008) and this was suggested as originating from the Iberian peninsula. This is now disputed (O’Connor 2004: 208) and when combined with further examples found from Gilmorton (Needham and Sheridan 2014: 906-7) may suggest a local origin.Regardless of origin these items are also suggested to date to the earliest phases of metallurgy in Britain and into the beaker period (Taylor 1980: 22; Needham and Sheridan 2014: 907). These are usually associated with burials and are very rare, dating to the earliest phase of the Bronze Age, c. 2400-2200 BC.It is the first example of its type recorded by the Portable Antiquities Scheme and is listed as a 'Find of Note'.ConclusionIn conclusion, this object constitutes a prima facie case of treasure by consisting of more than 10% precious metal content in that it is gold and is of an antiquity greater than 300 years
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description:  A fragment possibly from a gold Middle Bronze Age composite penannular ring, dating to c.1300-1100 cal BC.The fragment survives as two strands of gold wire, stacked on top of each other and fused together to produce a ribbed effect.  The wires are a pronounced D-shape, almost triangular, in cross-section, the flat surface being the inner surface of the ring where the fusing of these two pieces can be clearly seen. At one narrow end these wires end in smooth rounded terminals but at their opposite narrow terminals they are truncated by rough transverse break indicating these only represent a portion of the pieces’ original circumference. Similarly, while one wire’s outside edge is smooth and rounded, the second wire’s outside edge is rough with a slight lip indicating it is likely further strands of wire were soldered to this piece which have now been lost.In profile the ring is an irregular curve indicating that it has been warped out of shape since deposition.The ring retains a gold lustre to its surface.Dimensions: In its current state the ring is 16.8mm long, 5.1mm wide, 2.0mm thick and weighs 1.72 grams.Discussion and Dating:  There are a number of parallels on both the PAS database for individual rings of this type.  These include ESS-0068F1 (2005 T495), SWYOR-B50B30 (2015 T364), HAMP-SA5729 (2015 T586) and LEIC-88F086 (2021 T762), all of which are made up of three strands of wire. Penannular rings with more than three strands are less frequently recorded on the PAS database although an 11-strand ring from Kent has been recorded as SUR-1B64F5 (2012 T659).  A 6-strand ring can also be found on the British Museum’s Collections online (WG.19), which is an Irish example with a broad date of c1300-750BC, from Arboe, County Tyrone.Meeks et. al. (2008, 13)  notes that “although small, penannular rings are amongst the most common items of gold to survive from the British Bronze Age, they remain one of the most problematic classes of prehistoric artefacts as they generally lack good contexts or associations with other classes of metalwork, making them difficult to date accurately”. These objects also take several forms with those that are thicker than this example (such as OXON-FFD016, 2020T77) given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997).However, this multibed form made of relatively narrow cords has parallels found in at least three Middle Bronze Age contexts. The first, the Burton Hoard (PAS-5B1745 – Welsh Treasure case 04:02), includes a composite gold penannular ring formed from three round-sectioned wires which have been fused together, with simple clipped or cut terminals. The Cirencester Hoard (BM-28B710 – 2004 T416) includes two double penannular rings and a fragment of a third. Finally, the Granta Fen hoard (British Museum Accession No. 1884,0520) includes several multistranded penannular rings looped around a gold bracelet which was found with an incomplete rapier. Each of these hoards have been dated to the Middle Bronze Age (c1300-1150 BC) based on the range of chronologically diagnostic artefacts within them which would suggest this form may be dated to this period.Conclusion: The ring appears to consist of more than 10% precious metal and at the time of finding was more than 300 years old, it thus qualifies as Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete Middle Bronze Age gold penannular ring.Description: A complete Bronze Age gold penannular ring. The object is sub circular or oval in shape. There is a clear join in the loop where the loop is thinner. One side is plain and undecorated. One face or side of the object is smooth and the other has a rough surface and small amounts of rough gold fragments on the surface. This appears to be the scar left from the detachment of another matching ring that would have been soldered in place. There are examples of multi-ribbed forms of penannular rings such as LIN-B62849.Measurements: Length: 11.60 mm; Width: 9.81 mm; Height: 2.89 mm; Thickness: 2.33 - 2.73 mm and Weight: 2.11 g.Discussion: Penannular rings are a relatively common class of artefact reported through the Treasure Act and are often hard to date, due to being found in both Middle and Late Bronze Age contexts (Meeks, et al. 2008). However, similar penannular rings made of narrow cords have been found in at least three Middle Bronze Age contexts. The first, the Burton Hoard (PAS-5B1745 – Welsh Treasure case 04:02), includes a composite gold penannular ring formed from three round-sectioned wires which have been fused together, with simple clipped or cut terminals. The Cirencester Hoard (BM-28B710 – 2004 T416) includes two double penannular rings and a fragment of a third. Finally, the Granta Fen hoard (British Museum Accession No. 1884,0520.3) includes several multistranded penannular rings looped around a gold bracelet which was found with an incomplete rapier. Each of these hoards have been dated to the Middle Bronze Age (c1300-1150 BC) based on the range of chronologically diagnostic artefacts within them which would suggest this form may be dated to this period.Many penannular rings of this type are composite with copper alloy cores but there is no evidence visually that this is the case with this example. Further examples of two gold or gold-plated penannular rings, stacked one on top of the other, can be found on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database: GLO-A9AD4A (2018T981), LIN-9DC2D1 (2020T693), SOM-4D34ED (2018 T14) and DENO-A13440 (2010 T821).Treasure Conclusion: It is therefore clear that this object is over 300 years old and as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Complete copper alloy flat axe of Early Bronze Age date (c. 2200-1900 BC). This example fits best into the earliest known copper axe and early bronze axes discovered in Britain. These are dated to the Early Bronze Age of metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC.The flat axe is broadly sub-triangular in plan with a broad, rounded crescent shaped blade. The cutting edge has a width of 77.9mm and a thickness of 5.93mm. It is asymmetrical. From the cutting edge the body of the axe gradually narrows in shape and curves inwards. The axe gradually gets thicker in the centre and tapers off towards the butt, creating a broadly lentoid profile with slight tapering edges. The butt forms a curved end that is 43.91mm wide and 6.79mm thick.All edges of the axe are worn and smoothed. The overall surface has a rough dark green patina with patches of dark brown / red. One face presents deep and shallow irregular striations.Dimensions: Overall length 143.05mm; width (widest point) 77.9mm; thickest point 8.53mm; weight 523.5gThis axehead is best described as coming from the later phases of the Migdale tradition (specifically the undecorated variant) dated: 2250-1900 CAL. BC / end of EBA II - III. It is very similar to Needham's flat axe class 3 having a medium sized butt, lenticular profile, no stop and no side flanges (i.e. flat). They are dated to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Treasure case 2022 T1057Description: An incomplete sheet gold strip dating to the Bronze Age (c. 2200-800 BC).The sheet is sub-rectangular in form and flat. One terminal has a straight cut edge, the other is incomplete and crumpled and presents five small punched hole for attachment. The holes have a diameter of less than 1mm. The surface is decorated with a series of incised thin, straight, longitudinal lines with a thickened border along the two edges. The reverse is plain.A tear cuts through a small portion of the body. The object was folded on discovery and subsequently unravelled by the finder.Dimensions: Length 31.12mm; width 14.03mm; thickness 0.56; weight 1.74gDiscussion:A similar object reported as potential Treasure is from Sproxton, North Yorkshire (2010T664; LVPL-83FE92), while further multi-grooved strips of a Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as recent finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48). There is also a similar grooved strip from The Hamel, Oxford, Oxfordshire excavated from a layer which yielded Beaker pottery of the Early Bronze Age (Palmer 1980, 124-134). One further example on the database has also been found in a hoard from Cornwall (2020 T222; CORN-705C14) which has been dated to the Penard phase (c.1275-1150 cal BC following Roberts et al. 2013)
notes: Conclusions:The object appears to have a composition of more than 10% precious metal and is at least 300 years old; it therefore meets the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.  References:Palmer, N. 1980. A Beaker burial and Medieval Tenements in The Hamel, Oxford. Oxoniensia 45, 124-134Treasure Annual Report 2003Treasure Annual Report 2007
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete, gold penannular ring dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC).Description: The ring is formed from a gold rod with a broadly sub-oval cross-section which forms a circular penannular loop with a small gap between two terminals measuring  2.19mm.  The upper surfaces at each terminal end are slightly flattened creating a D-shaped cross section. The object is plain and covered with pitting, dents and scratches on all surfaces. This is a very robust example. Measurements: length: 18.83mm; width: 17.51mm; thickness: 6.82mm and weight: 10.83g. Discussion: There are many examples of these objects recorded on the database and passing through the treasure process including: SUSS-95F65C (2021T821); LANCUM-C2543F (2017T810); ESS-EDCA69 (2019T1068) and OXON-FFD016 (2020T77) which notes: this penannular ring appears similar to a class of artefact which have in the past been given various terms such as 'hair-rings' (Eogan 1997) and other monikers such as ‘Ring Money’ (Green 1988) which are now no longer supported (Taylor 1980, 65; Varndell 2001). Their function remains uncertain (Varndell 2001, 516), although it is likely that they were personal adornments (Hobbs 2003 opinion cited, 102-107), possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange'.They are given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800 cal BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and the Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13). Gwilt (2015) suggests (citing Raftery 2004, 87-8) that, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing such that these items may be placed within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC).ReferencesEogan, G. 1997. ‘Hair-rings’ and European Late Bronze Age society. Antiquity, 71(272), 308-320.Green, H. S., 1988. A find of Bronze Age" ring-money" from Graianog, Llanllyfni, Gwynedd. The bulletin of the Board of Celtic Studies 35, 87-91Gwilt, A. 2015. NMGW-04216C: A BRONZE AGE HOARD Web page available at: https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/727558 [Accessed: 11 Mar 2019 09:12:36]Hobbs, R. 2003. Treasure: finding our past. London: The British Museum Press.Meeks, N., Craddock, P., Needham, S. 2008. Bronze Age penannular gold rings from the British Isles: technology and composition. Jewellery Studies 11, 13-30Raftery, B. 2004. Pit 119: Rathgall, Co. Wicklow. In  Roche, H., Bradley, J., Coles, J., Raftery, B. (eds) 2004. From Megaliths to Metal. Essays in Honour of George Eogan. Oxford:Oxbow Books, 83–91Taylor, J.J. 1980. Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles. Cambridge: Cambridge University PressVarndell, G. 2001. Ringing the Changes: when terminology matters. Antiquity 75,  515-516
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description:  A gold ribbon probably of Early Bronze Age date.The object is made of a flat gold sheet that is rectangular in cross section and sub-rectangular in plan, its long edges bowing outwards in smooth convex curves from slightly rounded narrow terminals. There are no clear signs of decoration although the edges on one surface are more scratched than on the reverse almost creating a border. Both surfaces are scratched and worn.  Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis of a gold ribbon from Wanborough, Swindon, indicated a surface composition of approximately 87-89% gold, 10-12% silver, the rest being copper.Dimensions: The ribbon is 75.5mm long, 13.2mm wide, 0.4mm thick and weighs 4.01 gramsDiscussion: There are a number of parallels from the Portable Antiquities Scheme database from Wantage, Oxfordshire(2013 T674), Northfleet, Kent (2004 T326), Brixton Deverill, Wiltshire (2006 T250), Gussage-all-Saints, Dorset (2013 T428) and Roche, Corwall (2014 T39). These ribbons, which lack the ribs seen on those given an Early Bronze Age date as typically suggested to date to the Later Bronze Age (c.1600-800 cal BC). The fragment’s gold content is consistent with Later Bronze Age gold (Taylor 1980:21) which is noted as having 5-18% silver content. Conclusion: The object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A cut fragment of a gold bracelet of suspected Middle to Late Bronze Age date (c. 1400 -750 BC). The fragment is 12.9g in weight and has been intentionally bent into a C-shape. The rod has a circular cross section of 4.4 mm in diameter and is undecorated, with the single remaining terminal being flat. The other end has been hammered and cut. The surface of the gold has faint faceting from hand working.Length: 32.1 mm; Width: 22.3 mm; Diameter: 4.4 mm; Weight: 12.9 g
notes: Found at some point in the 1970s/1980s whilst picking potatoes. Reported as Treasure Trove.A number of fragments of gold rods of similar dimensions have been found in isolation and recorded by the PAS (e.g. KENT-A071A8 (2017T131), HAMP-8AFE65 (2019T1197), SWYOR-CBC05F (2019T849) etc). Whilst dating these individually can be problematic, similar examples are included in a number of Bronze Age hoards including the Fittleworth Hoard (British Museum Accession no: 1996,0902 1996,0902), the Rossett Hoard (Davis 2006) a hoard found on the Isle of Wight (IOW-9F0C84 2020T2, 2018T5 IOW-50D55F) and another example from near Cirencester (BM-28B710 2004T416)The diameter of the rod and the shape of the terminal on this object can also be compared to completer and more identifiable round-sectioned bar bracelets of Bronze Age date (e.g, CAM-08B4E0 (2011 T926), LEIC-A3A9AE and NARC-10B4B1 (2019T1165)). The diameter of the rod is however also comparable to Iron Age torcs such as NLM-605352 (2013T130), although it lacks the characteristic terminals or evidence of twisting typically seen in these later objects.Conclusion: The find is comprised of precious metal and is of prehistoric date; however it was found prior to the commencement of the 1996 Treasure Act. As such its legal status is subject to the common law of Treasure Trove in place at the time. In order to be Treasure Trove, evidence had to suggest that a find was buried with the deliberate intention of future recovery. As a single find it is not possible to be certain on the balance of probability that the item was buried with the intention of retrieval rather than a casual loss. As such it fails to meet the criteria for Treasure Trove.
subsequentActionTerm: Treasure item found pre 1997, so undergoing Treasure Trove

description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of Early Bronze Age dating (c. 2350 BC to c. 2050 BC).The flat axe is broadly sub rectangular in shape with an incomplete rounded shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with tapering edges. The axehead is broken, with the butt end missing. The break is an irregular concave in shape; the width at the break is 37.99 mm (thickness:7.23 mm). The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the break to the blade; in shape they are relatively straight. The axe is thickest at the mid point (11.33 mm), with no sign of a proto stop ridge. The sides of the blade expand to produce a rounded blade edge with an abraded width of 45.59 mm (thickness 7.98mm).It measures 62.07mm in length,  and it has a maximum thickness of 11.32 mm. It weighs 145.65 grams.The axe is a mid to dark brown colour, with an uneven surface patina. One side has a patch of light green corrosion where the surface patina is damaged, possibly from abrasion caused by movement whilst within the ploughsoil, has resulted in a loss of the original surface detail.The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to (although not containing all the attributes of Migdale axes (many of these tend to have narrower butts which flare at the cutting edge).These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Reference:Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp121-140Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.46-47
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A complete copper-alloy penannular ring of possible Bronze Age date, c.1000 – 800 BC.The ring is circular in plan and section with a small gap between two flat terminals.The metal has a mid-green/black patina and is worn. The object is 14.7mm in diameter, 4.7mm thick and weighs 3.1gPenannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC), usually being gold plated around copper cores. They are commonly referred to as 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' but their function remains uncertain. It is perhaps most likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange. The uncertainties around their use are complicated by the fact that very few are recorded from secure archaeological contexts.While the general form of this ring is consistent with such Bronze Age objects, the lack of a gold covering makes it difficult to be certain. This object may be more recent and serve a different function than that suggested.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Description:  A complete Bronze Age gold item of jewellery dating to circa 2,300-800 BC. Now flattened and squashed, the piece is comprised of a cylindrical piece of sheet metal folded in on itself multiple times. The join is overlapping rather than soldered. The external face of the object is decorated with incised horizontal grooves running around the circumference. They cover the entire length of the piece.Length: 15.7mm; Width: 5.6mm; Thickness: 2.4mm; Weight: 0.60g.Discussion: The piece was likely used as an item of jewellery most likely a bead.It is similar to other objects on the database recorded as beads such as 2019T513 (GLO-FE959E), 2019T316 (LEIC-47D0C2) and 2018T876 (SF-AC2907). Their use as beads on a necklace is well illustrated by a complete example in the British Museum (BM 1853,0926.2). Similarly formed beads are also pictured by Armbruster (2021: 133, fig 138-9) which are suggested in Britain to date from the earliest Bronze Age (ibid: 131) to the end of the Bronze Age (ibid: 132) with those in France tending to be primarily Late Bronze Age (see Eluère 1982, 30-31, 168-171). However, stylistically, it has much in common with other Bronze Age sheet metal gold objects often recorded as ribbons including 2021T434 (LEIC-28D5B5), 2007T672 (WAW-C0C0B3) and 2012T577 (ESS-C13B97) attributed to the Early Bronze Age. An Early Bronze Age date would be supported by an in-context that was found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980) in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd -early 2nd millennium BC. One further example on the database has also been found in a hoard from Cornwall 2020T222 (CORN-705C14) which has been dated to the Penard phase (c.1275-1150 cal BC following Roberts et al. 2013).Consequently, a broad Early to Late Bronze Age date is suggested here.Conclusion: The object contains a minimum of 10% of precious metal and is over 300 years old. As a result, in terms of both age and precious metal content, it satisfies the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996. Authors: Dr Phil Hughes, SSCAS, November 2022. With contributions by Dr Edward Caswell, Finds Liaison Officer, OxfordshireReferences: Armbruster, B.R. (2021) Les ors de l’Europe atlantique à l’âge du bronze: technologie et ateliers. Mémoire LIV. Chauvigny, Association des publications chauvinoises.Eluere, C. (2000) Les Ors préhistoriques en France - T2: Tome 2, Les ors préhistoriques. Paris, PICARD.Palmer, N. (1980) 'A Beaker Burial and Medieval Tenements in the Hamel, Oxford', Oxoniensia, XLV 124-225
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold bi-partite penannular ring dating to the Middle to Late Bronze Age c. 1300-800 BC. The ring is comprised of two penannular rings of gold stacked one on top of the other and soldered together. Each ring is sub-circular (oval) in cross-section and sub-circular (oval) when viewed in plan. The terminals are flat one with a crack and another with a lenticular hole with possible void beneath. The external surfaces is scuffed with light scratches. Measurements: The ring is 13.85 mm long, 12.69 mm wide at the gap and 6.46 mm thick. The gap between the terminals is c.2.69mm. It weighs 7.08g. Each of the two individual bands are of equal dimensions.                          Discussion: Penannular rings are a relatively common class of artefact reported through the Treasure Act with bi-partite examples including SOM-4D34ED (2018T14); LIN-9DC2D1 ( 2020T693) and SUSS-42C974 (2021T174). The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Eogan 1994; 1997). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.Relatively few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation, or radiocarbon dating, however, burials in Belgium, northeast France, and The Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations, have suggested a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800BC (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and a longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing. Therefore, on comparative stylistic grounds, the penannular ring may be dated to the Middle or Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC).Many penannular rings of his type are composite with copper alloy cores and the hole and possible void in the terminal suggest this may be the case in this example. ReferencesEogan, G. 1997. ‘Hair-rings’ and European Late Bronze Age society. Antiquity, 71(272), 308-320.
notes: The object is a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content. However, due to the object being of Prehistoric, the presence of any precious metal would qualify this item as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996. Even if gold plated it qualifies as such under the Act.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description: A gold facetted rod probably dating to the Bronze Age.The object comprises a gold facetted bar of hexagonal cross section. The rod is bent, gently curving to 90°'s at one end, and both ends have been cut or clipped at an oblique angle, possibly with shears or nippers. The surfaces are covered with scratches but two small parallel knicks near one end may be test marks to check the purity of the metal. The metal has a yellow gold colour.Measurements: length: 45.18mm; thickness of rod: 4.86mm to 4.43mm and weight: 12.18g.Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis indicated a surface composition of approximately 78-80% gold, 15-17% silver, the rest being copper. Discussion: fragments of silver or gold that have been deliberately cut up, often from items of jewellery such as armrings or bracelets, are often attributed to a Viking date. Similar examples in silver that have passed through the treasure process include: DENO-705A57 (2013T8) and a decorated octagonal rod DUR-DFF172 (2017-T965) and a gold circular sections rod SF-233CD7 (2007T651). However, while gold bar ingots have been attributed to the Viking period the evidence for this dating is thin; the Viking, bullion economy was based on silver and gold is uncommon (Graham-Campbell, 2011, 151—53). Viking gold finds usually consist of rings although the Hebrides (North Uist?) hoard contained bar-ingot and ‘finger’ ingot fragments (Graham-Campbell, 1995, Pl.50a). The assumption that bar-ingots are Viking is based on comparison with silver ingots which are commonly found in hoards and must be challenged.Instead, this fragment may be dated to the Bronze Age. Facetted bar fragments are known from at least two gold hoard dated to this period at as at Fitzleroi Farm, Fittleworth (British museum Accession No. 1996,0902.3) and Cirencester (2004 T416).References: Graham-Campbell, J. 2011, The Cuerdale Hoard – and related Viking Age silver from Britain and Ireland in the British Museum, British MuseumGraham-Campbell, J. 1995, The Viking-Age gold and silver of Scotland (AD850-1100) National Museum of Scotland.
notes: The object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old at the time of finding. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Circumstances of discovery and background to findspot: Found in situ at a depth of 18 inches, whilst metal detecting on pasture during a commercial rally.  A hoard of three complete probably Late Bronze Age gold bracelets dating to 1150-800 BC, packed tightly together, two of which were folded and flattened prior to deposition, and placed to the side of the intact corrugated penannular bracelet. The finder left the soil inside the penannular bracelet for (partial) micro-excavation at the British Museum to enable the decoration and extent of the objects to be fully documented. The area around the hoard was thoroughly searched with a metal detector but no further metal finds were made, suggesting that the hoard was a lone deposit. A magnetometry survey was subsequently carried out at the location to establish whether there was any evidence of other archaeological features indicating past settlement activity in the field. The survey found evidence of possible archaeology including a possible enclosure within which there appeared to be an area of disturbed ground. However, this feature appeared to be relatively modern and not dated to the Bronze Age and therefore not associated with the find. The full report is available from the Wiltshire HER.In the same area is ST98NW641 which is recorded on the HER as a ring ditch visible on aerial photographs. It may be the site of a round barrow or a tree ring as it is within parkland. The only other Bronze Age find recorded on the PAS database from the same area, approximately 20m to the north, is an awl NMGW-8C8316, probably dating to Late Bronze Age.Catalogue of Finds:	Gold bracelet: A penannular corrugated bracelet made from sheet gold, sub-circular in plan. It is made from a band of beaten sheet metal (gold) decorated with four embossed ribs, evenly spaced. In the external furrows of the corrugated sheet, is lined with dot (pointillé) decoration. The upper and lower edges of the bracelet have been turned inwards to form its edges. Both terminals have hooks formed to fasten the bracelet neatly, like a clasp. Some portions of the bracelet are now slightly crushed, possibly due to soil pressure or pre-depositional damage. Dimensions: Penannular bracelet: diameter (max): 65.6mm; height: 41.0mm; thickness: 1.5mm; Circumference (slight distortion): 190mm; weight (incl soil) 165.0g; revised weight (without soil): 32.5g 	Gold bracelet/armlet: A folded, flattened armlet. This bracelet is tightly coiled. It is made from a band of beaten sheet metal (gold) and has been divided horizontally into four sections, each filled with repeating vertically incised/scored lines. The upper and lower edges of the sheet appear to have been bent inwards to form defined rims. On the reverse of the bracelet, the terminal end has been folded back to form a clasp for fastening. The bracelet appears to have been deliberately folded and flattened prior to deposition.            The object x-radiographed to observe structure and condition. Excavation dirt was removed from both ends of the bracelet to reveal the edges in order to estimate its circumference. The dirt was removed using water and IMS 50:50. The more visible of the two edges was measured using cotton string.Dimensions: Bracelet 2: height: 45.1mm; width: 34.8mm; thickness: 12.4mm; weight (incl soil): 54.49g (following partial cleaning): 53.2g; Length (estimated): 394mm 	Gold bracelet/armlet:  Folded, flattened bracelet/armlet. This bracelet is coiled into a spiral of five layers. It is made from a band of sheet metal (gold). The outer decoration is divided into three horizontal panels. The middle section is defined by a embossed narrow ribs. Below this rib is an apparently plain panel, followed by a further embossed horizontal rib. The panels on either side are decorated with vertical lines incised or scored into the gold (cf. bracelet no. 2). The upper and lower edges of the sheet appear to have been bent inwards to form defined rims. On the reverse of the bracelet, the terminal end has been folded in on itself to form a clasp.Object x-radiographed to look at structure and condition. Some dirt was removed from both ends of the bracelet to reveal the edges to estimate its circumference. The dirt was removed using water and IMS 50:50 on cotton swabs under microscopy. The visible (uncrushed) end of the bracelet was cleaned to reveal detail. Dimensions: height: 38.0mm; width: 38.6mm; thickness: 8.2mm; weight (incl soil): 21.84g; weight (after partial cleaning): 21.4g; Uncrushed end Circumference was measured using cotton at 305mm.An exact parallel for the gold penannular bracelet (No. 1) could not be found. However, this bracelet resembles broad sheet penannular corrugated bracelets with coiled terminals: one (part of a mixed copper alloy and goldwork hoard) from Thrisk, North Yorkshire (Needham 1990, fig. 3), a pair from Gelderston, Norfolk, one from the Derrinboy hoard, Co. Offaly (Eoghan, 1994, pl. XI and XII; Taylor, 1980, figs 29a-e), and the broad ribbed bracelet from Dysart, Co. Westmeath (Eoghan, 1994, 60 Fig. 24f). The dating of these objects is difficult to pin down. The bracelet from Thrisk, North Yorkshire, was found in association with a gold ring, three bronze spearheads, a bronze ferrule and a bronze tanged knife. Needham (1990, 263-4) dates the hoard to the Wilburton phase of the Late Bronze Age (c.1150 – 975 BC), based on the lunate opening spearhead. A corrugated bracelet/armlet was associated with bracelets and ‘dress fasteners’ from Heights of Brae, Easter Ross, Scotland, of Late Bronze Age date (c.1000 – 800 BC), although it should be noted that the bracelet/armlet was annular rather than penannular (Cowie 1988, fig. 33). It is also difficult to closely parallel bracelets Nos. 2-3. Although their decoration differs in some details to bracelet/armlet No. 1 (and, indeed, to each other in terms of the detail of the decorative scheme), they are comparable to it in terms of their clasp fastening. The closest parallels for the pair are therefore the same as bracelet/armlet No. 1. It is notable that the circumference of objects Nos. 2-3 differs considerably from No. 1: 394mm and 305mm compared to 190mm. This suggests they may have had different functions, the larger circumference perhaps indicative of decoration intended for a larger arm or worn further up the arm (i.e. not a bracelet). Although use in alternative ways is possible (e.g. as part of head-gear). Nos. 2-3 were treated in comparable ways (and differently to object No. 1): deliberately folded and flattened before deposition. This was possibly to fit the hoard inside an organic container (no trace remaining), as appears to be the case with the Crow Down goldwork hoard, Berkshire (Varndell et al. 2007).  A number of examples of gold strips and bracelets being folded prior to deposition are recorded on the PAS database, which have been through the Treasure process,  including 2018T164 (SOM-A4086B), a rolled gold bracelet from Piddletrenthide, Dorset, dating to the Middle Bronze Age; 2020T480 (DOR-86B8B9) a Late Bronze Age gold coiled strip or bar from Hilton, Dorset; and 2022T736 (OXON-A33005) a fragment of Bronze Age gold bracelet from Pyrton, Oxfordshire.The pointillé decoration in the furrows of the corrugated decoration of bracelet No. 1 is a notable feature of earlier (Early Bronze Age) armlets/bracelets, including Lockington types, although these have an annular form (cf. Needham in Hughes 2000). It is also a feature of the Woolaston bracelets, which combine that technique with embossing (Treasure case 2013 T805), although they are considerably smaller in size and have hook-shaped terminals rather than clasps terminals featured on the Malmesbury find (and on bracelet/armlet Nos. 2-3). It seems most probable that the bracelet (and indeed the hoard) is therefore Late Bronze Age in date. Conclusion: The objects have a minimum of 10% precious metal and are all over 300 years old. Consequently, the hoard qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Authors:Sophie HawkeFinds Liaison Officer for WiltshirePortable Antiquities SchemeNeil WilkinCurator, Dept Britain, Europe & Prehistory The British Museum References: Burnett, L., 2018, PAS record for SOM-A4086B Bronze Age gold bracelet Record ID: SOM-A4086B - BRONZE AGE bracelet (finds.org.uk)Caswell, E., 2022, PAS record for OXON-A33005 Bronze Age gold bracelet fragment Record ID: OXON-A33005 - BRONZE AGE ribbon (finds.org.uk)Cowie, T. 1988, Magic Metal. J., 1980, Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Varndell, G., Coe, D., Hey, G. & Canti, M. 2007, ‘The Crow Down Hoard, Lambourn, West Berkshire’, Oxford Journal of Archaeology, 26: 275-301. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1468-0092.2007.00285.x
notes: Thanks to the finder for allowing the use of his image of the hoard in situ.A magnetometry survey was subsequently carried out by Mike McQueen for the County Archaeology office in order to establish whether there was any evidence of other archaeological features indicating past settlement activity in the field. The survey found evidence of possible archaeology including a possible enclosure within which there appeared to be an area of disturbed ground. However, this feature appeared to be relatively modern and not dated to the Bronze Age and therefore associated with the find. The full report is available from the Wiltshire HER.
subsequentActionTerm: Informed finder that the object should be submitted as Treasure

description: Bronze Age penannular ring. On the surfaces of the terminals there are fine striations but also evidence of layering within the gold. In the centre of each terminal face is a rough semi-circular depression.
notes: As the find occurred in 1987, it falls under the old Treasure Trove Law, where evidence would have to point to the object having been deliberately hidden with the intention of recovery. The ring is most likely to be a casual loss, therefore does not constitute treasure.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being declared not Treasure

description: A penannular ring of circular cross-section with flat terminals showing lapping. The ring has alternate stripes of yellow and paler gold, but this is very worn on the outside. Analysis indicates that the ring is not solid gold; it is therefore likely to comprise gold wrapping over a base metal core.Maximum external diameter 17mm; internal diameter 5mm; thickness 6mm; weight10.08 grams.
notes: The object is a well-known Late Bronze Age type, decorative in character and dating to circa 1150-750BC.Gillian VarndellDepartment of Prehistory & Early Europe20.11.02
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Circumstances of discoveryThe two graves were found during controlled archaeological excavations by the Trust for Wessex Archaeology during the period leading up to May 2002. During the excavation of grave 1289 a large inventory of artefacts were found with the skeleton of an adult male of mature age, who has become known as the ‘Amesbury Archer’. Among the finds were two gold ornaments which under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996 bring the whole grave group into consideration as potential Treasure. The gold ornaments and some of the other artefacts lay near the knees of the deceased. However, in general, objects were found widely disposed around and above the body, mostly in clusters.The gold finds from the second grave (1236) only came to light when soil inside the jaw of the skeleton (again of an adult male: the ‘Archer’s Companion) was being cleaned away in the laboratory. One ornament was inside the other. A number of other finds occurred in the grave.GRAVE 1289DescriptionFor logistical reasons it was decided to leave the whole assemblage at the head-quarters of the Wessex Trust, where it will receive the standard post-excavation care and study. The compiler of this report visited to inspect all the material from grave 1289 with the exception of the flints recovered during processing of soil samples (items 17 & 18).By way of summary, the following were present:						 						Material									Objects									Nos of artefacts													1									Gold									Coiled sheet-gold plates with a spur or tang - often known as >basket earrings=, or >basket ornaments=									2													2									Copper									Tanged knife-daggers									3													3									Pottery									580 sherds of pottery, representing at least five Beaker vessels									5													4									Shale									Belt-ring									1													5									Stone									Archer=s wristguards									2													6									Stone									Anvil-cum-polishing stone, often known as >cushion stone=									1													7									Stone									Small, elongated oval stone - probably a fossil									1													8									Stone									Chalk-bearing fossils									20													9									Iron pyrites									Two complete nodules and 17 fragments from at least one			 more nodule									3													10									Flint									Barbed-and-tanged arrowheads									17													11									Flint 									Blanks for arrowheads									2													12									Flint									Plano-convex knife/striker									1													13									Flint									Knives									5													14									Flint									Scrapers									10													15									Flint									Other tools and utilised flint flakes									5													16									Flint									Flakes and blades - debitage from flint-working									33													17									Flint									Further flint pieces recovered from soil samples, not yet 			assessed in detail									73													18									Flint									Fragments of burnt flint									19													19									Bone									Boar=s tusks, all certainly or possibly trimmed to give 			functional ends or edges									4													20									Bone									Antler (or bone) rods - possible flint-working tools									2													21									Bone									Antler spatula - possible polishing and burnishing tool									1													22									Bone									Bone hammer-headed pin									1													23									Bone									Degraded bone or antler fragment									1													24									Shell									Perforated oyster shell									1										 			 						Total									213						Metal compositionThe metal composition of the two basket ornaments has not been tested, but after inspection the compiler of this report is confident that they are of high-purity gold.Identification The gold basket ornaments are of a known type belonging to the earliest phases of metallurgy in Britain. The type had been recorded from Beaker graves on three previous occasions, two of the finds being from central southern England. In broad terms, these and other types of early gold trinket date between 2500 and 2000 BC.Although the extensive inventory of finds is quite exceptional for a single interment of the Beaker series, none of the finds individually is unexpected. All of the types can be accommodated within the earlier half of the Beaker grave sequence (total sequence circa 2500 - 1700 BC). Pending detailed study, the particular composition of the assemblage points to a date circa 2300 - 2150 BC.GRAVE 1236The quality of workmanship of the Companion’s ornaments seems to be a little better than that of the Archer’s.Metal compositionAgain, the metal composition has not been tested, but Dr Fitzpatrick of Wessex Archaeology is confident that the two ornaments are of gold.IdentificationAs in grave 1289, the ornaments are of the >basket= type. The boar=s tusk and flint implements, although not especially diagnostic, are regular accompaniments at this period.
notes: DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONThere is no doubt that the majority if not all of the finds in the graves were purposeful inclusions, placed in homage to powerful and respected individuals in Copper Age society. In grave 1289 only the flints within items 17 & 18 might conceivably be accidental inclusions at the time of backfilling the grave; all other objects were observed to lie in careful arrangement around the corpse.The objects itemised above as 7-9 require special discussion, since unlike all the others they are not obviously humanly modified. The 1996 Treasure Act explicitly excludes >unworked natural objects (such as fossils, minerals or human or animal remains)= (Code of Practice, clause 11). The fossils should thus be excluded from eligibility. However, a case can be made for including the iron pyrites nodules and fragments, since there is evidence for the recurrent inclusion in Beaker period graves of fire-kits, comprising a flint striker and an iron pyrites nodule. On this basis, the nodules are almost certainly cultural artefacts used for fire-making.Similarly, only the cultural artefacts in grave 1236 are eligible as Treasure: the gold ornaments, the fired clay, flintwork and any modified or utilised animal bones.Dr S.P. NeedhamDepartment of Prehistory & Early EuropeBritish Museum
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description: A folded fragment from a gold bracelet dating to the Middle Bronze Age c.2400-800 cal BC.The bracelet is made from a single flat rectangular shaped gold sheet that has been folded over itself over c.450 degrees to form a squashed warped cylinder. One terminal is obscured by this coiling but would appear to be the same as the visible example. The sheet is pierced by two visible circular holes (c.1mm diameter) placed at the corners of visible terminal.The outer surface of the sheet has incised decoration consisting of 16 parallel lines that run the length of the object taking up its entire width. This creates a ridged design. The reverse is plain although traces of the upper design’s creation are faintly visible.The object is a bright gold colour.Dimensions: In its current state the bracelet is 16.8mm long, 18mm wide, the sheet being c.16.9mm wide, 6.3mm thick in profile, the sheet being 0.7mm thick and weighs 3.90 grams including soil stuck within the coil.Discussion:  Similar gold strips with incised decoration have been found as isolated objects in Hampshire (2019 T866 Hinds 2019, 2019T 513 Adams 2019), Shropshire (2017 T42 Oakden 2017), Yorkshire (2019 T274 Griffiths 2019), Sussex (2018T513 Richardson 2018) Staffordshire (2016 T1039 Gilmore 2016), and Warwickshire (2007 T672 Bolton 2007).One has also been found in a hoard on the database from Cornwall (2020 T222 Tyacke 2020) which has been dated to the Penard phase (c.1275-1150 cal BC following Roberts et al. 2013)Similar narrow embossed strips are also illustrated by Taylor (1980, fig 28a-f) which are suggested to date to the Early Bronze Age.Further multi-grooved strips of Bronze Age date are in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) while an in-context example has been found from The Hamel, Oxford (Palmer 1980) in a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery dating to the late 3rd -early 2nd millennium BC.As such there are a number of parallels spread from across the country that would support this is Bronze age in date, these tend to be suggested to be Early Bronze Age but the Penard dated hoard cited above suggests they may also date later into the Bronze Age.Conclusion:  The object is a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Cast copper alloy flat axe of Early Bronze Age date. The axe is sub-triangular in plan with a wide rounded butt that is 24mm wide, the sides expand out evenly in a gradual concave arch to the cutting edge which is 48mm wide, the blade is slightly convex in shape. The blade bevel is slight and when viewed to the side the axe has a low lentoid profile. The axe has suffered from corrosion that has removed the original patina and left a pitted surface. The axs fits with some of the earliest metal artefacts found in Britain, possibly associated with the Migdale Metalworking tradition. This would date it as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to. These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold penannular 'lock ring' of late Bronze Age date, about 1000 - 800 BC, formed from gold sheets - the weight of the object suggests that these are probably wrapped around a copper-alloy core. The ring is circular and is bi-conical in form. There is a prominent ridge running around the outer edge. Both faces are decorated by circumferential, closely spaced parallel striations, about 20 on each face. Where damaged, there is a split between the grooves. The straight inner face has also split away from the angled upper and lower faces in places. The gap in the penannular ring is 7.6mm wide. The terminals are plain. They were probably once flat, but have become distorted. The ring is now slightly oval. It is 30mm long, 28.4mm wide and 7.5mm thick. 6.7g. X-ray analysis undertaken by the finder indicates a gold content of 85.66%.Compare HAMP-259538 (2022 T138), LANCUM-968995 (2019 T464), SUR-EFB639 (2019 T87), SOM-50218D (Not Treasure) and SUSS-5EA230 (2017 T349).There are now a number of lock rings recorded on the database that have been classified as treasure including HAMP-259538 (2022 T138), LANCUM-968995 (2019 T464), SUR-EFB639 (2019 T87), SOM-50218D (Not Treasure) and SUSS-5EA230 (2017 T349).As with these examples the object can be termed a lock-ring, a distinct class of personal ornament belonging to the Late Bronze Age (Eogan 1969; 1983; 1994; Taylor 1980; Lynch 1991; Northover 1995; Gwilt et al 2005; Needham et al 2007; Armbuster 2021; 212-9). Of the examples recorded to date the majority are formed of gold sheet often shaped around an organic core (La Niece & Cartwright 2009). They have been found primarily in contexts dating to the Late Bronze Age particularly the Ewart Park phase (950-800 cal BC following Roberts et al 2013) (Cowie et al 1991; Eogan 1969, 106-7, 130-46; Needham et al 2008, 43; Northover 1995, 525-9) although there are only a few radiocarbon dates available to confirm this (notably of a hoard recorded on the database NCL-9F9F92; 2005T120; Needham et al 2007, 400; 2008, 43).The intricate technique and quality of workmanship indicated in the making of lock-rings has long been commented upon, despite their small size (e.g. Eogan 1969, 93, Armbruster 2021, 216). This current example appears to be formed of conjoined (probably soldered or possibly heat fused) gold wire. This can be seen on three other lock-rings. The first was reported through the Treasure Act from Leamington, Warwickshire (LEIC-D9CD94 2021 T515); another was found in Eldesborough, Buckinghamshire (Varndell & Watters 2009); and the other from the antiquarian collection of the Rev. William Greenwell now housed in the British Museum but originally collected from Cheeseburn Grange, Northumberland (Eogan 1969: 111 Cat No. 37 / BM Accession Number WG:20). Similar gold wire work can also be seen in a Late Bronze Age gold ornament possibly from Rathfarnham, County Dublin, Ireland (Cahill 2009:102-4 - National Museum of Ireland: object reg. no. NMI W51) and in a composite gold wire ornament from La Rochepot, Burgundy, France noted as unusual, if not unique, in form and dated to the Atlantic Late Bronze Age (Armbruster 2021)Their precise function as personal ornaments remains uncertain (e.g. Taylor 1980, 68–9, Armbruster 2021, 212). For some, they are interpreted as ear-rings (e.g. Armstrong 1917, 29; Savory 1958, 14), the frequency of their occurrence in pairs being used as supporting evidence. Many would now see them instead as used for gathering the hair, hence their name lock-rings (Raftery 1967; Eogan 1969, 95–6; Lynch 1991, 239–41). What is generally agreed, is that they denoted wealth and high-status within Late Bronze Age society.      In Britain, the find-spots for these lock-rings currently concentrate in three zones: firstly, south-west Ireland; secondly, north and west Wales, northern England and southern Scotland; and thirdly, East Anglia and south-eastern England (Eogan 1969, 97, Fig. 2; 1994, 100, Fig. 41).Of about 30 examples of lock-rings on the PAS database, a significant number of these were discovered in hoards with other contemporary objects, as pairs (or more), and/or close to associated objects. While undecorated examples and examples of decorated sheet gold faces are recorded, the conjoined rib formation / decoration seems to be the most common type. References:Armbruster B.R. 2021: Le Ors de l’Europe Atlantique A la’Age du Bronze / Gold from Atlantic Europe in the Bronze Age. Technology and workshops Association des Publications Chauvinoises APC Armstrong, E.C.R. 1917 The Great Clare Find of 1854, Journal of the Royal Society of Antiquaries of Ireland 47, 21-36.Cahill, M. 2009: ‘Working with wire—the functional and decorative uses of gold wire in Bronze Age Ireland, 2200–700 BC’ in Cooney et al (eds) 2009: Relics of Old Decency: archaeological studies of later prehistory. Dublin: Wordwell 91-105Cowie, T., O'Connor, B. & Proudfoot, E. 1991 A Late Bronze Age Hoard from St Andrews, Fife, Scotland: a preliminary report, In C. Chevillot & A. (eds) 2009: Metals and Society; Studies  in honour of Barbara S.
