Oxford, Oxford University Press. pp. 17–46.Savory, H.N. 1958 The Late Bronze Age in Wales: Some New Discoveries and New Interpretations, Archaeologia Cambrensis 107, 3-63.Taylor, J.J. 1980 Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Varndell G. & Watters, J. 2009: BH-8DC056: A Late Bronze Age Gold Penannular ‘Lock’ Ring from Eldesborrough, Buckinghamshire. Web page available at:  https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/269841
notes: The item comprises more than 10% precious metal and was over 300 years old at the time of finding. Additionally it is of prehistoric date and contains a proportion of precious metal. On both counts it therefore appears to qualify as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.This example appears to be the first from Yorkshire recorded on the PAS database.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description:  A practically complete gold ribbon (possibly a finger ring) dating to the Bronze c.2200-800 cal BC.The ribbon is made of a rectangular strip of gold sheet. This is likely to have originally been bent into a circular shape but has since been squashed flat with two sections of the ring being folded over 180 degrees so that each terminal is placed next to the other. Each terminal is broadly flat although one is slightly damaged. Just before each terminal is a circular pierced hole pierced from the outside of the strip to the inside. Each hole is c. 1.2mm in diameter.The sheet has moulded decoration this includes a shallow raised central ridge running down its length. It also has pronounced borders down its long edges which are thicker than the plate and slightly rounded.Dimensions: The object is 27.2mm long, 10.5mm wide and 6.5mm thick in its folded state, although the plate is only 6.8mm wide and c.0.9mm thick. It weighs 1.98 gramsDiscussion:  The strip was found in an unstratified context during metal detecting. It has no decorative or other diagnostic features, and thus it is difficult to assign a date. There are a range of gold strip and ribbon ornaments datable to the British Bronze Age on the PAS database. These include BERK-B58065, BH-1BE953, DOR-173265, NMS-A3603B, SOMDOR-D3E8B7, KENT-34916A. These vary in their decoration, terminal size and sometimes size but often include longitudinal ribs and pierced terminals and all are considered to be Bronze Age in date. A similarly formed gold sheet with central rib and expanded long edges is also illustrated by Armbruster (2021: 97) as part of the Saint-Babel hoard.Conclusion: The object appears to consist of more than 10% precious metal and at the time of finding was more than 300 years old, it thus qualifies as Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description: An assemblage of four copper alloy objects all of potentially Bronze Age date recovered within an area of 100 square metres in the same field corner, with the River Perry running just to the south of the find sport. The descriptions of the objects are as follows:Palstave: Probably of the Acton Park ii/Taunton metalwork style dating to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1400 BC - 1250 BC).The blade is crescentic in plan with the tips of the cutting edge chipped off in antiquity. In profile the object is sub-oval with the widest point being before the stop ridge. There is a clear casting seam along both edges of the object. There are slight bulges on the side just after the stop ridge.The palstave has a U-shaped septum and straight-sided open flanges, which are complete. The septum has a depth of 6.56mm on one side and 5.56mm on the opposing side. Corrosion material adheres to both sides of the septum just before the stop ridge. The butt of the object is complete with a straight edge. The object is a mid-green to light brown in colour, with an uneven surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the plough soil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface.Overall dimensions: 188.06mm in length, 75.01mm in width, 38.17mm in thickness and 660g in weight. No exact parallel for this palstave are illustrated by Schmidt and Burgess (1981) however it contains several features which are all seen on Early/Primary palstaves defined by this study and Rowlands (1976) study of metalwork in the south of Britain including the lack of a loop, flanges which rise above the stop ridge (typically a south western trait but also seen on Early forms e.g. No.776), an expanded nick in the blades (Schmidt and Burgess 1981: 126) width just below the stop ridge and apparently plain decoration. Both studies highlight how dating the origin of these forms is complicated by their rare association in hoards but that their use continues until at least the end of the Taunton phase.Socketed axehead: A late Bronze Age socketed axehead dating to c. 1000-800 BC. This example belongs to the Ewart Park metalworking phase and is of the 'Meldreth' type. The socket mouth is circular sectioned and flares outwards slightly at its upper edge. Below the mouth is a transverse collar, immediately beneath which is a single, D-shaped side loop. The main body of the axe is broadly rectangular in plan, expanding outwards along its length to produce a widely-flared sub-crescentic blade. One of the tips of the blade and the cutting edge are now chipped. A casting seam can be seen around the loop and down the opposing side of the axehead. The object has a dark green patina and patches of corrosion across all faces. Overall dimensions: 107.68mm in length, 47.58mm in width, 27.25mm in thickness and 187.65g in weight. This axeheads’ most distinctive features are the clear facets in its body alongside the widely spaced double collar at an oval shape fluted collar which categorise this as a Meldreth form axehead a type named after examples found in the Meldreth Hoard, Cambridgeshire (Hawkes and Smith 1955: 13). Many similar examples are illustrated by Schmidt and Burgess (1981: nos. 1212- 1252) who date this form from the Wilburton to Ewart park phases of the Late Bronze Age (c.1120-800 cal BC following Roberts et al. 2013). Needham (1990: 43) whilst recognising the type choose to group Meldreth forms within his group D (faceted axeheads). Similar examples on the database are SF-19193A, LANCUM-F46D05, DOR-3F8141 and WILT-A49B7A.Razor: An incomplete Late Bronze Age tanged bifid razor dating to circa 900-700 BC. The tang and all edges are broken. From the base of the handle down the centre of the object on both faces are three, slightly raised ribs. Overall dimensions: 47.31mm in length, 39.10mm in width, 2.19mm in thickness and 10.42g in weight. For comparable examples see PAS records NMS-3FD035, SOM-D64647, LON-9DB207 and CORN-D746F1. These are all identical to example illustrated by Jockenhövel (1980: tafel 10-11) which are categorised as Type Feltwell suggested to date to c. 1120-800 cal BC in the same study.Blade Fragment: A fragment of a copper alloy spear tip or blade fragment dated to the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c. 1000-800 BC). The fragment is lentoid in section and sub-triangular in plan. The blade tapers from a worn break to the tip where the very tip of the blade has broken away. The cutting edges are chipped and worn. There is a central mid-rib apparent on both faces of the blade. The object has a dark green patina with corrosion material adhering to both faces. The object is too damaged to provide further parallels to known types of tools and weapons.Overall dimensions: 50.86mm in length, 22.95mm in width, 6.28mm in thickness and 17.77g in weight. Discussion: These objects have been recovered within an area of intense Bronze Age activity of a potentially ritual nature. Specifically, Treasure cases recovered within the neighbouring parish of Hordley include a middle Bronze Age assemblage of two palstaves (2020 T547), a late Bronze Age hoard of two gold lock rings encased in lead wrapping (2018 T769); a late Bronze Age gold bulla (2018 T343); and two late Bronze Age hoards of socketed axe heads and other associated material (2018 T341 and 2018 T342). This assemblage appears to span the Middle to Late Bronze Age, much like the cases noted above. However three of the objects (2-4) may all be confidently dated from the Wilburton to Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age (c1200-800 cal BC following Roberts et al 2013). The palstave meanwhile typically dates to the Middle Bronze Age although examples are known as “out of time” objects in later hoards (see multiple examples in Knight 2019) such that its inclusion is not anomalous.Thus it is possible that all together these objects relate a legacy of ongoing Bronze Age activity across this location.  Conclusion: As a single find of more than two base metal objects of prehistoric date, this find potentially qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 (Designation Order 2002).References: Hawkes, C.F.C. and Smith, M.A. (1955) Inventaria Archaeologica - An Illustrated Card-Inventory of Important Associated Finds in Archaeology Founded by M. E. Marien?:Great Britain, 2nd set, GB; 9-13 (ten cards). Bronze age hoards in the British Museum. Garraway.Jockenhövel, A. (1980) Die Rasiermesser in Westeuropa: Westdeutschland, Niederlande, Belgien, Luxemburg, Frankreich, Grossbritannien und Irland. Prähistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung VIII?; Bd. 3. München, CHBeck’sche Verlagsbuchhandlung.Knight, M. (2019) Doubtful associations? Assessing Bronze Age ‘multi-period’ hoards from northern England, Scotland and Wales. In: Matthew Knight, Dot Boughton, and Rachel Wilkinson (eds.). Objects of the Past in the Past: The Significance of Earlier Artefacts in Later Contexts. Oxford, Archaeopress Archaeology. pp. 19–41.Needham, S.P. (1990) The Petters Late of Bronze Age Metalwork: An Analytical Study of Thames Valley Metalworking in Its Settlement Context. London, British Museum Press.Roberts, B., Uckelmann, M. and Brandherm (2013) Old father time: the Bronze Age chronology of Western Europe. In: A. F. Harding and Harry Fokkens (eds.). The Oxford handbook of the European Bronze Age. Oxford handbooks in archaeology. Oxford, Oxford University Press. pp. 17–46.Rowlands, M.J. (1976) The production and distribution of metalwork in the MiddleBronze Age in Southern Britain. British archaeological reports 31, i–ii. Oxford [England], British Archaeological Reports.Schmidt, P.K. and Burgess, C. (1981) The axes of Scotland and northern England. Prähistorische Bronzefunde. München, C.H. Beck’sche Verlagsbuchhandlung.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description:  A strip of gold ribbon of probable Bronze Age date c. 2350-800 BC.  The strip is rectangular in shape with a perforation at each end.  It is decorated on one side with 11 grooves that run along the length of the strip.  The other side is plain.  The strip edges are damaged by nicks towards the centre and it is slightly bent in a number of places, including at the ends so the strip does not sit flat on a surface.Dimensions:  L: 73.56mm, W: 14.96mm, T: 0.62mm, Weight: 4.73g.Discussion:  Similar multi-grooved strips of a Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906, 1224.1-2).It is not clear how these gold ribbons were used or what period of the Bronze Age they date to. Eogan (1994), referring to them as ‘Tress’-rings, included them in his discussion of gold working in the c.13th–12th centuries. Examples with one or more perforations that have progressed through the treasure process include 2012 T577/ ESS-C13B97, 2013 T326/ WILT-26F931 and 2020 T581/ HAMP-0FCEE9.Conclusion:  In terms of age, being more than 300 years old, and precious metal content, being of at least 10% precious metal by weight of metal, this find qualifies as Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.References:  Eogan, G. (1994) The Accomplished Art. Gold and Gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300–650 BC). Oxford: Oxbow.Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A complete copper alloy flat axe of Early Bronze Age date (c. 2200 - 1900 BC). This example fits best into the category of the earliest known copper axes and early bronze axes discovered in Britain. These are dated to the Early Bronze Age of metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 c 2350- 2050 CAL. BC.The flat axe is sub-triangular in plan with a splayed crescent shaped blade.  From the cutting edge the body of the axe gradually narrows in form with the upper and lower edges tapering and curving a little inwards to a blunt butt. In section the axe is thicker in the centre and tapers off towards the butt, creating a broadly lentoid profile with slight tapering edges. The butt forms a narrow curved end.All edges and surfaces of the axe are abraded with parts of the surface missing.  About half of the original surface survives on each faces.Dimensions:  90.6mm in length; 62.0mm in width (at cutting edge); 10.2mm thick; 159.7g in weight.See LVPL-4DA982 on the PAS database, in which Heather Beeton notes: 'It is very similar to Needham's flat axe class 3, having a medium sized butt, lenticular profile, no stop and no side flanges (i.e. flat). They are dated to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae'.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A possibly incomplete Middle Bronze Age (c.1300-1150 BC) gold composite pennannular ring, its (presumably originally abutting) ends now bent apart to give the object an elongated C-shape in profile. The object comprises two bands of thick gold sheet, C-shaped in cross-section and hollow to the inside surface, apparently soldered together longitudinally. The ends are slightly thickened and measures 1.3mm in thickness as opposed to 0.8mm thick at the long edges. The object measures 27.1mm in length (original estimated diameter c.20mm), 6.9mm in width, 1.6mm in thickness, 12.7mm in depth and weighs 2.70g.
notes: It is likely the gold sheet was formed around two base metal or organic rods (with a circular or C-/ D-shaped profile) as a cover, perhaps with an additional inner gold sheet. Cf. WILT-788C7B and YORYM-06C5C1. Small penannular rings such are discovered both as single finds and as part of a linked ring set (eg. BM-261FA2) and can be threaded onto wire, bracelets or torcs, etc.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A group of three Bronze Age gold objects, A, B and C. Report by Dr Ed Caswell.Object A: A bent, spiral-twisted ribbon torc dating to the Middle Bronze Age. The object is made of a flat (rectangular cross section) narrow thin gold strip that has been bent out of its original shape. The sheet is mostly straight sided (6.6mm wide, 0.7mm thick) narrowing only close to its terminals which narrow to rounded points folded over 180 degrees to be flat against the plate. The plate appears to have been twisted into a spiral with an unclear number of turns. It would have been then turned into a circular hoop but has since been bent into an irregular flattened shape. The object is a lustrous gold colour with scratched surfaces and soil in some cracks.Dimensions: In its bent, folded state the bracelet is 78.1mm long, c.40.8mm wide and weighs 20.18g. Date: Middle Bronze Age c.1400-1150 cal BC.Discussion: Similar ribbon torcs are pictured by Taylor (1980: fig 42, 44), Eogan (1994: fig 23B, 25). Similar examples were also found in the Priddy hoard (2005T523, SOM-1C2C53). The British Museum also holds several similar examples (Accession numbers 1873,0602.1, 1838,0718.1 and 1857,0729.1). These are sometimes described as Welsh type ribbon torcs (e.g. Taylor 1980: fig 42) and have been found in groups of gold hoards as at Lower Largo, Fife, and Heyope, Powys. Gold ribbon torcs like these are found most frequently in both Ireland and Scotland and are rare in Southern England (Eogan 1983, fig. 25; 1994, 47-79). The damage and distortion to the torc is not unprecedented, even within Somerset: the bracelet from the Edington Burtle hoard, Somerset, has a straightened terminal and appears to have been modified from a larger piece (the relatively loose twists of the Edington piece are also similar to Durley) (cf. Smith 1959, GB44).Object B: The object is made of a flat (rectangular cross section) gold strip that has been bent out of its original shape. At one terminal it has a rectangular terminal which is slightly thin and ragged, possibly suggesting it had been cut. There is a circular hole placed in the middle on the plate just offset from this edge (c1.5mm diameter) that has been punched through the plate. At this point the plate is broadly straight sided 25.7mm wide with slightly thickened edges. After c.23.6mm the plate becomes bent and torn. While it is not clear exactly where, the plate starts to narrow in a slightly convex curve to 6.7mm wide. From this point a rectangular tab or hook projects that is 3.7mm and 1mm thick. This is folded over 180 degrees and ends in a rounded terminal. The object is a lustrous gold colour with scratched surfaces and soil in some cracks.Dimensions: In its crushed state the bracelet is 84.2mm long, 30.6m wide and weighs 17.39 g. Date: Middle Bronze Age c.1400-1150 cal BC.Discussion: The artefact is closely paralleled by two conjoined objects classified as rings (possibly ear ornaments), from Binstead, West Sussex (TAR: 1998-1999, p. 10-11, fig. 3a) Maesmelan, Powys (Green et al 1993) and also from Capel Isaf, Manordeilo (Savory 1980: fig 47, No.1-2). A similar object, classified as a bracelet, has been recorded from Northfleet, Kent (TAR: 2004 T326; PAS: KENT-AAA333) and another from Freshwater, Isle of Wight (2014 T15, IOW-0195D2).In discussing the Kent bracelet, Stuart Needham is quoted as stating that “The prevailing opinion is that these are of Bronze Age date and, if so, they are likely to date to before the middle of the Bronze Age (circa 1500/1400 BC), after which the copper content of the gold rises significantly. A mature Early Bronze Age or earliest Middle Bronze Age date is feasible and would tie in with a similar date for the Heyope ribbon torcs with similar terminals from a hoard in Powys.'Object C: A coiled gold bracelet probably dating to the Middle Bronze Age. The object is made of a rectangular-sectioned narrow gold strip that has been bent out of its original shape. The sheet is mostly straight-sided (9.4mm wide, 1.7mm thick) narrowing only close to its terminals which are squared-off points (1.7mm wide 1.9mm thick), bent over 180 degrees but not folded flat to the plate. The object has been coiled into a spiral over 540 degrees. The object is a lustrous gold colour with scratched surfaces and soil in some cracks.Dimensions: In its coiled state the bracelet is 45.5mm long, c.32.4mm wide, 11.5mm thick and weighs 46.48g.Date: Middle Bronze Age, c.1400-1150 cal BCDiscussion: Similar examples on the database include WILT-1D8478 (2022 T286), BUC-C07E88 (2009T435) one of which is described as a gold ribbon torc, which this is potentially too small in size to be described as, and the second an unclear fragment of uncertain date. The item was found in an area of two further Middle Bronze Age ornaments so the former interpretation is likely for this object.
notes: The find contains a minimum of 10% gold and predates 1722. It thus qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of precious metal content and age.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: DescriptionPenannular ring comprising a gold wrapping over a base metal core (this was tested by radiography). Alternate light and darker gold stripes can be seen but the exposed surfaces are very worn. The ring is circular to a slightly flattened oval in section with a slight taper towards the flat terminals. The gap between the terminals is filled with a concretion which has partly invaded the central void.
notes: IdentificationA well known type of ornament of Late Bronze Age date, circa 1150-750BC.Gillian VarndellDepartment of Prehistory & Early EuropeThe British Museum
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: DescriptionThe object is a fragment of a parallel sided strip, or ribbon. One end is neatly squared, apparently in its original form. The other shows a ragged break and has also suffered some thinning, perhaps from hammering. Prior to buckling from damage, the back would have been flat, while the front carries sixteen very finely executed grooves aligned longitudinally.
notes: IdentificationThis object cannot be identified with total certainty, but similar multi-grooved ribbon ornaments of Bronze Age date and of varied sizes are known from north-west Europe; this provides the most likely cultural background. Narrow-ribbon ornaments from the Saint-Marc-le-Blanc hoard, Brittany, have fewer and correspondingly broader ribs/grooves. They are finer on an earring from Saint-Père-en-Retz (Loire-Atlantique) and finer still on some Irish Bronze Age ornaments. Among the latter are examples in two important associations, from Saintjohns, Co Kildare, and Derrinboy, Co Offaly. The Derrinboy pieces have enhanced ribs along the long edges not present on the Fontmell Magna fragment. Good parallels are harder to find in Britain, but there is a similar grooved strip from The Hamel, Oxford, excavated from a layer which also yielded Beaker pottery of the Early Bronze Age. Three gold grooved strips from Scottish grave finds which served as pommel mounts for Early Bronze Age daggers are crafted differently and may be less relevant.ConclusionThis object is predominantly of precious metal, is almost certainly over 300 years old and potentially of archaeological interest both locally and for broader stylistic studies.Dr S.P. NeedhamDepartment of Prehistory & EuropeBritish Museum
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: A broken fragment of a gold ingot, 13 mm in length, 8 mm wide, 2 mm thick and weighing 2.46 g.Probably from the Bronze Age, c.1600-800 BCThe fragment has ragged breaks at both ends and a sub rectangular to trapezoidal cross section, with irregular edges characteristic of being hand worked; one edge being bevelled and the other recessed with a concave centre line. The surface is undecorated.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Gold ingot fragment from the Bronze Age, c.1600-800 BCA single cylindrical fragment of solid gold which appears to have been snapped at one end and flattened then cut at the other. The surface is slightly scratched with some abrasions and slight indentations, but otherwise smoothly finished. The “damage” may well have been caused by being buried. Dimensions: Length: 26 mm; diameter: 6 mm, widening to 7 mm, weighing 8.51 g.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Circumstances of discoveryThe large group of gold and bronze artefacts described here were found between September 2004 and December 2005, initially by metal detecting, later by a combination of excavation and metal-detector survey. Most finds were made within a zone  25 x 10 metres in extent with just a few further away, up to  40 m. The finds circumstances are fully dealt with in Gloucestershire County Council?s preliminary report (Barrett & Vallender 2005); in summary they can be broken down into six groups:	Thirty-five objects were initially found before any archaeological involvement (nos 1-35); the finds were between 1 and 50 cm deep. Finder marked the positions of twenty-one findspots with pegs ? these were later surveyed in by GCC archaeologists.	Fifteen relevant objects were among those recovered during archaeological excavation of a 10 x 3 m trench in December 2004 (nos 39, 41-42, 44-47, 50-55, 57-58). One gold fragment (no 52) was later found to belong to one of the initial discoveries (no 31).	Following the excavation, but before the associated survey, Finder recovered a further two objects (nos 37, 43); no positions were marked, but they were reported to come from the area of the main scatter.	The archaeologically monitored gridded metal-detector survey, covering a zone 70 x 30 m roughly centred on the excavated trench, recovered a mixed assemblage of finds including three relevant to the Bronze Age deposit (nos 40, 48-49). Find no 40, furthest away from the main concentration proves to join no 16; however, it is not known whether the latter is one of the plotted initial finds.	Three more objects were submitted to the Corinium Museum by metal detectorists on 22 February 2005. These were reported to have come from an area about  40 m to the south of the main concentration, adjacent to a ploughed out field boundary on a NE-SW axis (nos 36, 38, 56).	Finally, object no 59 was later submitted by Finder, said to have been found in the same area, but the location has not been reported.Descriptions[Objects are gold unless otherwise stated]	Bronze awl or punch. Complete stout double-ended tool, both ends tapering to rather bullet-like tips. The shank section is round close to the ends, but mainly square with body angles locally faceted. Length: 40.1 mm; width: 4.9 x 4.5 mm; weight: 5.0 g	Bronze awl or tracer. Complete; slender rod mainly of square section, but becoming more round at pointed end. Maximum width lies closer to presumed butt end, which was likely wedge-shaped before patina loss locally. Length: 45.4 mm; width 3.1 x 2.9 mm; weight: 1.6 g	Torc trumpet terminal fragment. Gradually expanding torc terminal of round section, the flattish end having a slightly dished centre. Other end bifacially cut then torn; associated bend is probably part of the original tight turn to the hoop. Length: 50.0 mm; diameter 7.4 x 7.7 mm; weight: 14.5 g	Bar-twisted ornament fragment ? torc or bracelet. Medium-thick bar of trilobate section, evenly twisted except close to one break where plain round section and bend suggest beginning of recurved terminal. Both ends torn. Length: 40 mm; unfurled length: c.110 mm; diameter: 3.8 mm; weight: 11.2 g	Flange-twisted torc fragment. Piece of hoop of cruciform (?four-flanged?) section. Roughly coiled (secondary), the tighter bends distorting otherwise neat twisting. Flange crests neatly flattened up to 0.7 mm wide. Both ends bifacially chopped. Coil diameter: 31 mm; unfurled length c. 120 mm; bar diameter:  6 mm; weight: 17.7 g	Flange-twisted torc fragment. Piece of hoop of cruciform (?four-flanged?) section. Flange crests flattened up to 0.7 mm wide. Fairly evenly twisted except where compressed at the two bifacially chopped ends. Length: 29.1 mm; bar diameter: 7.2 mm; weight: 6.1 g	Twisted-rod fragment with trumpet terminal. Irregular, secondary coil of fairly thin rod of trilobate section, twisted tightly and neatly. Becomes plain round-sectioned for last 32 mm, expanding very gradually to near flat end ? ie a trumpet terminal. Stress fractures suggest terminal originally recurved relative to hoop. Broken end torn. Coil diameter: 34.5 mm; unfurled length c. 250 mm; terminal diameter: 2.3 mm; hoop diameter: 1.7 mm; weight: 7.8 g	Twisted-rod fragment. Irregular, secondary coil of fairly thin rod of trilobate section, twisted tightly and neatly. Fine cracks along furrows. Both ends torn. Coil diameter: 20.0 mm; unfurled length: c. 115 mm; rod diameter 2.0 mm; weight: 4.2 g	Twisted-rod fragment. Irregular, loose coil (secondary) of thin rod of trilobate section, twisted tightly and neatly. Hairline cracks intermittently along furrows. Both ends twisted-and-torn. Maximum dimension: 29.7 mm; unfurled length: c. 65 mm; rod diameter: 2.5 mm; weight: 3.7 g	Two twisted-rod fragments. Two roughly coiled and intertwined thin rod fragments of quadrilobate section with tight, neat twisting. All four breaks are torn. Coil diameter: 28.5 mm; unfurled lengths: c. 95 & 120 mm; rod diameters: 1.8 & 1.9 mm; weight: 7.0 g	Twisted-rod fragment. Roughly coiled as if to form a penannular ring, but both ends unifacially cut. Medium thick rod of quadrilobate section with very neat, tight twisting. Coil diameter: 22.5 mm; unfurled length: c. 55 mm; rod diameter 2.7 mm; weight: 4.2 g	Twisted-rod fragment. Bent rod fragment of quadrilobate section; twisting not as tight as associated fragments. One end bifacially cut, the other unifacially. Length: 30.2 mm; unfurled length: c. 33 mm; rod diameter: 2.2 mm; weight: 1.4 g	Twisted-rod fragment. Loose (secondary) coil of thin rod of trilobate section, tightly twisted. Both ends twisted-and-torn. Coil diameter: 27.5 mm; unfurled length: c. 110 mm; rod diameter: 1.8 mm; weight: 3.5 g	Doubled-strand coiled rod finger ring. Complete and neatly coiled ring with one-and-a-half circuits of doubled, plain rod of round section. The doubled-strand was formed by squashing flat a single unbroken ring, the tight bends at either end then serving as the terminals of the coil. Well finished, just tiny facelts in places. Ring diameter: 25.0 mm; uncoiled length: c. 115 mm; rod diameter: 2.0 mm; weight: 11.5 g	Doubled-strand rod fragment. Rod of round section tightly doubled back to form terminal very similar to those on ring no 14. Facets present around terminal. One rod end torn, the other unifacially cut. Length: 20.5 mm; unfurled length: 22 mm; rod diameter 2.0 mm; weight: 2.1 g	Coiled rod ring fragment. Joins object no 40 to make complete ring. Medium-thick rod of round section having a simple but neat terminal with side facets leading up to a flat sub-pentagonal end; other end torn. Fairly neatly coiled into slightly oval shape. Roughly coiled and loosely intertwined, three wires of approximately round section with a little faceting. Fairly even in thickness, but each tapers slightly to one end. Two possible torn ends, others original. Slight longitudinal grooves could be from drawing process. Coil diameter: 18.9 mm; unfurled lengths: c. 32, 42, 65 mm; wire diameters: 0.7 ? 1.0 mm; weight: 2.0 g	Double penannular ring. Complete ring comprising two rods side by side, presumably soldered together. Rods round in section with partial flattening on inner faces. Well finished, but tiny transverse nicks close to one terminal may be flaws of manufacture. Terminal ends are marginally convex from finishing. Diameter: 14.3 x 13.4 mm; total breadth: 6.0 mm; rod thickness: 2.9 mm; weight: 7.1 g	Double penannular ring. Complete ring comprising two rods side by side, presumably soldered together. Rods round in section except mostly flattened on inner faces. Terminal ends slightly convex and two of four bear residual clefts. Diameter: 14.5 x 13.5 mm; total breadth: 6.0 mm; rod thickness: 3.1 mm; weight: 7.4 g	Single penannular ring. Complete ring of near-round section with slight faceting all round associated with relatively coarse grinding striations. Latter also present on flattish terminal ends, while small folds and lipping have not been erased. Piece is probably essentially finished, but lacks the finer polish acquired during use. Diameter: 13.0 x 13.9 mm; breadth: 3.1 mm; thickness: 2.9 mm; weight: 3.2 g	Single penannular ring. Complete ring of round section rod tapering a little towards terminals. Latter roughly flattened at their ends with some faceting around a central cleft and external lipping. Rod also covered in diffuse facets and light striations. Diameter: 14.5 x 13.5 mm; breadth: 3.0 mm; thickness: 2.9 mm; weight: 3.4 g	Single penannular ring. Complete ring of thick rod of slightly oval section tapering a little towards the terminals. Ends of latter roughly flattened with facets extant; slight lipping at the edges has in part been folded back and burnished into the sides. Diffuse hammermarks run back from terminals on generally smoothed outer face. Diameter: 13.5 x 12.0 mm; breadth: 3.4 ? 4.0 mm; thickness: 3.0 ? 3.7 mm; weight: 5.0 g	Penannular ring fragment. Very thick rod of near round section and tightly curved without sign of distortion; almost certainly therefore from a ring of about 22 mm external diameter. Both ends chopped ? one unifacially, the other bifacially. Another deep cut notch just inside latter. Length: 5.2 mm; breadth: 6.4 mm; thickness: 6.6 mm; weight: 6.7 g	Rod fragment. Thick rod fragment of round section. Original surface with diffuse longitudinal facets. One end cut and torn, the other dented and torn. Length: 25.1 mm; rod diameter: 5.0 mm; weight: 7.3 g	Rod fragment. Thick rod fragment of round section. Two unusual patches of blackened surface with silvery outline (analysis shows them to be silver splashes). Both ends with unifacial chop and opposing shallow facet, the remaining tongue torn. Length: 24.8 mm; rod diameter: 4.6 mm; weight: 6.6 g	Rod fragment. Thick rod fragment of round section with slight S curve in profile ? presumably not original. Most of intact surface with very diffuse dimpling. One end dented and torn, the other, bifacially chopped and torn. Length: 31.8 mm; rod diameter: 5.2 mm; weight: 9.8 g	Rod fragment. Tiny segment of round or oval section rod. Both ends unifacially chopped then torn. Length: 3.3 mm; breadth: 4.8 mm; thickness 4.3 mm; weight: 0.5 g	Bar fragment ? unfinished bar ornament?. Joins no 52 to make complete bar. Thickish fragment of near rectangular section, tapering slightly to one end, which is a probable terminal. Narrow facet along one body angle and part of another. Faces covered with hammer-rippling, while two longitudinal grooves are residual from working. Terminal has asymmetric convex end, roughly faceted and with residual cleft not worked out. Other face flat and smooth. Both ends cut unifacially and steeply, one a straight cut, the other convex in plan.
