description: A Bronze Age undecorated gold ribbon (c. 2350 - 800 BC). It is rectangular in plan and section, half of the ribbon is bent and slightly distorted. There are two punched holes at each end. At the folded end the ribbon is torn at the holes.Length 53.09mm, width 12.70mm, thickness 0.48mm and weight 1.6gSimilar undecorated and punched gold ribbons have been reported as Treasure and dated to the Bronze Age, such as NMS-B2D198 and NMS-C2FF83. Therefore, as this item is more than 300 years old and composed of more than 10% precious metal and should be considered Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A Middle to Late Bronze Age gold penannular ring dating to c. 1300 - 750BC.A complete gold bi-partite penannular ring comprising of two bands of gold stacked one on top of the other, and apparently soldered together. Each band is sub-circular (oval) in cross-section and the ring is sub-circular (oval) when viewed in plan. The terminals are flat and meet in the centre. There are scuff marks located near the terminal on the outer side. In the soldered recess on either side of the terminals, there is slight cracking which can be seen under a microscope. No decoration.The ring is 15.41 mm long, 13.15 mm wide and 7.64 mm thick. The gap between the terminals is c.0.37mm. It weighs 10.13g. Each of the two individual bands are of equal dimensions.                          Penannular rings are a relatively common class of artefact reported through the Treasure Act with many known examples including NMGW-04216C. The report for which states: "The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Eogan 1994; 1997). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.Relatively few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation, or radiocarbon dating, however, burials in Belgium, northeast France, and The Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations, have suggested a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800BC (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and a longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing. Therefore, on comparative stylistic grounds, the penannular ring may be dated to the Middle or Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC).Many penannular rings of his type are composite with copper alloy cores but there is no evidence visually that this is the case with this example. Further examples of two gold or gold-plated penannular rings, stacked one on top of the other, can be found on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database: DENO-A13440, IOW-1F5D46 and HAMP-471843.Eogan, G., 1997. ‘Hair-rings’ and European Late Bronze Age society. Antiquity, 71(272), pp.308-320.Eogan, G., 1994. The Accomplished Art: Gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC) (Vol. 42). Oxbow Books Limited.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Small strip of gold wound around a strip of gold wire. The gold strip on this peice of 'hack' gold is wound around the bars three times. On the opposite side to the start of the strip is a small perforation. The wire inside appears to be bent over on itself 4/5 times. Date c.2350 - 800BC.Length: 12.2mm, Width: 11mm, Thick: 5.1mm, Weight: 4.4gDiscussion:This object is similar to other pieces of wrapped gold dated to the Bronze Age GLO-FE959E and SF-D30D10, although this piece is not ribbed and CORN-0E9443 which is plain. This places the object before 1720 and as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A fragment of a gold penannular bracelet of Late Bronze Age date (1150-800 BC).Description: The fragment survives as a small section of the full band with a circular section. Each of the ends terminates in jagged unworn breaks which appear to indicate that it was broken away rather than cut or snipped. The outer side is slightly scratched but mostly in good condition there is some marks on the inside which maybe plier or pressure marks from its constructions.Measurements: Length 46.8mm, Width 7.8 mm, Thickness 5.2mm and Weight of 22.66gDiscussion: The original form would likely have been similar to LEIC-A3A9AE or examples without flared terminals such as BM 1996,0902.38 or 1996,0902.12, though several similar fragments of goldwork have been recovered from hoards containing diagnostically Bronze Age objects (e.g. Poulton, Gloucestershire: Treasure case 2004 T17 and the Fitzleroi Farm, West Sussex, hoard: BM accession nos. 1996, 0902.1-42). Those hoards, and several others recorded in recent years, contain fragments of gold that have been snipped with a pincer like instrument, this one is interesting for having such ragged breaks.

A complete gold penannular bar bracelet, dating to the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1400BC-750BC).Description: The bracelet is composed of a cylindrical bar, curved to create a sub-oval shape in plan. The terminals of the bar are slightly expanded and, from the photograph, appear sub-circular in section with short, incised linear decoration.Dimensions: length: 101.5mm, width: 58mm, weight:113.4g (dimensions approximate and taken from photograph, weight provided by the finder).Discussion:  At the time of recording, this object appears to be the first Bronze Age gold bar bracelet, from Buckinghamshire, to be reported to the PAS scheme.  Three comparable bracelets, but with slightly more expanded terminals, were discovered as part of a hoard (PAS-833958) in Milton Keynes, which was Late Bronze Age (c.1150BC-800BC).  This hoard was processed as treasure and acquired by the British Museum (Treasure No.: PEE69; accession no.: 2002,0701).  Other comparable examples recorded on the database, including: NARC-10B4B1 (2019 T1165; Late Bronze Age, c.1150BC-800BC) and three further bracelets found as part of a hoard (BERK-6870F5/6863E4/6863E4; 2004T348; Middle Bronze Age, c.1300BC-1100BC).  Two similar bracelets can also be seen in the British Museum's collection: 1824,K/Armilla.17 (East Sussex, Middle to Late Bronze Age c.1400BC-750BC) and 1857,0627.4 (Ireland, Late Bronze Age c. 1150BC-750BC).Conclusion: Consequently, in terms of age and the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
notes: Photographs kindly provided by the finder due to COVID-19 restrictions.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A complete gold artefact of Bronze Age date. It comprises a crumpled strip of sheet or ribbon gold around 63.7mm in length, decorated with around 10 parallel ridges running along its length across one side; the reverse is undecorated. There is a partial tear across the mid section, probably from post depositional damage. The object has a rounded terminal with a ragged pierced oval hole. The other end of the object tapers into a narrow square-sectioned hook which curves under the plate and ends up 2mm wide. The surface of this terminal is smooth and undecorated, with the ridged decoration stopping short of it.  Length: 63.7mm; Width: 9.8mm; Thickness: 0.3mm; Weight: 3.5g.
notes: This appears to be a flattened item of personal adornment, originally secured in a loop using the hook and piercing and perhaps used as an earring, or finger ring. The presence of these features places this example into a less common group of Bronze Age ribbon gold artefacts found with fittings. Eogan (1994) has categorised these objects as ‘Tress’-rings, including them in his discussion of gold working in the mid to late Bronze Age. More generally, there are a range of comparable ribbon gold ornaments known from the duration of the Bronze Age, particularly from the 'ornament horizon' of the Taunton and Penard phases of the Middle Bronze Age (Roberts 2007).  This object also however finds parallels in its form within the earlier Bronze Age sheet gold tradition and an excavated example found in Oxford in a sealed alluvial deposit along with a Beaker period flint scraper and pottery (Palmer 1980) suggests that an early Bronze Age date for this type of artefact is entirely possible. A number of similar objects have been reported as potential Treasure and are recorded on the PAS database, including HAMP-B9814B (2018T700), SUR-DE6DF2 (2017T644) and BH-1BE953 (2014T901).
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: A complete late Bronze Age gold plated penannular ring, dating to 1150 - 800BC. The ring is circular in shape and in cross section, with two flat terminals. Between the terminals is copper alloy corrosion, suggesting that the main body of the ring is copper alloy plated with gold. One of the terminals is damaged, with the surface cracked and partly missing showing the inside of the ring.  The surface of the ring is a light yellow gold colour, with slightly darker stripes running across the ring in bands. Dimensions:Length: 15.8 mmWidth: 15.2 mmThickness: 5.2 mmWeight: 3.75 gDiscussion: Penannular rings are not uncommon finds reported Treasure and recorded on the PAS database. Other examples featuring similar ?tiger striped? decoration include: 2019 T1091 (HAMP-BE4072) and 2020 T780 (NLM-59A99B). The report and PAS database record for 2020 T77 (OXON-FFD016) notes that ring ?appears similar to a class of artefact which have in the past been given various terms such as 'hair-rings' (Eogan 1997) and other monikers such as ?Ring Money? (Green 1988) which are now no longer supported (Taylor 1980, 65; Varndell 2001). Their function remains uncertain (Varndell 2001, 516), although it is likely that they were personal adornments (Hobbs 2003 opinion cited, 102-107), possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange?.
notes: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Author: Arwen Wood, Finds Liaison Officer for BuckinghamshireContribution by: Ian Richardson, Senior Treasure Registrar, British Museum             References: Eogan, G. 1997. ?Hair-rings? and European Late Bronze Age society. Antiquity, 71(272), 308-320.Green, H. S., 1988. A find of Bronze Age" ring-money" from Graianog, Llanllyfni, Gwynedd. The bulletin of the Board of Celtic Studies 35, 87-91Hobbs, R. 2003. Treasure: finding our past. London: The British Museum Press.Taylor, J.J. 1980. Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles. Cambridge: Cambridge University PressVarndell, G. 2001. Ringing the Changes: when terminology matters. Antiquity 75,  515-516.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

The surfaces are slightly scratched and abraded, but otherwise smoothly finished. Dimensions: length: 14.2mm; width: 9.3mm; thickness: 1.2mm; weight: 2.0g. The surfaces are slightly scratched and abraded, but otherwise smoothly finished. Dimensions: length 10.7mm; width 10.5mm; thickness: 1.5mm; weight 1.64g. (47).48. 01/05/22: A small fragment of Bronze Age gold ingot. The fragment consists of just the rounded tip, sub-spherical in shape, the back of which has been slightly flattened and pinched to create a low ridge. The surfaces are slightly scratched and abraded, but otherwise smoothly finished. Dimensions: diameter 8.1mm, height 5.7mm, weight 2.47g. (48)49. Also: A fragment of copper alloy gouge. Recorded as DOR-D8A38B and currently with the Dorset FLO The tip only. The fragment is parallel-sided with a U-shaped channel from the tip to the break. The tops of the sides are angled at the tip.Dimensions: Length 34.1mm; width 13.5mm; thickness 12.2mm; weight 18.91g. (49).50 & 51. Two Bronze Age copper alloy tools (recorded as DOR-2D2A57, and as a separate Treasure Case 2023 T212). Currently with the Dorset FLO:A] A casting jet, possibly from casting a bronze axehead, The jet has a large irregular well, rounded at the corners. It is uneven on the upper surface where the metal pooled and cooled. On the underside it is rounded and birfurcates into two vertical channels or sprues, one at each end on the longest axis. Each has a thin external collar, one slightly higher than the other. Both taper to their breaks. One has a lozengiform cross section and is slightly longer that the other which has a shallow D-shaped cross section. Dimensions: Length 28.7mm; Width 30.2mm; Height 11.9mm; Weight 35.80g. (50)B] An incomplete copper alloy chisel. The chisel is collared and has a broad, flared blade. The tang is missing. The collar forms an oval cross section . The top of the blade is narrowed from the collar. It thins to the cutting edge as the sides flare out forming a sub-triangular blade with a straight cutting edge and rounded lower corners. The cutting edge is somewhat damaged. The sides of the blade are faceted along their length. Dimension: Length 31.8mm; Width 28.6mm; Thickness 7.7mm; Weight 13.15g. (51).52. An incomplete copper alloy collared and tanged chisel (recorded as DOR-C6A95F and currently with the Dorset FLO). The chisel has a flared blade the end of which is damaged. There is a broad transverse collar before a tapering tang. There is surface damage to the tang in particular, but it appears to have been square in cross section. The tang tapers to a point. Dimensions: Length 52.6mm; Width 11.7mm; Thickness 8.1mm; Weight 10.38g. (52).53. 02/08/2020:  A small, Bronze Age gold fragment. It is sub-square in plan and appears broken across each of the four edges. It is slightly warped and no longer lies flat. The surfaces are slightly scratched and abraded. Length: 11.2mm; width: 10.1; thickness: 1.6mm; weight: 1.48g. (53).54 & 55. 01/04/2021: Two Bronze Age gold finds: a gold fragment and a gold ingot. The gold fragment is flat and sub-rectangular and appears broken across the edges. The surfaces are slightly scratched and abraded, but otherwise smoothly finished. Length: 10.2mm; width: 7.1mm; thickness: 1.3mm; weight: 1.03g. (54). The ingot is sub-pentagonal in section and rectangular in plan. The sides are irregular with some wider than others, and the edges are uneven. The whole ingot is slightly bent. The surfaces are slightly scratched and abraded but otherwise smoothly finished. Length: 43.9mm; width: 6.1mm; weight: 15.59g. (55).56. 2020 T554 addendum (originally recorded as SWYOR-F0F72E - record now deleted) 26/11/2023: A small, flat Bronze Age gold fragment. It is sub-rectangular in plan, slightly bent to make it wavy in profile, and appears broken across the short edges. The surfaces are slightly scratched and abraded, but otherwise smoothly finished. Dimensions: 12.1mm long, 7mm wide and 1.1mm thick. 1.2g. (56). (reported by Amy Downes ).One Bronze Age gold fragment not received. Finder has lost the artefact – Coroner is dealing with the matter.Discussion: All finds have been retrieved from the fields close to an Iron Age hillfort, an area encompassing a rare combination of Neolithic and Early Bronze Age sites, comprising one of the largest concentrations of burial monuments in England, the largest known cursus and a significant number and range of henge monuments. Other important remains include a variety of enclosures, settlements, field systems and linear boundaries dating throughout pre-history and into the Romano-British and Medieval periods. The socketed chisel is unusual but not without parallel. Examples are known from Middle Bronze Age hoards as at Highworth, Wiltshire (Taylor 1988, W71) Ongar Hall, Essex (Rowlands 1976: Hoard 43), and Taunton Union Workhouse, Somerset (Taylor 1988, SW71). They are also known in Late Bronze Age hoards at at Portfield Hillfort, Lancashire (Schmidt and Burgess 1981: plate 150), Roseberry Topping, Yorkshire(ibid plate 148) and in Derbyshire (see DENO-88980E).The collared awl has a parallel from the Carleton Rode hoard, Norfolk (Taylor 1988: EA45) and on the database in a hoard from Norfolk (PAS-9474B1) both of which are suggested to be Late Bronze Age in date. A chisel similar to (52) is recorded in database record WREX-8372FD where Dr Susie White notes: “Tanged and collared chisels typically date from the Late Bronze Age to Earliest Iron Age.  They have a broad distribution across northern France, Britain and Ireland though there are relatively few examples from western England and Wales.” For an example on the database see NMGW-E96F08.Other Bronze Age finds associated with this site include an axe fragment (HAMP-5DA054), a gouge (SUR-1536D1) and a sword (WILT-81D6A7). The gold fragments are largely undiagnostic, although it is possible they comprise part of a founder’s hoard. Similar examples of such goldworking hoards are known from Britain including that at Fitzleroi Farm, Fittleworth (British museum Accession No. 1996,0902.26) and Cirencester (2004 T416).Due to the small size of the ingots, their full form is not clear and recent examples are usually thought to be undiagnostic as it has been accepted this form of ingot was used in several periods. However, before 2007 most fragments of ingots that had been hammered to thin them out before being snapped were thought to be Bronze-Iron Age in date, and the location of these finds would suggest that, on the balance of probabilities, a Bronze Age date is correct in this instance. Database examples include SOM-E5EF83 (2019T226), IOW-3C40219, CORN-50D181(2021T271).The clipped fragments are also likely to be late Bronze Age as similar clips occasionally show up with complete Bronze Age bracelets. Many such fragments are also recorded onto the PAS database: IOW-3CB691, NML-C0A809 (2022T357), and KENT-34916A (2021T635). Information from Dr Matthew Knight at Historic England suggests that the possible bent bar bracelet (1) can be broadly dated to the Late-Middle Bronze Age, c.1300-800BC, probably towards the later period. A number of fragments of gold rods of similar dimensions have been found in isolation and recorded by the PAS e.g. KENT-A071A8 (2017T131), HAMP-8AFE65 (2019T1197), SWYOR-CBC05F (2019T849), SURR-3DE17A. Thanks to Dr Matthew Knight for his comments on the hoard.Conclusion:  Most of the objects contain a minimum of 10% precious metal (the two copper alloy tools are linked by association) and are over 300 years old. Consequently, they qualify as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Alix Smith, Finds Liaison Assistant for WiltshireSophie HawkeFinds Liaison Officer for WiltshireWith contributions by Dr Edward Caswell Finds Liaison Officer for OxfordshireReport updated December 2023
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A fragment of an incomplete gold band or ribbon of rectangular shape, now in two pieces, of Bronze Age date (2100 BC - 1150 BC).Description: The parallel sided strip of gold has twelve (possibly thirteen) embossed longitudinal lines visible on both faces, giving a corrugated effect. Both ends appear to be breaks, and the strip has broken into two pieces post-recovery. Both long edges are folded making a thicker edge. About 2.6mm - 2.8mm of the sheet is folded over on each edge. This flange is damaged and partially missing on one long edge, and partially unfolded. There is some modern damage on the outer face of the larger piece, in the form of transverse scratches across the face. The whole object is bent and creased and was probably more crumpled when first found, the modern break appearing to be along a previous fold. The finder took the object to be tested by a jeweller who reports that it is 20ct and 5g. Short piece: 29.9mm long, 14.2mm wide, 1.3mm thick as folded. The sheet is 0.3mm thick. Larger piece: 47.6mm long, 14.7mm wide, 0.6mm thick as folded. The sheet is 0.4mm thick. Discussion: Several ribbons of Bronze Age date have been previously reported as Treasure. Many of these have incised decoration on one face only, rather than the ribbed and corrugated effect seen on this piece. An example is WAW-C0C0B3 (2007 T672) which is published as number 38 on page 47 and 303 of the 2007 Treasure Annual Report.Examples with embossed linear decoration include WMID-3CBCF0 (2013 T471) for which the record by Teresa Gilmore and Neil Wilkin notes that "Similar multi-grooved strips of a Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as recent finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48) [this is mentioned above and is only decorated on one side]. A very similar strip from Sproxton, North Yorkshire is recorded on the PAS database as LVPL-83FE92 [2010 T664]. There is also a similar grooved strip from The Hamel, Oxford, Oxfordshire excavated from a layer which yielded Beaker pottery of the Early Bronze Age (Palmer 1980, 124-134). Similar narrow embossed strips are known from the pommels of daggers accompanying Early Bronze Age burials in Scotland (Henshall 1968, 173-95; Hardaker 1974, 21-23. fig 6.; Taylor 1980, fig 28a-f) but not however comparable to gold dagger fittings in contemporary burials southern England.". Another similar examples is WMID-FE3C28 (2016 T1039).The embossed rather than incised decoration makes an early Bronze Age date seem more likely, but a date in the middle to late Bronze Age cannot be entirely discounted.
notes: This object is made of precious metal and is more than 300 years old, so it appears to meet the requirements of the 1996 Treasure Act.
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: A fragment of gold strip or bar with a flared terminal. The strip has been coiled with the terminal on the inside. The strip is rectangular in cross section. At one end is a flared, flat-ended, terminal (approximately 4.5 mm thick) which is oval in cross section. At the other the strip has a deliberate angled cut. The strip is flattened from the terminal and expands in width to the cut end. The sides have been raised to create low flanges. This is slightly more prominent along the edges of one face (the outer face of the coil) than the other. The strip is 1.4 mm thick at the ridged edge and 1.2 mm thick in between.Date: Late Bronze Age c. 950 – 750 BCDimensions: 32.83 mm x 1.10 mm x 7.80 mmWeight: 14.05 gDiscussion: The fragment has its closest parallel to NMGW-E48854 on this database which is dated to the Late Bronze Age. That example has a circular cross section to the flared terminal and is similarly flattened and flaring with raised flanges at the sides. Further parallels include Fragment 1 from CORN-705C14 which has been paralleled to an example from St Martin's, Isles of Scilly (Tyacke 1993). Further similar examples are also illustrated by Eogan (1994) from Caister on Sea Norfolk (Eogan 1994: pl 13, no. 1) and Berwickshire (Eogan 1994: pl 15, no. 6) all of which are also suggested to date to the Late Bronze Age. This is supported by a bracelet with an expanded terminal being found with a Late Bronze Age socketed axehead at Llanarmon-yn-Iâl in Denbighshire (Green 1983). These are sometimes termed Potterne type bracelets following the publication of a similar bracelet from this site (Taylor 1984)Conclusion: Consequently, this item qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Authors: Ciorstaidh Hayward Trevarthen (Finds Liaison Officer) And Edward Caswell (Finds Liaison Officer)ReferencesEogan, G. (1994) The accomplished art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC). Oxford, Oxbow.Green, H. S. (1983).'A late Bronze Age hoard from Llanarmon-yn-Ial, Clwyd', Antiquaries Journal, 63, 384-7.Taylor, J. (1984) The Potterne gold bracelet and its affinities. Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Magazine, 78, 35–40. Available from https://archive.org/details/wiltshirearchaeo7819wilt/page/40/mode/2up?view=theater last accessed 13th February 2023Tyacke, A. (1993). Recent archaeological acquisitions at the Royal Cornwall Museum. Cornish Archaeology, 32, 142-145.
notes: Conclusion: Consequently, this item qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A strip of ribbon gold, dating to the Bronze Age c. 2200 - 800 BC. One side is covered with 14 parallel grooves running along its length, the other is undecorated. There is damage to one side at the mid point where the strip is buckled; both ends are cut. There are no piercings or evidence for fittings.Length: 37.2mm; Width: 9.2mm; Thickness: 0.3mm; Weight: 1.1g.
notes: The style of this object with its parallel linear ridges is typical of gold strips and ribbons of known and probable Bronze Age date. Examples from excavated contexts which could lend weight to this dating include an excavated example from Oxford found with a Beaker period flint scraper and pottery (Palmer 1980). Comparable finds recently also reported under the Treasure Act include IOW-CE16C7(2020T431)  and LVPL-954858 (2020 T120).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: TREASURE CASE: 2020 T426Description:  A single cylindrical fragment of solid gold which appears to have been neatly rounded at one end and cut at the other. The surface is slightly scratched with some abrasions and slight indentations, but otherwise smoothly finished.  The “damage” may well have been caused by being buried.Dimensions:  Length: 38mm in length; diameter 5.3mm diameter, tapering to 4.7mm, weighing 11.1g.
notes: Discussion and Dating:  The precise date and function of this object is unclear however, it bears a very close resemblance to three similar fragments that were recovered from inside the socket of a Late Bronze Age axe found near Rossett in North Wales (Gwilt et al 2005). These fragments formed part of a hoard, now known as the Rossett Hoard, dating to 1000-800BC, which was acquired by Wrexham Museum (Acc. No. WREMA.2003.2.1-6).  The Rossett fragments were identified as “hack” gold of Irish origin which are believed to have been cut in order to act as currency. Further gold rods with cut edges appear to have been found in a number of Bronze Age hoards including the Fittleworth Hoard (British Museum Accession no: 1996,0902 1996,0902), a hoard found on the Isle of Wight (IOW-9F0C84 2020T2, 2018T5 IOW-50D55F) and another example from near Cirencester (BM-28B710 2004T416).There is also a shorter fragment of gold of almost identical diameter recorded on the PAS database as ESS-6C5E03 (Treasure case: 2017T1099).  This example was recorded in 2017 and identified as being possibly early Medieval in date and was declared treasure the Essex Coroner on 30 Sep 2019. Statement:  Although there is no associated dating evidence with this object, parallels would suggest that this item was more than 300 years old at the time of finding; possibly even as early as the Late Bronze Age.  It is also formed of more than 10% precious metal and, as such, would qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.ReferenceGwilt, A., Kucharski, K. Silvester, R. & Davis, M. 2005 A Late Bronze Age Hoard from Trevaly Farm, Rossett, Wrexham; with some observations on hoarding practice and gold bracelet weights, Studia Celtica 34, 27-61.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A Bronze Age gold ribbon (c. 1150-c. 850 BC). Treasure case no. 2020 T431.A rectangular strip of corrugated sheet gold folded along the longitudinal centre-line through 180?.17.1mm (length); 5.4mm (width); 1.2mm (overall thickness). Weight: 0.56g.
notes: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description: Penannular ring of probable Bronze Age date, probably from a composite (multiple strand) ring. It is C-shaped in cross-section, with a convex outer and a concave interior. The width of the ring is very consistent but the two ends do not sit quite in line, as if the ring has been slightly bent out of shape. There is a c. 1.5mm gap between the two ends, one of which is slightly incurved and the other slightly outcurved, as if they once joined. The top and bottom edges are neat and parallel, but one is more highly polished than the other, which has a narrow roughened strip by its edge, perhaps keying for solder or perhaps the remains of gold solder.Dimensions: Diameter 12.7mm, width of ring 5.3mm, thickness of ring 2.1 to 2.4mm, weight 2.8g. Discussion: Although penannular rings are well known Bronze Age finds, they normally have circular cross-sections, or sometimes D-shaped. C-shaped cross-sections are unusual, and are normally found on composite rings made from multiple bands soldered together; there is some evidence that this ring may once have been part of a soldered-together composite ring. Although the band widths on composite rings are usually much thinner than this example, the widest composite rings recorded on the PAS database are WILT-788C7B (2019T253) and ESS-71DFE4 (2014T169), where the individual bands are respectively almost 4mm wide, and 4.5mm wide. Date: Penannular rings belong to the middle Bronze Age, c. 1300-1150 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: An incomplete cast gold bracelet of Bronze Age date (1300-1100 BC).Description: An incomplete cast gold bracelet of Bronze Age date (1300-1100 BC). The object is a loosely twisted, square-section rod. At one end the rod finishes at a cut, while at the other its finishes in a tapered tip. Here, the rod straightens slightly but appears wavy, suggesting it has been untwisted. The surfaces of the rod are very rough and dimpled with some hammer and file marks visible.  Measurements: length: 75mm; width: 5mm; thickness; 3mm; weight: 12gDiscussion:  Similar objects recorded on the database include BM-25EFE8, DOR-C5C932  and NMGW-A93765. A fourth from Gloucestershire is also recorded in the Portable Antiquities Scheme and Treasure Annual Report 2007 (figure 36). Each of these objects are suggested to be twisted Middle Bronze Age gold bar bracelets found in Britain and Ireland. For example Eogan (1994: fig 27) illustrates several similar bracelets which he classifies as his type iii (Eogan 1994: 50).Twisted gold bracelets and torcs have been found in fields in Wiltshire and throughout southwest England though they have tended to be deposited with accompanying gold objects (Roberts 2007).Conclusion: It is therefore likely that this object was at least 300 years old at the time of discovery and as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description: An early bronze age gold sheet, ribbon or diadem which was originally found folded repeatedly into a tube.The sheet is rectangular in plan. It is notably thin, measuring 0.4mm in thickness. The sheet has been pierced twice from the front, once on either end, after the decoration was applied. The piercing’s measure at 1.6mm in diameter each. On one end of the strip, the two corner edges have been folded over onto themselves, giving the end a trapezoidal shape. The sheet has had eleven instances of linear stippled decoration applied in rows across its width via a circular shaped punch tool. It has been deliberately folded in between each row of linear stippling a total of thirteen times, which would have left the sheet in a tubular shape. It was subsequently unrolled by the finder at the time of finding, as they weren’t aware of the deliberate nature of the folded state the piece was in.The gold is a rich, full, butter-like yellow colour, with small amounts of scratches visible on the surfaces exposed to wear. There are minor cracks present on the edges of some of the bends.Dimensions: Length: 44.6mmWidth: 12.4mmThickness: 0.4mmWeight: 2.2gDiscussion: Thin sheets of gold, often featuring piercings and adorned with lightly incised linework, punched repousse bosses or pointillé decoration are associated with examples of early gold metal working in Bronze Age Britain. The fact the piece was folded and manipulated in a deliberate and intentional manner, a known practice in the bronze age, further gives weight to this conclusion.The piece was originally reported to and identified by Mr. Peter Reavill, who has assisted Ciorstaidh Hayward Trevarthen (Finds Liaison Officer for Dorset) with the recording of a particularly similar example, 2020 T825 (DOR-015978), found in Burton, Dorset. As of writing this record, the find is currently going through the treasure process. This example is also a thin strip of gold, decorated with linear stippled decoration applied in rows across its width, although this example hasn’t been pierced. The record notes:‘The form of this gold sheet is similar to gold ribbons, plaques, mounts and other gold sheet decorations known from the British Bronze Age (2500-800 BC) although it should be acknowledged that the form as such is not widely understood mostly due to the lack of discovery within excavated archaeological contexts. At present these objects fall into two distinctive groups those formed on thick and those formed of thin sheets. Those on thin sheets are thought to be of Early Bronze Age period (2150 – 1750 BC) whilst those thicker may also be associated with Middle Bronze Age (1500-1150 BC). The date and function and often referred to within the literature as ribbon ornaments. Both groups are decorated with repousse longitudinal bands or rows of applied indentations or bosses.This artefact (like most of the thin sheet examples) is most likely to be of Early Bronze Age date. These sheet mounts often have circular perforated holes on their terminal ends through which they are fixed – presumably onto organic elements – that we think form decorative pieces on personal dress (including scabbards, diadem headwear, neck (choker) or chest (pectoral) mounts).’In addition to this, other similar examples of early bronze age gold plaques, ribbons or diadems have been recorded on the PAS database: 2021 T608 (YORYM-B1A82B) is a folded gold sheet with a single border line of roughly evenly spaced small, sub-circular applied repoussé bosses created by a circular headed punch. It has been dated to the early Bronze Age, c.2150 – 1750 BC, and has been processed as treasure. 2021 T975 (WMID-09EF95) also shares similarities with the record in question, namely the series of nine circular pointillé bosses formed with a round headed punch from the back of the sheet. This example has been dated from the early to middle bronze age and has been donated to a museum after being declared treasure. 2017 T798 (PAS-35C8A8) is a folded gold sheet with borders of pointillé decoration that has been dated to 2500 – 1500BC and has been processed as treasure. It has a tapered terminal which has been pierced in a similar fashion to the example in this record. Similarly, 2016 T521 (BERK-BA8440) also features the border of pointillé decoration and tapered terminal, except with three distinct piercings instead of a single one. It has been dated from 2400-2200 BC, and consequently has been processed as treasure. 2018 T700 (HAMP-B9814B) is an example of a plain, thin gold strip / ribbon / diadem with a tapered terminal and singular piercing which has been given a wider dating range of 2500 – 800BC, but is still considered to be Bronze Age, and has been processed as Treasure.Conclusion:Author(s): Peter Reavill, Former Herefordshire & Shropshire FLOPeter Carey, Treasure Finds Liaison AssistantDate: 16th April 2024References:2020 T825 (DOR-015978) https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/1012847#2021 T608 (YORYM-B1A82B) https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/1037047#2021 T975 (WMID-09EF95) https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/10467972017 T798 (PAS-35C8A8) https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/973486#2016 T521 (BERK-BA8440) https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/791779#2018 T700 (HAMP-B9814B) https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/919630#
notes: As of writing this record, this find represents one of the earliest examples of worked gold recorded in Shropshire.The piece has been found within the vicinity of the Britonnic ring, now in Ludlow Museum.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Three fragments of an incomplete folded gold strip or ribbon dating to the Bronze Age (c. 2200 - 800 BC).Description: The ribbon is in three separate fragments, each of which are decorated on one side with four regular, longitudinal, parallel grooves whilst the other side is plain. The very tips of the ends of each fragment fold over slightly and the two smaller parts fit the two ends of the larger, so it can be deduced that these snapped off through being bent. A near 90 degree bend is present halfway down the larger fragment and a split is visible at one of the fold's edges. Because the ends of the smaller fragment, which do not fit the larger section, are also bent slightly at the tips, it is likely that the original ribbon was longer and further breaks occurred at these points. Measurements: Fragment 1: length: 24.7mm; width: 6.7mm; thickness: 0.7mm; weight: 0.97gFragment 2: length: 12.6mm; width: 6.5mm; thickness: 0.6mm; weight: 0.34gFragment 2: length: 11.5mm; width: 6.4mm; thickness: 0.6mm; weight: 0.28gDiscussion: A number of gold strips of a similar size have been recorded as treasure on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database, for example: 2019T991 (DUR-9B1BA0), 2019T574 (BERK-B58065), 2014T777 (HAMP-36C41B), and 2014T63 (BERK-387817). Interestingly, the descriptions are broadly similar in that they are often folded or crumpled, with one ‘original end’ that is smooth and rounded and one cut end that is sheared off. Some, but not all examples, have a small perforation at one end (e.g.  2014T6 (NMS-6E2A74), 2012T577 (ESS-C13B97), and 2013T326 (WILT-26F931) with two holes).It is not clear how these gold ribbons were used or what period of the Bronze Age they date to. Eogan (1994) referring to them as ‘Tress’-rings, included them in his discussion of gold working in the c.13th–12th centuries. One excavated example was found in Oxford in a sealed alluvial deposit along with a Beaker period flint scraper and indeterminable pottery that was consistent with Beaker pottery (Palmer 1980). Similarity of the Oxford example with Early Bronze Age Scottish dagger pommel strips has been noted (Case 1980) but dismissed as it was missing the flange that was present on the Scottish daggers. Many of the examples reported as Treasure and subsequently recorded on the PAS database (including several of those above) are accorded a date of middle to late Bronze Age (c.1500-800BC). However, based on the excavated contextual data the possibility that these strips date to the Early Bronze Age cannot be discounted.Conclusion: It is therefore clear that this object likely dates to before 1721 and, as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Incomplete cast copper alloy flat axehead dating from the Migdale tradition of the Early Bronze Age, c.2200-2000 BC. The sides of the axehead look slightly raised on both faces but that is because the original surface, which has turned dark brown in colour, has only survived around the edges making it look crisper, and also on the blade above the slightly expanded but worn and rounded cutting edge. The axehead is sub-trapezoidal in plan, triangular in profile, tapering towards the cutting edge, and rectangular in section at the butt end. The blade narrows towards the damaged butt end, but with almost straight sides. There is no evidence of any form of incised or cast decoration present on the surface of the axe, but the original surface has corroded away and is now very pitted, so that preservation is poor. There are many circular depressions on the surface that have been caused by blisters forming as the axehead has corroded and then breaking down and powdering away. Similar slender flat axeheads with straight-sided butt ends can be seen in records CORN-6C605C, DENO-93FB17, SUR-E3F467, LANCUM-6507C2, and SOMDOR-C71623 on the database.These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 (c.2350-2050 cal BC). This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Schmidt & Burgess (1981) illustrate similar flat axeheads of Type Migdale from Scotland, Briach Moor and Morayshire on pp.41-42, pls.12-13, nos.143, 147 &155.Pearce (1983) illustrates a similar example of slender Migdale type flat axehead from Tregonjeeves Quarry in Cornwall on p.400 & 453, pl.1, no.6.Knight, Ormrod & Pearce (2015) illustrate the latest slender Migdale type of flat axes to be recorded in the South West from Boscastle in Cornwall, Bishop's Tawrton in Devon and Burton in Dorset on page 87, pl.14, nos.3, 111 & 213.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A Middle to Late Bronze age penannular ring, consisting of gold sheet wrapped around a copper alloy core, with corrosion products from this core now expanding through the gold sheet and visible through tears. The ring itself is oval in cross section and the gold sheet is inlaid with circumferential bands of silver or electrum wire. Dimensions: Length 19.7mm; Width 19.2mm; Thickness 7.2mm; Weight 10.49g.Discussion: Such rings are dated to the Middle or Late Bronze Age and a number have now been reported through the treasure process: NMGW-928F55; HAMP-90A3E2; SOM-E86C93; WILT-F01E84; KENT-F381C6, amongst others. The use of gold sheet covers is well attested in the Bronze Age, particularly in the Early Bronze Age, and as opposed to processes such as mercury gilding used in later periods, these sheet covers form distinct, recognisable artefacts in their own right.
notes: The gold sheet cover comprises of over 10% precious metal and is more than 300 years old and as such qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996, the copper alloy core, by association with its cover will also meet the criteria to be considered. Additionally, the Treasure (Designation) Order 2002 provided that any object of prehistoric date is Treasure if any part of it is precious metal.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description:  The object is broadly T-shaped in plan, composed of a plate which has been pressed to form a rectilinear shape (albeit with one side flaring downwards markedly giving it an irregular and asymmetrical appearance). This plate thickens and slopes upwards and is attached to a flaring tang which is triangular in plan but rectangular in cross section. The shank bends slightly to the break, and becomes thinner and more ribbon-like at this point. Dimensions: It is 17.38mm in length, 18.92mm wide at the plate, 1.26mm wide at the tang, 0.7mm thick at the plate and 1.49mm thick at the tang. It weighs 3.06g.Discussion:  High carat gold is characteristic of Bronze Age gold working and the high shine and rich colour of this example are consistent with this kind of gold. The shape is reminiscent of Early Bronze Age/Chalcolithic gold “basket ornaments” such as BERK-0D1A05 (Byard 2012), and GLO-92912E (Adams 2019), which both display the same kind of design with a central tang flaring outwards to a flattened plate, giving the impression of a T-shape. However, in these examples, the plates generally have a more oval appearance, rather than the sharply angled plate present on this example. They are additionally generally more fragile and sheet like, with the Gloucestershire example measuring 0.2mm in thickness, significantly thinner than this Devon case. There is also no decoration on the Devon example comparable to that on other examples of “basket ornaments” which may have been worn in the hair, as ear ornaments or as items of decoration attached to clothing. It is more likely, therefore, that the fragment is from a different and much later class of object, namely a Middle Bronze Age ribbon torc terminal. The rectilinear shape in this example is not paralleled precisely, but there is a suggestion of a similar form in a damaged example from Hampshire (HAMP-1AE583, Hinds 2013). In that example, one of the now damaged terminals show signs of flaring widely at both sides creating a relatively similar fluke-like terminal which could be used to secure the torc in position. The Priddy Hoard (SOM-1C2C53 Payne 2007/ Minitt and Payne ) contained a group of 19 ribbon torcs of varying styles with a wide variety of terminals incorporating hooks and loops, and one example from that group also shows the same flared terminal, although not to the same angular degree. It is most likely to be of Middle Bronze Age date (1600/1500-1150 BC), perhaps more specifically of the Taunton phase 'Ornament Horizon' (c.1400-1300 cal BC; cf. Roberts 2007), although it may be of later Bronze Age date and represent a later stage in more defined angular terminals. The relatively local comparable examples further support this conclusion. Conclusion: The fragment appears to consist of more than 10% precious metal and to be more than 300 years old at the time of finding, it thus qualifies as Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Hoard of fourteen gold objects that date from the Penard (c.1275-1150 BC) phase of the late Middle Bronze Age to the Ewart Park / Carp's Tongue phase of the Late Bronze Age (c.1000-800 BC): three annular rings, one with a decorated band wrapped around it, one with rouletted or stamped decoration and one made of plaited wire; one bracelet fragment with a flattened band and 'buffer' terminal; one fragment of a ribbon ornament; one fragment of a bracelet or cuff with a raised outer edge; one domed mount formed of ridged sheet; two ovoid ingots and one fragment with two sheets of gold soldered together which has been sheared off at both ends with a raised edge; one penannular composite ring; one decorated plate with pointed tabbed terminals; one decorated mount; and one perforated cuff edge.1. Bracelet fragment, hammered flat, triangular in plan and rectangular in section at the broken end, 8 mm wide and 1 mm thick, which has been sheared off from the rest of the armlet. The arm tapers to 3 mm in width and then expands into the circular 'buffer' terminal that is 4 mm in diameter, with a flattened end that is 5 mm in diameter.Similar flattened bracelets with buffer terminals from hoards found at Bexley Heath, Kent and Morvah, Cornwall are illustrated in Eogan (1994) in plates 9 and XVIII, which are dated from the Late Bronze Age, c.1000-800 BC.Local comparanda includes the gold bracelet from St Martins, Isles of Scilly which is mentioned by Stuart Needham in his discussion of the bracelet from Brean Down (M. Bell, Brean Down excavations 1983-1987, 1990, 146) and published in Cornish Archaeology, No.32, 1993, pp.144-145 by the recorder, Anna Tyacke. Stuart attributes this bracelet to Class B1, which occurs locally in the Morvah and Rosemorran hoards and elsewhere in southern England and Wales in contexts that indicate these bracelets were current during the Ewart Park / Carp's Tongue phase (c.1000-800 BC) (Brendan O'Connor pers comm).Length 23 mm; width 8 mm; thickness 3 mm; diameter 5 mm; weight 2.78 g2. Annular ring with sheet hasp wrapped around it that is decorated with incised horizontal, transverse and oblique lines within filled triangles between zones of four parallel lines in seven rows to form a herringbone pattern. The winged hasp has two tabs that continue the decoration from the plate on their undersides as they are curled outwards from the edge and would have slotted through the aperture or eye of another object, acting like a hook.An object with similar annular rings and attachment conical hasps was found at Kernoberon or Kernivin, in Ploneour Lanvern, in Finistere, France, and is illustrated in Avant Les Celtes (Le Goffic, 1988) on p.106, no.12.01.04 which are referred to as Pendentifs Cliquetants or Tintinnabulum, or 'little bells' and dated from the Late Bronze Age. It looks as if these hasps might have held the three larger rings which have circular plates suspended from them. It was on display or was at the Musee de Chateaubriant in 1988.The decoration is similar to that on the upper bands of the gold bulla from the Bog of Allen in County Kildare, Ireland, which is dated from the Late Bronze Age (Eogan, 1994, p.89, pl.XIX) and one section of the decorated cup-ended ornament from Morvah, Cornwall illustrated in Taylor (1980) in pl.56, d, which dates from c.1000-800 BC. More recently a gold binding with the same pattern, fitted around the socket of a Late Bronze Age (c.900-790 BC) spearhead, found at Pyotdykes, Angus, Scotland in 1963, was analysed and found that it might be made of Cornish gold. See https://www.nms.ac.uk/collections-research/our-research/featured-projects/prehistoric-gold/gold-object-of-the-week/gold-object-of-the-week-8/There is also a double gold ring attached by a looped plate to the rim of a Late Bronze Age decorated sheet-gold vessel from Paimpont, Ille-et-Vilaine. See https://musee-archeologienationale.fr/oiseaux-du-ciel-et-de-leau (Dr Brendan O'Connor pers comm).Annular ring: diameter 16 mm thickness 2 mm; weight of objects combined 2.82 gSheet hasp: Length 10 mm; width 5 mm; thickness 0.4 mm; diameter 5 mm3. Cuff or armlet edge with a raised edge that projects proud of both faces by about 0.9 mm from the face as the whole edge is 2 mm in thickness and the sheet is only 0.2 mm in thickness.A similar raised edge can be seen on an armlet from the Morvah hoard, Cornwall illustrated in Eogan (1994) in plate XVIII, which is dated from the Late Bronze Age, c.1000-800 BC.Length 27 mm; width 6.6 mm; thickness 2 mm; weight 1.1 g4. Bracelet fragment with hammered outer edges to produce flanges that are 1 mm thick with eleven parallel horizontal ridges and grooves between them on the band that is 0.4 mm thick.Similar bracelets were found in a hoard from Saintjohns, County Kildare, Ireland illustrated in Eogan (1994) on p.63, fig.27, nos.4-5, which are dated from the Middle Bronze Age, c.1300-1100 BC and narrower tress rings with fine ribs and rolled over edges from the Derrinboy hoard, County Offaly, Ireland, which was dated from the Bishopsland phase (c.1200-1000 BC) of the Middle Bronze Age, but has since had a radio carbon date of 1600 BC for the leather core of the neck ornament that was part of this hoard. See pl.2, no.29 in O'Floinn, R., Wallace, P. F. (2002). Treasures of the National Museum of Ireland: Irish antiquities. Dublin: Gill & Macmillan (Mary Cahill pers comm).See similar examples on the database such as LIN-946F12, LVPL-25FCB6 and HAMP-36C41B. Length 24 mm; width 10 mm; thickness 1 mm; weight 1.09 g5. Annular flattened circular ring stamped or rouletted with a rope-like pattern on two concentric raised circles.There is a stamped decorative gold strip found in the Llantrisant Fawr hoard, Wales, which is supposed to be emulating twisted wire stranding like the stamped ring above, and dates from c.1400-1275 (see https://museum.wales/collections/bronze-age-gold-from-wales/object/769e44e5-9cbc-38af-8586-0b5dbbb7dcd8/Middle-Bronze-Age-gold-strip/).External diameter 15 mm; internal diameter 11 mm, thickness 1.3 mm; weight 0.8 g6. Annular ring made of three plaited wires that has bent into a bean shape. Plaited gold bracelets have been found in the Barton Bendish hoard from Norfolk and the Beerhackett hoard from Dorset illustrated in Eogan (1994) on p.55, fig.20, no.3, which are dated from 1300-1100 BC. See also PAS-5B1745 for the Burton, Wrexham hoard which has a bracelet made up of multiple plaited wires, and is dated from c.1300-1150 BC.Length 17 mm; width 14 mm; thickness 0.5 mm; diameter 16.5 mm; weight 0.4 g7. Domed mount formed of a ridged sheet, ovate in plan and plano-convex in profile with a hollow back and a central aperture, but crushed and torn so that its original shape is unknown. It may have originally been flatter and shares some details, such as the domed centres and the raised concentric ribs, on the discs found in a hoard near Lewes, Sussex, illustrated in O'Connor, Roberts & Wilkin (2017) on p.274, fig.4, which is dated from c.1400-1250 BC.Similar ridged bead covers were found in Barrow 2, Radley in Oxfordshire and are illustrated in Taylor (1980) in pl.26, d-e. A similar ridged and domed sheet gold object, which has been identified by Mary Cahill as a Wessex type perforated bead or button cover, was found at Tullamore in County Offaly and dated from the early Middle Bronze Age (illustrated in PAST Number 69, November 2011)Length 16 mm; width 12 mm; thickness 0.7 mm; height 5 mm; weight 0.43 g8. Ingot, ovate in plan and plano-convex in profile and section.Similar ingots were found in a hoard (2004 T416) from near Cirencester, Gloucestershire, illustrated in the Treasure Annual Report 2004 on p.233, fig.17.5, which is dated from c.1300-1100 BC but the forms of ingots do not change from the Middle to the Late Bronze Age.Length 11 mm; width 7.5 mm; thickness 5 mm; weight 3.86 g9. Fragment of an ingot or object, trapezoidal in plan and in profile and triangular in section, sheared off on two sides.Length 11 mm; width 6 mm; thickness 5.4 mm; weight 2.06 g10. Fragment of a worked ornament that appears to be two plates soldered together, one L-shaped with a tooth or triangular ridge that can be seen in profile at one edge, and the internal band with a raised ridge that rests on this triangular edge, like it is keying into it as a clasp and hasp would.Length 8 mm; width 6 mm; thickness 2.4 mm; height 4 mm; weight 0.85 gA FURTHER FOUR FRAGMENTS OF GOLD OBJECTS WERE FOUND BETWEEN APRIL 1ST AND APRIL 8TH:11. Incomplete penannular composite ring with four bands fused together that might have been used as mount for a handle or socket. Each band is D-shaped in section and is 2 mm wide and 0.7 mm in thickness. The interior of the ring is smooth but each band edge is defined by a very thin line with no gaps. Similar composite rings can be seen strung along a twisted torc found at Haxey, Lincolnshire, illustrated in Eogan (1994) on p.57, fig.22, no.1, and in O'Connor, Roberts & Wilkin (2017) on p.273, fig.3, no.2, which is dated from the Penard phase (c.1275-1150 BC). There is also a quadruple composite ring from Saint-Jean-Trolimon, in Finistere, France, illustrated in Taylor (1980) in pl.34, b. See also records PUBLIC-F4E0EY for a single composite ring with four D-shaped bands and PAS-5B1745 for the Burton, Wrexham hoard which has a composite rings associated with a twisted torc, and is dated from c.1300-1150 BC. Length 46 mm; width 7.3 mm; thickness 0.7 mm; diameter 15 mm; weight 1.75 g12. Decorated plate with tapering tabs at either ends which have been forged over with a hammer into a point and might have been used to hook the plate to another object. There are four gold granules or balls, 1.3 mm in diameter, applied at one end of the plate and raised borders on each side of the upper face of the plate along with a central rib that are 0.6 mm in thickness. The plate is plain and smooth on the back. See GLO-E9EC16 for a record of the Woolaston hoard from Gloucestershire with similar tabs and hooks on the ends of a bracelet that is dated from c.1500-1100 BC.There is a bracelet with a wrought buffer terminal and applied bosses, which have then been hammered flat, between ribbed borders in the British Museum (see https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/H_AF-410) that is now suggested to be from France as it is a French type and is dated from the Late Bronze Age (Mary Cahill pers comm).There is also what might be an Etruscan bulla from the Redmond Antony collection in Mary Cahill's paper on The Man in the Bulla in Archaeology Ireland Autumn 2018, which has similar traits to three of the objects in this hoard: the plaited annular ring (no.6) around the circumference of the domed mount (no.7) and the granulated strip with the three ribs and the tabs to connect it as a suspension loop for the bulla like this piece.Length 30 mm; width 6.4 mm; thickness 1 mm; weight 0.87 g13. Fragment of a decorated mount or strip torn at both ends and bent back on itself, perhaps deliberately to be melted down in a crucible. On the upper face of the mount there is a central rib and raised borders that are 1 mm thick and 1 mm in height standing proud of the strip. Within these borders are thinner, 0.6 mm wide, parallel ribs on either side of an upper and lower row of raised bosses, 1 mm in diameter, that have been pressed from the back of the mount. See GLO-E9EC16 for a record of the Woolaston hoard from Gloucestershire with a similar pattern on a bracelet that has been pressed from behind and is dated from c.1500-1100 BC.Length 23 mm; width 14 mm; thickness 1 mm; weight 1.15 g14. Fragment of a bracelet or cuff with a raised edge, now twisted from damage since deposition. There is a small perforation, 1 mm in diameter, at one end of the strip which may have been used for attachment and is similar to perforations below the edge of a cuff from the Capel Isaf hoard from Wales, illustrated in Savory (1980) on p.195, fig.47, no.302.4, which is dated from c.1500-1275 BC. See also two linked ribbon ornaments or rings with raised edges and a perforation for the corresponding hook from Binstead, West Sussex illustrated in the Treasure Annual Report 1998-1999, pp.10-11, no.3.Length 70 mm; width 4 mm; thickness 1 mm; weight 1.17 g
notes: Three of the objects (1, 2 & 3) can be dated by association to the Late Bronze Age and three of the objects (8, 9 & 10) cannot be dated to either phase unless they are analysed (see below).See NMGW-E48854 for a similar bracelet terminal fragment to No.1 which states:This form of bracelet has been recognised by Taylor (1984) as a type, which she has termed the 'Potterne Type', after a similar bracelet found at Potterne, Wiltshire. The form corresponds to Hook and Needham's (1989) Class B1 bracelet (which may or may not have the flanges). Hook and Needham list 21 examples of Class B1 and related bracelets from Britain and Europe, with a clear concentration of the type in southern England and with a band stretching across north Wales and Cheshire.The parallel from Potterne is of very similar form and is similar in  width at 8.25 mm. Other examples of the Potterne type have been found at Llanarmon-yn-Iân in Denbighshire (Green 1984) where a heavily worn bracelet with smaller terminals but of the same type was found with other gold items (a bracelet, an ingot and a link) and deposited within the socket of a faceted axe of type Gillespie. Excavations at Brean Down, Somerset revealed an associated pair of Potterne Type bracelets and possibly a small fragment from a third. The Brean Down examples are also more slender with maximum widths of 8.2 and 9.2mm. The dating of this bracelet type can be confidently placed in the Ewart Park period of the Late Bronze Age, corresponding to Needham's (1996) Period 7 and dated to 950-750 BC. The Llanarmon-yn-Iân bracelet was associated with a faceted axe of Ewart Park date, the Potterne find is thought to have been associated with the settlement rather than the midden with a suggested date in the mid 8th century BC. The Brean Down finds may be slightly earlier with a proposed date within the 10th-9th centuries BC (Bell, 1990 pp.71, 108).However, eight of the objects (4, 5, 6, 7, 11, 12, 13 & 14), which is over half the objects in the hoard, can be typologically dated to the Penard phase (c.1275-1150 BC) of the Late Middle Bronze Age so there is some suggestion of possible curation of artefacts or that they are focused in an area where continued activity in gold working or trade in gold objects spanned several hundred years.See record HAMP-8A11A7 for a hoard which contains two Bronze Age gold objects from different phases, a composite ring and a lock-ring, apparently deposited in the 2nd or 1st century BC, so providing a useful precedent for the gold objects of mixed chronology in this hoard (Dr Brendan O'Connor pers comm).It is hoped that the hoard will be analysed by Professor Gregor Borg using a non-destructive pXRF spectrometer at the Martin Luther University in Halle, Germany as part of the Cornish gold project in association with the analyses of the Nebra Sky Disc as a fragment of a worked piece of gold from the Middle Bronze Age.This hoard is an unusual one, both in the identification of the objects it contains and in its overall composition. While some of the objects can be identified as characteristic British Bronze Age types, others cannot. And even the identifiable types do not seem to be chronologically consistent, which is unusual for hoards of Bronze Age gold from Britain. It would thus be desirable for the contents to be analysed to establish whether or not the compositions of the individual objects are consistent. This might also help to judge whether any of the unusual types might be of exotic origin or significantly different date (Dr Brendan O'Connor pers comm).
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Treasure Case 2020 T120Description:A small rectangular strip of folded gold with one decorated surface that likely dates to the Bronze Age (c.1500BC - 800BC). The edges of the strip appear to have been cut rather than broken, suggesting that the object is complete. The strip has been folded almost exactly in half, with a small portion left uncovered. The outermost side is decorated with numerous fine, straight, 'incised' grooves, whilst the inner side remains undecorated.Dimensions:Length (folded): 16.5mmWidth (folder): 9.2mmThickness (folded): 1.2mmThickness (sheet): 0.5mmWeight: 0.9gDiscussion:The linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date, including finds from Sherborne St John, Hampshire, The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Case 1981; Palmer 1981); Corringham, Lincolnshire (2011 T459); Sproxton, North Yorkshire (2010 T664); Flixton, North Yorkshire (2003 T40a&b); and Ansley, Warwickshire (2007 T672). The find from The Hamel, Oxfordshire, came from the same layer as typologically late Beaker pottery dating to the Early Bronze Age (cf. Needham 2005). Given that it is similar to strips that usually have a greater length; it is not inconceivable that the Retford find has been cut from a longer strip.It is possible that the object was once tubular, in which case it may have formed a gold bead or similar (e.g.a fitting folded around the edges of another object). Elure provides a number of French examples of such beads ('perles tubulaires lisses': 1982, 29, figs. 24-7). An example from Bern, Switzerland is twice the length of the putative Retford bead and is decorated with grooves separated by undecorated surfaces (British Museum WG 468). Undecorated cylindrical gold beads have also recently been discovered in a Chalcolithic Beaker burial from Kingsmead Quarry in Berkshire (S. Needham pers comm.).Similar examples which have been recorded on the PAS database include LVPL-34D297 2012 T926, GLO-F8F3B7 2012T382 and SF-D30D10 2011T825.Conclusions:As the object likely contains at least  10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it meets the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A small rectangular fragment of Bronze Age gold, truncated by probable cuts at either end, dating to 2,400-800 BC. The front of the fragment is moulded into five parallel ribs, with an incised zig-zag on the sides of each rib, except for those on the external edges. The reverse is plain.  Dimensions: length 15.9mm; width 9.7mm; thickness 1.5mm; weight 2.48g.Discussion: The fragment can be compared to other ribbed gold strips identified as Bronze Age ribbons and recorded on the PAS database, cf. HAMP-36C41B; NLM-9CECFC; WMID-3CBCF0; WAW-C0C0B3.Conclusion: The artefact appears to be over 10% precious metal and to be over 300 years old at the time of finding, it therefore qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Wil PartridgeFinds Liaison Officer for Wiltshire
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: An incomplete strip of decorated gold, of probable Bronze Age dating (c. 1500 BC to c. 800 BC).The strip of gold is sub rectangular in shape and has been folded into a sub triangular shape. The strip has been decorated with a series of embossed ridges along its length. One end has a relatively straight and smooth cut edge, the other end is hidden inside the folds. It measures 13.2 mm in length, 4.4. mm wide and 4.0 mm thick. It weighs 1.1 g.Similar strips of gold with ribbed decoration have been recorded on the PASdatabase including WMID-fe3c28, ESS-C13B97, SUR-1B64F5, NMS-46A4D6, PAS-E9E2A1, SF-D30D10, LIN-946F12 and WAW-052196.Similar multi-grooved strips of a Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as recent finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48). A very similar strip from Sproxton, North Yorkshire is recorded on the PAS database as LVPL-83FE92. There is also a similar grooved strip from The Hamel, Oxford, Oxfordshire excavated from a layer which yielded Beaker pottery of the Early Bronze Age (Palmer 1980, 124-134). Similar narrow embossed strips are known from the pommels of daggers accompanying Early Bronze Age burials in Scotland (Henshall 1968, 173-95; Hardaker 1974, 21-23. fig 6.; Taylor 1980, fig 28a-f) but not however comparable to gold dagger fittings in contemporary burials southern England. Other Bronze Age gold strips found singly such as at Flixton, Yorkshire (British Museum 2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16, no. 2) are broader and have more and narrower incised grooves. The annular ring from the Late Bronze Age hoard at Abia de la Obispalia, central Spain is comparable in form and dimensions but the grooves appear to have been incised rather than embossed (Almagro Gorbea 1974). Similarly, the Bronze Age annular ring from Armissan, southeast France may be comparable (Elure 1981, 48-49, fig. 55).As this fragment is older than 300 years in age, with a precious metal content of greater than 10%, it should be considered as potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.ReferencesAlamagro Gorbea M. 1974, Orfebrera del Bronce Final en la Peninsula Ibrica. El Tesoro de Abia de la Obispala, la orfebrera tipo Villena y los cuencos de Axtroki, Trabajos de Prehistoria, 31, 39 - 100Case, H. 1980, 'Pottery, Flint and Metalwork' In Palmer, N. 1981, 'A Beaker Burial and Medieval Tenements in the Hamel, Oxford', Oxoniensia, XLV (1980), [Mircofiche], 1 A04Elure, C. 1982, Les Ors Prhistoriques, Paris: PicardHenshall, A.S. 1968, 'Scottish dagger graves', In Coles, J.M. & Simpson, D.D.A. (eds), Studies in Ancient Europe: Essays present to Stuart Piggott, Leicester: Leicester University PressPalmer, N. 1980, 'A Beaker Burial and Medieval Tenements in the Hamel, Oxford', Oxoniensia, XLV (1980), 124-225
notes: 3D model has been generated using mobile phone scanning application Qlone.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Summary: A hoard of late Bronze Age objects, with possible casting waste and lead ingots. It consists of:	4 socketed axeheads, one of which is near-complete	1 gouge	1 sword blade fragment	1 possible casting waste	3 rectangular lead objects, possibly ingotsCatalogue:1. Almost-complete socketed axe with double mouldings at socket, the fainter lower moulding is in line with the top of the side loop. The mouth of the socket is rounded and sub-square, tapering into a rectangular cross- section as the blade constricts to the slightly flared cutting edge. No hafting ridges were seen in the interior of the socket. Outer mould seams of the casting have been quickly finished but are still visible, especially at the socket mouldings and loop.The cutting edge was damaged in antiquity with an old, patinated break to one side of the blade; further (but minimal) recent edge loss has occurred and now appears a light green colour. Other localised patches of this surface loss are confined to the upper socket moulding, loop and small areas of the body of the casting. The main patination is otherwise dark brown, with rusty, iron oxide deposits adhering to the surface.Length 95.6mm, maximum width 44.4mm, thickness at socket 37.6mm. Weight 220g.2. Incomplete, facetted, socketed axe with one main moulding to the top of the socket; a second, fainter moulding is just visible below, in line with the top of the loop. The socket is sub-oval in cross-section with no hafting ridges visible. The lower portion of the socket is filled with soil which may include possible remains of the wooden handle. The side loop has triple mouldings along its length, one to the middle of the seam line, and one either side of the loop; the inside of the loop also has a slight ridge, though this is where the two halves of the mould join. The exterior mould seams have been worked, though they still stand marginally proud of the surface.The blade was broken across in antiquity, and is now patinated dark brown with slight iron oxide deposits to the surface. Minimal surface loss to the ridges of the body and socket now appear light green.Surviving length 80mm, width at break 38mm, thickness at socket 32mm. Weight with retained soil, 143.2g.3. Incomplete, almost square- to rectangular-section socketed axe. The mouth of the socket is double moulded, the lesser, lower moulding is in line with the top of the side loop. Below this are four vertical ribs moulded into the surface on both faces, starting to fade into the surface of the axe at the break. No internal hafting ribs are visible. The cutting edge is missing, broken across; the break is unworn but patinated the same colour as the surviving surface. The lower part of the break is partially filled with iron oxide deposits, as is one side of the upper surface of the side loop. The two valves (halves) of the mould used to cast this axe were misaligned; this is very noticeable on the loop. The casting seams are reduced, yet still visible and stand proud of the surface slightly. Similar patination as axes 1 and 2.Length 65.8mm, width at loop 46.3mm, thickness at socket 43.9mm, weight 188.4g.4. Fragment of an axe, the cutting edge only, broken across the bottom of the socket which is now partially filled with iron oxides. Patination as before; the recent light green losses to the surface are confined to the crescentic and gently expanding cutting edge and only lightly to parts of the break.Surviving length 25.4mm, width 46mm, maximum thickness 13mm. Weight 43.3g.5. Complete socketed gouge of typical elongated form. It has a circular cross section at the socket with no collar or mouth mouldings. A little less than halfway down the object, a longitudinal concave groove begins and runs down flaring to a semi-circular cross-section which forms the cutting edge at the other end. Patination as before, though the surface is a little more pitted, probably due to the casting rather than post-depositional degradation.Length 89.4mm. Socket outer diameter is 18.6mm, inside diameter is 13.7mm. Width across cutting edge, 16.9mm. 54g.6. Short length of sword blade, part of the width constriction between the main expanded, leaf-shaped blade and the handle. It has a thick cross-section with a convex centre which changes smoothly to concave towards the cutting edges. The edges themselves are recently damaged, with light green patination and no step visible to the (now missing) thin edges. Where undamaged, it has a dark brown patina. The same colour covers the unworn, granular breaks at either end as well, suggesting these are old breaks.Surviving length 40.4mm, maximum width 27.5mm, thickness 9.7 mm, weight 37.6 g.7. Bun ingot, irregular lumpen surfaces with some air bubbles within. One side is roughly convex and the other is almost flat. Grey/green patination with light brown sandy soil adhering in the hollows. There are no obvious breaks.It measures c. 45 x 45mm and is 19mm thick. Weight 132g.8. Rectangular lead possible ingot, neatly cast with rounded edges and a slight concavity to each face. Patination is off white with mottled brown iron oxides adhering, Slight abrasion to some of the edges showing as white or light grey compared to the original surfaces.34.5 x 31 x 12.5 mm, 107.8 g.9. Rectangular lead possible ingot of slightly larger size than 8, neatly cast with rounded edges and a slight concavity to each of the sides, the largest two faces are flat. Patination is white with very light brown speckles to one of the large, flat faces.38.8 x 31.8 x 15.3 mm, 180.8 g.10. Rectangular lead possible ingot of slightly larger size than 8 and 9, neatly cast with rounded edges as before, though the outside edges are straight, rather than convex. One main face is flat, the other has an off-centre depression, this appears to be ancient rather than post-depositional damage, as the surface is covered with rusty covered iron oxide deposits. The rounded edges are slightly abraded, and the off-white patination of the lead beneath is showing, one of the larger faces has lost a large proportion of its rusty coating.45.8 x 42.6 x 12 mm, 178.9 g.Discussion:AxesAxe 1 is of relatively plain form, with the only decoration being the double moulding at the mouth and just below at the socket. It is the most complete of the axes in this hoard, and is of typical plain South-Eastern type (Schmidt and Burgess 1981, pl. 85, nos. 1272-1290; Needham 1996 type A, sub class 1 plain). Ewart Park Phase (c.950-800 BC). See LVPL-201FD7 for a similar type.Axe 2 is of sub-octagonal cross-section and facetted form. Although the cutting edge was broken at the time of deposition, the remnants of the handle appear to be still attached within the socket. The break is slightly bent to one side, as if the axe twisted and broke while in use. Type Meldreth (Schmidt and Burgess 1981, pls 82 to 83, nos. 1222-1252). Ewart Park Phase (c.950-800 BC). See NLM-6A5B21 and OXON-84347A for other examples of this type.Axe 3 is of a pronounced square or rectangular cross-section, and of heavy build. The two sides are decorated with multiple ribs and the mouth is double moulded. Again, the cutting edge is missing, broken away before deposition. Type Sompting, Variant Roseberry Topping (Schmidt and Burgess 1981, pl. 103, nos. 1615-1622). Llyn Fawr Phase (early Iron Age, c.800-600 BC). See HESH-5C40D5 for a broadly similar type.Axe fragment 4 is a broken cutting edge which is not part of any of the other axes in this hoard. It is of a fairly standard type with slightly flaring, crescentic blade. As such a small, plain part remains, it is difficult to assign a type, though it is likely to be of the Ewart Park to Llyn Fawr phase (c.950-600 BC).GougeThis is a gouge of standard form. The lack of collar or mouth mouldings suggests it is likely to be a later type; see LEIC-6E2039 for a brief discussion. Ewart Park phase (c.950-800 BC).Sword fragmentOnly a small fragment of the blade of a sword was recovered, with old breaks at either end. The exact type is difficult to ascertain, but likely to be Ewart Park type, South-Eastern Step 1 to 4, Ewart Park Phase (c.950-800 BC).Bun ingotThe rough shape of the ingot 7 is recognisable as being at least part of a bun ingot, broadly diagnostic of the Late Bronze Age. Their distinctive plano-convex shape is due to the use of a bowl furnace to initially produce ingots from the raw copper-rich ore. They are normally roughly circular, and although there are no obvious breaks on this one, it is less regular in shape and may be incomplete. See KENT-14DDA6 for a complete example.The three lead itemsLead was increasingly used as an alloy in Bronze Age castings, with some Late Bronze Age axes containing upwards of 15% added lead (Timberlake 2016). Despite this, it is rare to find objects made from pure lead; exceptions include two earlier (middle Bronze Age) lead palstave axes, perhaps models used to make two-part moulds, recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database at DENO-A24823 and KENT368. There are also occasional lead-filled hollow items, such as the rings and socketed axe in hoard KENT-7C3863, and the socketed axes in hoard NARC-77BD13.Objects thought to be Bronze Age lead ingots are even rarer. A very few Late Bronze Age hoards include possible lead ingots, and those recorded on the PAS database include: HESH-9EC8BE (2018T769), a flat lead sheet used to wrap a pair of gold lock-rings; KENT-7DA0B5 (2004T228), two lead ‘objects’, one perforated; and ESS-F88237 (2018T659) a piece of lead casting waste. None of these is similar in shape to the three ingots from near Dereham, however, and their shape is not diagnostic of Bronze Age ingots.The hoard as a groupIt appears that many of the items were buried with contemporary breaks and parts missing, probably in order to store them safely until the metal could be melted down and reused. The gouge, being complete, may have been redundant and destined for recycling. The function of the three lead rectangular blocks remains obscure; although it could be suggested that they were there to be added to the recycling crucible if needed, the great rarity of lead ingots in the Bronze Age suggests that they may have had another, less utilitarian, function.Date: Most of the datable items within this hoard are from the Ewart Park phase of the late Bronze Age, c.950-800 BC. The most recent object is axe no. 3, a type known from the Llyn Fawr phase of the earliest Iron Age, c.800-600 BC, and this item’s date-range must represent the rough date of the hoard’s deposition.
notes: It is likely that the objects form a single find of Late Bronze Age date, which qualifies the group as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 (Designation Order 2002).
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure
