description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of Early Bronze Age dating (c. 2350 BC to c. 2050 BC).The flat axe is broadly sub rectangular in shape with a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with slight tapering edges. The butt is relatively thin having a narrow rounded profile; the width at the butt is 17.1 mm (thickness: 2.0 mm). The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the butt to the blade; in shape they are gently curved. The axe is thickest at the mid point (8.6 mm), with no traces of a proto stop ridge present. Potential decoration is present on one side as four circular depressions around the mid point. The sides of the blade expand to produce a crescentic blade edge with an abraded width of 34.3 mm (2.6 mm thick). The tips of the crescent shaped blade have been damaged through either abrasion or wear, as has the blade edge itself. It measures 80.7 mm in length, maximum width at the blade is 34.3 mm, width at the butt is 17.1 mm and it has a maximum thickness of 8.6 mm. It weighs 77.7 grams.The axe is a mid to dark green colour, with an uneven surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the ploughsoil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface detail.The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age and is comparable to (although not containing all the attributes of Migdale axes (many of these tend to have narrower butts which flare at the cutting edge).These axes all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2 circa 2350- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.Reference:Needham, S. (1996) Chronology and Periodisation in the British Bronze Age. Acta Archaeologia, vol 67, pp121-140Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.46-47.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold plated penannular ring. Small penannular ring with a copper core and thick gold sheet covering. The gold has decorative banding in narrow stripes formed by bands of yellow gold and paler, silver rich gold. It has a sub-circular cross section and the ends of the terminals are flat. One terminal retains a gold end cap, the other is missing, exposing the copper alloy core of the ring.It may be similar toDate: Late Bronze Age - c. 1150 - 800 BCDimensions: 14.86 mm x 14.05 mm x 4.41 mmWeight: 4.13 gAlso similar to DOR- 0A6139, DOR-D914C7 and DOR-18E227
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description:  A fragment of gold flange-twisted torc dating to the Middle Bronze Age (c. 1300-1100 BC). The fragment is a small section of the four-flanged twisted bar that is cruciform or '+' shaped in cross-section. It is broken at both ends.Measurements: The fragment measures 19.2mm in length, a maximum of 8.9mm wide, 8.2mm thick and weighs 3.31 grams.
notes: Conclusion:  Made of gold and of Bronze Age date, the fragment is evidently of a precious metal and over 300 years old, and therefore constitutes treasure under the Treasure Act (1996).
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description: A bent and twisted gold bracelet dating to the Middle Bronze Age c.1400-1100 cal BC.The bracelet is made from a single rectangular gold sheet that is crescent shaped in section with a convex outer surface and concave inner surface.  It was presumably originally curved into a penannular hoop without twists, however, it is now twisted into a spiral consisting of at three turns which is mostly flat in profile. Both ends of the strip end in clean transverse terminals which are slightly expanded. It is not clear whether these terminals represent the original length of the object or whether this has been damaged although have almost no sign of damage such that the former is more likely.The object is a bright gold colour. There are numerous scratches and dents on its outer surface and no signs of decoration.Dimensions: In its current state the bracelet is 104.2mm long. The strip has an estimated original width of 23.3mm, and original thickness of 3.0mm and weighs 63.3 gramsDiscussion: Being so warped the piece has only a few diagnostic features including a crescent cross-section and relative robust thickness. Similarly bracelets are held in the British Museums Collection originating from the Bexley Heath hoard, Kent (Museum number 1906,0709.9 also see Eogan 1994: plates 8-9), Tisbury, West Sussex (Taylor 1988: W79; Museum number AF.400) while other examples have been found in a hoard from Cottingham, Yorkshire (Eogan 1994: plate 12), Colaton Raleigh, Devon (Taylor 1999) and Rosemorran Farm, Cornwall (Knight et al. 2015: No.40). Each of these hoards contains gold bracelets with a similar thickness and cross section to this example. Often these have large everted terminals. This example possibly lacks the same terminals although one does begin to turn outwards and both may be truncated.  Furthermore those hoards cited above are notable for containing multiple gold bracelets with several different forms including plain terminals. It is therefore reasonable to conclude that this item fit the same tradition of metalworking seen in this period of these hoard’s deposition. Each of the hoards above are thought to date to the Ewart Park stage of the Bronze Age (see Eogan 1994 chapter 5 and references above) which dates to c.950-800 cal BC (following Roberts et al. 2013) which would be supported by the presence of similar items in the South Cadbury hoard (Pearce 1983 No. 731).Conclusion:  The object is a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Dr Edward CaswellFinds Liaison for Oxfordshire16th February 2022BSibliography:Eogan, G. (1994) The accomplished art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC). Oxford, Oxbow.Knight, M.G., Ormrod, T. and Pearce, S. (2015) The Bronze Age Metalwork of South Western Britain: A corpus of material found between 1983 and 2014. Oxford, British Archaeological Reports Oxford Ltd.Pearce, S.M. (1983) The Bronze Age metalwork of South Western Britain. BAR British series 120. BAR Publishing.Taylor, R.J. (1988) Hoards?: The interpretation and analysis of hoards of the Bronze Age in Southern Britain. Ph.D. [Online]. University of Reading. Available at: https://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?did=1&uin=uk.bl.ethos.380811 (Accessed: 7 May 2021).Taylor, J. 1999. ‘The Colaton Raleigh gold bracelet hoard and its significance to the interpretation of the Later Bronze Age’, Proceedings of the Devon Archaeological Society 57, 205-18.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Sheet gold hollow annular bead, circular in plan and slightly biconical in profile, but crushed since deposition so that its original form is unclear. The central circular piercing is 4 mm in diameter and the edges of the sheet are open to the inner aperture, but would have originally met and have been forced open from subsequent damage.See HAMP-72E451????? (2011 T526) for a similar annular sheet gold bead with a shallow biconical profile, from Buriton, Hampshire, and ESS-E87773 (2005 T150) from Harlow, Essex (Treasure Annual Report 2005/6, p.17, no.6), which are both dated from the Middle Bronze Age, c.1500-1000 BC.The three biconical gold beads from the Burton, Wrexham hoard are similar in form, size and weight (PAS-5B1745; Gwilt et al. in Barton 2011). The Burton hoard comprised of several typo-chronologically distinctive artefacts, including bronze palstaves, that allow it to be dated from c.1300-1150 BC (Ibid).Middle Bronze Age gold beads are a relatively rare find (Murgia et al. 2014) and can be contextualised with reference to the so-called 'ornament horizon(s)', which see a proliferation of bronze and gold ornaments in Southern England and Britain (respectively) during the period c.1400-1100 BC (Smith 1959, pp.151-155; Roberts 2007, pp.14-16).Murgia, A., Melkonian, M. & Roberts, B.W. (2014), European Bronze Age Gold in the British Museum, British Museum Press.
notes: Analysed by Professor Gregor Borg using an XRF spectrometer at the Martin Luther University in Halle, Germany as part of the Cornish gold project in association with the analyses of the Nebra Sky Disc as a fragment of a worked piece of gold from the Middle Bronze Age.Au 80 - 82.2 %Ag 14.4 - 16 %Cu 2.3 - 2.7 %Sn 0.37 - 0.45 %
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Description:A folded fragment of a gold strip or ribbon possibly dating to the Middle to Late Bronze Age c. 1500 - 800 BC. The ribbon is sub-rectangular in plan and made from a sheet of gold. One side of the ribbon is decorated with eight regular, longitudinal, incised grooves. The other side of the ribbon is plain with some light scratches. The ribbon is folded almost half-way down to face the reverse side and folds again at the terminal which has rough damaged edges. The damage is not new. The other end has a neat, flat-ended terminal with sharp 90 degree corners. There is a circular perforation at this end of the ribbon on the fourth and fifth ridge which is slightly off-centre. The diameter of the perforation is 1.1mm. There is an indentation on one edge of the ribbon by the terminal. On the decorated side of the ribbon, the perforation is surrounded by a lip and on the back of the ribbon it is surrounded by a shallow recess indicating that the perforation was punched through from the reverse side. The opposing end of the ribbon is also square-shaped but the edge has been bent over back to rest toward the perforated side of the ribbon. It is a little rough around the edges. There are also some longitudinal scratches and scuff marks on this plain side of the ribbon.Dimensions:Length: 17.8mmWidth: 6.6mmThickness: 3.93Weight: 1.3g.Discussion: A similar grooved, pierced gold ribbon is recorded under Treasure number 2012 T577 (ESS-C13B97), and other similar types of ribbons include: 2013 T326 (WILT-26F931), 2007 T692 (WAW-C0C0B3), 2014 T63 (BERK-387817), and 2013 T154 (PAS-067AC5).The incised linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date, particularly the find from Sherborne St John, Hampshire (2013 T154), which also had a single perforation to one and was decorated on only one side. The dimensions and weights of the bands are also comparable. The Tendering strip also bears comparison with gold strips from The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Case 1981; Palmer 1981); Corringham, Lincolnshire (2011 T459); Sproxton, North Yorkshire (2010 T664); Flixton, North Yorkshire (2003 T40a&b); and Ansley, Warwickshire (2007 T672). The find from The Hamel, Oxfordshire, came from the same layer as typologically late Beaker pottery dating to the Early Bronze Age (cf. Needham 2005).Conclusion: Due to the precious metal content of this object being over 10% gold, and it being over 300 years old, this object qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: A complete late Bronze Age gold penannular C-section bracelet with expanded terminals (c. 1000 BC-c. 750 BC). Treasure case no. 2019 T588.This bracelet is in good condition but is slightly misshapen and has some modern scuff marks. There is an old fracture on one edge of the band.Length: 86.8mm; width: 51.7mm; width of band: 9.3mm; width of terminals: 11.4mm; thickness of band: 2.4mm. Weight: 43.23g.Similar bracelets have been found throughout southern England, Taylor 1980; Eogan 1994). Eogan (1994) has noted nine different varieties in the British group and this bracelet, with its C-shaped body and expanded terminals, coincides with Eogan's (1994) Type no. 3. Two bracelets from the Tisbury Hoard, Wiltshire, are similar to this Isle of Wight example. (Eogan 1994, 85, fig. 38, pl. 11, no. 4 and 5).Compare with similar bracelets from Freshwater, Isle of Wight: IOW-FA17F8 (2007 T490) and Foxley civil parish, Norfolk: NMS-1FE356 (2005 T347).Taylor, J.J., 1981 Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Eogan, G. (1994). 'The Accomplished Art: gold and gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC)'. Oxford: Oxbow Monograph 42.
notes: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Declared Treasure but returned to Finder as Museum unable to acquire

description: A complete and unfolded Copper Age basket ornament dated to 2500-2200BC. This item, possibly hair ornaments or ear rings, has been cut from thin gold sheet and would normally have been wrapped into a cylindrical 'basket' shape. This example has been flattened out and shows the full extent of the oval plate which is 38mm long and 16mm wide with semi-circular ends and long straight sides. The interior of the plate is decorated with two concentric lines that run around the outside, inside of this are four zones of about five to six vertical lines running perpendicular to the long edges. This plate is heavily damaged with extensive creasing at either end, plus an off centre crease that runs the length of the plate. Protruding for the centre of one of the long edges is a long and thin (21mm long, 2.5mm wide) tang that would have ultimately been wrapped around the rolled cylindrical plate. As with the plate the tang is heavily creased.An almost exact parallel was found in South Oxfordshire 2012 T774 BERK-0D1A05, but also see BERK-F548E6, SUSS-096CEB, LON-FF7E65 and BH-956274This class of object belongs to the earliest phases of metallurgy in Britain. These are usually associated with burials and a very rare, dating to the earliest phase of the Bronze Age, c. 2400-2200 BC. Such objects are variously referred to as 'basket ornaments' or 'basket earrings', or 'hair rings'. They are in any case personal ornaments, and have been found in pairs in graves dating to the early Beaker period. Whether worn on hair, ears or items of costume, they were rolled into a basket shape in use.In shape and decoration this example falls into Needham's Atlantic Group B (ii) (Needham 2011). Closely similar ornaments were found in Beaker burials at Chilbolton, Hants and Radley 4a, Oxfordshire (Kinnes 1994).
notes: Acquired by the Corinium Museum
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Incomplete possible Bronze Age gold object, date unknown.Description: An incomplete and distorted gold object, possibly a bracelet. The object is made of what would have been a flat gold plate strip with slightly convex long edges, one rounded narrow edge, possibly representing a terminal and a ragged transverse break at its opposite end. The object is now bent and distorted over itself and into an L shape.18.0mm (length); c. 55.0mm (length if straightened); 5.0mm (width of band); 1.2mm (thickness of band). Weight: 3.19g.Discussion: The object has few diagnostic features being made of a thin strip of gold. Gold bands are relatively undiagnostic component of (perhaps especially Middle and Later) Bronze Age goldwork in Southern England (c.1500-800 BC) (see Murgia et al. 2014a; Murgia et al. 2014b).There are similar examples previously recorded on the database that have been declared treasure from Dorset (2014T256), Wiltshire (2020T803), Warwickshire (2018T288) and Surrey (2017T922) which are suggested to be fragments from Bronze Age bracelets (e.g. 2009T435 and 2014T39). There are also examples which are suggested to come from the Roman to Early Medieval period (NLM-E8C60D, SWYOR-089827 and IOW-36803C) although each of these examples have less clear rounded terminals. As a result on the balance of probabilities this band can also be assigned to the Bronze Age, although a more precise date within the period is difficult to ascertain.Metal content: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it therefore qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
notes: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A gold unidentified object possibly of the Bronze Age period, dating to 1500 BC- 800 BC. This consists of a rectangular strip of metal which has been rolled into a cylinder with wrapped overlapping terminals, the item has been subsequently squish resulting in its current flattened form. The outer face of the cylinder is decorated with eight parallel grooves running lengthwise.Discussion: This multi-grooved strip of gold is possibly a bead of potential Bronze Age date. It is similar to several examples recorded through the Portable Antiquities Scheme and dated to the Late Bronze Age. See SF-AC2907, SF-D30D10, GLO-F8F3B7, WMID-FE3C28.The object contains more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

otherRef: Hampshire Cultural Trust Object Entry Form WINCM 823
description: A Late Bronze Age (1150-800 BC) small gold penannular ring, circular in cross-section with cut terminals, the gap between them measuring 1.8mm wide. The circular cross-section measures 3.1mm, narrowing at the terminals to 2.8mm.The object is oval in overall shape, measuring 14.0mm in length, 12.5mm in width, 3.1mm in max.thickness and weighs 3.56g.
notes: 'The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange' (Mark Lodwick and Mary Davis in record NMGW-04216C; references therein).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Late Bronze Age (c1150 to c800 BC) gold penannular ring (or 'lock ring') formed from gold sheets; the weight of the object suggests that these are probably wrapped around a copper-alloy core. The ring is bi-conical in form, with flat triangular terminals. There is a prominent ridge running around the outer edge. Both faces are decorated by transverse, parallel striations. There is some damage to the inner edge of one of the faces, where the two sheets have come apart slightly.Diameter: 28.69mm, thickness: 8.86mm, weight: 7.25gThere are a number of similar examples recorded on the database, including: NCL-066786 (2019 T94), SUSS-5EA230 (2017 T349), ESS-5ECCA2 (2016 T592) and SUR-EFB639 (2019 T87). This type of object is well-represented from late Bronze Age contexts, although the precise function of these rings remains unclear.As the object is an item of prehistoric precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
notes: Valued by the Treasure Valuation Committee (24/03/22): £1,500
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Hoard consisting of two complete gold-plated cast penannular rings dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c.1150-750 BC), and a probable Bronze Age (c. 1000 BC-750 BC) awl. The rings and awl were discovered within a few feet of each other.The penannular rings are in the shape of an oval-sectioned loop that tapers slightly towards the terminals. One of the rings is plain. The other is heavily corroded on the surfaces but appears to have ribbed decoration.The uncorroded ring is 16.9mm in diameter, with a thickness of 5.7mm and a weight of 8.14g. The corroded ring is 19mm in diameter, 7mm thick and weighs 11.41g.The probable Bronze Age awl is circular in section and tapers to a blunt point at one end and a rounder point at the other. The surface has a dark green patina with some small areas of fine pitting.The awl measures 85.2mm in length, a maximum of 4.2mm in diameter and weighs 6.88 grams.Awls are difficult to date but most are probably the Late Bronze Age. They can have circular or square cross sections and are generally undecorated. They would have been used to make holes in leather or wood and probably were inserted into a handle made from organic materials. Awls were a range of rod-like tools that were usually round sectioned and pointed at one end, and rectangular sectioned with a square or chiselled edge at the other (Rowlands 1976 48). 'Awl' is often used to refer to any number of small, pointed instruments. Referred to as "pointed punches" by Coles (1963-64 117), they were presumably used for perforating leather.As a functional object the form of the awl barely changes from the Bronze Age to Medieval periods and a selection of broadly comparable awls are recorded in Ottaway and Rogers (2002). They note that although most awls are associated with leather working, some would have been used in woodworking, bone working and other crafts.
notes: Conclusion:  As the penannular rings are Bronze Age in date and made of gold, they qualify as treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996. Being found close to them and of similar date, it is possible that the awl is associated with them and qualifies as treasure as part of this case.BibliographyColes, J.M. (1964). 'Scottish Middle Bronze Age Metalwork', Proc Soc Antiq Scot, 97 (1963-4).Ottaway, P. and Rogers, N. (2002). Craft, Industry and Everyday Life: Finds From Medieval York York: York Archaeological Trust and CBA.Rowlands, M.J. (1976). The Production and Distribution of Metalwork in the Middle Bronze Age in Southern Britain: Part ii'. Oxford: British Archaeological Reports.
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: Two amorphous globs of molten gold, that survives as evidence of goldworking of an uncertain date. In both cases the gold is very pure, with a slightly pitted surface of a solidified fluid and bases that are flat suggesting they were poured or dropped onto a flat surface when molten. One piece is slightly rougher on its surfaces having ragged breaks on all sides barring its base. The high purity, pitted surface and solidified fluid form confirms that this gold has been (re)worked rather than being an example of a naturally occurring nugget of gold ore. Piece 1 is 45.5mm long, 31.3mm wide, 9.5mm thick and weighs 48.92 grams Piece 1 is 15mm long, 10.2mm wide, 14.1mm thick and weighs 14.19 gramsDiscussion: The form of this object is undiagnostic meaning it is difficult to date with certainty, although other finds in the area have been dated to the Bronze Age (see below). Similarly undiagnostic examples on the database have been found from Yorkshire (2018 T986), the Isle of Wight (IOW-41DA55) and Cheshire (LVPL-B3875C). Conclusion: On balance of probability, the two objects are likely more than 300 years old, and being composed of more than 10% precious metal, fulfil the criteria for Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996.Note: This group of artefacts was found within several hundred metres of two other assemblages of likely Bronze Age material: references 2019 T426 (a copper-alloy axehead and 10 piece of gold) and 2019 T617 (a bent and twisted gold bracelet). Whilst not believed to be directly associated with one another, the three finds demonstrate that this was an area of Bronze Age depositional activity.Dr Edward Caswell, Finds Liaison Officer, Oxfordshire
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A gold working hoard dating to the Early Bronze Age consisting of a flat axe, gold bar ingot fragment and 8 pieces of scrap gold. These are discussed below.1) An incomplete cast copper alloy flat axe or chisel of Early Bronze Age date (c. 2000 - 1700 BC). The axe probably best fits within the Migdale metalworking traditionThe object is sub-trapezoidal in plan expanding from one broken terminal, marked by an irregular transverse break, down most of its length before narrowing again at an incomplete crescent blade edge. This blade is missing a chip at one of its wings, giving it a diagonal edge and has chips along is edge. The object is rectangular in cross section and profile thickening only slightly towards its centre.The fragment has a medium green patina that is pitted and chipped with several parallel scratches running diagonally across its body on one side which may be the result of movement in the ground.The fragment is 50.6mm long, 30.6mm wide, 5.1mm thick and weighs 31.09 gramsThis axehead is almost identical to an example from a Hoard found in Cornwall (2018T617) described as coming from the later phases of the Migdale tradition (specifically the undecorated variant) based on a parallel illustrated by Pearce (1983: no.587) from Banner Down Somerset. This form of axehead is suggested to date from 2250-1900 cal BC (Needham 2017). The axe matches Needham’s (2017) class 3 (possibly 3D Type Barton Stacey) a having narrow thin butt, lenticular profile, moderate haft end expansion, sides with gentle curvature, and broad mid-blade and cutting edge. Also being flat (as in having no raised flanges or stop ridge) which is dated to this same time period. Further examples on the database include HAMP-3781B6, CORN-3237B8 and CORN-7ACDD7.Gold fragments2) Fragment of scrap gold placed in same bag as the axeA broken fragment of a gold ingot dating to the Bronze Age. The fragment has ragged breaks at both ends and a sub rectangular to trapezoidal cross section, with irregular edges characteristic of being hand worked. Both edges are beveled and the surfaces are undecorated.The fragment is 8.6mm long, 8.1mm wide, 3.1mm thick and weighs 1.81 grams3) A broken fragment of a gold ingot dating to the Bronze AgeThe ingot is sub-rectangular in plan, with one rounded end and another that ends in an ragged transverse break. It has a sub rectangular to trapezoidal cross section, with irregular edges characteristic of being hand worked. Both edges are beveled and the surfaces are undecorated. There does appear to be a contraction point close to the break marked by a wide (c.2.2mm) transverse lines visible on both wide surfaces possibly the result of being clipped at this point.The fragment is 15.3mm long, 8.9mm wide, 4.1mm thick and weighs 5.70 grams4-11) 11 fragments of scrap gold. The largest fragment (4) is thick at one ragged break but then widens and flattens down towards it second ragged transverse break. It is 21.4mm long, 20.2mm wide, 4.8mm thick and weighs 8.88 grams5 is an irregular fragment that is 13.9mm long, 11.7mm wide, 2.9mm thick and weighs 2.22 grams6 is an irregular fragment that is 11.7mm long, 8.1mm wide, 1.9mm thick and weighs 1.31 grams7 is mostly flat with slightly upturned edges and is 11.2mm long, 6mm wide, 1.5mm thick and weighs 0.72 grams8 is an irregular fragment that is 7.1mm long, 5.8mm wide, 1.8mm thick and weighs 0.42 grams9 is an irregular fragment that is 7.1mm long, 5.4mm wide, 2mm thick and weighs 0.67 grams10 is an irregular fragment that is 7.5mm long, 6.6mm wide, 1.5mm thick and weighs 0.57 grams11 is an irregular fragment that is 8.9mm long, 6.5mm wide, 1mm thick and weighs 0.49 gramsDiscussion: The axehead can be confidently dated to the Early Bronze age specifically  c.2250-1900 cal BC. The fragments associated with this abject are varied in form and shape but  are all appropriate fragments that could have been cast into various other objects. The range in shapes and forms is very similar to that seen in a larger hoard from Fitzleroi Farm, Sussex held by the British Museum (Museum number 1996,0902) which was dated to the Middle Bronze Age based on the inclusion of objects (bracelet) specifically the Ornament Horizon (c.1400-1100 cal BC). Gold working assemblages are also known in the Early Bronze Age most notable at Upton Lovell (Shell 2000).Conclusion: Many of the object are a minimum of 10% precious metal and are likely to be over 300 years old. These are associated with one copper alloy object. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content and also being a collection of more than one metal object buried in association.Dr Edward Caswell, Finds Liaison Officer, OxfordshireBibliographyNeedham, S.P. (2017) The Classification of Chalcolithic and Early Bronze Age Copper and Bronze Axe-heads from Southern Britain. Oxford, Archaeopress Access Archaeology.Pearce, S.M. (1983) The Bronze Age metalwork of South Western Britain. BAR British series 120. BAR Publishing.Shell, C.A., (2000) Metalworker or shaman: Early Bronze Age Upton Lovell G2a burial. Antiquity, 74(284), pp.271-272.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A fragment of a gold plated copper alloy Bronze Age penannular ring fragment dating from 1150 - 750 BC. When complete, the ring would have been circular and penannular. About a quarter to a third of the ring survives. It is circular in cross-section, tapering from a break where it is about 5mm diameter, to a fairly blunt, gold-plated terminal of about 2.5mm diameter. The break and places where the gold has flaked off reveal the core to be copper alloy. The fragment is about 22mm long, and 5mm in diameter at wider end. 3.99g.The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange' (Mark Lodwick and Mary Davis in record NMGW-04216C; references therein).Most of the examples on the PAS database are solid gold and have a more uniform diameter along their length. However, more tapered examples are known, including DUR-EC189D (2015 T978), DOR-1B028B (2015 T193) and LEIC-4AB781 (2012 T573). Gold-plated base metal examples are also well represented, including WILT-36F326 (2014 T676).
notes: The item qualifies as Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996 as amended by Designation Order 2002, in that it is of prehistoric date and part of the object is precious metal.Report compiled from images and notes during the Covid-19 Crisis without access to the object.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: An incomplete strip of decorated gold ribbon, dating to the Bronze Age (2350 - 800 BC). The ribbon is rectangular in plan but has become bent in some areas probably due to post depositional damage. One edge of the ribbon has slightly rounded corners and does not appear to be broken unlike the opposite edge which appears to have been cut, resulting in one of the corners protruding jaggedly from the diagonal cut. The object is decorated on one side with nineteen parallel, incised grooves, these are evenly spaced except the first and last grooves which are set further in from the edges of the ribbon than the spaces between the rest of grooves. The other side of the ribbon is undecorated.Similar strips of decorated gold ribbon have been recorded on the database and dated to the Bronze Age: WMID-FE3C28, BERK-387817 and NMS-6E2A74. There was also a similarly decorated gold strip excavated in The Hamel, Oxford which was contextually dated to the Beaker Period (Palmer, 1980, 131).Length 29.79mm, width 15.24mm, thickness 1.2mm and weight 2.97g.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

otherRef: Hampshire Cultural Trust Object Entry Form WINCM 780
description: A fragment of Middle Bronze Age (probably Penard phase, c. 1300 - 1100 BC) flange- or bar-twisted gold torc bent almost in half on itself longitudinally, with breaks at either end. The torc has a cruciform (x-shaped) cross-section with four flanges, although they twist in such a way as to give a circular cross-section around the flanges. The breaks are quite sharp, suggesting they could be quite recent. The bend is not quite at the centre of the object.The ends, both slightly squashed, measure 8.2x6.2mm and 8.4x7.3mm. At these breaks the flanges are c.0.6-0.8mm thick, with a thickened rim (slightly flattened to the outside surface) 0.9-1.0mm thick. At the deepest, the depth between the flanges is c.2.5mm deep. The width/ diameter of the object is relatively parallel and c.9mm.The fragment measures 41.6mm in bent length (unbent it would be c.75mm), 26.8mm in max width and 8.9mm in max.thickness. It weighs 18.24g.
notes: Its cross-section is very similar to another (terminal) fragment, 2015 T983, found in a neighbouring parish.
subsequentActionTerm: Declared Treasure but returned to Finder as Museum unable to acquire

otherRef: Hampshire Cultural Trust Object Entry Form WINCM 788
description: An incomplete Late Bronze Age (1150-800 BC) gold-plated copper alloy penannular ring, D-shaped in cross-section and missing an area of gold-plating revealing the (corroding) copper alloy interior. Both 'faces' of the object are slightly flattened, as is the interior edge; the outside edge is convex. The terminals are cut in parallel alignment with each other and measure 4.1x5.0mm and 4.3x5.0mm. The object is slightly thicker at the edge opposite the terminals, where it measure 5.1mm in max.thickness. It measures 15.3mm between this edge and the terminals, and 15.7mm perpendicular to this. The internal area is oval in shape and measures 6.8x7.1mm. The object weighs 4.68g.
notes: 'The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange' (Mark Lodwick and Mary Davis in record NMGW-04216C; references therein).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Bronze age? gold bead or bracelet fragment, 11mm long, 4mm wide and 2mm thick with a weight of 0.25g. The object is rectangular in form and sub circular in cross section. It consists of a rectangular fragment of worked sheet which has been folded up to make a bead? It has one clear complete plain edge then the body has a series of parallel indented lines about 0.5mm apart, running across its body to an incomplete edge. These appear to be the impressions of incised decoration, forming a ridged surface on what is now the inside. The two almost joining edges appear to be one straight, probable complete edge and one irregular edge.The decoration is similar to various Bronze age Bracelets /ribbons such as LEIC-171B50 SOM-62CE08 WMID-3CBCF0
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Description: Rectangular piece of gold sheet with repoussé and punched decoration, of early to middle Bronze Age date. The decoration consists of three longitudinal panels, each one made from a pair of relief lines or creases with  corresponding grooves on the reverse, so either pushed out from the reverse (the repoussé technique) or hammered over a  shaped former or patrix.  Each of the panels is filled with two longitudinal rows of punched dots, some set in pairs and others offset to give a zig-zag effect. The punch used was circular and round-ended.Each short edge is broken, but each straight long edge has about 2mm in width neatly folded over to the reverse; the fold runs along the outermost of the relief lines. The entire object is now crumpled.Part of the same object later recorded, though the two parts do not join: NMS-81CA76Dimensions: Maximum surviving length 40mm. The width varies due to the crumpled condition, from a minimum of 13mm in the centre to a maximum of 17mm at one end. The sheet is perhaps 0.25mm thick and the folded areas are a maximum of 1.5mm thick. It weighs 3.0g.Discussion and Date: Rectangular gold strips with dot or pointillé decoration have been recorded on the PAS database at BUC-4313C7, PAS-35C8A8 and WAW-FF1E9A, and longitudinal creases have been recorded at WILT-34D958. This example has relatively complex decoration, but otherwise fits well into a group of ribbon or strip ornaments of early to middle Bronze Age date, c. 2350 to 1000 BC.
notes: As the object is made of more than 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.ENF145877Drawing by Jason Gibbons
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: TREASURE CASE : 2019 T274.Description:A decorated sheet of gold of probable Bronze Age date, c.1000 - 800 BC.The object is formed of a thin sub-rectangular sheet of gold, folded over at one end. It is not possible to determine if the object is complete or cut down though the latter is likely. The front surface of the sheet is decorated by a series of sub-parallel indented grooves running along its length.Dimensions:Length: 10.4mm; Width: 9.6mm; Thickness: 0.3mm; Weight: 0.4g.Discussion:Similar objects have been recorded as 2019 T316 (LEIC-47D0C2), 2018 T650 (HAMP-F792A5), 2010 T664 (LVPL-83FE92) and 2013 T471 (WMID-3CBCF0). The latter record states that similar multi-grooved strips of Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as recent finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48).2017 T882 (SOM-62CE08) states that several similar pieces have also been found bent into cylindrical beads and it is unclear if this was their original purpose or if this was a common reuse for parts of larger ribbon ornaments.Conclusion: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description: A Middle Bronze Age gold composite penannular ring, possibly incomplete, probably dating to c. 1300-1150 BC. The object consists of two concavo-convex bands of gold sheet which appear to have been soldered together and curved around to form a loop, the latter left open.Dimensions: diameter 13.9mm; width 7.9mm; thickness 2.3mm; weight 3.26g.Discussion: Comparison to other artefacts of the same type would suggest that the present artefact formed the outer cover for a base metal or organic core, along with an inner gold sheet, cf. YORYM-06C5C1, BERK-E2ED60, NMS-ACBFA4 on the PAS database.The penannular ring appears to consist of over 10% precious metal and to be over 300 years old at the time of finding and as such qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Wil PartridgeFinds Liaison Officer for WiltshireMarch 2019
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Brooch of Central European, Bronze Age, type, c.1100-800 BC. It is made from a single length of 2.7mm diameter, copper alloy wire, one end of which is a tightly wound to form a six turn spiral. From this the wire is bent back on itself to form a hook-like catch plate. The wire is twisted back and forth to form five, figure of 8 loops on the end of which is an integral pin. The wire is cracked at this point. The brooch is in excellent condition with a mid-brown patination which contains some grains of sand. Length 99.3mm, Width 41.7mm, Height 26.2mm, Mass 30.31g.This brooch is of Central European type and can be closely paralleled by two examples found in a hoard of gold jewellery on the bank of the Danube between Duna-Fldvr and Paks in Hungary. This was dated to the 11th to 9th century BC (Hugh Tait, 7000 years of Jewellery, The British Museum, 2006, 51, plate 108). A further parallel is provided by an example in Merseyside Museums which is provenance as 'Northern Hungary' (Susan Nicholson, Catalogue of the Prehistoric Metalwork in the Merseyside County Museums, Merseyside County Council, Liverpool,, 1980, 70, No. 141.While it is not impossible for this object to have found its way to England in antiquity its condition, and the fact that it was a surface find, suggest that it may be a recent import, perhaps coming from a European collection during the Second World War and, its significance unrecognised, subsequently lost.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold terminal from a bar torc of Middle Bronze Age date. c.1300-1150 BCThe terminal is trumpet shaped with a flat end, 8.7 mm diameter. In section it is more or less octagonal, having eight irregular, undecorated facets. It narrows to 4.5 mm diameter and bends back on itself, forming a U-shape and terminating in a break. At the break, the shaft of the torc is bent upwards slightly, ie, out of alignment with the terminal; this probably represents damage rather than the original shape. (compared with intact examples of bar torcs such as British Museum number 1932,0511.2 ) The surface of the break has a flat, sloping component, which may suggest it was cut. The break does not appear to be fresh.Apart from the bending associated with the break, there is no evidence of twisting of the bar, which was a common decorative feature of Bar Torcs (Eogan 1967, 8 - 12 ) It is possible that the terminal was fashioned as a separate piece and attached to the bar by a collar, as in the case with the east Cambridgeshire torc, described on this database in record CAM-E5D871, but no evidence of a collar or other means of attachment can be seen.The eight-facetted cross-section appears to be unusual, most bar torc terminals are circular or square in section. The facets are not regular and show signs of hammering.The length and diameter of the terminal are smaller than other examples on this database or on British Museum gallery; possibly this is from an armlet rather than a neck torc.Length from end surface to bend 42 mm, from bend to break 31 mm. Overall width 40.3 mm. Weight 21.1 g
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Gold bracelet fragment. Cast pentagonal-section strip, broken at one end and flattened to spatulate form at the other. The section is angular, with two low and probably worn facets on what is taken to have been the display or outer face, producing a gently keeled appearance. This is carried along the object to the spatulate end, which may therefore be regarded as a deliberately fashioned terminal to a penannular and probably symmetrical form, with its equivalent now lost. The object is now curved with two sharper and one more gentle bends, with two cracks near the latter. The finder kindly notes that the curved parts near the flat terminal and towards the other end of the object both fit snugly against the wrist if the keeled face is set outwards, though of course the object may as easily be worn around the neck. The finder also notes the object has been tested - presumably non-destructively - and its material confirmed as 'pure gold'. Extensive search around the find spot has yet to reveal the missing fragment. Suggested date: Late Bronze Age, 1000-800 BCGiven its age and material the object is to be subjected to the Treasure process, Ref. 2019 T188. Its association with other Bronze Age finds reported from the vicinity also commends it as a 'find of note'.Length: 127mm, Width: 18.4mm, Thickness: 3.4mm, Weight: 48.58gms
notes: The landowner kindly waived a reward for this find, to enable it to be acquired by North Lincolnshire Museum.
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: Copper alloy spear head. Cast pegged and socketed spearhead, retaining the end of a wooden shaft within, which is now pale brown in colour and fibrous in its appearance. The spearhead takes the form of a regular cone with opposed flanges forming blades which extend from the pointed tip for 71mm, or to 21mm above the mouth of the socket. Opposed drilled holes are set 9.4mm, or half way between socket and flanges, and are aligned with them. One of these holes is of 4mm diameter; the other retains the burred head of a rivet of diameter 4.4mm. Three finely incised circumferential lines immediately below them may have served to set out the holes. Above them, a zig-zag pattern of elongated dots - or perhaps dashes given the form - produces a series of six triangles between the rivet holes and a seventh carried over the occupied hole, with each triangle of height 4mm. A further two circumferential lines of dots are carried around the socket mouth below the triplicated continuous lines.The outer cutting edges of the blades are lightly abraded, showing a green tint against an overall brown patina, and along with limited abrasions on one side of the object these are the only indications of deterioration or damage. As with other objects of the period hereabouts, the spearhead appears to have been deposited in working order. The practice of ritual 'killing' of an object does not seem to figure here.The triplicate decoration combined with zig-zag motifs recurs in WAW-C65A09, a spearhead recently reported from Warwickshire. That example is held to be of later Bronze Age date, 1150-600 BC. In this case, the relative proportions of blade and socket are different, with more blade and less socket. A stubby peg-hole spearhead from Burton on Stather, North Lincolnshire, displayed in the North Lincolnshire Museum, more closely resembles this example, and is ascribed to the Early Bronze Age, probably c.1600BC or thereafter.Suggested date: Middle to Late Bronze age, 1600-800 BCLength: 94mm, Width (at blade): 24.5mm, Diameter (socket): 22.6mm, Thickness (wall, at mouth of socket): 1.7mm, Weight: 50.20gms
notes: This object gains in importance from its apparent association with other objects, including a gold bangle or torc, and axe heads of Early, Middle and Late Bronze age form, reported from the vicinity. Like this spearhead, all of these objects except the mangled bangle were found in 'working order'. The individual deposits would appear to have been deliberate rather than casual losses. This pattern of deposition may follow the model of a 'persistent place' as advanced by Dr Adam Daubney with reference to Lincolnshire, an observation kindly offered by Dr Kevin Leahy. However, with objects so far dated to between the Early Bronze Age (2350-1600BC) and the Late Bronze Age (1000-800 BC), it would imply this to be a cultic centre of greater longevity than any Christian holy place in Britain. The model may also cut across those interpretations associating Later Bronze Age metalwork deposits with the margins of encroaching wetlands in periods of climatic change.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: A gold biconical bead of 8.4mm diameter, with slightly dished, concave faces and a central hole 2.5mm in diameter. The inner surface of the hole is rough and there is a visible casting flaw within the interior. The solidity of the bead and the rough cylindrical interior of the central hole suggests that the method of manufacture was casting rather than construction from sheet metal.Diameter: 8.4mm, thickness / height: 6.3mm, weight: 1.88g.
notes: This bead is likely to date to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1500-1100 BC) based on comparanda from the database (NMS-AEC678 (2013T20), HAMP-72E451 (2011T526), PAS-65902F (2015T175) and GLO-46CA05 (2014T358)) and various other excavated examples from stratified contexts (as quoted in these PAS records). Such Middle Bronze Age gold beads are a relatively rare find (Murgia et al.) and can be contextualised with reference to the so-called 'ornament horizon(s)', which see a proliferation of bronze and gold ornaments in Southern England and Britain (respectively) during the period c.1400-1100 BC (Roberts, 2007).Conclusion: The object contains more than 10% precious metal and is of prehistoric date. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 and the 2002 Treasure Designation Order, in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description: A gold-plated Late Bronze Age penannular ring, dating to 1150-800 BC. The inner edge is slightly flattened. At the ends, the edges have several cracks, which reveal the copper-alloy core. In the gap between the two ends of the ring there is a fragment of copper-alloy corrosion. The surface is decorated with a series of parallel bands of two different colours or alloys of gold.Dimensions: 17.51mm external diameter; internal diameter 6.51mm; 6.73mm in thickness. It weighs 7.65g.Discussion: From NMGW-04216C 'The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange'.A number of such rings have been reported to the PAS (KENT-FF00A6) and some have been declared treasure. E.g banded plated example PAS-011055 (2016T920), plane plated), SUSS-1CBAB0 (2017T984) rolled up tube LANCUM-80A136 (2011T499).The object contains precious metal and is of Prehistoric date. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Hoard of two cast copper alloy miniature flat axeheads of the Early Bronze Age, c.2200-2000 BC.The smaller of the two flat axeheads (2018 T617a) is about two thirds the length of the other (2018 T617b). The axehead is sub-triangular in plan, lenticular in section and in profile, 59 mm in length, 30 mm wide at the blade end and 18 mm wide at the butt end, 7 mm thick and weighs 40.75 g. At 59 mm in length the axe is about a third of the size of a standard Early Bronze Age flat axehead from South West England. The sides are straight but not parallel and expand outwards towards the blade end which is crescentic in plan. Half of the surface is covered in a dark brown skin of corrosion product with some deep pits revealing copper-coloured layers beneath, and there is no evidence of any form of incised decoration on the surface of the axehead. The butt end and the opposite cutting edge has been damaged through movement in the soil since deposition but the sides are still untouched showing the cast edges, which suggests that the axehead was never used. The size of the axehead makes it difficult to haft and would also render it useless for chopping and the blade would not be suitable for chiselling either.The larger of the two flat axeheads (2018 T617b) is sub-triangular in plan, lenticular in section and in profile. At 89 mm in length the axehead is about half the size of a standard Early Bronze Age flat axehead from South West England. It is 41.6 mm wide at the blade end, tapering to 20 mm at the butt end; its maximum thickness is 6.7 mm and its weight 101.9 g. The sides are straight but not parallel and expand outwards towards the blade end which is curved in plan. Much of the surface is covered in a brown skin of corrosion product with some pits revealing light green bronze disease, and there is no evidence of any form of incised decoration on the surface of the axehead. One face has been damaged by a sharp blade that has created a diagonal groove across the entire face. The cutting edge is also damaged through movement in the soil since deposition and there are scratches in perpendicular directions on one face where the skin has been removed from abrasive action, exposing some of the original surface. On either side of this damage, some of the original cutting edge of the blade survives, suggesting that the axehead was never used as a tool.Pearce (1983) describes a miniature Migdale (Sutherland, Scotland) type flat axehead, with an expanded blade like 2018 T617a, from Banner Down, Somerset on page 502, which is illustrated in pl.69, no.587 and a wider, broader Migdale type flat axehead with straight sides like 2018 T617b, from Harlyn Bay, Cornwall on page 418, pl.12, no.98c, which are both associated with the Migdale metalworking tradition of the Early Bronze Age, c.2200-2000 BC.Schmidt & Burgess (1981) discuss Migdale flat axeheads on pp.35-45 and the Biggar variants, with their straighter sides and less rounded cutting edges, on pp.46-48. These are illustrated in plates 5 to 19. A similar Migdale miniature flat axehead to 2018 T617a with a more crescentic blade is illustrated in pl.22, no.266, and similar narrow small flat axeheads of the Biggar variant type to 2018 T617a, with a more expanded blade, and to 2018 T617b with a shallow curve to the blade, from Caithness and Yorkshire, are illustrated in pl.19, nos.235 & 241.There are similar miniature Migdale type axeheads recorded on the database in WMID-58D2F4 and LVPL-DA4598, which is referred to as a 'Biggar' variant of the Migdale type of flat axehead, with slightly crescentic blades like 2018 T617a, and similar small flat axeheads to 2018 T617b recorded in HAMP-3781B6, CORN-3237B8 and CORN-7ACDD7.These axeheads all fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, Metalworking Stage II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996, p.122) Period 2 (c.2350-2050 cal BC). This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae.
notes: The dimensions recorded below are for the larger of the two flat axeheads (2018 T617b) but the dimensions for both axes are above in the description field.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A gold lock-ring and three small fragments of gold. The lock-ring is decorated with a series of incised concentric lines. One edge of the lock-ring is broken in a ragged edge, the other follows a neat line that may represent the original edge or a cut mark. The lock-ring is in a moderate condition, with cuts and distortion across its faces. There is evidence of tubing holding the two faces together (this has lifted in one section to reveal this construction technique). Around 1 quarter of the object is now missing and it is unclear from the initial inspection whether the small gold fragments form part of the broken edge or whether they are remains of other elements within the lock-ring construction. More investigation of this piece is required. Dimensions: Weight 2.62g; Diameter: 29.6mmScientific AnalysisAnalysis was carried out by the Department of Scientific Research at The British Museum. Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis indicated a surface composition of approximately 80-82% gold, 14-16% silver, the rest being copper. DiscussionThis Late Bronze Age gold ‘lock-ring’ dates to the Late Bronze Age (c.1000-800 BC). Lock-rings are known in relatively small numbers from Ireland, Britain and western France (Eogan 1969). A small number of examples are known from the North of England and the South of Scotland (see Eogan 1994, figure 41). Most of the finest examples have been found in Ireland. The find from ‘Near Errington’ is a fine example of its kind and, despite its moderate condition, deserves to be acquired and studied in further detail. ConclusionDue to the precious metal content of this object being over 10% gold, and it being over 300 years old, this object qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

subClassification: Gold face made from wires soldered together plates in triangular cross-section
description: A complete, Late Bronze Age penannular ring (or lock-ring) made from decorated gold sheet around a copper alloy core. The ring is oval in plan with a triangular cross-sectional profile. The face has a pronounced midrib and eight smaller concentric ribs running around either side of the face (17 ribs in total) suggesting construction from gold wire, in contrast to the gold sheeting of the inner surface and terminals which is flat and undecorated. The opening in the ring has been damaged, with the gold plate broken to reveal the corroded copper alloy core. One of the terminals has split and been pushed back inside the ring, with the sheeting ruptured; there is additional crushing damage to one side of the ring which has ruptured the sheeting on the inner surface.Length: 19.6mm; width: 17.1mm; thickness: 5.2 mm; weight: 3.66g
notes: These types of gold or gold-on-base-metal rings and penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Late Bronze Age (1150-800 BC). They belong to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings', 'ring-money' or 'lock-rings' but whose function remains uncertain. They may have been personal adornments worn on the ears or nose, rather than items of exchange. A closely similar example in size and construction in the British Museum's Greenwell Collection (WG 20) was found at Cheeseburn Grange, Northumberland.For comparable examples on the database which have been declared Treasure, see SOM-50218D, ESS-5ECCA2 (2016T592), BERK-4A433E (2016T106) and BH-8DC056 (2009T513).Conclusion: The item comprises more than 10% precious metal and is dated at over 300 years old at the time of finding. Additionally it is of prehistoric date and contains a proportion of precious metal. On both counts it therefore qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A complete, gold-plated Late Bronze Age (1150-800 BC) penannular ring. The ring is in the shape of an oval-sectioned loop. Many of these penannular rings have a copper alloy core wrapped in gold sheet; however, it is not entirely clear if this is the case for this example, as there are to chips or brakes showing the core.There are many examples of these objects recorded in the PAS database. Some of these include: BH-719492 (2018 T761), PAS-011055 (2016 T920), KENT-FF00A6 (2018 T376) and HAMP-425F0D (2018 T89).These penannular rings are sometimes known as 'ring-money' or 'hair rings' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008) [References from NMGW-04216C]. The function of these objects remain relatively unknown, having been possibly identified as currency for exchange, or ornaments worn by people to display wealth and power.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete gold penannular ring dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c.1300-800 BC). The ring is in the shape of an oval-sectioned loop and has an oval cross-section with slightly flattened inner and outer faces. One corner adjacent to the terminal is slightly indented but is otherwise plain and undecorated. The gap between the terminals is less than 0.5mm. Dimensions: The penannular ring is 14.5mm by 13.1mm externally. It is 4.2mm wide and 3.2mm thick and the ring weighs 5.32 grams.Discussion: This penannular ring appears similar to a class of artefact which have in the past been given various terms such as 'hair-rings' (Eogan 1997) and other monikers such as ?Ring Money? (Geen 1988) which are now no longer supported (Taylor 1980, 65 Varndell 2001). Their function remains uncertain (Varndell 2001, 516), although it is likely that they were personal adornments (Hobbs 2003 opinion cited, 102-107), possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange'.They are given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and The Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However, few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008, 13). Gwilt (2015) suggests (citing Raftery 2004, 87-8). that, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing such that these items may be placed within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC). The very narrow gap on this example may suggest it is part of the group thought to be made from bent gold rod, such as 2006 T451 (Scott 2007) dated to circa 1300-1150 BC rather than the main group of Later Bronze Age penannular rings.Many penannular rings are composite with copper alloy cores but there is no evidence visually that that this is the case with this example.Conclusion: The object is a minimum of 10% precious metal and is over 300 years old. Consequently it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Edward Caswell, Finds Liaison Assistant for Somerset & Devon, March 2019Checked by Neil Wilkin, Curator of the Bronze Age Collections, British Museum, December 2019ReferencesEogan, G. 1997. ?Hair-rings? and European Late Bronze Age society. description: Late Bronze Age hoardDate: c. 950-800 cal BCThe hoard comprises a sword broken into four pieces, a harness ring, toggle and socketed axe all dating to the Ewart park phase of the Bronze Age.Axehead1)    A complete Late Bronze Age socketed axehead dating to the c. 950-800 cal BC. The axe-head has an overall length of 64.7mm. It comprises a collared socket below which the body widens gradually from 29.5mm to c.34.8mm down most of its length before flaring more in sharp concave curves to form a winged crescent blade that has a maximum width of 43.9mm It has one integral attachment loop. The mouth of the axe is sub-rectangular, with internal dimensions of 23.7mm (depth) by 20.8mm (width). No casting stubs are evident on the mouth which is smooth and rounded possibly from being finished. The socket of the axe is empty such that it is possible to identify that it is triangular in profile, as is the outside of the axe, and has a depth of c.47.7mm.Expanding from just below the mouth is a prominent and well-defined moulded collar giving the socket a maximum width of 33.2mm and depth of 33.1mm. Beneath this is a plain by a second smaller but still clear collar spaced 2.2mm below the first. Three longitudinal raised lines extend from this second collar on each of the wider surfaces of the axe blade for c.20.8mm.The side loop extends from the second collar. The loop is oval in section; it measures 16.6mm in length, is 8.1mm wide, 3.4mm thick and projects 7.4mm from the body of the axe creating a D-shaped hole between it and the body of the axe.The object has a medium oragey brown glossy patina which may indicate it was buried in waterlogged conditions. Prominent unfinished casting seams are visible on the outside of the narrow surfaces of the axe running from the socket to just before winged blade edges. Further potential casting seams are visible on the interior of the socket in the middle of the wider surfaces of the axe for its length. The blade of the axe has chips to its patina but no clear marks that may be the result of use and no evidence for sharpening.The axehead is 64.7 long 43.9mm wide, 33.1mm thick and weighs 105.80 grams.The diagnostic elements of this axehead are its small size, double collar, three decorative lines extending from the lower collar and internal casting lines. These are all traits that Schmidt and Burgess attribute to the Yorkshire socketed axe type (1981: 223). There are numerous examples of this form of axehead illustrated by these authors (1981: pl 89-99) which are suggested to date to the Ewart Park Phase (ibid 238).2)    An incomplete bent and intentionally broken cast copper alloy Ewart Park sword dating to c. 1000-800 cal BC. Only a small part of the tang, and cross guard are missing to abraded and worn breaks. Otherwise the sword is complete but broken into four parts by two transverse breaks across the sword blade and one more across its grip.The sword’s hilt and grip are made of a broadly sub-rectangular plate. The grip’s sides are slightly convex widening from a diagonal break at its base to 20.8mm and then contracting to 15.5mm just below the hilt in smooth curves. The diagonal break truncated a central rivet hole (c.5.5mm diameter), probably placed just above its butt in half. Extending from the top of the grip is the sword’s hilt. One side of this is truncated by a vertical break although it likely mirrored the opposite side which extends 16.2mm from the outside edge of the grip before narrowing again in a straight line to the sword’s blade so as to form a point. An oval rivet hole (c.5.5mm by 5mm) is placed just inside and below this point on each side of the hilt, one of which has been cut in half by the break. The blade extends from the hilt and first narrows slightly to c.2mm wide. Beyond this the the sword blade is leaf shaped having edges that first expand for three quarters of its length to c. 37mm wide before narrowing to a point in a smooth arc. The blade is vesica shaped (pointed oval) in cross section at each of its breaks. The center of the sword becomes more prominent down its length as the blade edges become wider and creating an almost convex midrib.The blade has been bent close to it hilt with the regions indicating where the bend begins and ends being marked by transverse breaks. The sword mostly has a smooth orange patina possibly indicating being buried in water logged conditions, with some regions beneath having a more medium green colour. There are chips along the blade edge although it is not possible to tell wether these are chips from damage to the patina or use,The sword is c.50m long, 41.3mm wide at the hilt and weighs 460.1 grams,This is a Ewart Park sword containing all the diagnostic features of this type including the lead shaped blade oval cross section, lozenge shaped ricasso and shoulders and a bulging hilt. Colquhoun and Burgess (1988) have identified 4 stages in the development of this sword throughout the Ewart Park period which go in order although the juncture between each step are uncertain. This sword posses traits that would best group it within step 2 having rivets holes in the hilt, broadly straight shoulders and ricasso a bulging hilt and most notably flanges which appear to extend beyond the hilt onto the shoulders.3)    An incomplete hollow-cast copper alloy annular rings Dating to the Late bronze Age / Early Iron Age. The ring is oval in plan (internal dimensions being 38.3mm long and 32.5mm wide) and made of body that is oval in cross section (13.1mm wide, 10.6mm thick).The object has been truncated by a transverse break across the hoop revealing a hollow core (now filled with soil. The ends of this break are marked by the only decoration visible on the ring which may suggest this break occurred due a weakness in a feature projecting from this region rather than it continuing to be annular in shape. This decoration is molded consisting of slight thickening of the hoop, creating two liner lips between it and the rest of the hoop where it begins and ends. There is also one further prominent crack on the hoop, pitting and occasional scratches. Beyond this the object has a glossy dark brown patina The loop is 38.3mm long, 32.5mm wide, 10.6mm thick and weighs 52.38 gramsThe ring is similar to copper alloy rings found in the latest Bronze Age hoards as at Parc-y-Meirch (Sheppard 1941L Pl III), Heathery Burn Hoard (Britton and Longworth 1969), Hagbourne Hill Hoard (Coombs 1971), Green End Road (University  of Cambridge Museum for Anthropology and Archaeology Nos. 31.395 and 31.396) and Horsehope  Manor, Peebleshire (Schmidt and Burgess 1981, Plate 146, nos. 3–94)    A complete cast copper alloy strap slide fragment from a Bronze Age strap fitting.The piece is made of a long and thin rectangular strip of copper alloy that is crescent shaped in cross section with a convex outer surface and concave inner surface. The two ends of the strip have then been folded over 180 degrees in smooth arcs to create hooks which have flat cross sections. The outer surface of the object has a glossy dark green patina while the interior is still encrusted with soil.The strap fitting is 50.8mm long, 6.5mm wide, 2.0mm thick in the sheet and 7.4mm thick including the curved hooks. It weighs 4.81 grams.5)    A fragment of a cast copper alloy strap slide fragment from a Bronze Age strap fitting similar to object 4.The piece is made of a long and thin rectangular strip of copper alloy that is flat in cross section. One end of the strip has then been folded over 180 degrees in two sharpish right angled turns to create a hook. The outer surface of the object has a glossy dark green patina while the interior is still encrusted with soil.The strap fitting is 12mm long, 5.5mm wide, 2.0mm thick in the sheet and 6.8mm thick including the curved hook. It weighs 1.02 grams.6)    A near complete cast copper alloy spiked object possibly a Late Bronze Age awl.The object has a circular socket with a projecting integral spike. The socket’s edge is chipped and abraded with a circular cross section (c.15mm diameter) which has been left open so that it is possible to identify its depth (c.30.4mm) and that it is broadly straight sided within it. The socket’s plate has one pierced hole (c.4.0mm diameter) placed just above its mouth.. After 38.8mm the object contracts to 9.3mm in diameter, creating a vertical ledge on all sides, from this platform a spike extends which narrows down its length (c.33.5mm) to a sharp point with a sub-circular cross section.The object ha a dark brown sometimes orange patina that is glossy.The object is 75.3mm long, 15mm wide and weighs 27.06 gramsBrendan O’Connor has been able to identify a similarly shaped item from Pigeon’s Cave in Northern Wales. This was found associated with Bronze Age material dating to the Late Bronze Age (details available from https://museum.wales/collections/bronze-age-gold-from-wales/object/bfb4924f-2b99-3957-8fea-563ae35ac966/Late-Bronze-Age-socketed-awl/). This shares the same broad form and has a consistent patina with those objects in the hoard such that a Ewart Park date is also suggested for this object. Discussion: The objects above can all be parallel with objects from Bronze Age hoards dating to the Ewart Park Phase of the Bronze Age. These parallels extends from Wales to North East England and are consistent in date. It is therefore reasonable to conclude that the objects listed above were deposited as a closed group over 2000 years ago during a single event.Conclusion: The objects detailed above qualify as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act (1996) (Designation Order 2002), being a group of more than one base-metal objects, other than coins, of prehistoric dateBibliography Britton, D., and I. H. Longworth. "Late Bronze Age finds from Heathery Burn Cave, County Durham." Inventaria Archaeologica (9th Series, GB 55M) (1969).Colquhoun, I. and Burgess, C. (1988) The swords of Britain. Prähistorische Bronzefunde. Abt. 4 Bd. 5. München, C. H. Beck’sche verlagsbuchhandlung.Coombs, D. (1971) Late Bronze Age metalwork in the south of England. Unpublished PhD thesis. Cambridge University.Schmidt, P.K. and Burgess, C. (1981) The axes of Scotland and northern England. Prähistorische Bronzefunde. München, C.H. Beck’sche Verlagsbuchhandlung.Sheppard, T., 1941. The Parc-y-meirch hoard, St George parish, Denbighshire. Archaeologia Cambrensis, 96, pp.1-10.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: Gold torc, sheet and hack piece wrapped together. An unidentified gold cluster consisting of a Middle Bronze Age spiral twisted torc fragment wrapped around a fold and bent gold sheet. The gold sheet appears to have impressed decoration running in broadly parallel lines down its length. The torc is made of a rod that is square in cross section with accentuated corners created by slightly concave edges. This has been twisted tightly but unevenly across its surviving length. These twists end c.10mm from one terminal where the rod becomes sub-square almost oval in cross section and narrows to a blunted irregular point.
notes: Discussion: Similar examples to the twisted spiral torc fragment are illustrated by Eogan (1994: pl.4) and Taylor (1980: pl.41) who term these Gold “bar” and “flanged twisted” torcs. These have been dated typologically to the Penard (c. 1300-1150 BC) metalwork phase of the Middle Bronze Age (Eogan 1994: 69, 74, 91; Roberts 2007: 141) albeit with the suggestion they may overlap into the preceding Taunton phase (ibid), when twisting and flange twisting bars and ribbons of gold were common techniques in Britain (Taylor 1980: 60) and in Europe (Armbruster 2021: 156-8). Torcs of this style are most common in southern England and East Anglia, but do occur elsewhere in Wales and central Britain (Roberts 2007: fig.4). Deliberately cut fragments like this occur relatively often in  hoards such as the Salcombe hoard, Devon (Needham et al. 2013)and the Fittleworth hoard, West Sussex (British Museum number 1996,0902.21) and occasionally as stray finds (e.g. treasure case 2003T19,  2016T203 and 2011T501). The object this wraps around has numerous Bronze Age parallels recorded on the database variously known (based on their complete form) as ribbons (2019T383, 2021T937), mounts (2021T608) and plaques (2020T332) with one example also possibly coming from a lunulae (2017T405). These are all dated to the Bronze Age and often paralleled to objects dating to the Early Bronze Age supported by similar examples dated to this period by Taylor (1980, pl 28) although similar techniques are also seen on Middle Bronze Age gold  bracelets (e.g. 2013T805).As such the two items together can be dated to the Bronze Age with the twisted torc placing this in the Middle Bronze Age c. 1300-1150 cal BC.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Two complete gold penannular rings dating from the Middle to Late Bronze Age (c. 1300 – 800 cal BC). The first ring is in the shape of an oval-sectioned loop (15.0mm wide by 14.0mm high) and has a circular cross-section frame that is the same diameter (2.8mm) along its whole length. Both terminals have a shallow rectangular shaped recess in the centre of their face. There is a thick scar that runs along the top edge of the penannular from the right-hand terminal to just beyond the midsection of the frame.The second ring is a similar form being an oval-sectioned loop (15.2mm wide by 13.9mm high) and has a circular cross-section frame that is the same diameter (4.2mm) along its whole length, although it is notably thicker than the first ring. As with the first ring. both terminals have a shallow rectangular shaped recess in the centre of their face. On one surface there is a scar that runs along at least half of the top edge of the penannular from the left-hand terminal to just before the midsection of the frame. The other half of the ring shows corrosion across all sides that is possibly indicative of its original manufacture method.Dimensions: The first ring is 15.0mm long, 14.0mm wide and 2.8mm thick. The gap between the terminals is c. 3mm and it weighs 3.57g. The second ring is 15.2nn long, 13.9mm wide and 4.2mm thick. The gap between the terminals is 4.0mm and it weighs 5.88gDiscussion:  These penannular rings belong to a class of artefact which have in the past been given various terms such as 'hair-rings' (Eogan 1997) and other monikers such as ‘Ring Money’ (Geen 1988) which are now no longer supported (Taylor 1980, 65 Varndell 2001). Their function remains uncertain (Varndell 2001, 516), although it is likely that they were personal adornments (Hobbs 2003, 102-107), possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange.They are given a date belonging to the Ewart Park phase of the Late Bronze Age, between 1000-800BC based on burials in Belgium, northeast France and The Netherlands and secondly, Scottish and Irish hoard associations (e.g. Eogan 1997). However few examples have been dated through associated finds, archaeological investigation or radiocarbon dating (Meeks et al. 2008,  13). Gwilt (2015) suggests (citing Raftery 2004, 87-8) that, in recent years, the evidence for their earlier development and longer period of manufacture and circulation has been growing such that these items may be placed within the Middle and Late Bronze Age (1300-800BC). The items were found about 20 meters of SOM-4D34ED/ Treasure case 2018T14, a bi-partite gold penannular ring of similar date. The presence of a scar on the items and their proximity to the bi-partite penannular ring suggest these rings may each have been one half of a similar double ring, although their variable thickness suggests that they were not mounted to each other. Further examples of two gold or gold-plated penannular rings, stacked one on top of the other, can be found on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database: DENO-A13440, IOW-1F5D46 and HAMP-471843. It is highly likely that the two rings reported here and SOM-4D34ED/ 2018 T14 are associated finds from a hoard or archaeological deposit that have become dispersed by subsequent agricultural action.Many penannular rings of his type are composite with copper alloy cores (See Green 1988 or Ashby 2007 for examples) but there is no evidence visually that that this is the case with this example with no copper corrosion showing through in the scratches on the rings. Conclusion: The penannular rings appear to be over 10% precious metal and more than 300 years old and as such qualify as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996. subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: A single fragment of gold ?bar? of probable prehistoric date.Description: It is snipped (in a pincer-like or ?chisel-cut? way) on either end. The object has a sub-hexagonal cross-section.Dimensions: Length: 18mm; Width: 6mm; Thickness: 4.5mm; Weight: 4.32gMetal composition: Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis of a gold bar fragment by the British Museum, indicated a surface composition of approximately 81-83% gold, 14-16% silver, the rest being largely copper.
