This deliberate destructive treatment (folding, rolling, damaging) is fairly common in Bronze Age objects that are deposited as part of a hoard. The second 'diadem' comes from Stratford-on-Avon, Warwickshire (WAW-FF1E9A). It is broken into two pieces, but they appear to have formed a long slender sheet of gold with tapering ends. Both ends have three small perforations. Unlike the first example, the edge of this sheet is decorated with a border of fine pointille decoration and although the sheet was crumpled, it was not folded.Based in the available parallels, the rolled-up gold strip can be assigned to the Bronze Age and deserves further research.
notes: In terms of age and precious metal content, the object qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: A complete but distorted solid gold tripartite penannular ring dating to the Middle Bronze Age, c. 1550-1150 BC. It is broadly oval in plan view and plano-convex in section, being formed of three 'D' sectioned bands which have been soldered together, though in places these are starting to come away from one another. The terminals are squared off, but now overlap due to damage.Date: 1550-1150 BCDimensions: The external diameter of the penannular ring is 12.16mm, while the bands have a maximum width of 8.74mm and a maximum thickness of 1.33mm. It weighs 3.68g.Discussion: Composite penannular rings formed from C-sectioned, D-sectioned or sub-circular strips soldered together are a well known Middle Bronze Age artefact type as single finds or forming part of sets of linked rings that are sometimes found attached to bracelets. For examples of this registered on the PAS database see records NMS-ACBFA4, NMS-A1B392, SF-A6DEC7, PAS-DA09A3, SUSS-63B7A6, LIN-9F2713, LIN-D7E6D1, BERK-A5FFE5 and ESS-CB3683.The object contains over 10% precious metal and as discussed above is certainly over 300 years old. Consequently, it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: An incomplete cast copper alloy (Bronze) flat axe of the Early Bronze Age period dating from  c. 2250 BC - 1900 BC.The flat axe is broadly trapezoidal in plan with a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid (pointed oval), with slight tapering edges. In cross section the axe is lentoid. The axe is broken toward the butt of the axe, but more than three-quarters of the axe survives. The break is relatively jagged and uneven; however it has a similar patina to that of the rest of the axe - suggesting damage in antiquity. The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the broken edge to the blade. The edges of the axe have not been raised to form flanges. The sides of the blade expand to produce a crescentic blade edge. The tips of the crescent shaped blade have been damaged through abrasion, as has the blade edge itself. There are a series of striations (incised lines / file marks) running across the width of the axe. These are likely to be a result of sharpening the cutting edge. It seems most probable that the axe was cast in an open mould. All the diagnostic elements of the axe are lost (such as shape of butt and hafting specifications). The condition of the axe is poor - the majority of the surface patina has been removed by laminating corrosion, which appears to be active. The axe measures 77.6 mm in length, it is 34.4 mm wide at the butt and the blade is 75.2 mm wide. The butt has a thickness of 8.7 mm, the blade is 2.8 mm thick. It weighs 253.6 g.The object is a dark brown in colour with an uneven patina. Areas of green active corrosion are present on the surface of the object. Abrasion caused by movement whilst within the plough soil may have resulted in the loss of much of the original surface detail. From the blade shape (which could be described as fan-like) it is probable that the axe falls into the Migdale tradition of metalworking. This fits with the Early Bronze Age (EBA phase II / III), of metalworking stage IV-VI, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 2-3 circa 2250 - 1900 CAL. BC. Axes such as this are dated to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae. Other broadly similar axeheads have been recorded on the database, including HESH-33EA4A, LANCUM-E30276, NMGW-5F8955 and LVPL-DA4598.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

otherRef: Hampshire Cultural Trust Entry Form WINCM 416
description: A complete gold or possibly gold-plated copper-alloy Late Bronze Age penannular ring, dating to the period 1150-800 BC. The object measures 16.24mm in diameter, is oval in cross-section, and with a gap measuring 2.39mm wide and 3.94mm in height. The thickness of the ring measures 6.59mm. In total, the penannular ring weighs 9.31g. The weight may indicate it is more likely the penannular ring is made of gold, rather than gold plated copper-alloy. There are small indentations on the face of both terminals, probably residual marks from where a stone was wedged between them (with thanks to the finder for reporting this information). The penannular ring is decorated with a thin, winding strip of a contrasting silvery-coloured metal. They are particularly clear on the inside surface of the ring, which is rather tarnished compared to the outside.'The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange' (Mark Lodwick and Mary Davis in record NMGW-04216C; references therein). Other parallels to this can also be seen in HAMP-0F9AF6.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: A length of gold strip or ‘ribbon’, with eight longitudinal lines incised or grooved into the gold on one side only. Condition: broken at either end with no signs of preformation or terminal (some examples previously discovered do feature these elements). The ends are broken and ragged and there are a number of tears and folds along the body of the strip.Dimensions: Length: 32mmWidth: 9mmWeight: 1.52gGold content: Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis of the strip by the British Museum Scientific Research team indicated a surface composition of approximately 86-88% gold, 11-12% silver, the rest being copper (1-2%). See appended report. Discussion: Similar grooved, pierced gold ribbons are well known, examples include: 2013 T326 (WILT-26F931), 2007 T692 (WAW-C0C0B3), 2014 T63 (BERK-387817), and 2013 T154 (PAS-067AC5); 2012 T577 (ESS-C13B97.The incised linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date, particularly the find from Sherborne St John, Hampshire (2013 T154), which also had a single perforation to one and was decorated on only one side. The dimensions and weights of the bands are also comparable. The Tendering strip also bears comparison with gold strips from The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Case 1981; Palmer 1981); Corringham, Lincolnshire (2011 T459); Sproxton, North Yorkshire (2010 T664); Flixton, North Yorkshire (2003 T40a&b); and Ansley, Warwickshire (2007 T672). The find from The Hamel, Oxfordshire, came from the same layer as typologically late Beaker pottery dating to the Early Bronze Age (cf. Needham 2005).
notes: Due to the precious metal content of this object being over 10% gold, and it being over 300 years old, this object qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Author: Neil Wilkin – Curator, The British Museum
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: TREASURE CASE 2017 T234. An incomplete Middle Bronze Age composite penannular gold ring dating to the period c. 1300-1150 BC. Now almost straightened, the ring comprises two ribs formed from separate C-sectioned bars with convex upper faces and hollow reverses, soldered together longitudinally. One terminal end of the ring is complete with a clean, smooth finish while the opposing end is broken. There are several small post-depositional scratches on the outer, curved surface of the ring.Discussion: Composite penannular rings formed from C-sectioned, D-sectioned or sub-circular strips or bars, are a well known Middle Bronze Age artefact type as single finds or forming part of sets of linked rings. For similar rings see LIN-D7E6D1 and ESS-E9CCB4 (two ribs), BERK-A5FFE5 and HER43133, Norfolk (multiple linked rings), ESS-CB3683 and IOW-0EAD26 (three ribs) and a set of multiple linked rings from Norfolk (HER43133).
notes: Conclusion: This object is more than 300 years old and is made substantially of gold, therefore it qualifies as Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: An incomplete strip of decorated gold, of probable Bronze Age dating (c. 2150 BC to c. 1150 BC).The strip of gold is sub rectangular in plan, and is folded horizontally (width ways) in half twice, forming a squashed 'S' shape. The strip has been decorated with a series of embossed ridges along its length. The strip has been severed at one end, with a ragged edge. The other edge can not be easily seen as it is hidden between the folds.It measures 25.3 mm in length, 16.1 mm wide and 9.1 mm thick. The strip is 0.8 mm thick. It weighs 5.2. g.Similar strips of gold with ribbed decoration have been recorded on the PASdatabase including ESS-C13B97, SUR-1B64F5, NMS-46A4D6, PAS-E9E2A1, SF-D30D10, LIN-946F12 and WAW-052196.Similar multi-grooved strips of a Bronze Age date are known from throughout Britain including in the British Museum collection from Flixton, Yorkshire (2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16. no. 2) and Ravencliff Cave, Derbyshire (British Museum 1906,1224.1-2) as well as recent finds such as Ansley, Warwickshire and West Acre Norfolk (Treasure Annual Report 2007, 47-48). A very similar strip from Sproxton, North Yorkshire is recorded on the PAS database as LVPL-83FE92. There is also a similar grooved strip from The Hamel, Oxford, Oxfordshire excavated from a layer which yielded Beaker pottery of the Early Bronze Age (Palmer 1980, 124-134). Similar narrow embossed strips are known from the pommels of daggers accompanying Early Bronze Age burials in Scotland (Henshall 1968, 173-95; Hardaker 1974, 21-23. fig 6.; Taylor 1980, fig 28a-f) but not however comparable to gold dagger fittings in contemporary burials southern England. Other Bronze Age gold strips found singly such as at Flixton, Yorkshire (British Museum 2004,0904.1a-b, Treasure Annual Report 2003, 16, no. 2) are broader and have more and narrower incised grooves. The annular ring from the Late Bronze Age hoard at Abia de la Obispalia, central Spain is comparable in form and dimensions but the grooves appear to have been incised rather than embossed (Almagro Gorbea 1974). Similarly, the Bronze Age annular ring from Armissan, southeast France may be comparable (Elure 1981, 48-49, fig. 55).As this fragment is older than 300 years in age, with a precious metal content of greater than 10%, it should be considered as potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.Notes:ReferencesAlamagro Gorbea M. 1974, Orfebrera del Bronce Final en la Peninsula Ibrica. El Tesoro de Abia de la Obispala, la orfebrera tipo Villena y los cuencos de Axtroki, Trabajos de Prehistoria, 31, 39 - 100Case, H. 1980, 'Pottery, Flint and Metalwork' In Palmer, N. 1981, 'A Beaker Burial and Medieval Tenements in the Hamel, Oxford', Oxoniensia, XLV (1980), [Mircofiche], 1 A04Elure, C. 1982, Les Ors Prhistoriques, Paris: PicardHenshall, A.S. 1968, 'Scottish dagger graves', In Coles, J.M. & Simpson, D.D.A. (eds), Studies in Ancient Europe: Essays present to Stuart Piggott, Leicester: Leicester University PressPalmer, N. 1980, 'A Beaker Burial and Medieval Tenements in the Hamel, Oxford', Oxoniensia, XLV (1980), 124-225
subsequentActionTerm: Submitted for consideration as Treasure

description: An incomplete copper alloy palstave with raised flange facets dating from the Middle Bronze Age (1500 BC - 1150 BC).The blade of the palstave is sub-triangular in plan with convex expanding sides and an incomplete convex cutting edge. In profile the blade is sub-triangular with the widest section being before the stop ridge. The sides of the blade are convex in shape. The blade (measured from the cutting edge to the stop ridge) is 75.4 mm long and the width of cutting edge is 55.3 mm. The thickness of the blade tip is 7.0 mm. The maximum thickness of the blade is 17.4 mm (measured at thickest part below the stop ridge, the width at this point is 28.8 mm).The rear part of the axe (from the stop ridge to the butt) is sub-rectangular in plan and sub-triangular in section (profile) with the widest part at the stop ridge. The septum (the area between the flange facets and the stop ridge) is 64.1 mm long, 24.2 mm wide, and 12.9 mm thick. The butt of the axe has been slightly damaged leaving two rounded corners with a gap between. The butt is 27.1 mm wide and 58.7 mm thick.The flange facets are fused to the stop ridge forming two sub-rectangular raised elements to haft the axe by.In total the palstave measures 134.8 mm in length, 55.3 mm wide (maximum) and 22.7 mm thick. It weighs 168.3 g.The palstave is a mid to dark green colour, with an even surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the plough soil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface. XRF analysis on this palstave was carried out at Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery conservation laboratory, using a Mistral Tabletop XRF machine. The results are below:Element			Front (conc.%)			Back (Conc.%)			Original surface (conc.%)		Copper (Cu)			68.93			62.42			56.71		Zinc (Zn)			1.93			1.69			1.50		Tin (Sn)			14.54			20.95			27.32		Antimony (Sb)			0.36			0.35			0.34		Arsenic (As)			0.10			0.09			0.08		Lead (Pb)			8.83			7.73			6.87		Silver (Ag)			0.16			0.14			0.12		Gold (Au)			0.00			0.00			0.00		Iron (Fe)			5.14			6.63			7.05		Mercury (Hg)			0.00			0.00			0.00		Similar examples to this palstave can be seen in Savory, 1980; catalogue entries 171, 172, 175, and 263 (the Mynydd Ta-y-glannau, Cemmaes Hoard). All of these examples fit into the middle phase of the Middle Bronze Age (MBA II).Reference:Savory, H. N., 1980. Guide Catalogue to the Bronze Age Collections Cardiff : National Museum of Wales, pp46-47, 106-107, 170-171 and 179
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Description: Incomplete fragment from a gold Middle Bronze Age flange twisted torc comprising one terminal and a length of twisted metal, terminating in a break. The surviving terminal is oval in cross-section and exhibits evidence of hammering at the tip. Four longitudinal cuts have been made into the bar to create an X-shaped cross-section and the bar has then been twisted. The piece curves along its length and terminates in a break. This would appear to be accidental, rather than deliberate. The edges of a number of the twists are dented, probably due to post-depositional factors. Dimensions: Length (curved): 71.9mm, maximum diameter: 3.8mm, minimum diameter: 2.8mm, weight: 5.7g. Discussion: A number of complete and fragmentary examples of flange twisted torc have been reported as Treasure and are recorded on the PAS database including: BERK-687927, BERK-83AC41 (both 2004 T348), CAM-E5D871 (2015 T715), IOW-C0C054 (2011 T501). Flange twisted torcs in both gold and copper alloy can be dated typologically to the Taunton (c.1400-1250 BC), more probably the Penard (c. 1300-1150 BC), metalwork phases of the Middle Bronze Age (Roberts 2007). Gold flanged twisted torcs finds are concentrated in East Anglia, southwest and southeast England (Roberts, 2007). A complete example, substantially larger than the fragment in question, is currently held by Norwich Castle Museum (accession no. NWHCM : 1947.5.1). Another, found at Ashill, Norfolk, is held by the British Museum (museum no. 1866,1201.1).Date: c. 1300 ? 1150 BC.
notes: The object appears to consist of over 10% precious metal and be over 300 years old at the time of finding and as such qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

otherRef: Shropshire Museum Service; Object Entry Form: E. 01504
description: Report on Potential Treasure for H M CoronerA Gold penannular ring from Dorstone, Herefordshire.Treasure Number: 2016-T811PAS Database number: HESH-E4B5D6Period: Later Bronze Age (1200-750 BC)Date of Discovery: August 2014Circumstances Discovery whilst metal detectingof discovery:HM Coroner: Mr BricknellDescription:A complete gold penannular ring being C shaped in plan and having an irregular sub-rectangular cross section. The ring is formed from a short length of gold rod whose external edges have been shaped to form an irregular sub oval shape / cross section. This rod has then been subsequently shaped to form an open-ended ring. The two opposing terminals are relatively well aligned and are unexpanded and undecorated. Sub-rectangular depressions are present on both terminal faces but there is no evidence of applied foil or sheet metal end-caps. On the upper edge of one terminal is a deep V sectioned linear scratch, this is likely to have been applied whilst the rod was being measured and might indicate that the ring was cut into shape using a blade. A slight lip is present on the internal edge, again possibly being a relic of construction. There is no decoration present at all; likewise, there is no evidence of corrosion. Slight abrasion in the soil has resulted in surface scratches and there are compression tension lines, at right angles to the ring in plan, are evident in the surface on the interior face, suggesting that the ring was formed from an oval sectioned gold rod. The surface and terminals of the ring have been examined under high (x30) magnification and the surface of the ring is smooth and unblemished. All this suggests that the ring is formed of solid metal and does not have a copper core and applied foil surface like some examples within this artefact type / form.Dimensions:Weight: 5.33 grams; Length 13.1mm, width, 15.2mm, thickness 3.9mm - gap between opposing terminals: 2.4mmDiscussion:The penannular ring belongs to a relatively common class of treasure artefact which has been erroneously termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money'. Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange' (Gwilt, Lodwick and Davies 2014). The form of this example fits best with Meeks, Craddock and Needham's type or Group Ia - Plain Gold (2008: 17), although they note that some of these are cast. This group formed the most common / largest group within their study.The national distribution of this form of late Bronze Age artefact indicates that penannular rings are more common in the south and east of England with very few known in Northern Britain and Wales. Significant examples are also known from Ireland (Taylor 1980; Eogan 1994 and 2007; Raferty: 2004) and recent examples from Western Britain have a distinct Irish seaboard distribution. Gwilt et. al. (2014) define and discuss the known Welsh examples. However, this new example from Dorestone seems to be the first example to be recorded from either Herefordshire or the wider Welsh Marches area.Statement:Consequently, in terms of age and precious metal content, the object qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.References:Eogan, G. (1994) The Accomplished Art; Gold and Gold-working in Britain and Ireland during the Bronze Age (c. 2300-650 BC), Oxford: Oxbow Monograph 42.Eogan, G. (1997) 'Hair-rings' and European Late Bronze Age Society, Antiquity, 71, 308-20.Gwilt, A, Lodwick, M. Davies M. (2014) NMGW-928F55: A gold bronze age penannular ring from St. Donats, Vale of Glamorgan. Web page available at:https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/628395Meeks, N.D., Craddock, P. & Needham, S.P. (2008) Bronze Age Penannular Gold Rings from the British Isles: Technology and Composition, Jewellery Studies 11, 13-30.Raftery, B. (2004) Pit 119: Rathgall, Co. Wicklow, in Roche, H., Grogan, E. Bradley, J. Coles, J. & Raftery, B. From Megaliths to Metals; Essays in Honour of George Eogan, Oxford: Oxbow. pp 83-90.Taylor, JJ. (1980) Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles, Cambridge: Cambridge University PressAuthor:Peter Reavill - Portable Antiquities Scheme
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: Description:A fragment of a gold torc. The torc consists of an elongated shape bar that is broken on both ends and circular in cross section. One of the ends has been hammered and flattened.Dimensions: The fragment measures 25.71mm in length, 7.61mm in maximum width 5.72mm thick. The object weighs 6.89g.Metal composition: Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis of a gold torc fragment indicated a surface composition of approximately 94-97% gold, 3-5% silver, the rest being copper (see appended report for details).Discussion and Date: It was originally believed that this gold torc fragment may belong to the Middle Bronze Age based on parallels to a known type of fragment dating to the Penard period (c.1300 - 1150 BC). However, on closer examination it was recognised that the form and decoration (i.e. twist) of the torc is not similar to Bronze Age torcs and the composition of the goldwork is also dissimilar to Bronze Age torcs (see Murgia et al. n.d.). Wider consultation was made among specialist colleagues at the British Museum but the object could not be securely dated as ancient (over 300 years old) and can therefore be disclaimed as a case of Treasure.Conclusions:This object contains more than 10% precious metal but it cannot be shown to be over 300 years old. Consequently, in terms of age and precious metal content, the object does not qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Reference: Murgia, A., Melkonian, M. & Roberts, B.W. [no date] European Bronze Age Gold in the British Museum. Available at:
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: Description: Gold unidentified ornament of Bronze Age date. The object consists of a strip of sheet gold formed into the shape of a pointed oval. At either end, the long edges of the band have been folded inwards in order to create the pointed terminals. Near the tip of each terminal is a circular perforation. Both perforations are now blocked with soil.Dimensions: Length: 21.9mm, width: 4.6mm, thickness: 1.6mm, weight: 1.2g.Discussion: A number of parallels from the Portable Antiquities Scheme suggest that a Bronze Age date is most likely. Examples include Northfleet, Kent (KENT-AAA333, 2004T326); Brixton Deverill, Wiltshire (WILT-34D958, 2006T250); Gussage-all-Saints, Dorset (DOR-AC5494???????, 2013 T428); Roche, Cornwall (CORN-8EC344???????, 2014T39) and Cote, Oxfordshire (BH-1BE953???????, 2014T901). As Dr S. Needham pointed out in the report for Brixton Deverill (2006 T250): 'a range of ribbon, or strip ornaments in gold are known from the British Bronze Age, including for torcs, bracelets and small fittings'.???????Date:  ???????This find, therefore, probably dates to the Early to Later Bronze Age (c.2200-800 BC).
notes: The object appears to consist of over 10% precious metal and be over 300 years old at the time of finding and as such qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum by all parties, hence disclaimed as Treasure

description: A Late Bronze Age gold plated copper-alloy penannular ring (c. 1150 BC-c. 750 BC). Treasure case no. 2016 T755.The ring is oval in cross-section with flat terminals and has decorative silvery banding. The terminals were capped with gold. However, one capping is missing and the copper-alloy core can be seen.The gold plating is fractured in places.14.5mm (outer diameter); 5.7mm (inner diameter); 4.3mm (thickness); 2.1mm (distance between terminals). Weight: 3.61g.'The penannular ring belongs to a class of artefact which has been termed 'hair-rings' and 'ring-money' (Taylor 1980; Green 1988; Eogan 1994; 1997; Varndell 2001; Hobbs 2003; Meeks et al 2008; O'Connor et al 2008). Their function remains uncertain, although it is likely that they were personal adornments, possibly worn on the ears or nose, rather than being hair-ornaments or items of exchange' (Mark Lodwick and Mary Davis in record NMGW-04216C; references therein).
notes: Due to this object being of prehistoric, Bronze Age date, the presence of any precious metal would qualify this item as Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996. As this item is gold plated it qualifies as such under the Act.
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder after being disclaimed as Treasure

description: Middle Bronze Age hoard.1. Decorated gold strip fragmentDimensions: Maximum surviving length (bent) 38.9mm; maximum width 7.0mm; thickness approx. 0.3mm; surviving weight 2.40g.This is a highly decorated gold strip, with one surviving and slightly convex terminal, which has been carefully shaped and smoothed along its edge. A small pin perforation is located near the terminal at mid-width across the strip. The perforation is 0.4mm in diameter, centring approximately 0.7mm from the terminal edge of the strip. The perforation is not perfectly round having hexagonal facets with rounded edges. At the opposite end, the strip has been deliberately cut with a straight bladed tool, such as a knife. On one side, linear grooves indicate unsuccessful cut marks partly through the metal and at a slight angle to the cut edge. Four parallel linear zones of punch or stamp decoration in repeated flattened S-shaped motifs have been applied along the long axis of the strip. The overall effect is to resemble twisted wire stranding, but in one integral piece. While the back of the strip is flat, the upper decorated face has been grooved between each stamp zone and creating defined plain strip margins, approximately 0.6mm wide. The grooves are wide and curved, setting the stamped decoration in relief and creating a corrugated effect on the front face.2. Twisted bronze torc fragmentDimensions: maximum surviving length 170mm; internal diameter 160mm; maximum diameter of bar 7.7mm; surviving weight 52.5g.This is a near half fragment of a twisted bronze torc with a plain and tapering terminal. The twists are tightly spaced with an S-shaped curve. The twisting ceases to be evident towards the tapering terminal, starting to become apparent some 73.0-74.0mm from the surviving terminal end. The twists are far more pronounced on the interior surfaces and markedly worn around the external circumference surfaces, suggesting significant use-wear prior to burial. The bar is very slightly oval in shape, wider in the horizontal axis. The torc has been dented in two places, probably during recent retrieval, with fresh bronze metal showing at one point. The torc has a grey-green patination, which is slightly lighter than most other torc fragments (Nos. 3-8 below). The terminal end is fragile, with light green patination.3. & 4. Twisted bronze torc fragments (conjoining)Dimensions: combined surviving length approx. 144.0mm; surviving length of fragment 3- 125.9mm; surviving length of fragment 4- 33.2mm; internal diameter of collar 170-180mm; maximum diameter of bar 8.0mm; surviving weight fragment 3 - 30.6g; surviving weight of fragment 4 - 1.9g; combined surviving weight 32.5g.These are two conjoining fragments of a twisted bronze torc with a plain tapering terminal and combining to represent a one third fragment of the original whole artefact. The twists are tightly spaced with a Z-shaped curve. The twisting only ceases to be evident on the small terminal fragment, which is 33.2mm long, although missing its tip. The twists are evident on both interior and exterior surfaces of the torc, suggesting moderate use wear prior to burial. The bar is very slightly oval in shape, wider in the horizontal axis. A good conjoin is evident between the soil covered fragments. At the non-terminal end, the twisted upper surface has been shaved off, revealing bronze metal at the surface, and the end break is not fresh. There is differential corrosion and pock-marking on one surface, where the patination is a lighter grey green. The reversed surface is in better condition and has a dark grey-green patination.5. & 6. Twisted bronze torc fragments (conjoining)Dimensions: combined surviving length approx. 50.9mm; surviving length of fragment 5 - 38.2mm; surviving length of fragment 6 - 13.2mm; internal diameter of collar approx. 160-190mm; maximum surviving diameter of bar 7.1mm; surviving weigh of fragment 5 - 6.8g; surviving weight of fragment 6 - 1.0g; combined surviving weight 7.8g.These are two conjoining fragments of a twisted bronze torc with a plain tapering terminal and combining to represent a small terminal fragment of the original whole artefact. The twists are tightly spaced with a Z-shaped curve. The twisting only ceases to be evident approximately 26.0-27.0mm from the tapering terminal end, however the terminal tip has broken off and is absent. The twists are visible on both interior and exterior surfaces of the torc, suggesting moderate use wear prior to burial. The bar surfaces are damaged, making accurate estimations of its original shape and diameter difficult to ascertain. A good conjoin is evident between the sharply defined break points at the terminal end, however the break at the non-terminal end is soil covered and less fresh looking. The surfaces are pock-marked and corroded in places with a lighter grey green patination, however the majority of original surfaces have a dark grey-green patination.7. Twisted bronze torc fragmentDimensions: surviving length 36.8mm; maximum diameter of bar 8.7mm; surviving weight 10.7g.This is a small mid-section fragment of a twisted bronze torc. The twists are tightly spaced with a Z-shaped curve. The twists are visible on both the interior and exterior surfaces of the torc, suggesting moderate use-wear before burial. The breaks are soil covered, one end break being defined and the other looking more worn. One upper or lower surface has been recently damaged with a linear scar, revealing bronze metal. Original surfaces have a green-grey patination, while damaged surfaces and breaks have a lighter grey-green patination.8. Twisted bronze torc fragmentDimensions: surviving length 24.4mm; maximum diameter of bar 8.2mm; surviving weight 6.9g.This is a small mid-section fragment of a twisted bronze torc. The twists are tightly spaced with a Z-shaped curve. The twists are visible on both interior and exterior surfaces of the torc, suggesting moderate use-wear before burial. The breaks are soil covered, one end break being defined and the other looking more worn. One surface is more corroded than the other. The fragment has a dark grey-green patination.9. & 10. Decorated bronze bracelet of Liss Type (conjoining fragments)Dimensions: combined surviving length approx. 77.0mm; external diameter approx. 80-90mm; surviving length fragment 9 - 66.2mm; surviving length of fragment 10 - 28.9mm; maximum width bar 16.0mm; maximum thickness bar 7.5mm; surviving weight fragment 9 - 50.2g; surviving weight fragment 10 - 15.7g; combined surviving weight 65.9g.These are two conjoining fragments of a substantial bronze bracelet, in combination representing a little under half of the original complete object. In plan, the hoop is oval in shape, while in section, it is D-shaped, with a convex external surface. On the internal surface, slightly offset from the mid line is a continuous ledge running in parallel with the bracelet sides. This would appear to be a casting join, created by imperfections in the mould or poorly aligned mould pieces. The internal profile has a very slight convexity, but most closely resembles a D-shaped form, rather than an oval section. Along the small bracelet fragment, there is a slight tapering of the bracelet width, suggesting this was once a penannular bracelet with tapering terminals. Upon close inspection under the microscope, incised linear decoration is evident in places along the hoop of the bracelet. This appears to have been worn away in places through use. The breaks on the bracelet are soil covered, however the join is conclusive and the end breaks also appear well-defined, rather than worn. One exterior side of the hoop is differentially corroded and pitted, while there are localised patches of pitting and corrosion on the interior surface. The original surfaces have a dark grey-green patination, while corroded surfaces have a lighter grey green patina.11. Probable ribbed bronze bracelet fragment of Ramsgate TypeDimensions: surviving length 27.2mm; interior diameter approx. 50-60mm; maximum width 14.2mm; maximum thickness 2.4mm; surviving weight 3.7g.This is a small fragment, probably once belonging to a ribbed bronze bracelet. The curvature of the hoop fragment suggests an original internal diameter in the 50-60mm range, consistent with a small bracelet. The fragment has three ribs, and two grooves on its outer face, running in parallel with the axis of the hoop. One rib is central and the other two define the margins of the hoop. The interior surface of the bracelet is flat. While no conjoin exists between this fragment and fragment 12, it is probable that they once belonged to the same bracelet. Areas of corrosion and pitting are evident on the exterior surface, while the breaks appear worn. Original surfaces have a dark grey-green patination, while corroded surfaces have a lighter green patina.12. Probable ribbed bronze bracelet fragment of Ramsgate TypeDimensions: surviving length 19.4mm; maximum width 13.4mm; maximum thickness 2.5mm; surviving weight 2.2g.This is a small fragment, probably once belonging to a ribbed bronze bracelet. The fragment is curved along its length, however its original internal diameter cannot be accurately estimated. The fragment has three ribs and two grooves on its outer face, running in parallel with the axis of the hoop. The interior surface of the bracelet is flat. While no conjoin exists between this fragment and fragment 11, it is probable that they once belonged to the same bracelet. The external face of this fragment is well worn and corroded. Original surfaces have a dark grey-green patination, while worn and corroded surfaces have a lighter green patina.13. & 14. Swollen-shaft / Picardy related pin (conjoining fragments)Dimensions: surviving length of head fragment 13 - 71.9mm; surviving length of shaft fragment 14- 62.6mm; maximum surviving diameter of head 9.5mm; maximum diameter of neck (fragment 13) 7.4mm; diameter near broken tip (fragment 14) 2.9mm; surviving weight (fragment 13) 13.4g; surviving weight fragment 14 - 6.3g; combined surviving weight 19.7g.These are two conjoining fragments of a largely complete bronze pin, with a distinct swelling evident on the upper shaft. The head of the pin is damaged around its sides, although the original form appears to have been an expanded circle in plan with a dished and concave profile, with no evidence of decoration. The shank tapers towards the tip end, however the tip of the pin is missing, the break being soil covered and worn. Near the broken tip (the lower 9-10mm), the shank has been significantly bent, leaving expanded stress lines on the outer side, opposite to the direction of bending. The pin is undecorated and there is no visible evidence of a perforation through the neck. The conjoining breaks are soil covered and not particularly fresh looking, however the join is certain and convincing. The pin has localised areas of corrosion and pitting along surfaces and breaks. Original surfaces have a dark grey-green patination, while corroded surfaces have a lighter green patina.15. & 16. Dirk & loose rivet (Group IV dirk, with Archaic Group II Affinities)Dimensions: surviving length 123.3mm; maximum surviving width of butt 56.5mm; maximum blade thickness (upper blade) 6.1mm; maximum diameter of attached rivet head 10.7mm; length of attached rivet 18.3mm; maximum diameter of loose rivet head 10.5mm; length of loose rivet 18.1mm; surviving weight of dirk 90.8g; weight of loose rivet 7.2g; combined weight 98.0g.This is a short bronze dirk of ogival form (No. 15), with a wide and low butt. The butt has two corner placed rivet holes, both now damaged and open along the butt edge. One large, round-headed rivet survives intact with the blade. The extant rivet has widened heads of domed form, with a maximum diameter of 10.7mm. Original surviving edges at the top of the butt show a flat ended form, however the side edges of the butt are damaged, making it difficult to estimate whether the original form was square, angular, trapezoidal or curved in shape. At the top of the blade, the interface with the butt is marked with an omega shaped hilt-mark on both surfaces. The blade has a flattened mid-blade, with an overall slightly rounded profile. One blade surface has multiple linear hammer marks at the upper end and at right angles to the axis of the blade edges. Towards the top of the blade, on both surfaces, there is a reversed V-shaped thickening of the blade, coming to an apex at the butt end. The tip end of the dirk is missing, although it is probable that the blade was originally less than 150mm long. The blade has a dark grey green patination. One surface has localised bronze concretions, and these and unstable blade edges have a light green patination.A second loose rivet (No. 16), found some distance from the dirk, has very similar size and proportions to the attached one, with widened circular heads, dome shaped in section. Original surfaces have a dark grey-green patination, while the more corroded heads have a lighter green patina.17. Palstave (Group III Low-flanged (Broad-blade) Palstave)Dimensions: length 149.8mm; surviving blade width 56.6mm; butt width 22.5mm; weight 392.9g.This is a complete bronze looped palstave of slender proportions but broad-bladed form, with a single midrib extending down at least two thirds of the length of the blade. The body tapers slightly beneath the stop, while the sides are straight and divergent, down to the recurving of the blade edge. The loop is narrow, overlapping with the positioning of the stop. The flanges are convex, curved and widest above the stop, merging with the septum short of the butt end. The septum represents less than half of the length of the palstave and has a central rib on both faces. The stop is curved, while the butt end is straight and angular. The blade edge is deeply curved and expanded, with protruding blade tips. The casting seam is off centre, indicating one mould part deeper than the other. The seam has been filed or hammered down, but still visible and slightly protruding. On the loop side, there are slight indentations below the loop, possibly hammer marks. On the blade bevel, there are hammer marks, while striations are evident at right angles to the blade edge, suggesting the blade was sharpened for use. On one blade bevel surface is a long prominent surface scratch, possibly made in antiquity. The palstave has a mid to dark grey green patination, with localised bubbling concretions. The blade edge is fragile, with one or two recent chips to the edge, with a light green patination.18. Semi-worked barDimensions: surviving length 66.8mm; maximum diameter of head 7.7mm; diameter shank 5.7-6.5mm; thickness flattened tip 4.0mm; surviving weight 14.1g.This is a semi-worked bar, with circular section and a slightly flattened circular shaped head. The tip end is slightly flattened and tapering. Below the head, there is slight grooving and ridging parallel to the axis of the bar. The head and tip ends appear worn, while the bar has a grey patination.19. Circular flat-headed rivetDimensions: diameter of head 10.1mm; maximum surviving length 3.8mm; surviving weight 0.9g.This is a probable circular rivet head of copper alloy. The head is flat on the upper surface, while on the underside there is a ledge and circular thickening, conical in side view. At the centre of this thickening, there is a circular hollowing or depression, approximately 1.8mm in diameter, perhaps a point of attachment with a now absent component. The object has a dark green patination.20. Flattened sheet edgeDimensions: surviving length 34.7mm; maximum width 9.2mm; sheet thickness 1.3mm; weight 3.6g.This is a small copper alloy sheet fragment with a T-shaped section, suggesting a flanged edge or rim. Along the top and outer side, there are scored or incised lines. Although now bent from original shape, this fragment has a curvature suggesting it was once from a circular object. All breaks are worn and soil covered. The object has a dark green brown patination.21. Flat lump with vesiclesDimensions: length 36.0mm; width 31.2mm; thickness 4.7mm; weight 7.6g.This is a thin but amorphous fragment of copper alloy with undulating and rounded surfaces indicating it solidified from a lump of unformed molten state. The fragment has two small holes through its surfaces and vesicles suggesting gas holes or bubbling. The edges are worn. The fragment has a dark green patination, while the worn edges are lighter green in colour.22. Copper alloy lumpDimensions: length 22.8mm; width 19.6mm; thickness 11.6mm; weight 13.1g.This is a small and sub-rounded lump of copper alloy, of amorphous shape and formed by the solidification of a lump in unformed molten state. The fragment has irregular pitted surfaces, with vesicles suggesting gas holes and bubbling. The edges are worn and the fragment has a light green patination.23. Copper alloy pot or cauldron leg - late Medieval to early post-MedievalDimensions: maximum length/base diameter 56.1mm; maximum width 36.2mm; maximum height 20.2mm; weight 109.2g.This is a semi-circular wedge-shaped piece of copper alloy, containing significant black inclusions within the metal. The upper point of attachment to the original vessel is shaped as a flat segment of a circle, with a diameter of 56.1mm, the inner face being curved. The outer face is straight. The object has broken so that only the upper portion survives, the tapering foot being missing. The upper outer face is flat, with a central ridge evident, running parallel with the axis of the foot. All surfaces are very worn and pitted and the break is old. The lump has a grey-green patination.24. Flint flakeDimensions: length 24.9mm; width 17.2mm; thickness 6.5mm; weight 2.4g.This is a small flake of flint of mottled pale brown colour. Small areas of original natural nodule surface are evident, however the majority of surfaces are fresh as struck, with typical conchoidal fracturing evident. This flake is the bi-product of human flint working, rather than being a worked implement.The results show that the majority of objects (Numbers 1-17) are consistent with a Middle Bronze Age date and compositions. The majority of the twisted neck ring fragments (Numbers 3-8) vary in composition to some degree, but the general pattern of major and trace elements suggest they are from the same object; the exception to this is the largest fragment (Number 2) which is deliberately leaded.Objects 18-23 have compositions suggesting a Roman or later date, but probably modern. Fragment 23 may also be identified on stylistic grounds as being of late Medieval to early post-Medieval date.Identifications (AG)Seven fragments of bronze twisted torcs or neck-rings (Nos. 2-8 above) are included within the artefact group. The survival of two terminals amongst these indicate that they had tapering and plain terminals, while the contrasting twist patterns, metallurgical compositions and wear patterns between half fragment 2, with fragments 3-8 (including terminal fragments 5 & 6), indicate that at least two partially surviving torcs are represented in the group. These twisted torcs or neck-rings are a recognised artefact class belonging to the so called 'Ornament Horizon' of the Taunton period of the Middle Bronze Age (e.g. Smith 1959a; 1959b; Butler 1963; Rowlands 1976, 88-91; O'Connor 1980, 79-80 & 461-3, List 40; Eogan 1983, 27-8, No. 7, Fig. 6A; Roberts 2007). Torcs with plain tapering terminals are less common than torcs with hooked terminals, however a good British parallel is a single torc with plain tapering terminals in the Hollingbury hoard in Sussex (Butler 1963, 138; Rowlands 1976, 90 & 267, Cat. 143, Pl. 60; O'Connor 1980, 79 & 462, List 400; Roberts 2007, 161, No. 85). Bronze twisted torcs are frequently found in hoards in South Western England, with especial concentrations in Somerset, Dorset and South Wiltshire, with a few in Hampshire and Sussex and a cluster in East Anglia (Rowlands 1976, 88-9, Map 22; Roberts 2007, 142-6, Figs 4-6 & Table 2).The two clearly conjoining fragments of decorated bracelet (Nos. 9 & 10 above) may be identified as Liss Type, with incised decorative motifs (Needham 1989, 36-7). These have been related to the similar Bignan Type decorated bracelets of Brittany (Briard 1965, 123-35; Rowlands 1971), although they are part of a wider North European tradition (O'Connor 1980, 81-3; Needham 1989, 36). However, the distinctive decorative variations on the known British examples suggest there were regional places of casting and making, so that it is likely that many were made in Britain, rather than solely being Continental imports. These heavy cast decorated bracelets and armlets have been convincingly dated to the so called 'Ornament Horizon' of the Taunton period of the Middle Bronze Age, through their combination of hoard associations (e.g. Rowlands 1971, 193-6; O'Connor 1980, 80; Needham 1989, 38; Roberts 2007), dating to 1400-1275cal BC (Needham et al 1997). This bracelet from Llantrisant Fawr was once of oval shape, with observed slight tapering of the hoop width observed, suggesting this part is nearing an original terminal, now lost. It suggests that it was once an example of penannular, rather than annular form (Rowlands 1971, 186, Fig 1; O'Connor 1980, 81).The two ribbed and curved strip fragments (Nos. 11&12, above) can be identified as probably belonging to a single, narrow and cast bronze bracelet of Ramsgate Type (Piggott 1949, 120-1 & Fig. 6; Butler 1963, 155-7; Rowlands 1976, 91-2; O'Connor 1980, 85-6, 465-6, List 42 & Map 20; Needham 1989, 35). Although no join can be established between the two fragments, their closely similar style and dimensions, combined with very similar metallurgical composition, would strongly support their once belonging to the same bracelet. A number of hoards and settlement finds from Wiltshire and Somerset include examples of these bracelets (Smith 1959b, GB 42 & 44; Rowlands 1976, 251, 257, 260, 271, 277-8, Cats. 111, 115, 123, 154, 171-2; O'Connor 1980, 465-6, List 42; Needham 1989, 29-39). These can be securely dated to the so called 'Ornament Horizon' occurring during the Taunton period of the Middle Bronze Age, dating to 1400-1275 cal BC (Needham 1989, 38; Needham et al 1997; Roberts 2007, 141).The conjoining fragments of pin (No. 13-14 above) may be identified as belonging to a pin form with characteristic swollen-shaft and related to Picardy pins (Hawkes 1942; O'Connor 1980, 76-7, List 37; Roberts 2007, 139-40 & Fig. 3). These have been identified as a diagnostic ornament type of the so called 'Ornament Horizon', belonging to the Taunton period of the Middle Bronze Age (1400-1275 cal BC). In the past, the similarities of such pins with pins from north-eastern France were emphasised by researchers (e.g. Hawkes 1942; Smith 1959a, 161-2; O'Connor 1980, 76-7), hence their name, however the proliferation of swollen-neck pin discoveries in England has recently led researchers to question their origin. Although this example is not decorated with incised ornament, as most of the typical examples are, the circular dished top and swollen-upper shaft in combination are chronologically diagnostic.The combination of features evident on the dirk (No. 15 above) enable an identification as a Group IV dirk with Archaic Group II affinities (Burgess & Gerloff 1981, 63-5). As a Group IV weapon, it is characterised by having a blade with a flattened to slightly rounded centre-section, however its low butt, relatively wide and short blade, ogival shape with an omega hilt-mark and two rivets in rivet holes at butt corners indicate typological similarities with earlier Group II dirks with Low or Angular Butts (Burgess & Gerloff 1981, 27-8 & 30-1). Group IV dirks with Archaic features are typologically earlier than Group IV dirks of the Appleby Series (Burgess & Gerloff 1981, 106) and have been found elsewhere in hoards belonging to the Taunton phase of the Middle Bronze Age (Hemp 1917-18, 168-9; Piggott 1949; Smith 1959b; RCAHMW 1960, l & liv, Fig. 13, Nos. 3-8; Rowlands 1976, 229, 234-5, Cats. 21, 43 & 130 & Pl. 23; Burgess & Gerloff 1981, Cats. 29, 45, 296, 482, 497, 504, 567 & 572; 9, 11, 39 & 65, 67-8, 73-4; Pearce 1983, 439, Cat. 219, Pls. 28,101,142; Northover unpublished H25). The loose rivet (No. 16 above) has very similar dimensions and a similar metallurgical composition to the rivet still attached to the dirk. Although discovered dispersed from the dirk by approximately 8-9 metres, it is possible to be confident that it was once attached to this dirk.The palstave, which was discovered beneath the dirk and in the same detector pit, may be identified as a Group III Low-Flanged and Broad-blade palstave, most similar to the Type Carlton, Variant Kirkowan identified for Northern Britain (Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 139-40). This also equates with Class 5, Group 1 palstaves of Southern Britain (Rowlands 1976, 34-6), which have a long blade length in relation to the septum length. Group III Low-Flanged and Broad-blade palstaves may be dated to the Taunton phase of the Middle Bronze Age (Northover unpublished, 163-85; Schmidt & Burgess 1981, 1400, which has now been radiocarbon dated to 1400-1275 cal BC (Needham et al 1997, 82).In seeking to identify the narrow decorated gold strip fragment (No. 1 above), it has proven difficult to find an exact parallel with this piece. Gold artefacts found in direct association with bronze torcs, bracelets and pins of the 'Ornament Horizon' and belonging to the Taunton period of the Middle Bronze Age are uncommon. Nevertheless, it is possible to draw upon a number of the stylistic features of this strip and to correlate them with both bronze ribbed bracelets of Ramsgate Type and with occasional gold bracelets from Britain and Ireland. These suggest that this gold strip may once have been part of a narrow bracelet and contemporary with the other bronze objects in this artefact group. The ribbed and grooved upper surface and flat back surface of this decorated gold are similar to the ribbed bronze bracelets of Ramsgate Type.The metallurgical compositions of the remaining metal fragments reported (Nos. 18-23 above) have been established as being inconsistent with a Bronze Age composition and technology (Davis, above). The presence of zinc in fragments 18-20 and 22-3 indicates a Roman or later date technologically, although on balance they are most likely to be modern, while the composition of fragment 21 is also likely to be modern. Fragment 23 can be identified as part of a late Medieval to early post-Medieval pot- or cauldron-leg, therefore not contemporary or related to the other artefacts in the group (i.e. fragments 1-17). As such, fragments 18-23 may be deemed as not directly associated with the Bronze Age artefacts identified within this group, and not treasure. The flint flake (No. 24 above) is a non-diagnostic flake, rather than a tool or weapon, probably of prehistoric and Neolithic to Early Bronze Age in date. Although it is of interest to note its discovery, in terms of an earlier prehistoric landscape human presence in the area, it is not contemporary with the other main artefacts in the reported group, therefore not directly associated or buried with them. Flake fragment 24 may not therefore be deemed to be treasure.The individual identifications of artefacts 1-17 have established all to be of contemporary date, belonging to the Taunton period of the Middle Bronze Age and dating to between 1400 and 1275 BC. The account of discovery and follow-up archaeological investigation of the find-spot with the finder has established a probable original burial location of the hoard as a directly associated group, in the immediate vicinity of the excavated test-pit, over the detector pit from which the large torc fragment (No. 2) had been retrieved. The dirk and palstave (Nos. 15 & 17) had been found within a metre of this location, at reasonable depth, suggesting they were very close to the original hoard burial place. This location was near the crest of a plateau, while the remaining bronze artefacts had been scattered downslope to the north-north-east over a maximum distance of 43m from the test-pit. The decorated gold strip was discovered at a later date in the same field, also downslope, and approximately 55m to the north-west of the test-pit. This dispersal pattern is consistent with a disturbed hoard group and it is probable that these artefacts were once buried in direct association as a hoard. In modern times, the buried hoard was probably disturbed through ploughing or agricultural activity, with many of the artefacts being dragged in disturbed cultivated soil downslope from the original burial place.
notes: Metallurgical analysis (MD)MethodQualitative surface analysis of the objects within the hoard was undertaken using a Bruker TRACeR III-SD hand-held X-ray fluorescent spectrometer (HHXRF) with a rhodium tube, and a titanium/aluminium filter. The readings were taken at 40 kV and 9.6A for 100 live seconds. Surface analysis is susceptible to distortions due to the asymmetry of whole objects (rather that flat polished samples). Surface corrosion can lead to the surface enrichment (e.g. tin) and depletion (e.g. zinc) of elements. These factors can affect the quantities of copper and tin, lead and zinc analysed on the surface of an object.ResultsAll numbers relate to the artefacts as described above.1. Decorated gold strip fragment - three readings indicated a composition of 78-79% gold, 17.5-18.5% silver, and 2.6-2.8% copper. This is consistent with a Middle Bronze Age gold signature and contains less copper than gold of Late Bronze Age date.2. Twisted bronze torc fragment - a leaded bronze, with small quantities of arsenic andtraces of nickel. This fragment had a different composition to the other twisted bronze torc fragments.3-8. Twisted bronze torc fragments - these all had similar compositions - a bronze with minor quantities of arsenic and traces of nickel and lead. These fragments had a different composition to twisted bronze torc fragment number 2.9-10. Decorated bronze bracelet of Liss Type (conjoining fragments) - both fragments have the same composition - a bronze with some arsenic and traces of nickel and lead - same11-12. Probable ribbed bronze bracelet fragment of Ramsgate Type - both fragments have the same composition - a leaded bronze with small quantities of nickel and arsenic.13-14. Swollen-shaft / Picardy related pin (conjoining fragments) - both fragments have the same composition - a leaded bronze with traces of nickel and arsenic.15-16. Dirk & loose rivet (Group IV dirk, with Archaic Group II Affinities) - these items both had the same composition - a bronze with negligible lead and minor amounts of arsenic plus traces of nickel.17. Palstave (Group III Low-flanged (Broad-blade) Palstave) - a bronze with minor quantities of arsenic and traces of nickel, lead, silver and antimony.18. Semi-worked bar - a lead tin alloy with traces of copper and zinc - probably modern.19. Circular flat headed rivet - a leaded bronze with zinc - probably modern.20. Flattened sheet edge - a leaded bronze with some antimony and traces of arsenic and zinc - probably modern.21. Flat lump with vesicles -a leaded bronze containing less tin with traces of arsenic and antimony, but no zinc or silver - probably modern.22. Copper alloy lump - a leaded gunmetal containing significant quantities of tin, zinc and lead with traces of arsenic and nickel, but no silver or antimony - probably modern.23. Copper alloy pot or cauldron leg - a leaded bronze with traces of zinc, arsenic, silver and antimony - Roman or later in composition, but stylistically identifiable as late Medieval to early post-Medieval in date.
subsequentActionTerm: Acquired by museum after being declared Treasure

description: Bronze Age Gold Strip (possibly a bead) from Much Wenlock - ShropshireTreasure Case: 2017 T42A small rectangular strip of folded gold with one decorated surface. The object was folded upon discovery and subsequently opened up by the finder.One edge of the strip is complete having been cut regularly with a slightly thickened rim while the other edge of the strip has been torn resulting in a sharp undulating edge. The decoration consists of eight fine, straight ridges and grooves..Dimensions:length 17mm, width 14mm, weight 2.1gDiscussion:The linear decoration of the strip can be paralleled on a number of gold strips and 'ribbons' of known and very probable Bronze Age date, including finds from Sherborne St John, Hampshire, The Hamel, Oxfordshire (Case 1981; Palmer 1981); Corringham, Lincolnshire (2011 T459); Sproxton, North Yorkshire (2010 T664); Flixton, North Yorkshire (2003 T40a&b); and Ansley, Warwickshire (2007 T672). The find from The Hamel, Oxfordshire, came from the same layer as typologically late Beaker pottery dating to the Early Bronze Age (cf. Needham 2005). Given that it is similar to strips that usually have a greater length; it is not inconceivable that the Retford find has been cut from a longer strip.It is possible that the object was once tubular, in which case it may have formed a gold bead or similar (e.g.a fitting folded around the edges of another object). Elure provides a number of French examples of such beads ('perles tubulaires lisses': 1982, 29, figs. 24-7). An example from Bern, Switzerland is twice the length of the putative Retford bead and is decorated with grooves separated by undecorated surfaces (British Museum WG 468). Undecorated cylindrical gold beads have also recently been discovered in a Chalcolithic Beaker burial from Kingsmead Quarry in Berkshire (S. Needham pers comm.).Similar examples which have been recorded on the PAS database include LVPL-34D297 2012 T926, GLO-F8F3B7 2012T382 and SF-D30D10 2011T825.Statement:The object is predominantly of precious metal and is almost certainly more than 300 years old and therefore qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of theTreasure Act (1996).
subsequentActionTerm: Donated to museum after being declared Treasure

description: A complete gold penannular bracelet of possible Bronze Age date 1500-900BC. The bracelet is formed of a single continuous thick wire that has been formed into loops at the terminals and doubled back on itself. The wire has been soldered along its length to join the two parallel wires together, though there is a gap where the solder has failed. The terminal loops are slightly flattened at their tip. There are some scratches and striation on the metal possibly due to cleaning or deposition damage rather than decorative or manufacturing processes.The Bracelet would have had a relatively small diameter though it is now quite distorted in shape. The structure of the bracelet is similar to that recorded in BERK-A5FFE5, though much simplified.Length: 70.99mmWidth: 4.11mmThickness: 2.15mmWeight: 16.27g
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: An incomplete copper alloy (bronze) flat axe of the Early Bronze Age, dating from c. BC 2500 - BC 2050The flat axe is broadly sub rectangular in plan with a splayed crescent shaped blade. In profile it is broadly lentoid, with slight tapering edges. In cross section the axe is lentoid in shape. The butt is relatively thin having a flat edge, the butt has been broken. The patina at the break matches with the rest of the axe suggesting the break occurred in antiquity. The sides of the axe gently expand in width from the butt to the blade; in shape they are relatively straight. There is no evidence of the long edges being raised to form flanges and there is also no evidence of a median bevel (proto stop ridge). However, the axe is thickest at the mid point (9.5 mm). The sides of the blade expand slightly to produce a crescentic blade edge with a width of 62.2 mm. The tips of the crescent shaped blade have been damaged through either abrasion or wear, as has the blade edge itself. The blade facet has been heavily abraded and is virtually no longer visible, however the top and bottom of the blade do slope gently down to the edge. There is no evidence of any form of incised or cast decoration present on any surface of the axe. The object measures 86.2 mm in length. The width at the butt is 45.4 mm, the centre is 51.5 mm wide and the blade is 62.2 mm wide. The butt has a thickness of 6.9 mm, the centre is 9.5 mm thick and the blade is 5.3 mm thick. The axehead weighs 252.1 g. The axe is a mid to dark brown in colour with a much abraded or corroded patina. Traces of a light green patina, suggesting corrosion products. Abrasion caused by movement whilst within the plough soil has resulted in the loss of most of the original surface detail. The axehead is best described as coming from the first phases of the Early Bronze Age (or possibly even the Copper Age). This example fits best into the copper axes and early bronze axes. The form of the axe is comparable to Type Castletown Roche/Pitlochry (outlined by Schmidt and Burgess p 22-23, Plate 1, No 5). These axes fit within the earliest phases of metal working in Britain, metalworking stage I-II, which corresponds to Needham's (1996) Period 1-2 circa 2500- 2050 CAL. BC. This means that they are dated, broadly, to the same period as Beaker pottery, barbed and tanged flint arrowheads, copper halberds and gold lunulae. Similar axeheads have also been recorded on the database including HESH-ACD6C1, HESH-84D8A5 and LANCUM-AA5ED7. Ref: Schmidt, P.K. & Burgess, C.B. 1981. The Axes of Scotland and Northern England. Prahistorische Bronzefunde. Abteilung IX. Band 7. C.H. Beck'Sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, Munchen. p.22-23 (also Plate 1 no 5).
subsequentActionTerm: Returned to finder

description: TREASURE CASE : 2016 T683.A largely complete but damaged gold armlet of Early Bronze Age date, c. 2100 BC - 1900 BC. It is decorated with embossed patterns and pointillé and belongs to the embossed goldwork tradition (see Needham 2000a).The object is formed from a cylindrical band of sheet metal with no joins in evidence. In cross-section it has a corrugated appearance with six bulbous concentric embossed ribs, four decorating the body and two forming the rims. One rim has been damaged and the embossed rib is only partially visible. The ribs are fairly evenly spaced, separated by flat bands. They are not of equal size: the ribs on the edges of the band are rather wider (c.7mm), than the ribs decorating the body (c.4-5mm).Each rib is flanked by an irregular row of pointillé - a pattern of impressed dots applied from the front. The pointillé decoration does not neatly follow the edge of the ribs and deviates in several places. The sheet forming the edges of the armlet have been folded over. Needham (2000b,23) suggests this may function to strengthen the overall object and, possibly grip a backing material.Condition: The armlet is distorted, likely by soil pressure, and much of one side of the armlet is damaged due to plough action suggesting pressure may have been applied above and that the armlet may have been laid to rest on its better preserved side. Both surfaces are polished, or burnished, to a crisp shine reflected in the presence of fine striations. Some more prominent marks are however, more likely a result of subsequent depositional damage. A small section of the armlet has detached from the damaged side of the armlet and survives as an undecorated crumpled square of c.10mm by 8mm. It derives from the edge of the armlet: the folded edge of gold on the inner surface is still visible.Dimensions:Circumference of the more intact rim: 258mm Diameter (assuming the armlet was approximately circular): 82.1mm (measure using thread applied to scale image); Height: 50.3mm (in crushed state); Thickness: 0.7mm; Weight: 13.85g (incomplete state).Small detached square from edge of armlet: 10mm by 8mm; Weight: 0.09gMetal composition: Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis was undertaken at the British Museum by Duncan Hook and indicated a surface composition of approximately 82-84% gold, 14-16% silver, and 1.5-2% copper (see appended report). This can be compared to results for the Lockington armlets (see Hook and Meeks in Needham 2000b, 27-9).Discussion:This Early Bronze Age gold embossed armlet belongs to Group 3 of Stuart Needham's armlet typology (2000b, 29-38). Group 3 armlets of gold and copper alloy are unified by the presence of multiple ribs to decorate the body of the armlet (Needham 2000b, 31; also see Needham & Sheridan 2014, 913-14, Tradition 4: Embossed goldwork). Needham assigned 11 armlets to Group 3 and this figure has remained the same until the discovery of the Bewhome armlet, bringing the total to 12 armlets from Britain and Ireland. Among the group are four (five once we include the new find from Bewhome) made of gold with embossed ribs, two from the aforementioned site of Lockington (now in the British Museum), one from Whititeld, Co. Waterford, Ireland (now considered lost; Hughes 2000, pl. 18), and one from Cuxwold, near Caistor, Lincolnshire (also now considered to be lost; Hughes 2000, pl. 19) (see Hughes 2000, Appendix 1 for details).The Bewhome armlet is similar in several respects to two gold armlets found during the excavation of a barrow cemetery near the village of Lockington, Leicestershire: BM 1996, 0901.2 has a similar corrugated appearance to the Bewhome armlet while BM 1996, 0901.1 shares similarly applied pointillé decoration (see Hughes 2000). The Bewhome find shares several other features in common with Lockington. It was made without join and has wider ribs at the edges, serving to emphasise the rims. The diameter of the Bewhome find is also similar to Lockington:Internal diameter of Lockington armlet No. 1: 77.5 - 79mm;Internal diameter of Lockington armlet No. 2: 79 - 83mm ;Internal diameter of Bewhome armlet: c. 82mm;However, the Bewhome armlet is not as carefully decorated as the Lockington examples and is considerably lighter. Even allowing for the loss of material from the damaged rim of armlet, the Bewsholme example is substantially lighter (13.85g compared to 24.82g (Lockington armlet no. 1) and 28.16g (Lockington armlet no. 2). Needham and Sheridan (2014, 912), have noted that embossed gold armlets would likely have had organic backings (see details of the folded edges, above) and this may explain the lightness of the Bewholme find.The Whitield armlet bears more comparison to the fusiform bead-like decoration of Lockington armlet BM 1996, 0901.1. The lost armlet from Cuxwold, Lincolnshire is quite closely comparably to the new find and was found c.40-50 miles from Bewhome, separated by the River Humber. It is now lost (thus preventing closer comparison) but a woodcut published in the Archaeological Journal for 1857 (Trollope 1857, 92; May 1976, 07-101) suggests it was decorated with straight ribs decorated on either side with lines of pointillé.The key differences between Cuxfold and Bewhome are the number of ribs (seven in the case of Cuxwold, six in the case of Bewhome) and the dimensions of the Cuxfold armlet, as given in the Archaeological Journal, where the height is recorded as 3 ¼ inches (83mm), the internal diameter (at the wider end of the tapering armlet) as 3 ¾ (96mm) and the weight as 10 oz 5 dr 1 scr (given in Apothecary Equivalents) which can be converted to c.320g. That weight measurement is far in excess of any similar object and should be regarded with some caution.Conclusion: In terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal and is of prehistoric date. It therefore qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.References:May, J. 1976, Prehistoric Lincolnshire.Lincoln: History of Lincolnshire CommitteeNeedham, S. 2000a. Mitteldeutscher Archäologentag 6. Mitteldeutscher Archäologentag vom 17. bis 19. Oktober 2013 in Halle (Saale). Tagungen des Landesmuseums (11). Landesamt f. Denkmalpflege u. Archäologie Sachsen-Anhalt , Halle, GermanyTrollope, E. 1857. 'Antiquities and works of art exhibited', Archaeological Journal, 14, 92-93
